job_title: Sales & Service Specialist in Torrington, CT
pros: Good to have on your resume, growth available
cons:
Pay is not competitive

Personal bankers do not have series 6, 63, or health insurance. if you left as a PB, you might have difficulty getting anohter PB position because competitve banks (CHASE) have their PB's licensed. 

PB's typically have a low salary, 33,000-36,000
you have to make your money on the commission, which is harder because you don't have your series 6! you dont get anything for referring for mortgages or financial advisors. 

So you're limited in your sales. Management positions are seemilingly boring. you have to deal with the tellers crap, and push the PB to make sales. You're usually not in charge of many people so i'm not sure how much you'll enjoy your job. It's very difficult to get promoted to a district manager, that's where you'll see the real money though, but other bank's district managers make more. 

People get very lazy at this bank, and the customer's suffer through it.

review_title: B of A an excellent company to work for...but will it continue to be in the next year?
job_title: Sales & Service Specialist in Seattle, WA
pros: Bank of America provides excellent benefits to their employees.  My husband and have taken advantage of their tuition reimbursement program, with a value upwards of 20,000.  I have great insurance, consistently receive praise from supervisors and management, have three weeks of paid vacation annually, and was offered a promotion after only 6 months with the company.
cons: I'm somewhat concerned about upcoming changes at Bank of America given the economic climate and their recent acquisitions of other companies.  The recently discontinued a 'Spirit Rewards Program,' which was used in the past to award employees for various successes.  For example, I was awarded about 7,500 points in the past year which I used to purchase 350 dollars in gas card gift certificates.  Additionally, hours have been cut back and there's talk of layoffs.

pros: Good benefits, bonus incentives, good atmosphere to work. I worked at an awesome banking center. The manager was great and so were the teamwork. It was a smaller branch so we all got to bond. The only reason I left was because of family problems and didn't want to leave my co-workers short staffed and in the limbo. I wasn't sure when I was coming back. It kills me because I want my old job back. It's a hit or miss with the great working environment. I've heard of some centers taht don't do well. We were number two in our market. It's also great for bonuses becasue we did so well and we get top dollars! I'm sure it's changed with the economy the way it is.
cons: No flexible hours... meaning if the job offers 20 hours, you only get 20 hours. I wanted to increase my hours but because the banking center is allowed a certain budget, it wasn't possible (also may have been because of the economy shifting down).

review_title: Pretty disappointing - Get the experience and move on
job_title: Personal Banker in Laguna Hills, CA
pros: Brand awareness, Convenience, Locations, Lots of prospective customers walk in for new accounts, pretty decent health benefits and the time it takes for them to take effect
cons: At BofA, it was all about the numbers.  I recognize that this was a sales position, but branch management would encourage us to close out accounts and re-open new accounts for customers that had servicing issues to report better new account numbers.  The customer service was lacking terribly.  We were not empowered to do much of anything to actually help anyone.  We would tell them bank policy and that was about it.  We always had to call someone to get most servicing issues resolved as, again, we had no authority to make decisions or process most requests other than sales and very basic servicing.

review_title: I would say this is an ok place to work if you like the hours and sub-standard pay.
pros:
Benefits
Discounts
Perks
Transportation reimbursement
Education reimbursement if you are attending classes ore enrolled in college.
Time off to car for your children or partner if they are sick. 
Health benefits for partners including gay couples or parents.
Eye, dental, medical, and life insurance are all offered even to part-time employees.
cons:
Low starting salary
choice of when to take vacation goes to those with seniority
Advancement opportunities are lackluster.
You are the face of BofA therefore you receive all of the customers' wrath for things you cannot control or did not do.

pros: Competitive benefits, although they have been downgraded significantly on a year-by-year basis.  The best pro is the people who are working there--especially the "worker bees" and their immediate supervisors.  The senior and mid-level management employees are much more concerned about numbers than they are about people, even those who have proven themselves with many years of great service.
cons: The Bank is becoming much more internally competitive for recognition by management, although it does not show up in the compensation that is paid.  Even the "stars" are not compensated for excellent work, and the work-life balance is becoming much less satisfying.  The training is also an issue.  It is approached quite haphazardly, at least in my area of the Bank.

job_title: Personal Banker in Highland Park, IL
pros: the benifits offered such as insurance and dental are top of the line aswell as paid vacation and the oppurtunity for advancent.  2 Weeks training provided and commute to training facility can be written off.
cons: a company that cares very little for its employees and has a general attitude of you dont matter.  as an employee you can expect to be driven endlessly, micro managed in 15 minute increments and be given little to no respect.  A very repressive environment just do as you are told you dont need to know why ect ect.  False systems in place to give the false impression of employee empowerment.  Constant criticism (built into manager 'roadmap')  lots of terms to soften the reality of things such as 'coaching' which it literally just criticism not necesarily contructive.  Policies are in an employee accessible sites but are not always observed and if an employee violates a policy write ups are issued.  Mangement however is outside of the rules and do not observe the same rules and policies imposed on there employees.

job_title: Administrative Assistant III in Charlotte, NC
pros: Excellent company - I enjoyed every minute of it - had some of the greatest manager's I have ever had in over 40+ years of working.  Great benefits - as long as you proved yourself competent, they would leave you alone and let you get your work done.
cons: Always wondering if "I'm going to be one whose job would be eliminated under the "New BAC" process.  It just so happened that one day in 2013 that was the case - me and several others in my department were "laid off" and given a severance package.  I don't regret a minute of working with Bank of America.  Would recommend the company to everyone I know.

job_title: Small Business Specialist (Customer Service) in Tampa, FL
pros: Excellent Benefits, 3 weeks vacation, personal time and sick time right after training. Can advance very quickly with the company in different areas of the bank. If you have a serious focus on being in the financial industry, its a great company to start with as long as your friendly; they will work with you.
cons: High call volume, and poor training. No matter how well you perform your job is solely based on random surveys that customers take on how much they like you. Also a lot of favoritism amongst employees and managers. If you kiss butt, you can get to the top very easily(not to sound unprofessional, but its all a popularity game at least in my call center).

pros:
Great for building lasting relationships with clients and co-workers. Definitely a family friendly atmosphere.

You learn a lot about personal finance and small business practices.
cons:
live and die by the customer and branch. One minute you can be making calls the next you will be swamped with debit card replacements, fraud detection services, and wire transfers.

used car salesman culture in retail banking needs to stop asap. It takes away from what a bank and PB should do for customers. recommend based on need not what that branches goals are.  I shouldn't have to pressure people to get credit cards or open accounts because the branch is laking. It honestly shouldn't be a sales job. Recommend products based on need, if they don't need it do not pressure them to get it! that mentality is what got Wells Fargo in trouble!!!

pros:
Well known company.
Stable compared to other financial companies in the industry.
Flexibible
cons:
I've worked there for 10 years on the technolgy side in various lines of buinesses (Consumer, GCIB).   I suppose simiar to most companies, their is a lot of internal infighting, politics and process that makes it hard to get things done.  A major problem is the way projects are funded and staffed where every group bills another group like a consulting company.  Its all rather silly and makes it very expensive for projects to get funded.  Anyways, in my years at the bank the technology side is in the worse shape I've ever seen it.  

Communication is often in the forms of blast emails and communications.  There is so much "Communication' it is really just spam.  

It helps a lot to have a manager or senior manager that is well respected as well.  

I do belive the business side is run much better.

review_title: Former AVP/Product Marketing Manager I in Insurance Services
job_title: Product Marketing Manager in Irvine, CA
pros: Excellent compensation and benefits, great volunteer program, overall a wonderful company to work for. I wish I still worked there!
cons: The company failed to effectively integrate into the Bank of America culture those companies it acquired through various buyouts. The division in which I worked bore very little resemblance to what I I was introduced to during my orientation. In fact, I found myself working with people from two different company cultures, neither of which had the sense of balance or enthusiasm that Bank of America demonstrates in its orientation training. Extremely inflexible culture within their in-house advertising agency (which originated within an East Coast bank with a far more rigid culture). I found the inflexibility and rigid demands too much and, unfortunately, lost my job. I would love to work for Band of America again, but not within one of its acquired companies!

pros: Vacation time was really generous, and the best health care benefits I've ever had. And working at a bank, of course you get those banking holidays off, too. Multiple sites throughout the country for marketing (ECS). Management very personable and approachable. Flexible hours -- not an issue to take time off for appointments, etc.
cons: Remote work presented challenges in that it felt like things were happening at "the mothership" that didn't get communicated out across all sites. I like that they encouraged community involvement and volunteering. But they did a push with The United Way where we were encouraged to make regular donations through automatic payroll deductions -- and it wasn't anonymous. One coworker didn't and he found himself on some sort of list of people who hadn't signed up. I have nothing against the United Way but I prefer to focus my discretionary dollars on causes that have a personal connection. Raises were mediocre.

review_title: The Good The Bad and The Ugly
job_title: Customer Relationship Manager in West Seneca, NY
pros: When. I went to work for the bank, I was excited to be there. Lots of good support. Lots of good incentives. However, that soon changed. The bonus structure changed so drastically that people were leaving at a rapid pace. I chose go stay. We were redeployed to different lines of business so many times that it was difficult to keep track. But the training for each change was good and depending on management available, support was available.
cons: You never knew if today was going to be your last day. Also, there was a running joke about how little management actually knew about the last line of business that I worked. Everyone used to say "if you want three different answers to a question, ask three different managers." It seemed as if management did not care any more.

job_title: Sales & Service Specialist in Matthews, NC
pros: uncapped incentive plan, friendly people
cons: customer experience linked to teller performance

pros: Compensation is good. Good choice if you are a banker or loan officer.
cons: Extremely poor work life balance in IT. Senior management doesn't get in the way much, which is good. Working for a good manager makes a huge difference. I have worked for an excellent manager, and an extremely poor one.

review_title: Like any other trillion dollar global financial conglomerate...
pros: It's one of the best feather-in-the-cap items on your resume, as long as you last more than one calendar year. Your mere employment here makes you more valuable to other companies. Poachers will seek you out.
cons: Out of ~250,000 employees, what team and line of business you work for will fully determine your thoughts on the company. Every division is run like it's own fiefdom with salaries, bonus, perks, scheduling, and flexibility varying wildly. If you want to learn advanced technology like cloud, AI, and block-chain it's great, but the main group that works on those things doesn't pay well, doesn't believe in bonuses for the masses, and tends to treat employees as next-man-up commodities (for example).

review_title: Good Company but be wary of poor branch leadership
pros: Bank of America has great benefits both for health and family. The reputation of working in within a repspected company was great for the resume. I was also able  to leave work at work and not have the burden of taking it home with me.
cons:
Bank Of America did not train me to do the Job. I Had to take all of the compliance testing but had no training on how to use the software. However, other branches did send some employees to training but others did not. The issue with this was that it provided inconsistency and I was unable to perform as well I as otherwise would have.
The worst part was the communication between management and employees within the branch. I realize that this mainly has to due with the particular managers but as a company the problem needs to be rectified.

review_title: Love it or Hate it - Bank of America has a lot to offer its associates
job_title: Senior Vice President  in Charlotte, NC
pros: The benefits are top in the industry, the people are great to work with, and the brand name is a valuable part of your resume despite what you might read in the press. I've learned more about organizational politics and how to work with large groups of people in the last 18 months than in the entire rest of my career. Whether I go work for a large company again or a small one, that will be invaluable to my career.
cons: It's a large company. Any company made to operate with 300,000+ employees is going to have inefficiencies and things that don't make sense for each individual. Management communications can also seem to be superficial, but again, it's being geared towards 300,000 people - not just you and your small team.

review_title: Mixed bag at Bank of America
pros: The Bank allows for relatively rapid promotion, from what I've seen on the low end of the totem pole. I love that we offer tuition reimbursement, have insurance for employees (but recently it's been downgraded), and generally like most of my team-mates.
cons: It doesn't really seem like anyone gets the big picture, and is always scrambling to make themselves look good on all of these little metrics that can seem to be like minutia. There's intense pressure from every level of management on the lower levels of management, which all falls on the average associate. I've been working with this company for over six months, and I've been reminded virtually daily how tenuous my hold on my employment is. It's really not a good thing to have unemployment hovering over people's heads consistently.

pros: Their benefits are most excellent !
cons: The department I worked in had some of the worst management I have ever experienced. My direct manager did not have a clue of how to do the job of the employees. Nor did the manager answer the majority of questions we had regarding the job. Overtime requirements are not addressed clearly in the interview. You have to work too much OT to meet management goals. So basically say goodbye to your friends and family. The culture depends on the group. The old Countrywide employees are a cancer that are eating away at the BOA core values. They do not want to blend nor do they want to learn the new and better way.

review_title: It used to be a nice place to work...
pros: Benefits are good- they offer separate sick days (10) and vacation days (15) plus you  can buy up to another week of vacation.  I like the people I work with and the managers in general.
cons: Pay is very low compared to similar positions elsewhere.  They justify this by dangling a quarterly bounus in fron t of employees, but  they make make it impossible to earn.  Basically even you you jump throuhg all the hoops and "walk on water" you will QUAILIFY for the bonus.  then they take everyone who does qualify, and immediately eliminate the lowest 25% of thoses who qualified and give them nothing.  The bonus is then broken up and distributed to the remaining 75%- only 10% getting the full $2500.00 bonus HR states is part of your salary.  most people only get $500- before taxes.  Its is set up so they can get the most work out of people and then NOT pay them for it.

job_title: Assistant Vice President Small Business Banker in Phoenix, AZ
pros:
Great Pay
Great benefits
Middle Management is excellent
Remote Work is possible
cons:
Training is minimal, it's online based learning doesn't cover much and it's so much to remember that no one could retain it all. 
Technology is a huge challenge, systems suck. they don't integrate with other systems, using salesforce to manage thousands of accounts is time consuming, and inability to help clients with small issues like online banking make this position a nightmare.
Leads are blind, basically no contact has ever been made with clients, but somehow they know this client needs everything we offer.
Reputation is in the garbage and company doesn't really care.
No partnership between branches and other departments
Lending department steals clients and robs you of commission.

review_title: Good company overall, but the huge size  after all those takeovers- has impacted the quality of leadership & decisionmak
job_title: Vice President, National Group Banking Client Manager
pros: Covers all aspects of financial industry and thus offers variety of banking fields to work for. Pays commiserate with industry standards.
cons:
Too many leadership changes & because of its huge size, newer leadership doesn't always knows its associates & their strengths, thus tends to make wrongful decisions regarding its associates, which is detrimental to the company. 
Laying off too many quality associates.

pros: Learn basic business of banking and grow as a young professional (especially if it's your first job as it was for me).
cons: They don't recognize talent unless you sell your soul to the BofA devils. Which means if you are perky and smile all the time and get on managements good's side, they might consider you. As a teller, you won't like the pressure of meeting goals that won't help your professional growth in any way. There were weeks where I was reprimanded for not asking customers to swipe their IDs on the PIN machines. One banking center manager lined us up on a Saturday morning and asked us why we didn't bring a family or friend to open a bank account in order to meet the center's monthly goals for opening new accounts.

review_title: My Work program fading away fast
job_title: Business Technology Analyst in New York, NY
pros: I had 20-years with BofA where I was able to thrive and consistently advance into more challenging positions with better pay.
cons: Those opportunities began to vanish as the layoffs began. I watched my colleagues on-by-one get let go with their workloads falling on the remaining team. I get a title and band level promotion w/pay increase and was laid off months later. Never had a performance review without an "exceeds expectations" and I was still let go. Their telecommuting policy changes virtually eliminated me from a number of positions for which I was fulled qualified.

job_title: Vice President of Technology in New York, NY
pros:
- Good networking opportunities:  you'll meet people throughout the company that are happy to help you
- Mostly stable gig:  they need smart, active people who can push hard enough to break through the corporate red tape.  If you can do that, you'll have the job for as long as you want it
- Good pay for the work
-
cons:
- Corporate culture to the extreme.  Lots of conference calls, lots of layers, lots of people who are just cashing a paycheck
- Depending on the role, the work can be very pigeon holed.  Don't expect to learn new technology here.
- It is *hard* to innovate here.  Everyone wants to stay in their groove; so much so that the "innovators" at the company have typically been there for 10+ years creating innovations that no one outside of the company is interested in.

review_title: Great pay. Not so great culture
pros: Merrill Edge pays above market for talent and they're evolving pretty quickly when it comes to the staid world of banking. There are training resources available and generally every effort is made to help you out if you struggle in a certain area.
cons:
The work environment can best be described as "buddy-buddy". What I mean is that your social standing determines a lot about your work life - from how stressful your day to day duties are to when/if you get promoted.

Another con is that the culture is becoming more and more sales oriented to the detriment of other functions. Sales are definitely important, but so is risk management, compliance, and back office operations. This probably isn't specific to Merrill, but it still counts as a con in my book.

review_title: Bank of America is a bully.
pros: The benefits are some of the best around. They offer vision, dental, and medical and the cost varies by how much you want to spend every month. They also provide paid vacations, 401k, and health accounts. Associate discounts on credit cards are also decent.
cons: The employees are the last thing they think about. Do not expect a raise unless you makes sales, sales, sales. Experience, knowledge, reliability means nothing to them. They train you to do one thing, but expect you to do the complete opposite just so you can meet their numbers. No respect is given to employees. When employees are asked for feedback about what is working and what is not, they ignore any input if it doesn't follow their agenda.

review_title: Strong-willed employees prevail at Bank of America; promote yourself.
job_title: Premier Client Manager in Washington, DC
pros: Location, location, location.  FT jobs might offer flex time& other perks.  Professional work environment and very multi-cultural employees work at this Bank.  Referral bonuses for new employees who are hired into the company.  Great health benefits, education reimbursement, 401K plan with company match & company-provided pension plan that you are vested within 3-5 years.
cons: Inconsistent job promotions & old boys club environment still prevails.  Women & men in the same position should be provided with equal pay & equal promotion opportunities.  The trickle down theory is evident when financial goals are set by upper managment out of touch with our client base who present the goals to their leadership team on down to the supervisory level.  Sometimes these goal levels are very tough to achieve to secure bonus payments per quarter for those employees who work on a commission basis.

review_title: Ken Lewis quits before endictment?  Lies to shareholders.
pros:
Pay and benes are ok though you have to twist your Boss' arm to get info about a raise even after years of nothing.
Work at home process is good.
cons: Little focus on Associates despite what Execs say.   Associates satisfaction surveys have ltitle impact as in e-commerce they have changed little over the years and each year Execs say they will work on the issues but never do. Suspect they just check off the mark on their performance appraisal for Ken. Morale is low as it seems Ken lied to shareholders about the Merrill buyout. Lots of law suits against BAC which only hurts Associates as Execs & Board continue to get stock bonuses.  E-commerce is filled with imcompetent people and Execs keep changing yet bring little expertise.   Defintely a company where politics are high and its who you know and NOT what you know to get ahead.   Why are they not firing those folks who got us into this mess with the CountryWide and MBNA and ML buyouts?   Did Ken lie to AT Cuomo in NY State? We will soon find out.

review_title: Process transactions and refer financial products.
pros: The benefit package is exceptional.  The ability to network with customers who come into the banking center.  My managers are excellent and I like working for them.  They listen to me and give me responsibility if I ask for it.
cons: Always and I mean always under a microscope.  Referrals are exceptionally easy for me, so I would reccomend anyone who isnt shy around other people.  Policies change at the drop of a pin.  Our customers are really getting agitated with them-we have to listen to them.  We are getting better though.

review_title: Not the best place to work.
pros:
Stable job- It offers the normal bank hours.  Easy enough, there will be no surprises on the weekend if the bank gets too busy.
Decent pay- Hourly pay is ok.  After some time you will get some pay raises, but nothing spectacular.  
Advancement opportunities- But you usually must be willing to relocate, within the city, to a new branch.
cons:
One of the cons is that you are at the mercy of the branch manager.  My experience was that he wasn't professional at all, and didn't treat the rest of the employees well, or played favorites.  i.e. the cute girls would get everything.
Because of this, it was prone to petty office politics and petty squabbles.  Not a fun or productive work environment at all.

review_title: Good for starters, upper management is living in a dream world.
pros: For starters, it is a good place to learn. Lots of talents, but they are leaving in waves. Good technology footprint and lots of opportunities to learn.
cons: Benefits are ok, it used to be good, but it is getting worse by the day.Management (SLT) is in a dream land. They are moving all the jobs to NY and CLT, but the want the business from TX and other states. Someone heard one of the SLT (English), invasion of the Beatles.... All the direct leadership are all from across the pond in Technology. You are spared based on who you know. Not sure how long this is going to last.

review_title: Great company to work in. I worked with Bank of America Home Loans.
job_title: MLO-Senior Loan Services Specialist in Westlake Village, CA
pros: The company is big on their values and the leadership is, for the most part, great and easy to talk to. I enjoyed my job, it was something I knew how to do but kept learning along the way. My co-workers are some of the best people I know and have become close friends with many. This is a great company if you enjoy being around a positive atmosphere. It was not hard to move up if you are good at your job and have goals.
cons: The pay isn't the best since there is other companies making better offers. Also the mandatory overtime sometimes can be overwhelming.

review_title: Good bank to start your career, tough to move up
pros: Benefits, average pay, pretty easy to relocate
cons: If you're a salaried employee, expect a 50+ hour workweek. Way too many call nights and trackers to send in. Not necessarily what you know, but who you know if you're looking to advance. Be leary if you're looking to work in the branches as nearly 400 closed from when I started in 09 until I left in 13. They killed the Cme role (2 steps above a branch manager), so it'll be a big challenge to become a cmm (step above a branch manager) as many of these displaced execs are in joke roles until a cmm opening comes along. But, rest assure, as cmm opening s never get posted anymore.

review_title: To everything, there is a season.....
job_title: Senior Customer Service Representative/NS&S in Tempe, AZ
pros: Benefits are pretty good, and I learned a lot of different things about banking, and about things in life (The need for retirement accounts, trusts, ATM fraud, a bit about legal documents, etc.) A lot of good people work here. Well-rounded takeaway.
cons: I'm not going to be completely honest with you about everything at the bank (you'll have to find that out on your own) but one thing that I will comment on is the culture of management and their rationale for promotions and developing their employees. It's better in some departments than others, so don't expect too much. You will learn a lot working for them, but know when to leave and move on, unless you want to stay in banking or investing. (Tip: 100% Tuition reimbursement - don't leave without a degree! :-) )

job_title: Customer Relations Manager (Last Title) in Norfolk, VA
pros: My coworkers were great, teamwork, support
cons: Was with the company for 13 years, was in many roles, each role seemed to be less and less organized. It became apparent that upper management did not know what our goals were, and how to achieve profitable outcome. It became a very stressful environment.  Employees became self taught in mortgage retention. Then in 2014 they made the decision to sell our division to Stewart Lender Services.  We became their vendor doing the exact same work, then after 1 1/2 years they cancelled our contract and Stewart had to close our doors.

pros:
Bank's philanthropic work is great as is their encouragement of employee involvement with organized volunteer activities.  

Lots of technology related opportunities, especially for offshore and nearshore.
cons:
There was a culture clash between the bank and the company they bought as technology merged.   Bank is top heavy with management and process/politics so decisions/actions are slow .   The company they bought runs lean and fast with creativity where decisions are made at a lower level.   

They verbally encourage employees to move to other positions internally but don't walk the talk to truly support that.  

They are pulling back the "work at home" employees instead of giving managers/employees the tools/training to manage that remote relationship.  I think this is short sighted and a mistake.   Its a global workforce and you need to find talent outside the headquarters location.

pros: Good salary, nice benefits, company provides transportation from certain points of the city to the bank building. Onsite restaurant and gym. Nice and tidy building.
cons:
No training at all. People don't care about you, who you are, what's your name where you come from. Everybody is so "busy" to help a colleague, teach something about the role or even say a word of incentive. 
You just sit there and try to learn yourself something from the very confusing procedures files. Even though they expect you to know what you are doing without teaching anything.

review_title: Was once a great place to work for!
pros:
Flexibility 
Work Life Balance
Vacation 
Immediate co-workers are great
Benefits (Medical, Dental, Vision)
Work hours
Volunteerism 
Community Development
Bank Holidays
Maternity/Paternity leave
Childcare Expense
cons:
Bonus
Poor leadership
Poor technology
Career Advancement
Stressful
Employees are disposable
Job Security
No diversity in higher paying roles
Integrity
Perks that went away (i.e. reimbursement of a portion of parking expense)

review_title: Potential to grow with great benefits
pros: Great benefits and pay is aligned with workload and success. Flexible working options available for some. Potential to grow in the company (worked here for 13 years moved up to a VP designation).
cons: Constant reorganization means you will most likely not be working in the position or with the manager you originally applied. I was transferred to a different manager 22 times in less than 24 months. This means you have to "tell your story" over and over to get the assignments or recognition/bonus/incentive etc you deserve.  Unfortunately for me this meant that at any given time my new manager could let me go because my role did not fit within this "new way /business model" without taking into consideration the years I put into the company and that I wanted a different role.

pros: Benefits over all are very good and vacation time as well. Salaries are good. Better than other banks in Charlotte. BAC is leaps ahead of other banks in innovation and technologies.
cons:
They changed their tuition reimbursement program without notifying anyone. 
Not of any use to someone who already has a degree unless you’re interested in paying for an additional degree. 
Very hard to schedule training because you often do the work of two or three people. 
Employee review process really needs an overhaul all band fives are compared to band fives across the organization so it’s very very hard to be recognized for hard work, long hours.
They took work from home away, while parking uptown is a nightmare and the three hours a day in a commute are better spent working.

review_title: BOA works if you want to work for it
pros: Work life balance, the ability to buy an extra week of vacation time, the way that management lets you know what is going to happen, and the size of the company allows you to jump in to almost a new business while staying inside the company
cons: Slow promotions, salary increases are slow to happen and small, also if you are looking for a company to disappear in and just earn a paycheck then this is the company for you, but if you really want to move up and work hard there is a lot of talent here who is trying for the same position so be ready to fight for it. Also there is a lot of office politics here know who are you friends and you enemies will try to trip you on the way up.

pros: Awesome health benefits and 401k match
cons: They micro-manage everything to how many times a person uses the restroom!! Instead of working together as a team the managers would plot against each other - yes manager against manager in their own scheme to get over on each other which then trickles down to the rest of the department, which made for a very uncomfortable work environment.  On top of that there were more "managers" then there were employees in my department!! The bank also has a way of forgetting the years of service you gave to them when it comes time to "downsize" due to their mistakes and greed. If they didn't have as large of a ladder of "managers", "team leads", "team lead manager" , "unit manager", "team unit manger", and so on they would save millions in salaries and more work would actually get done on a daily basis.

review_title: Global Markets, Agreements & Documentation, Fixed Income
pros: Some very talented mid-level managers who one can learn, it is acceptable not to work long hours (but that is in large part due to the low salary base)
cons: Poor resource allocation, e.g. some ISDA and Futures negotiators are greatly overworked, creating risk, while others have very little, and hardwork is not always rewarded.  Group is heavily staffed with consultants, which is fine, but there is a lot of turnover and perhaps some productivity-reducing resentment from longterm (1-2 years +) consultants, many of whom have impressive qualifications but are never hired permanently and are treated somewhat like cattle.  Further, the group has no stature within Global Markets, making certain interdepartmental interactions a bit painful, and ensures that navigating a career into other Global Markets departments is nearly impossible.

pros: 401(k) match was nice and is more generous than I've found at my new Firm. This, along with decent health insurance, were two of the better facets of working at the Bank.
cons: The working environment was awful in both groups I worked in while at Bank of America. The environment was such that there was so much expected of you - working long hours and not having tools to do the work efficiently - and, although recognized as exceeding expectations at my level, felt that there was no significant upside in sight after doing the work. Little room for growth and jumped at a great opportunity with a company that recognizes hard work.

review_title: Registered Financial Advisor - BAML PMD Trainee
job_title: Financial Advisor Trainee in Santa Monica, CA
pros:
-Evolving Program: Optional new team structure for on-boarding financial advisor trainees
-Good Employee Benefits: Good health insurance options and employee discounts
-Great Training Program: Structured virtual and classroom trainings that prepare you for both licensing exams as well as sales trainings
cons:
-High Account Minimums: Difficult for new account openings for financial advisors
-Extra Non-Paid Work: Potential to be forced to work longer hours than the industry regulated max
-Long Path to Success and Prosperity: If you are in the sole practitioner program it's difficult to graduate and make decent money

review_title: Great job if you like being a verbal punching bag
job_title: Client Service Representative (Teller) in Dana Point, CA
pros: Tellers are paid better than the majority of those from other banks, 401k with easy access to a financial advisor if you work at a branch with a Merrill Edge employee, easy to work hours (branches are generally 9-5 or 10-6)
cons: You are the most visible employee so naturally you are blamed for everything and take most of the heat from customers, BoA has been cutting back on the number of tellers they employ so it is likely you may be the only one quite often and trying to deal with a pissed off customer with a huge line of people behind them can be very frustrating.  They also push sales very hard on you and gove daily quotas just to add on top of that.  Tellers also get no commission, the bankers and managers get to reap all those rewards.

review_title: Hard work goes unnoticed if it doesn't contribute to sales.
pros:
Great company to get promoted IF you're in the right branch, and selling product.

Great benefits
cons:
On evenings where everyone was trying to get their check cashed and the line was out of the door, you would get reprimanded for working too fast if you weren't pitching credit card and checking/savings accounts. 

Management ranged from excellent from horrendous, again depending on branch location. 

Hard work does go unnoticed, and if you weren't selling product every chance you had there were consequences. 

Selling product provides no benefit to the employee. I know Chase, at least gives the employee some form of compensation for each account they open.

Inefficient program to work in, needs a massive updating in the UI / UX.

job_title: Personal Banker in San Jose, CA
pros:
The benefits package is pretty decent (401k matching etc).
Coming from a retail background the hours are amazing.
The employees and culture are not as cut-throat as other banks that I've worked for (Wells Fargo).
Great place to make a career, especially if you are still in school or don't have a degree.
cons:
The physical traffic for personal bankers is limited.
Cold-calling is a must if you seek to exceed your goals.
High pressure environment with little room for failure.
Favoritism runs rampant as far as promotions go.
There is a lack of professionalism across the branches that I visited in my time there.
High turnover on branch managers.
I had 3 different ones in the year I was there.

pros: The wide footprint can provide opportunity if you either live near one of their hub cities or are willing to move.
cons: Difficult to maneuver through the maze of such an enormous company.  Much information gets lost when dealing with so many.  The layers of people and overlapping structures can impede progress, in spite of the efforts made by Sr. Mgmt to remove obstacles and empower employees.

pros: I am lucky enough to be able to work from home, though they have started an initiative to get everyone back in the office. I am somewhat pleased with the benefits package they have available for all employees, including the stuff I don't use but my co-workers do. I also like the amount of volunteering they encourage.
cons: It's a huge organization. They have a reward program for employees who are nominated by co-workers for excellent teamwork, but as you might guess, this is a popularity contest. They have a mentoring program in place, but unless you are interested in moving to other similar positions that you already hold, it's very difficult to transfer to different duties or departments.

pros: The people are great but management sucks.
cons: The company has changed over the years and is not a fun place to work at anymore.  Layoffs continue and outsourcing (India) is rampant throughout the company.  If your looking for IT positions, good luck finding any.  You either have to relocate to NC or FL, if you don't fit that mold they wont even consider you.  Its a shame because when I started back in 2007 it was a great place to work and now its a free for all to see who can save there own skin.

job_title: Mortgage Loan Officer in Houston, TX
pros: Great benefits and the team I work with is like a family
cons:
There is a lot of responsibility associated with this job.  I don't believe the base pay is equivalent to amount of work you do. You are not JUST a loan officer. You are basically managing a branch (sometimes multiple branches) going to meetings, constantly on conference calls, sending out reports, coaching the staff as to how to uncover opportunities, all the while trying to bring in new business and manager your pipeline. It is sometimes SUPER OVERWHELMING because you are spread so thin. 

Your branches are pulling you one way and your managers are pulling you in another. The base and draw is simply not worth the amount you really do. I would be 100% pleased if my base pay was indicative of my work load. You not only work the  branch hours but you ALSO work while you're at home to appease the clients.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: The conglomerate bank has exceeded profitability expectations and records in the past few quarters.
cons: Their profitability has been a partial product of lower expenses including replacement of permanent American jobs with that from overseas functional transitioning.  The best part of the tax reform of 2018 was the bank foreseeing their ability to continue their permanent employee footprint reduction in advance of a substantial tax benefit with no repercussion of government backlash for the thousands of American job losses.

review_title: Corporate America: Not the worst, Not the best
pros:
Benefits!  Like most large corporations the benefits are stellar and the pay is pretty decent for the amount of work expected.   Make sure you negotiate a strong salary up front, because once you're in, increases are minuscule. 
Decent middle management in that they aren't micro-managers; however they aren't exactly courageous either.
cons:
Much like any large corporation, it can take herculean efforts to make even the smallest of changes.
BAC used to feel progressive, but as of the last few years has been going backwards.  
Example:  where there was once a robust flex-work/work from home program - there is no longer.  While other corporations are doing MORE flexibility, they are  actively doing the reverse.
They wonder why they have lost so many female executives but don't make the changes needed to attract and retain them in a competitive market. 
Unless you are willing to relocate to headquarters, or work in the Consumer business - opportunities for growth are very limited.

review_title: Great if you are a office politician, otherwise avoid like the plague!
job_title: Investment Banking Vice President in Charlotte, NC
pros: The day you leave for good.  Seriously, the only good thing to me about BofA is that with the current financial crisis, I see people finally getting what they deserve.  I have witnessed far too many people get squeezed out at the bank over the years and only now I see people who deserved to be let go years ago being shown the door.
cons: Like Rodney Dangerfield said, "No respect at all."  Please note that I no longer work for the bank, I left on my own but know that I too would have been squeezed out over time.  It is all about politics.  My personal feeling, and that of many people I speak with who are still at the bank is that at least 20% of the staff could be let go and it would have no real effect on the day to day productivity of the bank.  IF you like a corporation that promotes politicing over intelligence this is the place for you.  Otherwise I would not work there.

review_title: It's a pretty good job, decent company.....but obviously could be a lot better.
pros: The benefit package offered by the bank is nice.  Not the best in the industry but pretty good.  In my position I'm able to manage my work without too much manager oversight.  Can work when/where I need so that flexibility is great.
cons: Who knows if my overall compensation is fair??  There's no way to determine how my pay compares to others because that information is just not discussed.  Communication in my line of business is terrible.  All of the managers are reactive and never proactive so all of our work is a constant fire drill.  Most of the time we're just in the dark on current status of work in our area.

review_title: A good starting place in the mortgage business
pros: I worked for Countrywide Home Loans, which is now Bank of America.  I worked from 2005-2008 which was right around the time of the hey day of making a lot of money in mortgages.  If you're good at product knowledge and really care about your customers, you can definitely make good money.  The best year I had (again, during the hey day) was around $90,000.  I think now, you can make around $50,000 or more maybe.
cons: I worked in a call center environment.  The pros of that was that leads were provided to us for free via their marketing systems, but the con was that I couldn't see my customers in person, and I was chained to my desk for most of the day.  If you like working over the phone, this would be a great deal, but if you like working with customers in person, then maybe working in a branch office is a better choice.

review_title: Severe Transition Pains for Industry Behemoth
pros: I was Very fortunate within my Time at Bank Of America, to hit a particular group of teammates and managers.  Who truly understood my style, better still were comfortable working with it..  While my efforts to gain promotion and advancement by traditional standards failed.  Eventually being laid off.. By most accounts having made National Asset Team ..National Quality ranking etc.. I was more successful here then in many other times in my career.
cons: If your looking to Change careers ( as I was) and not willing to grow through there accepted promotional path, depending on which area you begin at.  Forget breaking into your desired area..unless that role is a normally accepted  destination.  Past experience outside the company doesn't matter...!!!

job_title: Senior Account Manager in Atlanta, GA
pros:
Awesome training system in place, BOA employees are some of the best trained in the industry.
Great benefits package and access to EAP that really work.
cons:
The management staff believes in micromanaging you.  If you aren't performing in the top 95% look forward to constant emails and meetings with your supervisor.  Their system for improving performance is counter productive because they spend so much time sending emails and taking you away from your job that you miss opportunities for improvement.

Zero work/life balance.  They make you work 2 late nights during the weekend and 2 Saturdays a month. Forget about picking up a part time job, it won't be possible.  Other activities like attending your child's after school functions may be difficult as well.  They really invade your entire life.

review_title: I have had 15 years of branch experience in every position from teller to branch manager
pros: good benefits package, competitive wage
cons: very demanding, very micro managing, extremely hard for the branch to deal with customers with reputation the bank has earned in the last few years.  Continuously cutting staff and increasing work demand.

job_title: Senior Operations Consultant in Rancho Cordova, CA
pros: Bank of America provides highly competivie careers for those who need to work from home to achieve life balance. Associates can earn anywhere from $35k to $100K+ annually working from home 90-100% of the time. In addition, you are still able to network into other positions within the bank and live anywhere in the United States.
cons: Although I love the perks of working home home full-time, I am not too happy with the pay. I started with the bank in an entry-level position earning less than what I am worth. Although I was able to move up very quickly (less than one year), I have never been satisfied with the pay. In my opinion, the pay does not match the performance. I am also not too happy with the lack of opportunity to easily transition into other departments as a my work associate.

review_title: Not the meritocracy it claims to be.
job_title: Contact Center Representative in San Antonio, TX
pros: Good health benefits, annual increases in pay are a good start. Overtime opportunities are plentiful but rarely mandatory. Performance incentives.
cons: Difficult to advance. Weak training that does not prepare new hires for their jobs. Agents are empowered, but often rebuked for doing the right thing. Nebulous attendance and disciplinary guidelines that give leadership the ability to look the other way...unless they want to get rid of you, then they can and will find any excuse to put you on corrective action and take away your monthly performance bonus, raise, promotion, etc.

pros: Excellent health benefits and retirement options
cons: Corporate environment with way too many chiefs, too much politics, difficult to put policies into practice, extremely poor internal communication, expressed concerns go unanswered.  Training in my line of business was weak at best and needs definite improvement.  Upper management (with very few exceptions) far removed from day to day processes and not at all in tune with what it takes to make things happen on the front lines.  Everything is strictly a numbers game and as a result, quality customer service has suffered greatly.

pros: Great place to focus and sharpen the skills such as attention to detail, identifying, researching, analyzing, resolving claims with 98 percent and above accuracy range. The atmosphere with-in department was friendly, pleasant, flexible. Many department celebrations of employee recognition, staff meetings on department progress and feedback encouraged for better process of job.
cons: management exorcised their own discretion and not consistent  in following rules, guidelines and procedures to ensure employees met or exceed their monthly performance goals. very hard to transfer to a lateral and or upward to higher position with in department or other branch locations.

review_title: Good place to get experience, decent pay/benefits
pros: The company has very good benefits, and pays well in comparison with other banks. Bank of America seems like an excellent place to get into the banking industry, and later move on to more lucrative positions with local Credit Unions and the like.
cons: No incentives for selling products for the tellers, when they are crucial to the success of relationship bankers in actually meeting goals. The company doesn't give enough hours; they prefer to make people part time, and flex hours up or down as needed. The company recommends giving 10 minute paid breaks to employees, but I've had one in the past year.

review_title: Beware! This place will ruin you.
pros: Health benefits, some free food, some great coworkers who share your pain. Besides that there is not much else I can say.
cons: There is A LOT wrong with this company. Managers spend half their time interviewing and the other half sitting around doing next to nothing. “Training” is abysmal or nonexistent in most cases. You’re expected to sink or swim while dealing with clients who think they are talking to experts. The systems are so outdated and difficult to navigate. The level of internal pushback from different departments is astonishing considering we all work for the same company. If you enjoy getting screamed at by angry clients while you fumble around for answers, this job is perfect for you. Otherwise do yourself a favor and look elsewhere.

review_title: Be fair when it comes to providing  growth opportunities
job_title: Financial Center Manager in Houston, TX
pros: Health Benefits and vacation time.
cons:
BOA is biased when it comes to promoting associates. 
Low salary.
Very few growth opportunities

pros: Great culture within the bank.  Management encourages and support career growth as well as making the workplace a "family environment".  Bank of America usually hires strong individuals that have career goals.  Good place to develop banking skills. They focus on customer satisfaction more than anything.
cons: Goals are high and payouts are low and only twice a year (starting in 2010).  They want you to follow a sales sheet when assisting a new customer.  They do not encourge you to use your creativity or imagination to lock in on a sale or to build customer retention.  Pay is lower than some other larger banks.  Too many conference calls throughout the day.  Makes it hard to sell products when you're on calls 3 to 4 times per week.

pros: Management all on the same sheet of music as far as changes go. They all say the same things about guidance from above and do their best to implement it.
cons: Cranky customers, changes to what is required without any consideration of economic stress or the type of calls received in a given period of time.  Static requirements for sales with reduced incentive plans and favoritism among team managers are what you should expect.

job_title: Vice President & Senior Client Manager in Atlanta, GA
pros: I worked at the bank for a long time.  I would probably still be there if the economy and the purchase of Merrill Lynch had not precipitated the elimination of my division.  Senior management may have made some errors in the integration of the ML acquisition.  Only time will tell.  There is new senior management at Bank of America which may put the bank's management closer on par with Jamie Dimon at JPMorgan Chase.
cons: Management's short term solution to cut costs means that your job can be risk even if you have had a history of performing well.

pros: Start pay is not too bad and some positions allow you to work from home. Medical insurance cost has lowered some in the last year but not a lot. They offer a program to for child care reimbursement.  Not all managers are bad, there are still a few good and honest ones.
cons: Lots of politics and favoritism. As far as promotions go, it's all about who you know and who you are friends are. If you are not one of the favorites it can be frustrating . Annual increases are a joke. Medical benefits offered are still too high. Some managers are lack proper leadership and communication skills. Some areas are under-managed while others are micro-managed.

pros: Bank of America provide options for medical, dental, and eye insurance.  The cost is based  on a sliding scale according to your income.  Children of employees with at least one year of employment are eligible for a renewable scholarship, now set at $2500 per year. Associates, as we are called, are eligible for BAC associate banking discounts. Associates can purchase and additional week of vacation.
cons: The call center enviroment is designed for optimun production and limited individuality.  Goals are aggressive and achievement is required, yet set high enough to make it almost impossible to achieve on a monthly basis.  Goals are moved on a regular basis, education is limited as is the time needed to improve preformance.  Legal disclosures required by each associate to sign will allow BAC to terminate an employee for 1 of a myriad of reasons.  You are a machine when at work.  Ever possilbe measurement of your time and production will occur.

review_title: Nightmare.......no matter how good your work ethic is...you will get lied to!
pros: NONE - they took away anything that was good, ie bonuses for the little people, but don't worry, the big guys so disconnected upstairs, they get theirs!
cons: Let's put it this way, they treat their employees the way they treat their poor customers that they are trying to get rid of.  No matter your education, experience, diligent work ethic, they will make you crazy and have unrealistic goals and put crazy people in charge and when they don't know what to do with them then...they just switch them from place to place instead of firing them.   The nightmare of my jobs, I worked there for 2.5 years started and moved up twice, so I worked by behind off, didn't matter every door I opened was just a new level of one of "Dante's Layers" of you know where.  Don't do it, so many people were so unhappy and even yes, physically ill from the stress of this company.  And this is coming from an educated, hard working, go getting individual...so please heed my warning....I am so glad I got out of there.

review_title: For better or worse this is a very large company
pros: Massive client base that is incredibly varied in size and complexity. Well known company that until recently has had a rich history. You have the opportunity to do pretty much anything related to finance if you choose to pursue it. A lot of really good natured people that don't get enough credit.
cons: Management heavy organization. Recent history has caused people to have a very negative reaction to the company you work for. Red tape is never ending so it is difficult to get things done and almost impossible to do things that aren't part of the standard procedure.

job_title: National Production Support in Atlanta, GA
pros: Competitive salary and benefits.  I was in a work from home job the last 2 years employed which really cant be beat.
cons: 401k really din't have much in the way of  fund selection.  I've read that this is pretty much standard for the banking industry.  There is just too much money to be made back by offering mediocre funds and hoping you will buy the banks funds which tend to under perform the market and have high fees to boot.  They also rely on out sourced labor so be prepared to be jettisoned if they deem you replaceable.

pros:
Good advancement opportunities
Excellent benefits
Wide range of career paths
Stable work envirionment
Fair salary and bonus range
Fair review and performance plans
Enviroinmentally and socially conscious company who gives back and puts money into philanthropy
Innovative problem solving to meet client needs 
Associate reward systems - great at recognizing and rewarding hard work
cons:
Highly hierarchtical with layers of management who may not have a useful function
Right hand may not know what left hand is doing - certain level of disconnectedness
Promotions can be based on relationship (who knows who) versus actual skill and talent
Easy to get locked into a career path that may not be by choice - at a certain level, promotions may be assigned instead of applied for
No management training to teach managers how to manage people, rather focuses on performance of function and tasks

review_title: Mortgage Resolution Specialist at BoA: manual clerical work
job_title: Mortgage Resolution Specialist in Fort Worth, TX
pros: The work is not difficult, and you are generally not micromanaged.
cons:
You'll likely start out as a contract employee with a chance to move to permanent if the workload remains high.

The job itself was/is a glorified admin. position. There's nothing wrong with that if that is what you're qualified for. However, many of the MRTs had JDs, and some were licensed attorneys. The skill level of the work was pretty low despite the description of the job. If you have any legal training, do not be fooled by the dob description. There did not seem to be much room for advancement, and the job is very monotonous. 

BoA is such a large company that paper pushing is the norm, and the vast majority of the employees at my jobsite were less than ideal. The individual portfolios managed by each MRT were scores long which ensured that no attention was paid to doing the work correctly so much as doing a lot of it.

pros: Great exposure to software technology used in a fast paced environment.  Good opportunities to learn new tools on the myLearning resource site. Professional people on the teams and projects you work with.  Business is run like a well oiled machine.  Decent pay compensation and benefits.
cons: By having managers or teammates scattered throughout the country, there is little chance to meet face to face. Thus, when cost saving measures are taken to reduce staff, you have no way of knowing your manager or having a discussion.  Impersonal way of working with people and you feel like just another cog in a wheel.  Poor relationship connections on a human level.  All work focus and you are treated like a robot and not a person.

review_title: Great for employees, hands tied for customers
job_title: Professional Teller in Broken Arrow, OK
pros: The company treats its employees very well, even working part-time. The benefits are very nice and reasonable costs, with lots of options to find what works best for you. Generally the hours are pretty flexible if you are taking classes or have some other obligation I found management to be easy to work with.
cons: Working Saturdays, although I know they have now stopped having all branches open on Saturdays. Also the company was pushing sales through the teller line when I left and this hurt our relationships with our customers or our job performance rating. We had to choose between having a bad rating with the company or upsetting our long time customers.

job_title: Relationship Manager in New York, NY
pros: Better paying salary than most banks. Ability to get business from where you want to. If you perform, the day is spent how you like it to be spent
cons: In order to perform you must be willing to sell products like credit cards to people without a real need. Bank of America is heavy into credit card usage and makes it the best way to hit your goal. They mask widget selling with assisting clients with their "Life Priorities". In one sentence Bank of America is a pushing credit card business. If you are looking to build profitable long lasting relationships with clients " which usually develop over time", look elsewhere.

job_title: Senior Vice President in Charlotte, NC
pros: The benefits package and pay.  It is hard to beat them.
cons:
At BAC, you are simply a robot.  The company does not treat its people as people, but as subjects to the kingdom.  Witness the recent economic downtown.  Bank of America buys Merrill Lynch, then starts banging its employees out.

BAC is crowing about how it has the financial liquidity to survive the current situation and prosper.  It is bragging about how it has a higher volume and the "flight to quality," but it is reducing its own workforce, not the ML workforce, but the workforce that handles this "flight to quality."  In other words, if you go to work there, expect to do 5X the work with 50% of the needed resources.

There is also very little humanity to this company.  The Executive leadership style is all about humiliation and drive to compete, with no feel for people.

pros:
100% Employer funded health care account worth $600-1,200 
3 weeks paid vacation + Purchased Time off (one week max)
10 paid sick days for full time, 5 paid sick days for part time
Medical, Dental, Vision, Long term disability, Accidental death and Dis, free assoicate life insurance 1*annual salary—childcare reimbursement
Pension plan- you accrue 4% of your salary per year
401K plan- you get a 5% match up to 100 percent of your total eligible compensation
Tuition Reimbursement up to 5,250 per year –part time associates get benefits too
Hybrid Vehicle program- you get $3,000 for purchasing a brand new hybrid vehicle
cons: Management, most are not helpful at all. In fact, sometimes you may find yourself questioning their judgement. There is a high turn over in thebanking centers which results inpoor customer satisfaction as recently evidenced by the J.D. Power and Associates scurvey during our last quarter.

pros: The company has great benefits (you get 3 weeks of vacation to start) and there are lots of opportunities for making lateral career moves.  Many people take advantage of the size of the company to move around to different positions to grow their skills.
cons: You have to follow a process for every little thing that needs to be done which can make it difficult to accomplish anything in a timely manner.  There are endless governance committees, stakeholder meetings, tollgates and approval processes to go through for all projects and initiatives, big and small, high risk and low risk.  There are also constant organizational changes which can also make it difficult to get things done because management has to take the time to figure out how they want to organize their new team and what they want their priorities to be.  The up side to the recent organizational changes is that, this time, layers of middle (unnecessary) management are being eliminated.

pros: Bank of America provides good benefits and it's not difficult to move up if you work hard and have good numbers. Used to be an excellent place to work. Great management and employees at the branch level.
cons: Consistently cutting down staffing to an extent that it's extremely difficult to run our branch if even one person is out sick or on vacation. Our staff is 1/3 of what it was 2 years ago, our work load has tripled and not a single person receives additional compensation. It has been made VERY clear over the past few years that Bank of America cares infinitely more about the bottom line than it does its employees. BofA has already eliminated incredibly important roles and will continue to be eliminating jobs in 2015. It no longer feels like a secure place to work. Employees at the branch level are increasingly dissatisfied with Bank of America as a whole and many longterm employees in our market are seeking other employment opportunities elsewhere.

pros: Bank of America offers great and a pretty wide range of benefits to their employees.  Most departments do have great training programs to help new hires or transfers into new roles.  Like many large corporations they have efficient processes and lots of opportunities to move into.
cons: If you are not in a sales based position, i.e investment banking, the salaries offered tend to be lower than some of its competitors.  Although there are several opportunities at Bank of America, transferring from one line of business to another is pretty difficult especially when attempting to promote or move laterally.  I was personally told by a recruiter that in order to move to a new line of business I would have to reduce my Band ( affects vacation time) and take a severe pay cut.

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Renton, WA
pros: The pay for a CSR (formerly "Teller") is decent. If you like talking to people or working in sales, this could be a job for you. You get to meet all kinds of different people and, aside from trying to sell them something, you really get to learn who they are and try to HELP them.
cons: I'm an OTE (overtime eligible employee), but we are not allowed to go over our hours since we are technically "fully staffed". They want us out by 6:30 but still want us (CSR's) to complete all kinds of closing tasks before we leave knowing we are one of the busiest centers in our area. On top of that, they're now cutting CSRs hours and how many we have at one time. So now, majority of the tasks fall on one person at the end of the night. But still have to be out by 6:30.

review_title: Great benefits & good work, life balance
pros:
- Huge company so lots of options to move around to different departments/teams
- Many location so good for relocation
- Excellent benefits including 16 weeks of paid paternity leave for men and women
- Good work, life balance where it's encouraged to use all vacation time
- Great management team with managers that care about the employees and their future at the company
cons:
- Poor yearly raises (if any)
- Difficult to get promoted partly because of so many people; extremely competitive 
- Only certain band levels are eligible for yearly bonuses
- High turnover in some groups within operations
- HR department that focuses on career mobility is disorganized making it almost impossible to find an internal job on your own without knowing people/managers that can help you

review_title: Bank of America is spreading itself thin
pros: geographic diversity, technical development programs such as six sigma, retail presence and brand recognition, associate discounts on products, flexible work options such as work at home and remote, incentive comp (during profitable times), collaboration tools and encouragement, project discipline, values of the company are strong to the extent they are practiced and they are generally adopted in a real way
cons: large corporate focus on expansion, growth and product diversity at all costs, cost cutting to provide short term benefits and potential long term inability to sustain growth and innovation, benefits are expensive and not competitive, tuition reimbursement limitations, at times expense focus is irrational and immaterial (supplies, publications, etc), support for technology and the technology is dated and below what is needed for technical or analytical jobs

review_title: Bank of America's Corporate Treasury review
job_title: Associate Vice President in Chicago, IL
pros:
Vacation starts at 4w/year for Band levels 5 and up. The Bank provides many perks to its employees, but as of recently it has begun shutting off its perk programs. 
Computer-based training is available to all employees. In addition, the Bank covers up to $5000 per year in business-related educational expenses.
cons:
The Bank has many line of businesses, this review is only for the Corporate Treasury. 
Managers in Corporate Treasury tend to treat the pay-for-performance associate development program as a bureaucratic hussle - lots of activity is being faked around year-end on these plans, but it's all for show. There are tons of guidelines how to do this process properly, but managers simply can't be bothered. 

On the benefits side: the health insurance packages worsened signifficantly lately as the Bank has cut its health insurance costs signifficantly. 

Corporate perks programs are being eliminated one by one. This includes the associate home ownership program and the spirit awards program.

job_title: Banking Center Manager in Nashville, TN
pros: BoA had a very attractive financial package when economic conditions were more favorable.  Now, not quite as good, but still better than most.  They're a good bank to start with and learn retail banking.   They have many locations and lines of business, so there are good possibilities for advancement or transfer to another banking center.
cons: BoA cares more about they're shareholders than they do the customer.  They do not allow enough freedom to make decisions for the betterment of the banking center or the customer.  They're a cookie-cutter bank that seeks to take your focus away from the customer and toward micro managing your day.  They set goals so high that they create an environment that promotes unethical business practices and then turn a blind eye to those inappropriate actions.  If you enjoy unrealistic expectations, buzz words and the glib, up with people 'spirit' that BoA uses to cloak systems that really don't work, this is the place for you.  Just be sure to drink the kool-aid in one quick gulp, it won't taste so bitter.

review_title: Great company for the employees, not so good for the actual customers!
job_title: Senior Telephone Sales Representative in Fort Worth, TX
pros: Good promotion from within, great managers who provide you with the tools to succed in your position, decent pay, 3 weeks vacation with the option of purchasing an extra week!
cons: Every since the financial crisis the company became way to strict on employees as far as time management and began (in my opinion) stealing from customers who themselves were hurting with overbearing fees!  We basically had to become good at simply telling customers NO REFUNDS!   Before the economy went south employees were greatly rewarded for their work, but they have taken that all away as well.....The environment was very motivating, but now is stressful with all the stats you have to maintain and now they even have customer service agents selling credit cards!  UGH!

review_title: Depends on the group you are working in it can be good or bad
job_title: Assistant Vice President in New York, NY
pros: Good Benefits, Good name in the finance industry, Good name for your resume, if you have an ok or good manager this place is great, unfortunately I left because I didn't see my future shaping up well under the new management.
cons:
Current Manager is highly incompetent, uses scare tactics, plays favourites.  Of course this is something which is different from group to group. If you are a female, then no matter how smart you are, you will always be considered dumb and stupid. If you are too good at your job, the manager will get insecure and try to push you down, you will not get good work or be allowed to participate in meetings. decision making etc was only a male only area. 
Zero communication, zero conflict resolution ability.

review_title: Overall positive until the last few years - too much time wasted on non productive routines and processes.
pros: technologically advanced, fair benefits and pay
cons: Several poor management decisions over the last few years have had a significant impact on the company stock and as a result the significant downsizing and reorganization. There is an atmosphere of uncertainty felt by everyone. No one feels secure in their role.

review_title: I loved what I did and there was room for learning but not advancement .
pros:
It is a good place to start for someone interested in banking or the financial industry.
Very good compensation for future learning - bachelor's degree
A lot of opportunity for learning
cons:
Low benefits and compensation packages
Raises are low; only good for people who make money for company
Most of times they give you pat on back for a great job

job_title: Financial Advisor in San Bernardino, CA
pros: Great team atmosphere--this is the place to work if you thrive by strategizing with team members to meet targets.  This aspect of the job is what got me up in the morning.
cons: Unbelievable level of micro-management, not to mention cumbersome systems and procedures--I've worked in the financial services industry over fifteen years--never seen such archaic, time-sucking procedures! They say they want FSA's to give sound financial advice to clients, but they just want you to sell a client something--anything!  If the client can fog a mirror, he/she had better not leave your desk without having heard at least one product pitched--from credit cards to auto loans to mortgages--not the investment planning and financial planning metric that guides true financial advisors! Only reinforces why people hate to get financial advice from a bank--the banker will just trying to find a quick transactional sale so they don't look bad on next week's sales report.

review_title: Very stable, high pay, but no movement.
job_title: Software Engineer in Los Angeles, CA
pros: I love my job as a software engineer. The pay is really good (similar to Google/amazon/Facebook salaries), 4 weeks of paid time off, 3 weeks sick leave, and more time off if needed. It is very stable, with tons of employee discounts and benefits.  (I.e. they pay for my phone bill, we get free, unlimited stock trading, we get few thousand to spend on medical bills a year , we get great computer gear,  etc). Managers respect work life balance and never impose you to stay more than 40 hours per week. They encourage us to take time off to relax.
cons: It is very hard to move around in the company, and you are working with a much older crowd of people. Work can get stale.  Pros and cons I guess.

pros: The best thing is that they offer wonderful benefits. Medical, 401K, tuition reimbursement, and many discounts that add to the bottom line in your personal budget. The second best is that in the mix of crazy there are some amazing people that work here who give it their all.
cons: Very stressful and inconsistent management. As the company transitions this year to more of a self service industry with many tools provided to manage your daily finances, it has become impossible to continue to produce the same level of sales. Customers are treated in a rude manner and the concept is that they will either come along side the company and be willing to do business "our way" or they will leave. If you are a personal banker, it is time to step down to the newly created Relationship Banker position, transfer to a large Financial Center or find another job as your position is being transitioned out of the Bank of America system. Warning Do not apply for a Personal Banker Position unless you select a location in a large community.

job_title: Professional Teller in Saint Petersburg, FL
pros: Awesome relationship building with customers, good experience, wide variety of products to know, lots of room for advancement and responsibilities
cons: Long hours for ATM tellers, lots of pressure to sell products from the teller line to customers. This is difficult because everybody knows you just have a number to hit, etc. management was also not aligned with the corporate principles and regulations. Lots of choosing which customer to assist and which is not worth the time. There is also lots of transitioning to the new ATMs with teller assist, so the teller role won't be around much longer according to management. They quickly try to get you to perform so you can transition into a banker role with unrealistic monthly goals.

review_title: Management is not focused on customers
pros: Good opportunities to be an entrepreneur and earn a great income if Yu are willing to,work hard and smart.
