cons: Management wants the customer to be their own banker and service themselves. The bank is not willing to take risks to lend to small businesses or offer great deals to existing customers.  Also, too much management focus on coddling employees who identify as LGBT. If you are a white male, you may be discriminated against in favor of minority quotas.

pros:
Better incentive payout than other banks
More structural
Lots of sick time
Paid vacation time
Learning programs paid by the company
cons: You WILL be working 6 days a week. If you are a 40-hour employee, they will make sure you come in later in the day and stay during the busiest time, rather than come in at 8:00/8:30AM and leaving earlier; so that you can work Saturdays too. You will not have a full day off throughout a week, except for Sundays of course. So if you try balancing your family life with your work, this may not be a good fit.

pros: Steady, good benefits. Four months of paid maternity leave is pretty boss. Technology is pretty nice, and they are making progress in that area as well. It's not likely to make you six figures, but it will be a steady income for you. You'll also get reliable benefits and support, something that is totally lacking in most of the mortgage industry.
cons: Low pay for the industry, though you do get a non-recoverable draw now. The non-recoverable draw for most LO's is equivalent to about $15 an hour. You're paid 28-64 basis points on each loan you close, including HELOC's. There are minimum commission amounts, usually $1,000 for a purchase and $500 for a refinance.

review_title: The place is just too big
pros:
Great place to start one's career - training and rotations are offered to incoming graduates giving them exposure to broad spectrum of jobs and opportunities.
Management knows how to keep work/life in balance. Generally accomodative to individuals' needs. Work hours are reasonble. For those looking for stability, the company provides one.
cons: Decisions are made and passed mostly from top down. Very hierarchical structure with too many mid-level managers. Difficult to infuence or effect any change if you are not in the right place in the organization. Annual performance reviews are too formal and offer little value as far as constructive feedback. Pay is tied to performance only in theory, rarely in practice.  For those who are ambitions or looking for quick advancement, it is challenging to get very far very quickly. The best talent will ultimately find their opportunity elsewhere.

review_title: Exhausting, too many changes - 3 jobs consolidated into 1 with no extra pay
job_title: Senior Credit Support Associate in West Seneca, NY
pros: Bank of America is very family and female friendly.  They are are very involved in the community and encourage employees to volunteer, even giving paid time off to do so, which is good.  I like working for the Bank itself,  just not my current department.
cons: Way too many changes in the past year.  Was hired as a Portfolio Relationship Manager, but job was completelly overhauled and 3 positions were consolidated into one.  The new consoldated position is called a Credit Support Associate.  Many people have been burning out, the stress levels are extreemly high and moral is low.

review_title: Great pay, decreasing benefits and perks
job_title: Customer Marketing Associate in Newark, NJ
pros: They will train you! they will take someone who knows nothing and teach you and train you how to do your job. It is up to you from there on to want to achieve more and go for other positions. There is a heavy focus on networking and who you know, not just how good you are at your job.
cons: I worked in credit card and the incentives kept going down with the economy. Eventually we were working really hard trying to break records but money wise it only meant an extra $200, so you did it more for the recognition than for the money.

review_title: You are judged by who thinks you are good not how professional you are!
pros: Good environment and nice location. It is easy to grab some cheap Chinese food and bubble tea during your lunch break. You can grow up quickly in this branch because you are dealing with thousands of customers within ONE week. If you are aiming to gain more experiences not just do your job, this particular branch at 50 Bayard street is a good choice.
cons: Lots of workplace politics and especially when you are new in this branch. Your coworkers will start target at you when your performance score are higher than them and the more you try to hold your ground, the more they feel intimidated and the more pressure you will get from them. SSS will intentionally forget to retrieve your referral if you don't suck up with them. Work life balance is a joke here because the upper management will ask you work 8 days continuously to make up some senior employee's last minute request. Overtime is as said never happen and even it happened they will put it to next week.

pros: You get full benefits even if you're part time. Discount program is awesome. Paid sick, holidays and 2 weeks vacation for part time employees. The team I worked with was awesome.
cons: The way sick time is set up you practically can't use it even if you have the hours to use. Company as a whole is much less customer and employee focused than it used to be. Goals increasingly more difficult to achieve, but you get inconsistent coaching from bank leadership and they cut back employees making it much more difficult for people who work there. No overtime allowed at all.

review_title: Growing pains, but has the right idea
pros: A lot of growth. Relatively small player in the space, but growing. Exciting to see all the progress being made, with total assets, expanding departments, essentially all things you'd expect to see with that's still in the early stages of the expansion curve
cons:
-Still a lot of improvements to be made with systems. Some old technology platforms, and platforms built for advisory accounts, not really a retail/brokerage/trading business. 
-Lacking some of the internal/back end support you'd expect or need to compete with competitors, needs to be addressed in expansion and development plans

pros: Material to train and educate yourself on financials is available, but only while at the bank. 5% 401(k) or ROTH match is great.
cons:
There are no bonuses for Tellers. We are the ones who get more than 50% of the sale done (talking and convincing the client to sit with a Specialist or Personal banker to open a new account, credit card, mortgage, refinance, etc...) yet as a teller you get $0, and the Specialist or Personal Banker get around $20 per new sale, on top of their salary.

So you work hard to get the promotion and become a Sales and Service Specialist or PB. You hit your goals and are in good standing, ask for a promotion at your branch or at many of the other branches in the city and there's an excuse...yet, they promote someone else that didn't beat your numbers, so what's going on? oh, the other person has the "all american look" 
So pretty racial.

job_title: Asesor sénior de RR. HH. y jefe del equipo de servicios in Dallas, TX
pros: Great benfits package and people I worked with on a daily basis were great.  I thoroughly enjoyed helping people through the mortgage process.
cons: The Bank's underwriting policies made the process to obtain a refinance one of the hardest in the industry and caused much frustration for my borrowers.  I would personally not recommend Bank of America to others looking for a mortgage or refinance opportunities.  There should be more training for the loan officers as they would very often incorrectly advise the borrower and cause more stress through the process with unrealistic expectation from the beginning.

job_title: Investment Banking Developer in New York, NY
pros: Work from home when needed; Great computer architecture; Moving to Python and sharing code.  Very siloed.  Hard to learn new technologies since we specialize in only certain parts of the development life cycle.  Great teamwork and generally friendly culture inherited from Charlotte.
cons: Politics of promoting based on race/ethnicity rather than meritocracy.  Lots of bureaucracy though getting better.  Public relations disaster when BofA spearheaded charging fees for those checking accounts with a small balance.

review_title: A company that tries to 'do the right thing'
pros: The company tries hard to 'do the right thing' despite all of the negative publicity that is often mentioned in the press. They encourage us to debate and discuss issues freely in an effort to help mitigate risk and do what's best for the customer.
cons: They seem to layoff too aggressively just to look better to their board members and stock holders. Although they've been pioneers of new technologies in the past, they seem to lag behind 21st century technological advances in the way that they interface with customers and manage their internal workflow. We're still using a DOS based AS400 application in 2015, and that's sad. On another note, they have a hard time firing people who truly need to be fired. The only way someone ever leaves is either by their own choice or they were laid off. Rarely does my line of business get to fire 'dead weight' out of fear for being sued.

job_title: Business Systems Analyst in Los Angeles, CA
pros: A great place for a young person to start out to get a variety of experience and training: lots of entry points, lots of locations. Very interested and active in local communities, with plenty of fun volunteer activities for employees and their friends/family (paid leave up to 8 hours/month for volunteer work, plus $5/hr donated to the charity) which makes work more fun (and great for networking). Lots of opportunities for technical contract work. Ambitious people (including women, racial minorities, LGBT) will find mentors and plenty of opportunities to advance quickly as the company continues to go through major changes.
cons: The company is still shedding full-time employees and is still one of the main targets of regulators. Cronyism and internal politics are factors, as in most large companies.

job_title: Senior Video Teller Agent in Jacksonville, FL
pros: The job is what you make of it. If you take it at face value of just being a "job" then you won't really propel forward, but if you get involved and really care there is nothing but potential. The salary is way above average with differentials on shift and language with occasional opportunities for OT. The teammates around you are great and if you foster relationships with your colleagues, managers, and senior leaders you will enjoy your experience. Benefits package is above what you will get from most other employers.
cons: Admittedly, there can be some moments where the call volume is high, but that is expected because you are there to take clients and assist them, not to sit around. You will see people you have become friends with either post out or leave, that's the nature of an entry level job.

review_title: Bank Of America offers alot of opportunities to help others, learn, and grow!
pros: I like that it's such a large company with an extensive reach! Your path is limitless! My passion is in helping others, and that completely aligns with BOA's purpose. Helping financial lives through the power of each connection.
cons: This position requires you to wear many hats. In a fast-paced environment, that can be stressful. But the training and the "one-team" approach equips all associates to be successful and provide enjoyable client expereinces, even in times of high volume.

job_title: Financial Solutions Advisor in Boston, MA
pros:
great people to work with in my immediate location - they have the right people on the bus for the most part
reimbursement for training and continuing ed
managers have been good and leave you alone if you do  your job
compensation is fair 
very good work life balance - work Monday to Friday during bank hours and a few Saturdays per month
cons:
typical corporate environment (bureaucracy)
compliance is overzealous
you spend too much time on administrative and not enough time doing what they hired you for:  building client relationships and developing new business
the role is evolving from one where you felt like an advisor and could work with customers ongoing to retain and build relationships to one that is much more focused on banking and widgets.

review_title: This is not only a bank of opportunity for our customers it's also a bank of opportunity for the employees as well.
pros: The people are great and the opportunities are endless. Bank of America offers many career opportunities to all of its employees, the real challenges for most include myself is the willingness to get out of your comfort zone and take a leap on faith.
cons: In some areas management tends to micro-manage. I think management should allowed associates to be professional.

review_title: Avoid Banc of America at all costs
job_title: Vice President Equity Research Analyst  in New York, NY
pros: it's better than working at McDonald's or cleaning toilets. many folks worked 70-100 hour work weeks, and met all the goals of senior management only to be fired when it was time for BAS to pay bonuses. in fact, the bank fired its most talented and highest revenue producing analyst just two weeks before bonuses were due, and did not pay ANY bonuses. the bank also had the nerve to force non-compete clauses for those fired and in many cases are looking to hire analyst from other banks to replace those they pushed out only three months ago.
cons: they are liars and cheats. dishonest at best. the bank has no idea what it is doing strategically--overpaying for lasalle, bankers trust and countrywide. i expect more and bigger write downs from the bank, giving the lose lending standards over the past few years (i.e., actively targeting illegal aliens for credit cards, car loans and home loans).

pros: BofA runs its commercial bank very effectively.  It's a low cost, large economies of scale operation run out of Charlotte.  As an enterprise, its fairly impressive.  The firm has good footing in many markets and will probably prosper over the long run, albeit it may hurt for a while in these challenging markets.
cons: BofA provides pay and benefits below market.  The organization is somewhat stodgy and opaque.  People aren't encouraged to challenge the status quo, ask the tough questions, and truly assess the risk and reward of various choices.

review_title: Bank Of America --- The Big Bank where you can get lost easily
job_title: Business Technology Analyst in Charlotte, NC
pros: They have an excellent benefits package  They match your 401K up to 5% and offer a pension program after 3 years service. They also strongly encourage a Spirit program where employees are awarded points for going above and beyond their normal duties. Good name to put on your resume.
cons: No job security. Too many layoffs. The pay is less and the workload is greater than most workplaces. They dont care about the people who does the work but care about politics. Compensation is week in technology area compare to other companies. The worst part is the management is totally out of touch on what is happening.

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Jacksonville, FL
pros: They have the best benefits package I've seen any company offer.  Even part-time employees get  cheap health insurance, 401k, pension plan, child care and tuition reimbursement, parking reimbursement, disability insurance...The wages are a bit lower than other companies, but their benefits make all the difference, I mean how many companies give you $200/month per child to pay for childcare, even if you're part time?  My department is awesome and everybody is very friendly, unlike other call centers where everybody is competitive and they barely interact.  Also, I like that we're very well staffed, so most of the time we have breathing room in between calls.
cons: Their attendance policy is very strict, but so was the one at my previous call center job.  Also, because it's a call center they're less flexible about giving time off or changing schedules, but  again, it was way worse at my  previous job.

pros: BENEFITS ARE AMAZING!!! only reason why im here
cons: Management says customers first associates last...the benefits are good but when it comes to vacations and time off they roll there eyes and smack there gums if u take the time off. my parent passed away and management did not say sorry for your loss they said pull youself together, even though you get 5 days bereavement, they said well...whatever u want to do keep me informed...hung up....no type of empathy, just assumes that i would get over it. if you call personell to let them know whats going on they never keep it anonymous, everyone ends up finding out any way. it feels like highschool and they lose really good employees that way

review_title: Excellent grounding for a career in marketing
pros: The staff benefits given through the ABC system are superior to any others I have had or heard of. There is always chance to progress if you prove yourself, and there is constant opportunities for feedback through one to one sessions, personal development reviews and 360 group feedback sessions. The facilities at the office make it a great place to work -very sociable and a good atmosphere.
cons: The work was tough, and the economic conditions made it harder. Morale was sometimes low, which made coming to work difficult. Expectations are always very high, and sometimes a lot of pressure is put on the wrong people in the team - usually the junior members of staff are given tasks above their responsibility level.

pros: Bank of America does offer outstanding benefits such as 4 weeks pto within the first year, wonderful healthcare program and other employer related benefits such as discounts with nation-wide companies.
cons: BoA is not as family friendly as portrayed and certainly does not value it's employees.  Although metrics for performance are black and white there are too many other factors that determine if an associate is "liked" by management and therefore treated.  Typical of large corporations, front line employees are abused by executive level management and there is no control filtered to that level.  Unfortunately instances of such abuse and wrongful termination are more often than not reported due to the fear of facing off against a giant such as BoA.

review_title: Very disappointed in the functional competency of senior leadership and the lack of meritocracy.
pros: Decent benefits. Great opportunities to further your education and gain certifications. Lots of transferable knowledge and skill sets, and the esteem associated with working in the corporate arm of financial services.
cons: There is a lot of 'promote from within" even in the individual does not have the functional or leadership competencies. This process is also very subjective which leaves a lot of room for it to be the result of popularity as opposed to productivity. Also the sheer size of the company enables the perpetuation of irrelevant processes, positions and "supposed" innovations.

review_title: Excellent Benefits, little pay, stressful work
job_title: Teller Operations Specialist in Fort Myers, FL
pros: The company has some of the best benefits out there. Health/Dental/Vision plus childcare reimbursement and rewards for hard work. You want to work your hardest to make yourself know and rewarded. Some banking centers are fun family environments.
cons: Regional Management puts too much pressure on managers that just causes a ripple effect of a stressful work environment. Too many writeups and product pushing. It's all about money money money for the upper management. Your may work your best and hardest but upper management only goes by paperwork and goal results, they don't actually see you do your best, so they don't really know. Plus the pay their new hire employees more than what an employee who has worked there for 2 years makes. Not fair.

review_title: All that glitters is NOT gold!
pros: Great company to put on your resume. Depending on which location (affluent or busy city), you can meet a lot of powerful people. Easy to get hired if you pass the actual recruitment process. Decent pay compared to the starting wage of other large financial institutions. Great ability to build a career and advance within 1 year if you work well and kiss up a bit.
cons: Company is solely and widely numbers driven. Upper management constantly dishes order and goals in which they do not provide any assistance or directions as to how to acheive the goals. Vacation, personal, and sick days are like committing murder, especially if you work in a branch that is low staffed. Most likely your branch will be low staffed because of company wide budget cuts.

job_title: Team Manager in Fort Worth, TX
pros: Time off three weeks with tenure and you could purchase and additional week also got two weeks sick a year. All time off bank was filled at the beginning of each year not accrued. 5% match on 401k and great company discounts.
cons: Company is too big. Executives are too busy putting out the next fire and worrying about lawsuits to see what management under them are doing. Mortgage has too many fires going on for anyone on any level to get any type of constructive feed back or development. If you fall under a management team who has no management skills there is not much you can do. Decisions are made based on alliances and rarely on performance or experience.

review_title: Good company, good benefits, very strict and not lenient with time off.
job_title: Small Business Specialist in Tampa, FL
pros: Good salary, better than other places in Tampa. Good benefits; dental, vision, etc... They work with you as far as in schedules. Good atmosphere, great people to work with, no clicks.
cons: Sick days given (6), but if you use them you will be fired no joke!  Doesn't matter how good of an employee you are, they don't care. No cell phones allowed. If they hear it vibrating in your desk, they will walk you out (fire you). Calls come in right after the other, non-stop. They do not allow pausing between calls. It can really drain you mentally. Only 1/2 hr lunch.

review_title: Not as great as I thought
pros: I have pretty awesome coworkers. Everyone is really friendly, and close since there are only 5 people working in my branch. The pay is ok it could be better.
cons: The sales goals are nearly impossible to reach due to the fact that Bank of America in General is so short staffed! It's ridiculous! Upper management expects their tellers to refer while there is only one banker. The wait to see a banker is always about an hour. None of the customers want to wait that long for a banker. The teller line is always ridiculously long with only 2 tellers working. And another employee standing in the lobby literally doing nothing but talking to people when they can be helping us. Not getting paid for referrals also sucks! With the amount of staff Bank of America hires it's really really hard to reach sales goals and make customers and management happy. Almost impossible. This job can get really stressful and annoying.

review_title: Leaves a bad taste in your mouth
job_title: IT Business Analyst in Chicago, IL
pros: Work from home flexibility, good training program on a rather difficult/robust tool.  If you do well and learn quickly, it is noticed.
cons: The Director (who oversees the GIS department) has no idea what he's doing.  There is tons of conflict and uneasiness among the IT different teams and he chooses to "play all sides" instead of taking the lead in solving conflict.  The office has a very sexist culture, which is noticeable early on.  The Global Information Security (GIS) department is constantly "up in the air" as far as funding and budget cuts (which happen frequently) so as a contractor or full-time employee, there is zero job security.  BoA is known to cut contractors with little to no notice due to budget cuts.  Management is very unprofessional and play into the gossipy office talk.

review_title: A Billion dollar company with old computers and slow internet?
pros: Pay is okay if you are new to the industry, not if you are experienced.  Advancement opportunities.
cons: The computers are literally 15 years old if not older. The internet is the slowest I've ever seen. It makes it extremely difficult to do your job when your ipad can't connect, or your computer is just too slow. Also, the programs are extremely archaic, aside from CMC. Managers are in a frenzy when upper management comes to visit. You are constantly being micromanaged. Do this, don't do that. Be sure to do this. It's exhausting. Oh and Saturday hours are for the birds. You get Sunday off and a random day off during the week. Where's the work life balance? There's no time to fully rest with 1 day off.

job_title: Senior Financial Analyst in Charlotte, NC
pros:
BofA has great benefits and personal development opportunities, including active employee networks and mentoring programs.

The bank is also great about encouraging employees to get broad experience and not become stuck on one team.
cons:
Bureaucracy and politics are still alive and well at the bank. Hard to find roles that feel meaningful without giving up all semblance of work - life balance. 

The CFO org is especially discouraging to be a part of, with a special policy of requiring you to "prove yourself" by performing a promoted role for an undefined length of time before you are eligible for the compensation and title that go with the role.

review_title: not that bad but not that great
job_title: Senior Credit Analyst in Pasadena, CA
pros: Bank of America has good health benifits and retiremnt plans.  The acces to making adjustments to retiremnt plans is also very easy.  There is also a decent ammount of paid vacation and an option to buy an extra week.  while I do think that there are allot of job opportunities I believe that most of the movemnt is lateral, and that there are few opportunities to have true career growth.  It is more likely that there will be a job change.
cons: there is little to no assistance an associate is not meating goals and trying to make adjustments in attemp to meet them.  when an associate is not meeting goals more of the same tracking of the not meeting goals is completed.  there is also high likeyhood of getting "stuck" in a position.

review_title: Get ready to sell alot of products and worry about alot more
pros: Bank of America is a great place to work for benefits and great starting pay.
cons:
Managers change fast, hard to get promotions, hard to get ahread in the company. Very hard to get time off at my branch, and managers dangle firing over your head almost daily. It's impossible to sell financial products in this economy but Bank of America says you should sell products like normal. They lowered goals for one quarter, and then it went right back up to the normal goals. The goals are set too high for tellers, and not only are you responsible for sales goals, you're responsible for balancing and cash outages, and how well the bank is doing on customer satisfaction.

When my performance is evaluated quarterly, I feel like I can never do good enough.

review_title: It is what you make of it...
pros: Good benefits and plenty of opportunity to move around the company. The best way to make more money is to move around (which is encouraged).
cons: Seemingly constant organization changes can be demoralizing as coworkers are let go (especially very strong performers). It can also be frustrating to have to deal with multiple managers and/or jobs (up to 4 in one year for me). You really need to maintain a positive attitude and adapt to change quickly. Benefits have tumbled the last few years.

review_title: Excelled in sales, and did the job of multiple people!
pros: Very easy to learn, great family-feeling with coworkers within the branch. Management is helpful with coaching and constructive criticism, as well as being able to come over when you need help. Love my Consumer Market Manager, and really have a great relationship with all of those who I work with.
cons: Branch I work at is severely understaffed, often leaving one teller to operate both the drive up and lobby during peak lunchtime hours. Also, sales goals change all the time, with the drive for more and more revenue. Also, being non-fluent in Spanish was a hard thing for me. My branch was the hub for all of the spanish population in my town, and many did not understand or speak any english.

review_title: Great Company to Work For (...But a Few Tweaks Are Needed.)
pros: The schedule was perfect (9am-5pm most of the week), half-days on Saturdays, Sundays off & 11 paid holidays. Tuition/adoption re-embursment ($5,000+ annually). Competitive pay. Vacation time increased with seniority. Majority of employees are genuinely good people.
cons: Inconsistent and poor incentive plan--in the end, all the hard work needed to meet the sales goals wasn't compensated properly--. The mortgage department was awful to deal with. Most managers (at least in my area) lacked communication, management & basic computer skills--not to mention college education--. Very hard to get promoted from a branch to a corporate position. Dealing with customers in a bank environment can be exhausting.

review_title: Good company to work for if you're in the right department.  If not, watch out, you will be sacrificed en masse.
pros:
Call center was a friendly, family environment.
Hardworking people
First name basis with upper and middle management
Great pay for the position
Constant training modules and classroom instruction
Excellent benefits
Place to build a life-time career
cons: Off site management not always truthful.  After awhile you learn to identify the 1984 level lies.  When the bank wants to save money they have no problem laying off hundreds of people at a time or shutting the entire site down.  CEO and Senior Management make bad financial decisions for the health of the bank and then get a golden parachute, while the employees are left to clean up the mess, up to and including having their jobs sacrificed to increase revenue

pros: There is decent medical and insurance offered with the company. You have access to the best accounts and rewards that normally only apply to people with larger bank accounts. There is generally a good work atmosphere among your peers. A good stepping stone job.
cons: Pay is not terrible but not great either. The company will lie and deceive you left and right to get what they want from you. They are very sales driven but have unrealistic expectations. Nobody in the area reaches the goals they have set out. This leads to non-stop discussions and threats of losing your job. There is no room for advancement or transferring until you have been there for a year which is ridiculous. The entire job is extremely stressful and tough to detach from when home. Company also breaks labor laws regularly but does it in a way so they can blame you or make it your fault even though they threaten to fire you if you don't comply.

pros: There are so many locations that you're almost always guaranteed to find a spot by your home. I've met some of my best friends at Bank of America.
cons: Impossible to meet goals. Constant threats of being fired. Dirty and roach infested work environment. Always short handed because hours allowed to schedule are limited.

pros: Always got along with coworkers and grew many friendships with a ton of small dinners and happy hours. If you ever had any questions about any processes or needed any help with anything, the team was always there. Also has very good benefits. Medical, dental, vision, 401k with a 5% company match as well as tuition reimbursement
cons:
The expectations for deadlines and workload was not realistic and a lot of changes that occurred mid- 2015 was a complete transformation for the negative. Many processes changed, added more tasks that were to be completed everyday. Very redundant documentation that needed to filled out. The company tries to say they care about their customers, however if you don't meet your metrics or sales goals- there is HEAVY ACCOUNTABILITY.
Because of this sales stress, you hardly ever leave at a decent time during the week and often times take this work home with you. no work life balance

job_title: Consumer Products Strategic Analyst II in Simi Valley, CA
pros: Great Opportunities to develop new processes and provide appropriate recommendations and reporting to the business supported.  This allows you to extend your knowledge and be creative with your development.
cons: The constant reorganizations that create chaos and unrealistic expectations based on promises made in an attempt to impress the new stakeholders.  Simply put, the biggest con is the management.  The overall manager (new due to re-org) may be good, but the one and two down managers are inappropriate and under managed.  The second biggest con is the extreme discrepancies when it comes to skill sets for the managers as well as the associates.  That creates very unbalanced workload because those that are capable are given more and held to a higher standard while the others are "excused" with no repercussions.

review_title: Great employee benefits, business model under construction, overall it
job_title: Relationship Manager in Los Angeles, CA
pros: It needs to structured entirely. Bank of America has been known for not always following thru, which it seems they have become less of that statement, but at a slow pace. The appreciation for employees are thru the roof, but the tools and information given to us to do our job, is still stagnant. Great mobility in promotions, paid vacations, paid time off for all US calendar holidays, great exposure to employee networks for diversity.
cons: Management has been dicey. The structure on a branch level can be confusing, with 2 leaders over operations, and the other sales. The expectation from both teams are different in the daily practices they give to us. It would be more helpful to have them come to a decision together and we can all accomplish our routine successfully, and without errors.

pros: Health Benefits and 401k matching.
cons:
Managers and individual contributors are very nervous about keeping their jobs - as the Mortgage Banking area has experienced substantial layoffs. There is a culture of fear and passive aggressiveness coupled with stagnant growth opportunities (promotions). Militaristic, micromanaging environment contributes to a lot of anxiety.  Very top heavy with a lot of chiefs and few Indians.  Bonuses, even for high performers, are pathetic. 

Am a top performer - now my function is being moved offshore and my position is being terminated.  This seems to be the trend with this company - a race to find the lowest cost employee.  Further salt in the wound, they have yet to communicate an employment end date and still expect work to be completed as usual - just plain insulting.

job_title: Ops Officer Analyst in Chicago, IL
pros:
Solid Coworkers.
Nice office location.
Management often takes a hands off approach to managing so employees are able to do their job without someone looking over their shoulders. 
Decent pay and benefits for the work required.
cons:
It is very difficult to figure out what it takes to advance. Management will often give vague and conflicting advice/guidelines on what to do to get promoted. 
Lack of unity/team work between different departments can make it difficult to get information or answer in order to perform your job requirements.
Software/tech issues occur more frequently than one would expect for such a large institution and it can be difficult to get the issue resolved or even get a status update.

pros: Company latest technology implementation is very competitive, There's a never a dull day here.
cons: The sales quotas are ridiculous if you sold something but the person closes the product or cancels within 7 months, you would need to take the hit on your next commission, they  will be deducted from your bonus (this cannot be controlled), some Managers that one would wonder why they are managers in the first place,  the pressure is tremendous from all sides a lot of chiefs not too many Indians, many managers don't take accountability for the centers not doing well. Absolutely no human fulfillment here,  glorified paper pusher. Most centers are 6 days work weeks with only Sundays off, by then the exhaustion is real!

review_title: Great bank to be a part of; however, you need to be able to work at a large company with constant change.
pros: Work/life balance and flexible working arrangements are permitted and encouraged by many departments. Most years when the banking industry is doing well, we are allowed and expected to attend seminars and training to increase our personal development. Generous tuition reimbursement is provided for college courses, and they don't have to be career-related. Associates are often looking ahead for career advancement opportunities within the bank and discussing how to achieve them with their current manager.
cons: Change, change, change! Reorganizations happen often and people change positions regularly so you can't ever feel very comfortable or stable with the current state-of-affairs.  Additionally, because it's such a large organization, it's hard to learn about all of the lines of businesses, especially if you're new to banking.

review_title: There are plenty of better jobs out there...
pros: It's a job. Better than being unemployed, but not by much. The work is easy, although the bank hires mostly people who will never figure out how to do their job correctly (they are either too stupid to do the job correctly or too lazy).  You get free checking and stuff, but the people who handle the accounts constantly screw them up...so I actually bank with a different bank. They like to give out cheap 99 cent store type gifts and crappy food for doing a job well done instead giving out bonuses or raises for doing a good job.
cons: Senior management does not get people who actually do the job to work on projects that affect the job. They spew corporate BS about the BofA spirit and how family oriented the bank is then they require mandatory overtime for months at a time. Senior management lies to their employees to the point where we can't trust them anymore with anything.

review_title: Great people to work with, but a sluggish organization when direction changes are needed
pros: Honestly cared about the happiness and success of their people.  A great deal of attention was paid by managers to the mood of the floor and what could be done to improve the ability of the group to succeed
cons: The company was slow to recognize the changes needed to improve the business and would hold on to outdated approaches when past their prime.  When mistakes were made, if took front line managers forever to escalate the issues to the right department and to make changes happen

review_title: High Potential, Not Enough Investment in Talent
pros: BAC offers a wide range of job opportunities and growth areas. Great place to work if you are a hard worker and are willing to work harder, smarter and sacrafice to stand a head above the rest. Hard work is more important than if or where you got your degree and you are rewarded more for what you are able to produce than impressive credentials.
cons: Not enough investment in top tier talent. While there is great opportunity to drive change and improve efficiency, some in upper management tend to embrace an antiquated approach to business centered on simple cost savings that may be penny wise and pound foolish. Coupled with an assembly line business model, this can be restrictive and stifling to those of us who do want to revolutionize the business.

review_title: Great benefits, family atmosphere, but corporation likes to cut costs which means more work for the same pay, & job cuts
pros: Bank has great benefits that really make your lifestyle more comfortable. Great healthcare, childcare reimbursement, tuition reimbursement, wonderful discount programs. For the most part I have been very fortunate to be in a market with a lot of amazing people who honestly care about each other and their well-being.
cons: Company loooooves to cut costs, which comes at an expense to the employee and the customer. Be prepared for your job to constantly change, constantly require more responsibilities, but your pay never changed. Raises are pathetic here. :)

pros:
Health benefits
Free bank accounts
Generally consistent hours
cons:
Unpaid commission for sales/leads
Higher positions (even management) based on sales/numbers/time and not any actual knowledge
Company is ridiculously stingy and cheap
Constantly changing and setting new standards

pros: I worked as a teller and I thought as a young adult you received sufficient pay, good health benefits and at the time it was a great 401k program. I don't know what it is now. But the managers were great and knew what they were doing and overall I enjoyed the atmosphere.
cons: Sometimes your schedule wasn't all that great with working Saturdays and sometimes you wouldn't get all of your hours you hired for and other times when we were short staffed you would be working a crazy surplus of hours. So it wasn't always steady. Also, I didn't like the referral quotas. I hated being a sales person and having to meet referral goals.

review_title: The company is moving over to "everything automated" and your sole job becomes selling.
pros: The company will take care of you in terms of benefits; one worker had her fertility treatment paid for and another worker had her adoption fees taken care of. Also, the pay is very comfortable. Turnover is high so you're able to move up pretty quickly and their training, although lengthy, helps you grow as a seller customer service provider.
cons: It's a sell or die type of environment where your job is on the line if you're not meeting your quarterly goals. Because your job is to develop relationships with account owners, coworkers were always gossiping about the customers and each other. My superiors were the biggest gossipers and this was something I couldn't stand.

job_title: Financial Solutions Advisor in San Francisco, CA
pros: Base salary including bonuses are good for what it is.  Fairly laid back, it's simple just do the job and management stays off your back.  Very minimal micromanagement if you just do the job.  It's simple, open accounts, bring in new assets.  Great business opportunities in walk in business.  Great place to start an investment career.
cons: You don't own the book of business.  You'll come across menial bank duties that downplay the role by sometimes handling banking issues for customers who are of none or little value of your time.  You can't customize a portfolio under a managed fee.  Managed solutions are template-styled risk strategies.  Sales tracking is terrible.

pros: Bank of America has a relaxed company culture, great vacation policy and competitive benefits. If you are in a non customer facing role there should be little to no stress when doing your job.
cons: As a former foreclosure specialist I experienced the volatility associated with banking. I was laid off along with 1000 other people many of which had families to care for. I was only 22 at the time so it didn't affect me as much as others. Their severance packages were not very great but even worse was their attitude towards laid off staff. As with many large organizations, don't expect much sympathy.

review_title: Avoid unless you have no other choice.
pros: Comparatively good compensation and benefits for the skill level, and location of the job.
cons: The job was menial, the ethics of customer relations (while legal) were murky, time was managed in a draconian fashion, after taking over my division from MBNA there were definite declines in management practices, employee satisfaction, and treatment.  The management philosophy swings from barely competant, to laughably cumbersome.  Lip service is paid to making the environment as friendly and non-corporate as possible, but it's transparently a heartless corporate atmosphere with no human aspect.  When I finally quit they misrepresented the way that recommendations are handled (it's an automated process, while I was lead to believe it would be a personal recommendation) as a way to make me stay longer than I intended.

review_title: not a bad place to work
pros: my impressions are that management is generally concerned with the welfare of its employess and takes care of them. At least in my department there is a lot of flexibility especially with work life balance. For instance the bank is embracing a policy where if employees can work from home it is encoraged. the compensation seems to be fairly generous. However, I can only speak from the perspective of my department.
cons: the bank is very big so you cna definitely feel like a cog in the machine. Also, it might not be as prestigous as the other banks especially in IB

review_title: The right place to be for a career in financial services going forward
job_title: Pathways Financial Advisor in San Jose, CA
pros: A great institution who's branding alone can put a new Financial Advisor in front of Mass Affluent clients.   Not many other firms can bring the amount of prospects to an FA that BofA can.  The new ML platform will position the largest banking franchise with the best Financial Advisors out there.  With 500k new high net worth client relationships coming in the door year over year.  This is in addition to the approximately 8 million existing clients that qualify as Mass Affluent.  For any young advisor looking to grow their practice, we all know how hard it is to market yourself to this segment.  The bottom line is no other organization can put more clients in front of skilled people than BofA
cons: At the moment there is some cumbersome processes that slow down the production for FA's without sales assistants.

review_title: Salesman will love Bank of America
pros: I joined Bank of America about seven months ago as a Teller, and I am shocked by how much I have enjoyed working for the company thus far. I work in a smaller branch, which may influence the environment, but my coworkers made me feel as though I had always been there. The management is friendly and approachable, and you can easily and quickly move up within the company. In fact, I've found that here, more than any other place I have worked, the company wants its employees to rise quickly in the ranks. The banks continental reach provides an avenue for me to travel across the nation without the fear of finding a new job.
cons: Bank of America runs more like a sales company, than bank. Even tellers have sales goals.

review_title: Was optimistic until I saw what it was really like
pros: Nice facilities and equipment; good sense of company "spirit"; had an amazing assistant manager but horrible manager; good pay and great rewards programs.
cons: The stress. Simply not worth it-- my location had lines out the door all the time, and yet because of staffing issues, we would only have a handful of tellers on the line (which made for VERY happy customers, let me tell you-- ha!). Training is not nearly adequate to deal with the many complicated issues that arise. Trying to get help internally is a nightmare. Oh, and know that you're signing up for a "retail" position-- you sell, sell, sell products to customers that may not need them.

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Chandler, AZ
pros: If you ever do get hired on, there is a great benefits package, and paid holidays...
cons: the managers dont respect you regardless of your status (temp or hired), they keep 3/4ths of the staff as temps that way there is no benefits pay or paid holidays, everyone is cheap work, promotions mean nothing, basically more responsibility, same amount of respect (which is little to none), its all about who you know and if upper management likes you or not. regardless of work performance, if you rub someone the wrong way they have means of getting you let go. Dress code is strict, even though it is a call center, and you get erpremanded for just about everything. Even talking too loud, or driving too fast in the parking lot. Bank of America customer service is a joke. everyday is like walking on egg shells hoping when you come in the next morning your desk isnt boxed up.

job_title: Senior Operations Project Analyst in Irvine, CA
pros: Work experience differs greatly between Lines of Business and managers. My experiences is great with diligent and fair management and good compensation, but have heard horror stories from other employees. My Work (working from home) is a nice perk some positions can take advantage of. Make sure you get along well with your direct before getting into new positions.
cons: NYSE: BAC... Facilities are uninspiriting / depressing...Old employees with grim outlook...Getting responses from employees that role up to a different management team...incompetence is ignored

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Plano, TX
pros: It's a Stable job, it's got okay pay, has good benefits, there's room for advancement. You can learn a great deal about the mortgage industry.  It's a very satisfying job in that you can help people and there's always something new to learn.  You can make good over time pay. They also higher from within, so there's room to grow. They treat entry level workers pretty well.
cons: Your manager changes often, new processes are often unclear, some serving advice and best practices are  unethical, the culture is a highly Christian religious environment. It's very conservative, after a point.  If you get a bad manager you're going to have a rough time. But, since they change managers so often, it's not a long lasting issue. They are big on "team building" but they don't actually build teams. It's like working in a vast pool of cubical.

pros: Bank of America is a very large financial services organization and has a lot of opportunity for people to learn an grow.  If there is a technology out there, chances are it exists somewhere in the bank. With a good work ethic and good attitude, your options to move around to different jobs and grow are very good.
cons: With the intense regulatory / compliance pressures and need continually do more with less to cut expenses, the bank is a tough place to work. The bank expects a lot out of you and used to have a good overall compensation package - salaries and benefits. However, the overall benefits are shrinking and salaries haven't been adjusted to compensate.

pros: If you like to interact with customers and want to work on your customer service skills. Working as a teller really puts your people skills to the test. You'll start to build a community with the customers since most are regulars, and will enjoy talking to most. You'll feel a sense of satisfaction in being able to assist people.
cons: Meeting referral goals, constant coaching on how to improve on increasing referral goals, dealing with rude customers (most customers are nice 95% of the time), slowly becoming obsolete with the implementation of assist ATMS. I recommend picking up a teller job part time as it can be exhausting.

pros: Inbound calls, hard not to be somewhat successful in the role. The business is laid out in front of you to close so you won't have to worry about leads.
cons: The constant restructuring of the comp plan. Top producers and the sales force in general is punished for exceeding plan. That is a punch in the gut to anyone working hard to make maximum incentives.

review_title: Good if you enjoy the banking culture.
pros: BofA is a good company overall. They tend to support diversity and their salary is competitive.
cons: Still backward in some areas. They had work from home, and then shut it down. This, even though many IT teams work globally and do not sit in the same city or country.  They also tend to be very reactive. If a crisis arises in one department in the company, they assume they have the problem everywhere. Lots of time is spent solving problems you don't have.

review_title: It's banking, so you kinda have to know what you're getting into.
pros: Good benefits, fun coworkers, open opportunities for advancement (although it may not be as simple as they make it out to be)
cons: Pay is not what was promised, bonus incentive goals are high/difficult to achieve and don't really add much to your pay especially when averaged out over the quarter/year, makes it seem like it's up to you to advance in the company by achieving your goals, but in reality your financial center managers (who you don't actually report to) get final say over whether you can move up, not your actual performance.

review_title: You are a robot and nothing more
job_title: Finance Analyst Product Control in Chester, England
pros: Young people so good for developing group of people to socialise with.
cons:
You are only there for completing processes. People don’t care if you understand why you are doing something or whether you understand the purpose, you are simply there to complete the task and you will use procedure notes to do it. From day 1 you don’t get any training or onboarding. You will be given process notes and told go away and do this task. Effectively you are a robot donkey. 
Pay is awful and increases each year between £200 to £1500 for top performers. Many of the people I worked with suffered depression with most people leaving after 1-2 years after deciding they hate it. Very toxic culture where people are CC’d in emails to scaremonger others.
Hours are horrible and people pick on arriving late put are disgusted if you leave a minute earlier than 7pm

review_title: Definitely NOT the best place to work
pros: Bank of America, being one of the largest banks in the United States, looks good on resume.  Trainings, especially classroom sessions for sales and service training, are pretty comprehensive.
cons: The bank does not care much about their employees.  At the branch level, time/day off and vacation requests are often rejected.  Pay and benefit are lower than similar positions at other banks.  Sales goals are more difficult to meet than other banks and sales personnel are often facing sales pressure from management.  Career advancement (promotions/raise/bonus) are dependent largely on management's descretion and much less on actual performance.

pros: good benefits, 401k, 3+ weeks vacation, reputable company
cons: Too much bureaucracy.  Bank of america departments are widespread throughout the country and are not uniform in policy and procedures.  You will not get the same service or the same answers even if you call the same dept twice, back to back.  No one seems to know exactly what their job function is as there are layers and layers of procedures and policies that are not uniform to one another. Too much "grey" area that is left to the individual to deceifer and interpret.

review_title: Slow steady opportunities for upward movement
pros: Excellent benefits including matching 401k, adoption reimbursement, education reimbursement, ethical lending culture, an interest in seeing employees succeed and realize their potential.
cons: High turnover which results in work being constantly re-assigned to whatever employees remain on board. This results in poor customer service and the feeling that you are not working for a world class company. Mandatory overtime.

review_title: More concerned about quantity and process than quality and customer satisfaction
job_title: Business Analyst in New York, NY
pros: Many departments are still allowed to innovate solutions to their customer's problems. Creative and talented teams still operate, and if you get an opportunity to work in New York or on systems closely aligned with the trading floor, you will find an exciting, seat-of-your-pants culture that genius can thrive in.
cons: There are many departments at BofA, so my comments only apply to Risk. The risk department has tried to rein in the chaotic development culture of New York and govern it in the stodgy and plodding style of the head office. More procedures, more governance, more project planning, more steering, more Six Sigma. Development is almost completely off-shored (read: No talent required), so any local work is strictly PM. BA means PM at BofA.

review_title: Great Company with Ethical Workforce, but Countrywide merger ruined Home Loans
job_title: Mortgage Loan Coordinator in Charlotte, NC
pros: First few years at company were great because brand was strong, the mortgage division functioned well, and I loved my branch. I learned all aspects of the business and will never regret my time there. Benefits were amazing, and was able to balance work/life fairly well in my position.
cons: Mortgage business is very stressful in the best of times under the best of circumstances, but when the Bank bought Countrywide their systems became completely disfunctional and our jobs in the Home Loans division become unbearable. Also, even prior to this, I was always thankful to be in a small branch away from corporate offices. It was sometimes impossible to get away from the huge company mentality, however, and difficult to get something done because of having to go through so many channels. Not a single cost of living or incentive raise in 6 years!

pros: Very easy to win , goals are extremely reasonable , hours are great , paid holidays / vacation, benefits for the employee and or domestic partner. World class training.
cons: Being with the company for 10 years seeing the rapid changes. Sometimes it takes a little to get used to and we are asked to run threw fire - understood but at times we are juggeling staffing changes , drive up closures , hour adjustments etc and we face the customers not the company we need more advertising to back us up in these changes because they are smart stretiegic moves and I get it but it's hard to explain to a lobby of 30 people who don't.

pros: Good Salary £38k minimum great benefits (health, pension, etc) maternity package great - 1 year - 6 months full pay - 3 months statutory pay - last 3 months no pay. Sick Pay, bereavement pay. Great Managers (depending on team). Personal Assistants can earn up to £80k but expect to work 7-7 with out of hours contact sometimes
cons: Not as good for Temps or Contractors, no progression - majority of assistants get comfortable and stay for years with no progression. Managers are happy for you to stay doing the same thing as it makes life easier for them having to not deal with assistants moving around departments - big culture of assistants are at the bottom of the food chain! Beware of managers having their "favourite circle" DONT WORK IN RESEARCH (St Paul's)

job_title: Bilingual Retail Banker Specialist I in San Antonio, TX
pros: Good pay, great benefits
cons: Non equal pay for Bilingual reps in comparison to only English speaking reps. Terrible management.

job_title: Senior Tax Professional II in Charlotte, NC
pros:
Above average pay for accounting and finance roles
Nice office (Charlotte corporate center)
Great location (uptown Charlotte)
cons:
Manager track is the only path for promotion
Declining benefits (health care costs going up, bonus compensation and raises going down)
Little to no accountability for poor performance
Little to no reward for stellar performance
Projects and initiatives tend to be fueled by executive ego, as opposed to measurable metrics of success
Initiative to eliminate/offshore all non-manager or executive roles

job_title: Senior Vice President in New York, NY
pros: 401-K match....$500 health care discount if you do the health screening. Paid vacation
cons: Absolutely does not reward loyalty...horrible pay inequality.   Solution when I learned I wasn’t in the pay range for my job role...a demotion so I was.   Solution when my manager need more direct reports to keep his job...demotion to individual contributor.   Reward for negotiating millions of dollars in cost savings...meets/meets on year end review.   Having to manage people hired after you who make thousands of dollars MORE than you do!   Big DEmotivator.

pros: Salary around 61K if you have 2 or more years experience and have licenses . 52k if you have no licenses and less than one year experience ,. you can make up to 100k or little more than 100k if you meet Your goals . Only a few makes above 100k . Very good Insurance and benefits.
cons: If you are not ready to spend total 8 -9 hours  after work then you should not apply . This is especially true if you are a New employee .  Okay , if you are someone that is a quick learner and smart maybe you spend less hours after work. But normal individuals need to spend hours  and hours after work.

job_title: Assistant Manager in Los Angeles, CA
pros: great benefits, great perks, great team environment. it gets really fun when you get very competitive with other branches because each branch in each market is stack ranked against one another in a myriad of categories. I sometimes joke that i get ranked on the breaths that I take. Basically, if you are good and you come out on top all the time, you will be praised, nicely rewarded and continuously reinforced to do better. If you are mediocre, you will simply stay in the same position for a very long time and unless you screw up really badly, you most likely will not lose your job
cons: drastic disparity amongst age groups of people with whom you work with. a 25 year old might be managing a bunch of 55 year olds, vice-versa. sometimes, goals are hard to acquire and can be unreachable if you do not have right resources to meet your quota

review_title: An organization struggling to adjust to the new banking environment after the financial meltdown.
pros: Bank of America benefits, pay, and work-life balance are best in class.  These 3 things alone will continue to draw people and talent as it transitions to a new business strategy.  The people are generally talented, driven and continue to work daily to repair the brand's damaged image.
cons: Management expertise and knowledge has been drastically reduced by a number of departures (either through job eliminations or forced early departures).  Current management has failed to communicate changes in strategy during the early stages of Moynihan's tenure.  Employees are in frozen state due to lack of direction and concerns over job security as New BAC directives become transparent.

pros: great talent, products that really help customers, work locations, remote work policy, recognition program, salary, incentive, engaging work, techonology, mid level leaders, change, managers show interest in you and your development,
cons: seeing lots of great people leave the company because of the cost of doing business in todays economic environment, tarnished reputation due to economic meltdown in '08....Not even the CEO stands up for us on a consistent basis, the most senior of leadership not open about standing up against the unfair tactics and legislation that works against the financial industry...Pinks hotdogs is a great story on TV, dont be afraid to stand up for capitalism while admiting fault where it is needed., compliance and risk run the show

review_title: The best of places...the worst too
pros:
CAN be fantastic place, decent benefits - but vastly eroded - great flexibility in work options, such as flextime and remote working, BUT constantly threatened to be taken away...
If they settle down and stop picking apart every good thing left, could keep and strengthen workforce.
cons: Constant lack of any stability - even the best of the best can have job eliminated without any rhyme or reason - and change for the sake of change itself takes a toll. Employees have been squeezed so much over the past 5 or so years to keep afloat - would be nice to have some overall. positive growth come from something other than cuts.

review_title: I would now like to teach English to insurgents in Iraq.
pros: Decent benefits. Sometimes you can purchase extra vacation time. Sometimes there are bonuses.
cons: They're constantly trying to get rid of people to avoid layoffs or firing them. People get fired for using sick time, if there are too many "occurrences". They micromanage everything, and I mean everything. Management has no skills for the people they manage, yet you have to do what they say or you're insubordinate, then when you get a defect it's your fault because you put your name on it. If other people don't know how to do their job they just make someone else do it, including management. Sometimes there is at least 8 hours a week of mandatory OT, the opposite of that is laying off an the constant fear of being laid off. A lot of people take a leave of absence because of the stress. It beats unemployment if you have anything to say about it. Otherwise, be prepared to part with your soul and any inkling that you may be doing something with your life or for anyone else.

review_title: Good job for starting or re-entering the work force
pros: Great job for moms re-entering the work force or first time job seekers. Excellent benefits and work/balance. My center has some helpful and nice employees. My BCM is great at helping and the atmosphere is always upbeat and lively.
cons:
Only 20 hours a week. I can't get more hours at my center but I can at another center. There are only two full time positions available and both are full. It's hard to move from part time to full time unless you move to another center that is hiring internally. 

You must upsell or sell products to 10% of your daily customers

review_title: A solid job that can turn out into a great career opportunity if you choose to pursue it.
pros: There are many pros to the job.  You are working in a professional environment, so it's something that looks good on your resume.  The compensation is above average which is a plus. Work-life balance is manageable. Co-workers are always fun to talk to and the hours you work aren't bad at all. As a part-time employee you are still eligible for the benefits BOA has to offer.
cons: Sometimes 30 minutes isn't enough to go eat lunch somewhere or even take it to-go and bring it back to the break room to eat. There are so many things to learn to do your job well sometimes you may forget something that may affect your productivity.

job_title: Process Design Consultant in Charlotte, NC
pros: Good benefits although declining in coverage options and increasing in costs in recent years.  Compensation is slightly above average.  Depending upon direct supervisor, flexible working conditions.  Great place to meet people and network.  Collaborative environment with opportunity for exposure to different levels of the organization.  Ability to take on new responsibilities and gain new skills.  Wide variety of opportunities available.
cons: Constantly changing environment.  Layoffs occur continuously and without a consistent plan.  Heavy workload that is increasing as layoffs continue.  Work/Life balance has become less of a priority as employees are asked to do more with fewer resources both people and funding.  Many senior executives are only interested in building their own fiefdom and advancing their own career at the expense of those that work for them.

review_title: Perfect home for underachievers who don't want to think.
pros:
Pretty easy to get by doing the bare minimum as exceeding that is not encouraged or rewarded. 
They will pay you on time.
cons:
Lies at every turn if you question anything you are reprimanded and punished. 
People in management who have no business knowledge.
Insulting Compensation

pros: It's a good place to work, for starting out. It's fast paced, and keeps you on your toes. It offers great benefits such as health care, paid vacations, school refunds, life insurance.
cons: Having to offer products to customers who clearly did not want them, and being required to pass  certain amount of people per week on to bankers for such products offered. Never met the quote, I did try though.

review_title: Find the job/career that fits what you want to do daily abs stick with it.
job_title: Financial Center Operations Manager in Las Vegas, NV
pros: Bankers hours, including short hours on Saturdays (only open until 1pm), no drive up teller Windows, absolutely no sales pressure in the position I occupy, and definite chance at advancement.
cons: There is so much dependent on who you work for, and through no fault of the company, different Centers get more exposure than others and some have a better chance to shine based upon who they report to. Great accomplishments can be overshadowed when a superior does not see or perhaps comprehend the accomplishment or does not agree with the way that you've chosen to do something. Partnerships and open communication are essential.

review_title: Slow moving in the Technology space
job_title: App Development Manager in Jersey City, NJ
pros:
- the app dev/manager roles are usually flexible, working from home once in a while is not an issue
- the bank benefits are pretty good (ie preferential rates on mortgages etc)
cons:
- their technology stack is at least 5 years behind where you want to be.
- I understand that the bank operates in a heavily regulated environment and so solid audit processes are key, but the amount of red tape you have to navigate to get a feature out the door is insane
- the org is so large that your career success heavily depends on your direct management.  It's hard to get noticed outside of your direct line
- there is no formal 360 degree feedback, so you have no input on your managers perf

review_title: Best job, but not for everyone.
pros: The incentive plan is great! Salary is good. You have the ability to make a lot of money and advancement is very fast. Work life balance, sick and vacation time are awesome plus the paternity leave is amazing. Very flexible in terms of breaks and leaving work and switching schedules.
cons: There isn't really much to complain about. It can be a very stressful job for some and the goal can be tough. To be honest, it is not really hard to sell or do your job right. I wouldn't recommend this job to non self starters or unorganized people, you are held accountable for most things.

pros: The benefits are amazing and that's about it. Tuition reimbursement, partial daycare reimbursement, 16 weeks parental leave, 3 weeks paid vacation, and a week of sick time.
cons: I used to love working here then everything went downhill a couple years ago. Been here for over 5 years and B of A cares more about the bottom line than their associates. Management is incompetent. It's all about who you know. There is no loyalty. They've forced several people into retirement that were still very capable of working but they just didn't want to continue to pay their high salary. That's way so many of us have or are planning to jump ship. Terrible raises...you could work your butt off and still only get 20 cents raise per year.

pros: 3 weeks vacation from the first year you are in. Environment depends on the people you work with and the pressure your Regional Sales Manager puts on you.  If you work for a branch with good walk in traffic everything is good.  The bank closes at 4pm except for one day giving you a chance to go to school after or anything else for that matter.
cons: The top management puts ideas on the go before the are perfected causing a great amount of confusion on the front lines.  Which also affects customer experience which later on points are taken out for the month taking away incentives for the bankers and branch manager.  This causes the employees to not believe they work for a great company not due to the policy or ethics but to the poor implementation by the higher positions.

job_title: Assistant Vice President, Financial Center Manager in Boston, MA
pros: Great benefits, great salary, discounts, 4 weeks paid vacation for managers, 10 paid holidays and 10 sick days. Fast paced environment, multiple different lines of business so there is plenty of room for advancement. Bonus potential is pretty strong too if you hit your goals. They really have several programs in place to help employees grow with company. To be a successful Financial Center Manager you have to be able to adapt to constant change and have a positive outlook. I would recommend, definitely one of the best banks to work for.
cons: Staffing at times can be a big challenge. Company is very focused on convenient banking options, ATM, online, mobile banking etc. Unfortunately not all clients are willing to adapt to this ever growing technology.  If you can roll with some of the staffing gaps at times then you will be fine.

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Brea, CA
pros: Benefits are awesome , you can transfer to different jobs. Your co-workers are great. They do take care of their employees by training them good and knowledgeable
cons:
They only care about numbers and if you are making them look good 
Cafeteria over price and food not that great

job_title: Financial Center Client Representative in Berkeley, CA
pros: Great company to work. salary is satisfactory with all benefits. Vacation time is impressive. Bank of america has a culture of caring and sharing. BofA is a company with great value. All employees are valuable asset. Try to focus on customer satisfaction you will definitely be successful and achieve your sales goal too. Everyone is happy when a customer is happy.
cons: In a fast paced environment everyone is busy with their own training and goals so its hard to get noticed. Have to wait for promotion.politics depend upon manager's nature. Can't enjoy freedom. One has to be dependent upon manager's decisions. After working a year or more you feel like you have lost your independent thinking and problem solving skill.

review_title: Great only if you like the line of business
pros:
-Pay
-PTO, Holidays, benefits!
-Banking center hours
-My branch had an incredible team to a certain degree
cons:
-30 minute lunch break for a full day
-some branches don't have chairs so you have to be on your feet
-Constantly pushed to refer customers
-Horrible training system, pretty much forces you to be on the computer for what feels a million hours. 
-Tellers are expected to refer customers to specialist without having any idea what or how the product works. 
-Bankers are supposed to work along the tellers in order to achieve goals, I rarely saw any significant support from them. They'd rather be chitchatting while there's a huge line(they could have been lobby leading and getting those conversations with costumers in regards to a particular product)

review_title: Low work ethic and not enough supervision
pros: Benefits, PTO and sick days
cons: Low work ethic, not enough upper management supervision

job_title: Senior Vice President, Senior Product Manager in Charlotte, NC
pros: Flexible, a lot of opportunities to move around and learn, caring leadership
cons: People are people - good and bad anywhere you go, but mostly good intentioned

review_title: "Nice" place to be, but no long term opportunities.
job_title: Credit Products Underwriter in Austin, TX
pros: Many good people at the company. Compensation is generally fair. Training, if you can get it approved, is strong. Smart use of technology to improve operations. Decent place to learn commercial banking.
cons: Performance reviews are a joke. Zero opportunity for advancement or cross functional training. Low level of respect by Wall St firms. Management is vague in their all too frequent announcements. Little larger picture of downsizing efforts. Too much of operation focused on retail banking rather than growing middle market and corporate brand. Too many in middle management and backoffice are stuck in a rut and just going through the motions.

review_title: Good treatment of employees but limited advancement opportunities
pros: Bank of America offers flexible work schedules and locations for IT staff.  Most of the IT teams are distributed across the US so coming into the office was not required.  I would come to the office half of the time to meet with local team members or to physically work on the IT storage systems.
cons: Bank of America has limited career opportunities and professional advancement from my perspective as an entry level Systems Analyst.  New IT hires are distributed throughout a wide variety of teams each with different advancement opportunities.  Because of this fact, there was not formal career advancement track.  This is positive in the sense that I was put on a team of seasoned veterans but negative in the sense that after a decade, I could still be in the same place and seem team.

review_title: Many will agree with my feed back
job_title: Senior Personal Banker in Irvine, CA
pros: Good benefits, well known Company to the public, From the lower tier, With hard work there is good growth room for career advancement.
cons: management give you a very hard time for utilizing the sick day. Although you are really sick and have 10sick days, you get a crap/ guilt trip from the management for using the sick days. Many times you may called out from lunch time if you are within the premise. Although there is good growth room from the bottom of the chain, once you get to certain level you will realized that it is not all about your performance. Order for the promotion, you may have to relocate to different Market within same division or to completely change the division. Politics Politics just like any-other Large corporation.

review_title: Bank of America - Higher Standards Please
job_title: Senior Financial Analyst in Charlotte, NC
pros:
-Flexibility scheduling
-Great work/life balance (depending on your department and level of your career)
-Interesting assignments
-Knowledgeable* co-workers, especially at the 'do-er' level of the organization
-Form great friendships; can be almost a family atmosphere

*See cons below
cons:
-Although there are several knowledgeable co-workers, they keep people onboard who are severely incompetent*
-Management is often *clueless* about what's going on
-Large company, so the left hand doesn't know what the right hand is doing
-Promotions often based on politics and not merit
-Can be large pay disparities within the same job classification notwithstanding performance (a poor performer may make substantially more money than you)
-Pay for performance is a joke
-Reward & recognition... I'm not entirely sure what exactly that's based on
-Too many people just there for a paycheck

job_title: Vice President, Manager Technology in Wilmington, DE
pros: Little overtime.  Tremendous 'work from home' ability.  Generous benefits.  Lots of internal opportunities.
cons: Much of your time will be wasted in meetings ranging from the unnecessary to the absurd.  Knowledge and abilities outside your pigeon-hole are not understood or recognized.  Extremely meeting-centric.  Be there or be square.  Only way to find out what is going on in large projects is to sit in meetings that literally last all day, day after day.  Technologies are often outdated.  Extremely stingy on the expense allowance.  Extremely limited travel opportunities.  Dissent is generally not welcome.
