pros: Great conglomerate to gain experience in the financial industry. As long as you are working on a good team or better yet have a good manager then you are in a good place within the company. Good Managers, that are actually qualified and trained to be managers are hard to find at this company.
cons: Since good managers are hard to find at this company, it can be aggravating trying to maneuver up through the company without the correct structure and team support. There are many managers at this company but good managers are very hard to find. If they are not intimidated by your professional and technical expertise than you are on the right path for a successful stint in this company.

review_title: Its who you know to achieve career advancement within the Bank
pros: The benefits and vacation package is brilliant. I wish they could bring back the Health Reimbursement account card back....
cons: You can end up getting lost within the line of business you're in if you're not determined and motivated to advance in your career. Lack of training opportunities, encouragement and resources  to assist you in acquiring new skills for future roles is what one will encounter, while working here. Easily turned down at interviews within the company if you don't have the required skills for the job position at hand. How many years you've been with the company, your performance at past and current job positions and education, are not taken into consideration.

job_title: Senior Change Manager in Charlotte, NC
pros: Many opportunities to move around to gain valuable experience in many areas of the Financial Services world.  Also many SOLID training opportunities which are applicable to any industry.
cons: Layers and layers in the BAU world which lent itself to duplicated efforts as well as competing priorities.  I would point to the layers being the primary reason for continuous change in the BAU world which left one feeling uneasy about the next day being their last.

review_title: Thanks to senior management I enjoyed 7 years of employment.
job_title: Collateral Administrator II in Farmington, CT
pros: Several of my co-workers enjoyed longevity on their jobs.
cons: This is definitely survivor island.  They have frequent layoffs.  The business model is based on production numbers all numbers vary because some assignments are easy and some are hard and they yield the same number (1) point for each entity name, not (1) point for each piece of collateral released.  One individual was able to complete 900 loans in six months because she either released nothing on loans, or one piece of collateral. While other workers completed 350 - 550 loans that were more labor intensive. And still another worker was completing the work that was done by persons that were layed off.  That means she did not do the work, but was merely clocking and completing work on the system and getting credit for it.

review_title: Great coworkers and atmosphere. Did not enjoy selling products to people who didn't want them.
pros: Healthcare benefits are amazing. They contributed $850 to a health savings account after 1 month, super low premiums for high deductible plan. Great team oriented environment. Would love the job if I didn't have to sell crap to people.
cons: They want you to sell credit cards to people who already have credit cards. Asking people out of the blue if they need an auto loan can be awkward. Unrealistic sales goals. Worked 6 days a week 14 out of 16 weeks I was employed there. 2 weeks of paid vacation does not make up for having to work 40+ saturdays a year.

review_title: It was the best of times , it was the worst of times
pros: Benefits are great - so many extras that can be useful , Volunteering opportunities , Pay , Work Environment
cons: Career Opportunities , Management turns over like a turnstyle , Bonuses - Raises , Movement , Layoffs , training

pros: I enjoy working part-time and receiving benefits and a 401k.  Working for a large corporation there is room for growth.  As an employee you get VERY low interest credit cards, free accounts, and discounts on other loans.  I love having sundays off.  Working at different financial centers you meet a lot of people.  Volunteer events for employees were always fun to participate in.
cons: Constant changes in the banking center. The company is no longer hiring part-time positions.  It is possible to encounter leadership that do not support you, however this can happen at any company.  The constant complaints from customers telling us we need more teller windows open.  Stressful at times.  Company is currently going through changes that may eliminate positions within the next coming months.

review_title: Seem to be waiting for the other shoe to drop.
pros: Great benefits, many locations where you can work, that's about all I can say is good about working here right now
cons: Unrealistic goals, hard to get out of retail centers. Schedules are ridiculous and there are not nearly enough associates in banking centers.

review_title: Such a big company...your group is what matters
pros:
-get to work with many large corporate clients
-training is standardized and tried-and-true
-locations everywhere in the world
cons:
-ugghh feel like such a corporate drone
-many roles are so monotonous and repetitive; you can learn the position in 3 months, but the longer you stay in your role within operations, the less marketability you have to move on (because you only do 2-3 tasks, but 100 times a day, in your role)
-jr. operations roles are not a career path

pros:
Very structured and regulated environment.
Tasks are clearly defined and have clear goals which need to be met.
The company has a very solid compensation, growth and training packages in place you will really feel recognized when you are doing a good job and feedback is usually available to help you when you are doing something wrong.
If you are looking for a company that promotes growth, values their employees and truly invests in its employees then I would recommend applying.
cons: The company is very strict about security. No phones, no unauthorized computers or papers in production areas. Some of the operating guideline can become pretty redundant and time consuming.

review_title: Okay work environment, good benefits, poor management
pros:
Health insurance, vacation time, and 401k is great for an entry level job.
Co workers are friendly and always willing to help.
cons:
Management is awful, I'm not talking about the branch manager or assistant manager but the guys above them making decisions for the market. Constantly downsizing, expecting more and more from each financial center but not giving ANY incentive to do a better job.

Tellers are seen as expendable. No loyalty to employees but they expect employees to give their all for the company. 

Constantly pushing sales over customer service. They honestly do not care about helping out the customers, they just want more credit cards, loan applications, upgrades to your accounts that you probably don't actually need.

review_title: Think about what you are willing to sacrifice to get ahead here
pros: The people within the branch are great, problems arise from upper management. The benefits are ok, and you get most of the holidays. Actually helping customers makes you feel good about yourself and the work you are doing.
cons: Long hours, short staffed, they make you feel guilty about taking days off/sick days. Don't count on  taking your vacations when you are supposed to because even though they plead for you to submit your vacation in December, something always comes up so they make you change your vacation a day before it starts (if you had plans, too bad, already bought plane tickets? too bad). They also change their focus every other week, one day it is all about doing what is right for the customer, the next you are told that the bank knows what is best for the customer, and the customers don't know what they want.

job_title: Treasury Services Advisor in Charlotte, NC
pros: Learn a lot about client management and customer service. Stay away from GT&O and your possibilities are endless. Senior Management promote diversity and personal growth.
cons: Burnt out employees, even new hires. Management will never ask about your lunch plans..but only give marching orders. Management team all look a like and act a like. All promoted through a "buddy system", not management experience. Micromanage and believe employee development is telling you to read a book. Managers lock themselves away from teams in conference rooms most of the day. Great way to lead and inspire a team. stress and turnover is extremely high. People leave the company ...or when employees get new jobs the managers underhandedly move your start date with your new manager......without your input....self-serving.

job_title: Personal Banker in Saint Johns, FL
pros: Work with great teams. Benefits are awesome. $10 Microsoft office. 5% 401k match. Room to grow no matter where you start. Option to be a Shareholder in the company you work for.
cons: Room to grow as long as you can get a solid management team that does not change every 3-6 months. You can get lost when it comes to promotions because management changes so often. The company seems to change management so often that great employees fall between the cracks.

job_title: Financial Solutions Advisor in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Company used to have the proper incentives within the financial center but everything has now become to transactional.
cons:
Management changed executive hierarchy wherein consumer banking and investments now report to the same manager. The shortcomings of consumer banking are now being relegated to the Advisors. In essence, Advisors are expected to do significant bank servicing (debit cards, fraud claims, etc), not to mention, Market Sales Managers are now requiring every advisor to have 2 CREDIT CARD APPLICATIONS everyday (this is just one example of becoming a PB). 

Did I mention that these managers are saying advisors are doing too much banking and focus needs to shift to investments?

pros: Good benefits, not retail hours
cons:
Corporate keeps taking away staffing without reducing goals, to the point of a team being exahusted. When people are expected to work in that environment they burn out.
I used to love boa, but do to the fact they do not care about employee they don't  have my respect or loyalty anymore.
The clients are very disgruntled also due to long lines, long waits and crabby employees due to being overworked.

job_title: Relationship Manager in Fort Lauderdale, FL
pros: 3 weeks paid vacation starting, benefits are great!
cons: The company's message gets lost once it gets to the market level - Market Manager's only see the numbers and goals - very stressful position without enough support to relationship managers - You are the face of the company and are overworked and underpaid in most situations.

review_title: IT does not use, much less allow, automation or programming skills
job_title: Vice President, Systems Engineer Consultant in Dallas, TX
pros: There are none for IT.  Know that this company has it out for all things AIX.
cons:
Arbitrarily enact policies, ie, work from home.
Arbitrarily give packages to some and others will not.  This says a lot about the manager. 
Complete lack of automation of repetitive tasks.
Failure to unleash programming/scripting skills for IT types.  It's what we're trained to do.
Bad DMZ security model.

review_title: Do not take a job with this company.  No one is happy.
pros: None, it is who you know not kind of work you perform.  Vacation time.
cons: Everything, the company is no good.  A 2 percent raise on a 40 k salary is not keeping up with inflation.  Mr lewis can still make his millions.  No advancement.  I  you take an internal job they lowball you.  Management lie to your face and then get promoted.   Revenue sharing 500.00 if the company makes 15 billion.  Thanks for the 300.00 after taxes, what a bonus.  Now I can fill my gas tank.  You can talk to everyone across the company no one is happy.  I have never been in a company where everyone is disatisfied.  If you are looking here, look somewhere else.  I wish I read a review like this before I went to this company, because I would have stayed at my old position.  The grass is not always greener!!!!!!!!!

pros:
ability for job growth and promotions
lots of customer interaction training when first starting in Personal Banking positions
ability to move up in company if you can play the game
cons:
high turnover rate
high expectations
not enough positive feedback or encouragement
micromanagement even when you are meeting and exceeding goals
reduced bonuses/incentive without reduced expectations

job_title: Sales & Service Specialist in Tulsa, OK
pros:
I've only been a part of this organization for a little over 2 months and already they are grooming me for management positions. All you have to do is have the initiative and drive and convey to your management team what you want and they will help provide you the opportunity. 

Pay is pretty decent for what you do and also benefits are good. Can't go wrong with 3 weeks of paid vacation on top of the normal holidays that you get off, when you work for a financial institution.
cons: This is a very large corporation so it may be overwhelming at times.  There are people who have worked in the industry for too long and they need to change to the new modern day banking era.

pros: Some of the Pros working in my department would be; it offers different challenges everyday, the ability to work remotely, and the privilage to make decisions that can make a difference.
cons: Some of the Cons working for my department would be; Some members in my department apparently believe in neoptism, some of the managers are incompetent compared to their status, and although some decisions that should be made sometimes falls on deaf ears.

pros: great place to learn organization, customer service, pay, benefits, looks good on resume can move up fast great place to learn alot about everything! lol EMBRACING THE POWER OF OUR PPL! networking with customers, caring management
cons: SALES GOAL! TO MUCH PRESSURE! WHAT I WANT TO KNOW IS, IF BCCR AND SALES ARE LIKE GOD THEN WHY WERENT WE TRAIND ON THEM?? OH AND DID I MENTION THE SALES GOAL PRESSURE! MICROMANAGING LIKE CRAZY! NO APPRICIATION FOR EDUCATED PPL a high stress job if your not used to this sort of position fear of the "market" in southern CA its HIGHLY frowned uoun if you do not speak spanish, and that makes advancement difficult

review_title: One manager can negate many years of hard work and dedication.
pros:
Great benefits
Challenges if you are willing to step up and work hard
Flexible work arrangements depending on position
Most of your co workers are very nice and helpful people
cons: The current environment of 360 feedback leads to daily negativity and belittling by a manager.  Mid level managers who are erratic and unable to manage their own tasks are allowed to routinely berate and instigate difficulties for their associates.  Good manners and kind words are gone.  It is a place where a single manager assigned to you can ruin years of hard work and dedication to the organization.

review_title: Good company, but watch for setbacks
pros: Able to work remotely is a big plus. Never felt micromanaged at all. If you want a promotion, a good manager will help get you there. Manager was phenominal.
cons: Lots of different and challenging areas of the bank to get answers. Mid level management was good, but doesn't appear to have the right strategy and focus in certain areas. Rarely could hire to help out expanding team in order to manage work load efficiently for our clients. Set up for failure at times. Medical insurance was decent, but not great. With so many people working for this big company, a lot of different answers (some right, some wrong).

pros: Full benefits for part time employees, somewhat flexible schedules. Plenty of career paths "available". Lots of employee perks, prestige associated with working for the company.
cons: The customers treat you like you are their waiter. The managers will reinforce this by hovering, seeing this treatment and then reassuring the customer that they will take care of things. Improper training: 3-4 weeks of video training in a back room does not prepare a new teller to handle an actual cash drawer. Or customers. And the audits. And the spontaneous pop quizzes about laws by a manager as you're trying to serve a customer.

review_title: Bank of America has lot of pluses and some minuses
job_title: Senior Operations Project Manager in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Very good benefits, good communication from the Corporate level.  Excellent Diversity & Inclusion programs.  Genuine effort by senior management to streamline and improve processes in order to make jobs and operations easier for the employees and the customers.  A lot of friendly, smart people.
cons: Sometimes there are challenges with communication from middle management.  Typical large corporation left hand not know what the right hand is doing resulting in extra work for parties across multiple departments.  A times there seems to be inequity across different departments in promotions and awarding of corporate titles.

pros: The benefits package alone is outstanding - paid sick time, paid vacation, paternity/maternity paid after 1 year, holidays paid... the hours typically 8-5 M-F and 8-1 Sat - Assistant Managers are still OT eligible. they are heavily involved in the community and even offer scholarships to organizations that employees volunteer for. there is limitless opportunity to grow or even change career paths while staying with the company.
cons: it's a BIG company so with it comes the corporateness of rules/policy/procedures. there is not the level of humanness as there is with smaller companies. so if you like your birthday, anniversary, or other important dates to you recognized or appreciated it can be tough. As far as customer service there are many back office areas that truly solve the issues so it can feel like the bank employees don't own the issues or are making excuses as to why it takes time to resolve.

pros: The benefits, vacation and sick time are unlike what any other company offers. There is a lot of opportunity for growth if you’re willing to move cities or states.
cons: Management has become so top-heavy that your direct manager no longer has a say in your development or performance. I have routinely witnessed my manager struggle with policies and guidelines implemented from above but not given a choice or allowed to submit feedback. When policies and procedures change, it’s very clear the ones making the changes have little to no experience in the roles their changes effect.

job_title: Client Service Representative in Salisbury, MD
pros: Great company culture, excellent pay/benefits, and a good introductory role for learning risk management.
cons: New hire training was cursory and not much of a priority in the banking center (you learn as you go). Professional development is mostly self-driven, although many resources are at your disposal. This job has a significant emphasis on generating referrals through your transactions, but there is no real compensation for those referrals until you have been with the company for 3 or more years.  This may be specific to my district/market manager, but vacation must be scheduled before the start of the calendar year.

review_title: Stressful Environment. Pressured to sale daily. No work life balance.
job_title: Relationship Manager in Silver Spring, MD
pros: Good benefits.  Possibility for commission is available quarterly.
cons: The training process is very tense and long. You train in the back of a bank alone at a computer for 8 straight hours. The focus is on sales and employees are pressured daily about sales. Customer Service not as important as the customers. You are required to come in early and never allowed to leave on time and your schedule is changed without your knowledge weekly. Commission is only quarterly if you make 100% of your goal in the for months which is almost impossible.

pros: Good place to get a job and obtain experience within a large financial corporate institution. Benefits are great.
cons: Lots of layers of management - meaning people who were just paid to watch other people work and take credit for their load. Minimal raises so make sure you understand the pay range going in. Very hard to move up within the corporate ladder with more sideway opportunities vs true pay, title and status promotions. Saw lots of people there for a number of years who were truly unhappy so didn't make for a great work environment. Having said that, get training and experience to move on and up is worth it.

review_title: Bank of America - an O.K. place to work
pros: The benefits are really excellent overall and emphasis on work/life. The 8 weeks of paid paternity/maternity leave (full pay) is really one of the best benefits around.
cons: Not much room for growth in some areas. The transition of upper level management is rather slow. If you are in a "sales" type of position you can do very well, but if you're looking to be in a leadership role it can take quite a while. In the 6 years I've been at the bank I have seen exactly 2 positions in management/leadership open up, and only seen one immediate teammate promoted to a leadership position (of over 40 teammates)

job_title: Assistant Vice President Communications Specialist  in Charlotte, NC
pros: Great environment for advancement in your career. BofA is a great place to work and I enjoyed it very much. Having the weight of a large corporation behind you means that benefits are very good and the company can generally weather a storm better than a smaller financial firm
cons: Battleship in a bathtub mentality where it is difficult to turn things one way or another in such a large company. Overall this is a small price to pay though. I think because it is such a large organization, there are many communication breakdowns between different departments. This however would be the case at any large corporation and the way bofa handles it is admirable.

review_title: A good place to work but with a few challenges. . . .just like elsewhere
pros: Due to the large footprint of the company and many lines of business you can almost go anywhere and do anything with this company.  As with almost all companies the reason that you go to work each day are the people that you work with every day.  Direct management is knowledgeable and concerned about the staff.
cons: Senior leadership seems much less engaged and focused much more on the bottom line then the impact changes will have to working conditions for employees.  Often joke with peers using the Patton quote ".... we have been doing so much for so long with so little that we are now qualified to do anything with nothing."

review_title: Ok job but the pay is very low...
job_title: Teller Operations Specialist in Hillsboro, OR
pros: They are very good at coaching, both constructive and positive, for growth.
cons:
I don' t make as much as my friends who work at other banks. 
The quarterly goals are going up every quarter, and i feel we are getting to a point where no banking centers can make payout.
They are strict about no overtime, but it is VERY difficult to balance the job responsibilties, and get out on time, especially when i have no say in the hiring process and they hire people that can't balance their drawer

review_title: Proud to work at Bank of America
pros: I'm proud to work for this company. Associates are valued with fair pay and the ability to increase income with rewards for performance. The benefits are terrific and part timers pay the same rate as fulltime. Work-life balance is encouraged and supported. I have worked for the bank for years and have, at different stages of life, worked part time and full time. I have also been able to transfer to more convenient offices when I moved.
cons: I work in a banking center and we are micro-managed to death. Conference calls virtually every day- usually two. Reports on every move made during the day. Market managers seem to be scared all the time and so are very reactive.

review_title: BAC can be a great place to work
pros: The company is so large there is no problem finding other jobs that you qualify for. It is easy to move around within the company.  The pay is ok, but the benefits are very good. Work-life balance efforts in recent years have made the working environment very good. If you do not like your job or manager it is possible to transfer.  Most of the people you work with are smart and know their job. There are many volunteer opportunities and the bank even offers 2 hours a week for volunteer work! Internal training is offered in many courses available to all associates. They also have an excellent tuition reimbursement program.
cons: Pay is ok, not great.  There are time where the management doesn't understand what is going on, but acts anyway creating problems.

review_title: Consider working for Bank of America
job_title: Banking Center Assistant Manager in Las Vegas, NV
pros: Bank of America is a good company to work for. The size of the company lets you practically work anywhere in the country where you want to live. If you work hard and prove yourself, you can definitely get promoted to positions that you aspire to. Training is thorough for new managers and you are given the tools that you need to be successful at your job.  Finally, there is a certain amount of job security knowing that you work for one of the largest financial institutions in the United States. If you are considering working for Bank of America, I would recommend it.
cons: Working in a banking center, the sales pressure can be very intense at time. If you are not good at managing your time, the tasks that you are responsible for completing can seem overwhelming.

review_title: "Oh, how I LOVE TO BE MICROMANAGED !!! "
pros:
- 3 weeks vacation as a banker right off the bat. Option to "buy" a 4th week.
- Pension and 401K
- Childcare reimbursement
-Tuition reimbursement
-Bonus every quarter if you exceed.
cons:
-Extremely unstable schedule
-Micromanagenent is excessive
-Dealing with stupid, demanding, and lazy people at the bank. Only the old-school and ignorant people visit the banks. Anyone ever heard of online banking??
-You will never get a Saturday off.
-The job DOES NOT fit the lifestyle for a parent. Long hours at a time. A personal banker job is good for someone who is young and single. Only such people seem to get promoted, since YOU HAVE TO live for the bank , and no one else.
-Outside events. You must go to these, even on Sundays. 
-This is a high-class telemarketer job at times. You call people after the bank closes and pester them with sales offers.

pros: I LOVE WORKING HERE! I was never a fan of math or finance ever in my life, but surprisingly I am enjoying this job A LOT (by far). I have only been here about a month and a half but my team members are so awesome and even the platform associates are super cool too. The atmosphere is stress-free and although we need to make goal nobody is pressuring you or pushing you. As long as you do what you need to do everything is a-o.k.. I just wish I got more hours... haha...
cons: Other than having to make goal, the usual teller stuff like having to have exact amount when balancing, remembering to make referrals, and just not forgetting to do like 1million things. I wish part time tellers werent set to only working 20 hours a week. We want to work more too!

pros: Free accounts. (Our branch had) a diverse, multicultural environment & supportive, enjoyable coworkers. Promotes from within.. many opportunities. Educational opportunities.  Paid "volunteer" day.  It was a good job to work around my college schedule as well.
cons: Constant sales pressure with goals that were excessive.  Constantly having to deal with customer frustration of BOA policies, illegal mortgage issues, excessive fees, sales pitches, etc, etc.  Minimal appreciation for those on staff (such as myself) with extensive experience.  In my previous experience with other banks, I was responsible for management, overrides, checks, & approvals up to $500,000.  With BOA...we all were reduced to $1000..Sigh. A constant need for overrides seriously impacts quality CS & breeds employee dissatisfaction. Your lack of faith in those of us who excelled & tried to push this company forward in a positive way was a big part of why I left.

pros: BOA is heavy into tech and automation. If some process can be automated, you can bet that they will do it even if someone doing that job can point to aspects where it will harm the customer in the long run.
cons: Most of the managers I interacted with seemed to prefer to not interact with their reports unless there was a problem. Little or no chance of promotion in most areas (it was a lot of the "someone has to die or retire" mentality). If you wanted to move into an area where there might be more growth opportunities, you were on your own to network and get the training you needed. Your manager was most likely going to be in a meeting. Also, BOA seems to be trending towards "buzz words" and terms rather than action.

job_title: Vice President in New York, NY
pros: i have a decent work-life balance because i work in a satellite office, not a main office where you can be watched by management.  other than that, honestly not many pros at this behemoth that is completely out of touch...
cons: people are just not nice at this place.  senior management has it's favorites and that's it.  you REALLY have to drink the juice to fit in at this place.  benefits aren't that great and are expensive.  client base is old and tired and trying to on-board new clients is almost impossible due to high cost structure which does not allow for high rates being extended not lower fees...easily the highest priced bank on the street...also, their internal rating system is very GE-esque....i.e. SOMEBODY has to be in the bottom even if you did a good job, generated revenue and your clients like you....

review_title: Hours are great training and staffing is awful.
job_title: Banking Center Manager in Marlborough, MA
pros: The hours for the bank is really good.  You do have to work half a day on Saturday  sometimes you can take a half day during the week depending on your boss.  Also maternity and Paternity leaves are 90 days!  I never get calls on my days off.
cons: Training is awful...there is little to no hands on training.  Majority of it is computerized that you don't understand unless you were in the field prior to being hired.  Also, staffing is minimal and makes it hard to have anyone call out.  Also, anyone who questions authority gets told they are negative and need to follow the plan.  In other words don't ask why.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Francisco, CA
pros: When I got hired in the digital banking space, I was told that the best thing about the job was the benefits. And that part is true (great vacation time, 401 (k)). It's also great to work on projects for a website that's used by literally millions of customers a day and that's large (and complex) enough to keep projects challenging and mostly interesting.
cons: Upper management turns over often, and every time it does there's a massive reorganization and some level of layoffs. This is a big corporation, and it comes with all the frustrations that go along with its size. I would not recommend this department to anyone who is seeking a fast and innovative environment or a "fun" place to work.

job_title: Financial Solution Advisor in Houston, TX
pros: Merrill Edge is fairly a new company branch out from Merrill Lynch. The concept was a clever one, to cater Bank of America customers(since bank of America owns Lynch) who have small amount to invest. Give you a fixed salary, and you get to see all the customers who walk in the financial centers; so you don't have to look for prospects.
cons: Horrible management, hardly increase in salary and you work 6 days a week. Too much politics and nepotism. You work as a glorified banker, so practically you are a banker with licenses. You have to challenge your work constantly to get paid. You have to make 50 calls a day(minimum) and they do record every call you make. No future, either keep doing it and hitting your goals or leave. Most of the time either you will be fired or you would frustrated so much that you  would leave.

pros: Tuition reimbursement for part-time employees is available, Assistance with child care is also available. Nine to five standard work hours.
cons: I was with the company for six years and saw drastic negative change over the years. The company started to cut back staffing at all the branches. The last center I worked at originally had six tellers, when I left it was only two. Management squeezes every ounce of work from you. Occasionally tellers worked entire weeks with no days off, sometimes no lunch as well. The company is all about sales and customer service is last on its list. The retail banking operations of this bank are absurd, never enough people on staff to help customers. Its clear that the bank cares more about their shareholders than their employees.

job_title: Wealth Management Client Service Representative in Chandler, AZ
pros:
Amazing work staff. There is always someone there to help you within the department. Also, the managers want YOU to succeed. They want to look for people that want a career and that don't just want a paycheck. Plus the extensive training they put you through is more than enough to get you prepared for the job.  

The hours of employment are also amazing as well. You get a choice of 4 ten hour shifts or 3 8 hour shifts and you never get off too late depending on business needs. Plus overtime is always available! Finally, all of the Vice Presidents and Directors of this call center are SUPER friendly and sweet. They aren't the types to let you fall, they want you to succeed as well!
cons: I wish the training part was a bit more organized, but it is not bad at all.

job_title: Client Service Representative in Charlotte, NC
pros: Health Benefits are not bad.
cons: Call centers are aggressive and demeaning places to work. There is no exception here. Nepotism, favorites and cliques are alive and well. There is absolutely NO sense of future working in a call center and if you do not have a current resume then you are doing yourself a disservice. Algorithms, adherence, bathroom time are all measured against you.  A very wise person once told me "Charts and graphs do not lie.  Only liars use charts and graphs".  This very much applies here.  If for no other reason than some Leader or Manager does not like you the "Charts and Graphs" are easily manipulated to their advantage to excuse you from employment.  One last thought.  No one woke up one morning on their 12th birthday and said "I want to work in a Call Center as a career for the rest of my life!".  You will NOT be happy with this company or its management style in this function.

pros: Job good for overachievers who are self motivated, experienced at sales/lead generation, can take negative feedback constantly. Flexible holiday/time-off structure. Great maternity leave plan. Extensive knowledge base.
cons: Varies with branch, branch manager and Market Sales Manager.  Very pushy about sales; you are only as good as your last weekly performance report. Cut-throat competition, stressful job, continuous expectation/training to perform at financial planner level given the regulatory environment. Base salary therefore needs to be negotiated carefully.  It is not very easy to meet goals especially in a branch that has less foot traffic and/or multiple RMs competing for business.  Bonus is reduced by branch performance, training performance as well as lost accounts within a few months. Overtime is not encouraged. Paid hrs are very regulated /managed even if accrued for branch related work.

review_title: People are generally nice, but overall poor strategy and leadership
job_title: Assistant Vice President Global Information Security in Charlotte, NC
pros: Good work life balance, decent pay, colleagues are generally cooperative.
cons: Poor opportunities for internal mobility and personal growth.  Inept leadership and weak qualifications at senior manager and executive levels.  Degrees from University of Phoenix and in "Info Assurance" from Norwich University are not credible; one C-Suite exec has barely a community college A.A. – terrible!  Unclear strategy in Global Tech & Ops line of business (note to execs - reducing expenses as a strategy is not a strategy.)

job_title: Bilingual Customer Service Representative in Fort Worth, TX
pros: The best benefits!! 3 weeks vacation and one week of sick time apart from that. Depends on your band. Childcare reimbursement, good pay and bonuses. Great insurance coverage! Very lenient when it comes to attendance they understand life happens, the most lenient company I’ve worked for when it comes to attendance. You can wear jeans everyday.
cons: A lot of favoritism makes it hard for growth. Plano location in the heloc department required mandatory overtime They wld decide for you wouldn’t  let you decide wether to come in earlier or stay later which is very inconsiderate.

review_title: They care more about numbers than people.
job_title: Home Loan Processor in Chandler, AZ
pros: The pay is probably the best I've seen in the industry, hands down, and the benefits are definitely above and beyond compared to others.
cons: The pressure to produce loans in home equity is insane, even when volume is slow. If you have a good manager, it can make it easier, but if you have a bad manager, it will be a uphill battle the whole way. Management is rude to employees and can be quite adversarial at times. The policies and procedures can be convoluted and interpreted differently from person to person. There are not enough senior reps to help new people, and so they flounder a bit.  They want to please their shareholders, and dont truly care about the stress it can cause their employees. People are working through their breaks and lunches to try and meet production goals. I'm pretty sure that's illegal.

pros: Good/great pay, good benefits, 10 days of sick time (when you can manage to use it), vacation days (when you’re actually allowed to take it and not constantly rescheduling due to staffing issues)
cons: Staffing (always running on the bare minimum but considered “fully staffed”), recognitions and awards have greatly declined, too much micromanagement, lack of support from executives, work/life balance is a joke (it can’t be considered an 8-5 job when you have calls til 7pm/ 7am morning meetings an hour away), inconsistency with job requirements from location to location, inconsistency with performance management

review_title: In my career of over 20 years, easily the worst job I've ever had
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Good for clueless careerist managers
cons:
- Bad compensation. No raises, substandard bonuses. The bank is really cheap with everything from employee comp to benefits to canteen supplies. My next job pays 80% more.
- clueless management. The higher in the hierarchy, the less competent they are.
- rotten culture: a managing director never has a bad idea, a rank and file never have a good one
- zero opportunity to develop yourself or increase your marketable  knowledge. 
- initiative is generally punished
- a 'type faster' management style
- outsourcing full steam even as quality suffers
- As an MBA I can diagnose that pretty much everything is done badly: organizational structure is wrong, they are outsourcing core competencies, ignore strategy, do not manage company's culture, innovation and change etc. It's like management science advances from 1980s onward have bypassed them.

pros: The company is very positive and sets a fantastic team environment.  The benefits are better than any other company I have ever worked for and are only set to improve over the next year.  Most managers will go above and beyond to make sure their associates are happy moving schedules around, allowing trades, and understanding when an exception is needed for a vacation day.  This is by far the best company I have ever worked for.
cons: Although career advancement opportunties exist there isn't a comprehensive plan to help associates map out where they want to go.  Also, some ideas that come down from senior management don't sound right from the start and will be taken back or changed almost immediately.

review_title: Force you to refer products til you're blue in the face.
pros: Decent pay. Good benefits.  Decent shift lengths. Good for part t time.
cons:
Where to start? Management is terrified of upper management causing a stressful environment.   BoA is more about sales than anything. If you are underperforming in referals
due to no one wanting credit cards, your managers harass you until you make up the shortage of referrals. Will write you up if you don't meet referrals. Also they promise tuition reimbursement, only if you reach referrals which is impossible b/c their goals are unreachable. Miscommunication of regulation change. Managers very annoyed if you take a sick day and refuse to let you take it unless you bring an ER note. I have not attempted to ever takes sick days, but this is the way I've viewed my coworkers treated.

review_title: My experience has been great, management is very helpful and consistent in how they treat everyone.
pros: Bank of america is a great place to work because it is a professional environment. Management is willing to help you out when needed. Opportunity to advance to another position is relatively simple as long as you understand the policies and procedures. Overall, it is unlike any other job I've ever had, and i would definitely recommend this company to anyone.
cons: As a teller, the down side to working here are the sales goals. Also, they really push online banking and ATM usage. We're (tellers) forced to talk to every customer about this, it almost feels like you're pushing yourself out of a job.

review_title: over worked and underpaid. 1,000,000,000,000 things to do all the time.
job_title: Sales and Service Specialist in Gilbert, AZ
pros: good benefits. good hours, for 40+ associates. getting to interact with people all day!
cons: where do i start?! over worked and highly underpaid for the amount of work your expected to do. your constantly being pulled here-there-here-there-here-there its dizzying! they tell you up front that your going to be a 'multi-functioning position'....but what they mean is that your the 'whatever we don't feel like doing, your going to do position'.. I read terrible reviews about this position, but i knew i needed to climb the 'success ladder' at this company  because they force you to. i didn't heed their warnings and now i'm leaving the company all together because this position SUCKS and they won't let you be considered for promotion no matter how long you stay at 1st in the market as an SSS!

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Simi Valley, CA
pros: The Company offers benefits and career advancement BUT only if you can get past the EXTREMELY enforced rules regarding adherence.  Also, personality issues with the immediate management.
cons: 2  much emphasis is given on the "TIME MANAGEMENT" vs allowing the customer to be helped as needed.  Many times the CSR's are forced to cut a conversation or transfer due to the limitations of the amount of time they can spend on the phone.  The statistics are important to management and they enforce it.  Management at this level is poor & very inexperienced.   HIGH stress.

review_title: An interesting one, if not for the customer base...
job_title: Senior Collector in Westlake Village, CA
pros: Great position to learn the basics of mortgages and learn from the inside how everything mortgage-wise works.  This position has taught me the good and bad of the industry and what challenges must be considered when trying to tailor a positive experience to each and every customer you assist.
cons: There are some policies and procedures that I wish we could adjust, if it weren't for the investor of the loan demanding such inane things.  Also, you are not going to be able to help every customer (it is so unfortunate that they can sometimes have an extreme entitlement complex that prevents you from being able to help them in the best way possible, so frustrations can come from these moments...) but when you are able to, it is a very satisfying experience to help them!

review_title: Horrible Training Sets You Up For Horrible Experience
pros: Benefits. Pay was average for the area. I was expecting a bit more from such a prominent and profitable financial institution, but then again, average pay makes sense for a company too big for it's own good.
cons: I had over two years teller experience but knew it would take a a little bit to figure out company policies and their way of conducting business. After their horrible computer-only two week "training", I was expected to know every little thing and was coached when I had questions over something company-based. It was if they didn't appreciate having to do their job as "leaders", which brings me to the next point. Their leadership was deplorable. The store manager's idea of motivation was threatening me with my job right before I jumped on a drawer to begin my shift. Pavlov-style negative encouragement generally doesn't work too well in terms of an employee's work performance. I was so miserable I began looking for teller work elsewhere and left within 2 months.

pros:
Solid benefits - 4 weeks vacations as an entry level employee (that may have changed). 3 months for both maternity and paternity leave. Ability to work from home. Work-life balance was easy to maintain. Most people worked about 9 or 10 hours a day in NYC.

Many opportunities to move within the company.
cons:
Compensation is low compared to other firms in the industry. Bonuses we also low during the time that I was there (also a function of the economic environment).

The experience depends a lot on the manager. There are plenty of manager that haven't received sufficient training. The culture outside of Charlotte is weak. There is a culture clash between the various hub as a result of so many mergers.

Very hard to get things done in a timely manner. There are so many intermediary steps and approvals needed to complete anything.

review_title: Environment in Tech & Ops is terrible
pros: Good people on the ground, good employee networks and people who use their limited personal time to put together great events and learning opportunities.
cons: The CIO is out of touch with the people who do the work on a daily basis, the environment is punitive, inflexible, and we are constantly monitored. Flexible work was taken away, layoffs are so engrained in the culture now that it's not a surprise, even when we are told there will be no more for the year and 2 weeks before Christmas a round of layoffs happens again. Talented people are leaving in droves. Ego is mistaken for leadership. There's not enough thoughtful planning and too much jumping from fire to fire.  Project Management is considered a commoditized skill set (no wonder most projects are late, over budget and scope).  Any action based on employee surveys is all talk and not substantive.

pros: They're are some wonderful people to work with at BofA; hardworking, kind and smart.  The benefits are good and the many opportunities to join affinity groups and volunteer to help the community is great.
cons: Overall the company's mission and message sounds good and if you're in a good division, you may find they align; however, due to the constant and numerous organizational and leadership changes you often find it does not align.  I worked for BofA for 9 years and I have to say it's leadership is tone deaf to not only their employees but also to their own managers.  Teams want to contribute and do good work but the lack of consistent direction and support makes this a difficult task to achieve.

review_title: Honestly a great company to work for
pros: Career advancement, competitive pay, hours of operation are good for work-life balance
cons: As with most banks, NOT ENOUGH STAFF. a branch serving 6,000+ teller transactions, on top of having 2 ATMS still has only 1 teller... leaving everyone to work 10x as hard. Managers are expected to run a teller drawer daily because the company just wont provide adequate help. In my opinion, the company asks an unreasonable amount of work from management and will slap you on the wrist for OT

pros: Bank of America has great benefits.  They offer the standard fare, medical, dental and vision as well as a 401K and company funded Pension plan.  Vesting in both plans is very quick (3 years) and they match 401K 100% up to 5%.  They also offer Tuition Reimbursement and 8 week paid paternity & maternity leave.  There are many growth possibilities throughout the company.  One can move across different lines of business fairly easy. The bank prefers to promote from within, so utilizing your networking skills is a must.  The bank also acknowledges diversity groups.  They provide a generous allotment of vacation and time off.
cons: Huge company that is hard to find out about opportunities unless you are connected.

pros: Good benefits-12 weeks paid maternity/paternity, healthcare is reasonable, flexible work locations. Good technology, nice office spaces, good associate discounts on banking and other services.  Do not need advanced degrees to get ahead
cons: No pay increases in the last 3 years if you make over 75k, salaries used to be industry leader and now lag behind, bonuses are a joke, do not speak up if you disagree with management a reorganization will come and you will find yourself "layered" as BOA calls it which is basically demoted or put out the door.  Due to poor pay and poor management talented people are running like the company is on fire.

job_title: Sales & Service Specialist in Plainfield, NJ
pros: great benefits (after 30 days). health, vision, dental, 401k, life. free bank account. good pay. room for advancement. reasonable paid sick/ vacation time. busy/ fast paced. kept you busy.
cons: the branch that i worked for was very cliquey. management didn't do much but sit in the office, talk and drink coffee. they were in and out whenever they wanted while on the clock. the branch where I worked had no a/c and we were not allowed to take off our suit jackets. I was dying of thirst and felt sick, I was not allowed to go across the street to buy water. I dealt with this problem every summer. Higher management did NOTHING to help the situation. They often ask you to stay late and come in early. Whenever higher management comes to visit the branch they smile in your face and complain and criticize you to your manager about any little thing.

pros: A goal setting environment that involves quarterly performances. Exceeding and overall Expectation on performances will likely get you a 4 to 5% increase, that that is not too easy to accomplish. Yearly assessments on various cross-channel processes, which enhance knowledge, but scores are monitored to be successful/passing at 80% or greater.
cons:
Lots of departmental/location changes, resulting in closed job sites. Meetings on top of meetings to get aligned with other like departments where teammates are in various states. Some teammates are not so helpful, unless there is room to be noticed my upper management. Monitored with Numbers productive led to what some may call favoritism. 

There use to be a point system where points were valued for company store purchases. These points use to be easy to accomplish, but in the last 5 years, points did not come by so easily, do to cost/budgeting.

pros: Honestly there are none worth mentioning
cons:
Micromanaging has gotten out of control as the FSAs are getting hounded on a daily basis by their MSMs for totally irrelevant things.
As several other posts have alluded to, more focus now on pushing banking products rather than investment products which is contrary to what the role really should be. 
FSAs also are expected to do many menial banking tasks.
It is also true that the vast majority of customers do not want anything to do with investment products unless it carries that magical FDIC coverage. 
Many referrals that are passed along by business partners are a complete waste of time.
Sales goals are a joke and are completely out of reach for most FSAs.
The Compliance Dept. at Merrill Edge should be renamed the "Sales Prevention Dept".

job_title: Senior Vice President Human Resources Shared Services in Chester, England
pros: I was there in total for over 18 years (was previously MBNA) and really enjoyed the different phases of evolution. More recently the strategy changed from growth via acquisitions to consolidation, but the company was still investing in the people and infrastructure, whilst being mindful of spend.
cons: If you aren't based in Charlotte or at least London then opportunities wont be as readily available (hence moving on) and that's a shame. It may have been my role and specific circumstances, but I suspect that's not the case. I was based in Chester, but reported via London to global HR.

pros: The company does provide an fair amount of training, to ensure that you are not just thrown into a job without the proper knowledge. You do get vacation and sick days very quickly it you are just starting there. Fairly easy to get into the company.
cons: Incentive program does not promote you to help the customer, but to work as fast as possible and hence do as little as required for the customer. Takes 6 months to post to a new position with in your current department and 1 year to post out of your department. You can get shadows, however, you will need to actively ask your manager. They offer paid volunteer hours and flex hours. Lower pay to make up for the ease of getting into the company.

pros:
Very talented work force
Great team 
A lot of internal mobility 
More professional than most trading desks 
Management is always accessible
cons:
Compensation structure very flat 
Industry seems to be shifting to where risk and compliance run a firm
A lot of internal politics and egos
Multiple layers of management 
Some favoritism - a lot of people there that shouldn't be 
Ability and contribution aren't the main factors with progression at the firm
Overall very high turn over especially with Director level and below

review_title: Great company if you have a great manager
pros: Great company if you have a great manager. The benefits are great, they offer Tuition Reimbursement, Childcare reimbursement, adoption Reimbursement and have great medical and dental plans. The pay is OK, but well below what is deserving of the tenured employees.
cons: If you are a top performer on a team, the manager will block you posting out to a different position. They hire outsiders who don’t know their jobs and provide them with a higher salary than people that have been there for years that knows the job. Promoting from within is really not based upon your performance , but more on who you know who you are cool with... that’s why I left.

pros: Vacation days is good and pay is comparable. The facilities are decent they do give you a decent computer to work on.
cons: The Plano location is lacking diversity, most if not all are Indian decent. They talk about diversity but the managers are only hiring Indian workers. Many teams here are 100% Indians. The culture is also very political and a lot of backstabbing and managers are borderline dishonest. If your a woman employee good luck as you will be talked don to by most likely your Indian or Pakistani manager. The caste system here is very much in play.  I hate to generalize but this is the reality here.

pros: Benefits were amazing. 15 days of vacation. 10 days of sick time. Discounts were also good. Able to review paychecks almost three days in advance of the pay date. 401k match 5%.
cons: Favoritism leads to employees just doing what they need to do to get by. Upper management has the people they like lined up for promotions and unless you have been there forever, it is harder for newer employees to move up. Incentive is paid out 45 days after the last day of the month, which is unfair for those who leave the company because we worked that entire month and earned our top spots, but cannot get paid for it unless I am still there for another 45 days, in which case I will never get to leave. Too much work for little pay, other departments do not do their job and cause problems with customers.

review_title: Bank is great, Management chain was miserable.
job_title: Cyber Security Architect in Richmond, VA
pros: The pay was not bad.
cons: They spend nothing for a good working environment, office cubicles are getting smaller to non existent. Chairs are unbearable to sit in all day. Bare bones as far as on the job services such as administrative staff, office supplies don't exist. But all that aside, what drove me away was the management chain who felt the need to impress others at your cost, with ridiculous demands. Manager never has your back unless it has a knife in it.  Manager harassed me for taking sick time, and demanded answers about what kind of sickness I was experiencing, which is pretty much illegal.  No such thing as teamwork. If you want to apply for a different position in the bank, your manager will not take it well.

review_title: Good place to work as long as you stay out of managements cross-hairs
pros: Most co-workers are very pleasant to work with. Salary isn't the highest for the position but it is competitive in comparison with other large banks. Excellent schedule flexibility. Most managers are cool headed and easy to get along with. On site child care. Facilities are well maintained. Free shuttle transportation to and from Penn Station.
cons: Management has way too many meetings which makes them unavailable a little too often. Information is sometimes not communicated very well. Morale has dropped significantly over the last year. Incentive really isn't great. They can definitely do a better job at responding to associate feedback.

job_title: Consulting Systems Programmer in Concord, CA
pros: The bank uses about every piece of mainframe technology available, so provides experience in many areas.  There are interactions with people all over the world, so diversity is highly encouraged.  Working for the bank has until the last couple of years been reasonably secure employment, with the result that many people have worked for them in data processing for 20 or 30 years.
cons: Senior management has made very poor decisions with the advent of the current economic crisis.  The CEO Ken Lewis decided very much on his own to buy Merrill Lynch, resulting in a financial disaster for the bank.  The financial issues have resulted in project cancellations, wide-spread down-sizing of staff, and outsourcing thousands of jobs overseas.

review_title: Could be much better with the right management from Branch manager to market executive
job_title: Small Business Specialist in San Jose, CA
pros: Excellent training. With experience and understanding the system, SBS could give the kind of service that the Small Business Community need. Definitely a good bank to work for if you are lucky enough to be under a good branch manager. Customer service seem to be a notch better than competitors (faster).
cons: Most Branch manager does not how to manage SBS, abusive in term of production requirements. Run their SBS more like PB. Lack the knowledge to service the small business in the community. They all need more training to serve the Small Business Community, and should take their hand of the SBS and leave it to the Small Business Sales Manager.

pros: Great environment and very respectful towards employees. They don't belittle or downgrade an employee and are willing to help you do the job.
cons:
I worked in a "production" area regarding loans, and "numbers" are paramount.  It is produce, produce, produce.  No letting down.  You must be a marathoner to stick with it.  You must stay in a position for one year before you can transfer to another function.  I understand that this is easy enough to do however.

Contractors are treated somewhat "suddenly" when the contract is terminated.  The contract ends or the contractor is dismissed by email and a call to the effect of "no need to come back".  If you leave any personal property, it is a problem getting it back, and any office type of equipment might not be returned.

review_title: Overall it was a good experience but doing a call center job for 14 years takes a toll.
pros:
Great benefits including an onsite daycare.
Good salary compensation for type of job it was.
Overall coworkers were good to work with.
cons:
At times there was poor communication about changes in monthly incentive goals. Some of the changes seemed arbitrary and the managers did not always give a good explanation for the changes. 

Many times management would listen to the workers and improve things related to morale issues but right when a change was working things would go back to the way they were. If a change is working let it play out. You will have have much happier workers.

More opportunities for advancement at call center locations.

review_title: Bank of America seems to be going through a rough patch, but the fact is that other banks are much better to work for.
pros: The base salary for teller is significantly higher at Bank of America than at any other bank I've applied to, and the health benefits are good.
cons: One of the biggest things that makes Bank of America a dissatisfying company to work for is the atmosphere. People quit to go different banks, often U.S. Bank, regularly and claim that people are much nicer and more employee-centered at other companies. Another problem is that, while it is theoretically possible to get bonuses for things like referrals, almost no banks meet the minimum threshold for receiving bonuses. This is because they fail silly customer service surveys that use a sample size far to small to make them statistically valid. In contrast with this, at many other companies, tellers receive monetary rewards for every successful referral.

review_title: Virtually impossible to advance based on actual merit.
pros: Ok pay, decent benefits, you occasionally got to do some good for the customer.
cons: Virtually no support from management at any level. Rules are very selectively interpreted. Advancement is entirely socially based, and directly inverse to actual ability. Awards and recognition are never given based on merit, but which friends they're grooming for advancement. Most employees aren't seen as people, but utterly disposable resources to be burned out and replaced with a lower wage entry level workers.

job_title: Banking Center Manager in Las Vegas, NV
pros: Well established company with many available opportunity for growth.
cons: So big that you can also get missed placed or forgotten. I was hired for branch management and after completing the training I was sent from one branch to another as a floating banker to fill shortage of bankers to the point they forgot what I was hired for. They had split one district into two. The new District Manager himself was in training and every time I would call to request for evaluation I was told he would get back to me, but it never happed, till I decided to leave but that was too late because I had gotten a better offer from another Bank

review_title: Overall, it was a good place to work.
pros: Has great benefits! But the new health ins plan is weak compared to some years past. Maternity/paternity leave up to 3 months, child care reimbursement, and tuition assistance.Has the best product suite in the industry, as long as you manage to waive the fees.  Should offer a free checking account, without so many restrictions to get it for free.  Online banking is way better than the competition. Home Equity Loan is great, mortgages are also good, but way too many hoops to jump through.  Rates are not the best, can get better rates elsewhere almost every time. Company prices themselves out of competition when they get too busy to handle the work load.
cons: Must be willing to relocate to advance very far.  Too much micro managing! Unrealistic goals!!!

job_title: Personal Banker in San Diego, CA
pros: So many cons which need to be addressed at the corporate level.  The only pros worth mentioning are the medical benefits and 401k.
cons: Unethical management practices at the branch level in order to meet goals.  Micromanaging employees every minute of the day.  Expectation is to work overtime without pay in order to meet goals.  Dishonest to customers regarding their "needs" for new accounts in order to cash bank checks, and many customers have an unruly number of accounts just to show branch "sales".  Vacation requests approved would require employees to work the Saturday before and the Saturday after the one week request, to only allow 5 days off plus Sunday.  Ridiculous game-playing to kill morale.

review_title: Amazing Place to Begin your Career!
job_title: Customer Service Specialist I in East Providence, RI
pros:
Great Benefits, Helpful Coworkers, Competitive Pay. Opportunity for advancement, Bank Of America puts a lot of time and money into their employees, if  you're a good employee you can go far! I didn't have much interest in fiance before my position, but it may be something I'll look into going to school for, BOA also has tuition reimbursement!
This is a Place where you truly feel cared about and valued,
cons: I wish the schedules were a little more flexible in my current position, but I am relatively new, it comes with time.  This is an amazing job, and I'm so lucky!  So i a not so awesome schedule is the only downfall, I'll gladly take it. I've surely had much worse schedules.

review_title: Another Corporation not looking to Compensate
job_title: Customer Service and Sales Specialist II in Newark, DE
pros: I worked at Bank of America for over a year and it was a great experience. I met a lot of great people. Finished in the top percent nationally in my line of business
cons: Yearly raises for performances. I wouldn't call them raises though when top performers get a Max of approx 40 cents. They tell you about how you can grow into new roles in the bank. That is true but don't expect to be paid . I went from a band 7 to a band 6 position and received a raise for one dollar .

job_title: Senior Customer Service Associate in Tampa, FL
pros:
Come in off the street with 3 weeks vacation, 2 weeks sick time, and an option to purchase a 4th week for the following year.

Easy to get some form of bonus if you're doing your job.

Very laid-back office environment. Dress code is casual, o Everyone is friendly.
cons:
Call center

Policy/Procedures not always updated in a timely manner

Many different lines of business within the same company that operate totally differently. 

Company lacking in up to date hardeware/software/systems. My Buddy's PC is currently on the fritz because we got our primary work system "upgraded" and his PC only had 2 gigs of RAM and couldn't handle it.

Myriad of tech related problems that are not always addressed right away.

review_title: Consumer Banking - Sales and Service Specialist
job_title: Assistant Vice President in New York, NY
pros:
-Broader exposure to entire Bank of America organization through affinity, volunteer groups.   This is probably the most valuable - the chance to meet others within the organization truly opens doors so please don't discount it.
-Park Avenue location provided interaction with ultra high end clients with unique needs.
-Standard benefits are great in the corporate space - medical, dental, vision, 401K matching, matching gifts, paid volunteer days.
cons:
-Completely inept management on almost every level of the consumer, retail banking level - from the branches to those that run the local markets, and  then some.  
-Fundmental disconnect in the sales area - past habits reek of the current Wells Fargo debacle.    i.e. - pushing a savings account on someone who cannot afford it, but hey, 'Keep the Change' will help, right?

review_title: Miserable customers, miserable employees, miserable place to work
job_title: Customer Service Representative in Dallas, TX
pros: The company has excellent benefits such as 401k matching plans, employee banking solutions, paid vacation and sick leave as well as bonuses, etc.
cons: The company will not hire more than two CSRs and makes the lives of the tellers miserable because there is no balance between life and work. At one point I reached out to upper management to let them know the way the branch management was treating employees and customers. I was promised a transfer within a week and four weeks later still have not had the transfer and the upper management has ignored all of my emails. They pride themselves in customer service, but I have never seen such unhappy customers until I started working here. I am a student and my time is very valuable yet I have never felt more disrespected as I have working here. I do not recommend working for this company unless you are in a higher level position.

job_title: Fraud Analyst in Hunt Valley, MD
pros: Associates are nice. And the pay is decent only because they offer OT. Base pay is trash for the job it self. You can move up but it may take a while and first you have to be bashed every day by customers non stop.
cons: The company is compacting every position into one and instead of hiring more people, company is firing more people. Went from just doing debit fraud, to fraud and billing disputes, to fraud/billing disputes and ACH, then I left. But I have individuals I know who say now they added small business claims and they're doing back office work to add onto it. Bank of America is raising pay to 20$ and to offset the raise of pay, they closed other departments and making the work load ridiculous. You need 89.5% customer approval but most customers aren't happy because the bank IT staff is trash and literally don't know how to fix the algorithm for the customers and their cards are being blocked consistently. It's so bad at this company I would suggest you do not work there.

review_title: Bank of opportunitiy to burn out
job_title: Senior Personal Banker in Bellevue, WA
pros: The best reason to work for Bank of America is their generous Benefits package.
cons: If you are looking for a good work/life balance - forget about it. In exchange for its hefty benefits this company will suck the life out of you and spit you out. I see people burn out all the time in sales and management positions. And if you happen to be a working mother, 12-week paid maternity leave will be the only time when you'll be happy you chose to work for this company.

pros: BOfA is a great place to work for if you are young and interested in learning about the banking system.  Benefits and pay are competitive.  If you have the drive to grow within the company, you can (It takes hard work and networking as always). And one of my favorite reasons is that the workplace is flexible; if you don't fit in one branch, there's always another one to try just around the corner.
cons: From my personal experience I would say that I expected more mobility across departments that what I've found so far. Yes!, blame it on the economy, but it has been hard (if not impossible) to grow professionally outside the consumer banking area. Sales is a great start but college graduates expect much more.

job_title: Sales and Service Specialist in San Jose, CA
pros: College Tuition Reimbursements up $5500 (takes about 30 days to be reimbursed).
cons:
No Bonuses are given to Sales and Service Specialist or Tellers. 
When Personal Bankers get their semi-annual bonuses, each market will authorize a small bonus for lower positions that will be distributed as pay raises. For example, the market will authorize $500 bonus for tellers and SSS positions, but will distribute this as a pay raise in your personal assessments. How its calcuated ($500/52 weeks)/ 25/hrs = .38 cents (equivalent to a 2.5% pay raise if your paid $15.5/hr). If you work more than part time, most likely your raise will be less. These raises are masked to look like raises when they're taking your own bonus and distributing over the year. Unless your good with numbers you'll catch on, other than that most people don't realize this.

job_title: Customer Service and Sales Specialist in Fort Worth, TX
pros: Pay, benefits, casual dress code, and top notch training classes.
cons: Non-motivated management, always looking to fire employees, non-motivated associates.  Managers were the WORST part of being employeed by Bank of America.  They were either never physically there, or in meetings all day.  The set up of both Collections and Customer Service is to get rid of employees.  When associates have angry and irate customers, there is no correct escalation process established to resolve customer complaints and issues.  Bank of America treats all of their mortgage customers like crap.  It's usually up to the individual themselves to provide great service, but with the constant micromanaging, most associates just tell customers whatever to get them off the phone.  Bank of America sets up all their employees to fail.  They hire too many people, then spy and find ANY reason to let them go once they realize they can't afford to pay them.  It's pretty riduculous.

review_title: Software developer at Merrill Lynch would have been better off somewhere else
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Hopewell, NJ
pros: I am grateful that BofA Merrill Lynch was able to hire me at a time when few other banks were bringing on staff.  The compensation and my severance (of 4 months, with benefits) was generous.  Very good benefits and health insurance.
cons: Too many Indians in I.T., and there was rampant unethical treatment of contractors by BofA Merrill Lynch senior management (also Indians, generally).  Uses a proprietary software development stack that is about 10 years out of date.  Unrealistic expectations of technologists placed on the business.  No opportunity for innovation and people are generally unhappy.  All of the great technologists I worked with there have since moved on to other banks and finance companies.

review_title: A bank with a conscience - hard to find
pros: They offer many opportunities for everyone to succeed - it's then down to the individual to make the most of them and shine.  Work-life balance is encouraged, although with current initiatives to streamline processes, workload demands and expectations are high.  Turn this into your advantage and take on these challenges and you will shines.  Mobility within the organisation is well supported.
cons: Many challenges to be met in terms of the drive to become best in class.  Salaries are not bad, but not the highest for investment banks in the UK.  Benefits package is part of your salary rather than in addition, but is widely accepted as being the most tax efficient in the UK.

job_title: Software Engineer in New York, NY
pros: There are lots of educational resources and opportunities. The compensation is decent. You can take advantage of some of their banking benefits.
cons: Absolutely no work-life balance, everything is by the book, incredibly slow practices and lots of legacy systems. The technology culture is poor; as a woman developer, their women-in-technology program needs a lot of improvement. The mentorship program is weak. It takes ages to get promoted. Upper management expects you to live, breathe and sleep your work with barely any regard to your personal issues. The insurance benefits are a joke. No cohesion to a lot of their policies. If you work on the investment side, all your own investments are tracked by the bank and have to be approved by your direct manager.

review_title: At times they are squeezing blood from a rock
job_title: Assistant Banking Center Manager in Trenton, NJ
pros: Benefits, tuition reimbursement, work hours, and vacations.
cons: There is no money in the banking industry like it used to be years ago.  You are constantly short staffed, overwhelmed with hitting nearly impossible sales metrics.  If you do have a strong sales base growth is limited unless you can walk on water.  The base salary is awesome, and the work hours aren't too bad.  Don't forget to promote self service options that replace your job! Leadership is disconnected with the branch associates, and at times it's just you and another individual running the branch.  If you don't keep your sales up and compliance tight you  won't make it in the company.

review_title: Ugh, I can't even talk about it.
job_title: Operations Analyst in Saint Petersburg, Sankt-Peterburg
pros: Benefits are fantastic, with 12 weeks maternity leave, decent 401k match.
cons: I did about 3 people's jobs and wasn't given a raise or a promotion. People I know left the bank for the same reason. You job role will change or they will make you do things far above your pay grade, but when you do it, you're not given compensation fairly, and 9/10 times, they will make sure you don't meet expectations so that they keep you with your knowledge where you are. I don't feel valued or appreciated as an employee, and while it's a good job out of school, I think it's very frustrating sometimes. Culture is cut throat in some parts of the bank, while laid back in others, so inconsistent.

pros: Being a Fortune 500 company, BoA offers plenty of room for growth if you learn the corporate structure and work to set yourself apart from the herd.
cons:
Production Based. You can begin to feel like just another body on a large plantation if you get stuck in certain paths (customer service, call center, teller, etc.), but once you break free from that congestion (several years of crazy hours), it can be clear skies.

Also don't expect the best schedule to start... when it comes to hours worked and holiday time off (blame it on seniority); which isn't so bad once you earn seniority yourself.

job_title: Dedicated Service Director in Kennesaw, GA
pros: Great company to work for prior to its most recent merger with Merril Lynch. Had a good company culture and good leadership.
cons: Most recently the company has cut costs through reorganization closing large service centers causing hundreds of people invested into the company to loose their jobs. Many knowledgable long time and loyal employees are let go, and leadership hires and promotes candidates with less experience, merge job responsibilities over working current new hires causing high turn over across whole company.

review_title: Okay benefits, nice people but terrible management
pros: The 401k match is good and the company's automatic contribution in lieu of a pension is also nice.  Medical benefits have become pricey and the coverage has decreased.  The vacation policy is competitive and in general the people are nice.
cons: No consistency amongst management.  It really depends on who you work for since some managers are good (mostly the ones that got severed) and the yes men/women are left behind.
