Metrics change all the time and what they measure doesn't always make sense.  Some managers are clearly in position due to friendships and politics as opposed to brains and hard work.

pros: Plenty of room to grow and move up, great opportunities to make good money if you perform well. People around you are great and are always very helpful. Most are more helpful than management when it comes to helping you do your job.
cons: Training program for my position was total crap. You'll get many clients furious before you ever figure out what you are doing which is months down the line from when you actually start. It's a total client service call center position, didn't ever feel like my position had value. Also, no a sales role  but they push you to make 'sales' that you aren't really getting compensated for.

pros: Great company culture. Most employees are obviously happy to be here.  Vacation and benefits are decent.  Some flexibility with scheduling. My performance reviews were always positive. Also I received some  decent training the 1st 3 months of employment. Job is kind of cushy and I don't ever feel over worked or too stressed.  Fitness center on site for only $10/ month
cons: Pay is low for the industry. no bonuses and raises are low to non-existent (1%). Working remotely is denied by upper management. Overtime often denied or frowned upon by management. Lots of "restructuring" all the time which results in layoffs and employees being shuffled around often. Bank of America does not care about individual employees at all. You truly are just a number here

review_title: Good place to work, but promotions are very slow
pros: good environment, good culture, consistent amazing financial results (but not trickling down), decent pension (but not the best in the market), healthcare for the whole family, decent pay (but a lot of places pay much better), good people in the right places. A lot of training, plenty of opportunities to move laterally (but not up). 25 days holidays (which is probably standard). They look after employees (but don't promote easily). A lot of employee assistance programs. Fantastic office technology. The overall experience is priceless.
cons: Promotions take ages (you're better off in London than in Dublin, or leave, get experience, title and money, and come back a notch or two higher). Annual pay rises aren't great, pension contribution could be better (not market leading), bonuses are average, no car allowance. If you stay long, you'll be undervalued.

pros: I loved the people I worked with and felt that there was great support for career growth with in the company.  I felt that I had management support in my day to day job duties as well as with my career goals.  The benefits were great and there was a good work/life balance.
cons: I felt the salaries were not comprable to the market for senior level line employees or middle management.  The entry level positions paid fairly well and the Senior Management positions seemed to be compensated accordingly, but the middle management salaries were extremely low.

review_title: Excellent bonuses, no time to spend
pros: Empowerment to perform my job and excellent bonus package.  The job was challenging and everyday was a whirlwind of activity for which you were paid a lower than market base pay but pheonominal bonuses at the end of the year.  Our department was structured so that there were fewer layers of management so getting immediate answers on what we could do or couldn't do was only one person away.  All top management was available with an open door policy.  Management welcomed "thinking outside the box" and creative structering  in order to get a loan closed.  Very exciting and great comraderie amoung the group.
cons: No life outside of the job.  You had to be available via blackberry 24/7.

review_title: I am very disappointed with how Bank of America treats its employees.
pros: To acquire training and experience. They have very good training programs and online lessons.
cons: They say that they pay overtime; however, the Branch Manager instead gives you time off for the overtime hours. You usually ended up working for more than 40 hours a week without being compensated for all the overtime because the time off given is only half a day ( 4 hours) for each Saturday you work.   For example, in my branch we would get half a day off for working Saturdays from 8:30am to 1:30pm without a lunch break. However, we ended up leaving at about 2:30pm to 3:00pm on most Saturdays and only got a half a day off. In addition, sometimes we got only the morning off until 12:00pm instead of the afternoon.

job_title: Sales Support Associate in Atlanta, GA
pros: Bnak of America has some of the best benefits (high on health and dnetal insurance).  However, they do provide some flexibility for work/life balance more than other company's do.
cons: Advancement opprtunities are sometimes based more on who you know than what you know.  I must admit we as employees must network to get where would like to go in the company, but associates near the bottom of the barrel in terms of decision making are not always fully aware of opportunities within the company.  Because of that fact many people stay in positions too long with out knowing how to advance.

pros:
Opportunity to work at a very large company. 
Great benefits with matching 401k, 12 weeks paternity/metering leave, 10 holidays off a year plus more-than-average number of vacation days. 
Benefitial performance review process. 
Excellent opportunity for career growth.
cons: The Bank is sometimes portrayed negatively in the press, which prompts questions from family and friends.  Being a large company it is also a place that is driven by internal politics, which can be a hindrance until you adjust to the culture.

review_title: Horrible company enables poor management to target good employees
pros: Benefits are good but pricey, Many diversity groups, always promoting volunteering in the local community.
cons: Management is enabled to target hard working good employees. They claim the associates have a voice and they say there is a no retaliation policy but it's not true. Suggestions made by employees that actually do the work are brushed aside for ideas of grandeur by management that knows nothing about the functions the associates perform. Management is not required or even advised to learn how to do the functions of the teams they are managing. They look down on people that help their peers. Recognition is not given where due, but rather to associates that brown nose the management. Hard work is not rewarded but kissing up is.

pros: Salary and benefit package was good; co-workers were good people and pleasant to work with; location was a convenient commute
cons: Too large to care about customers or employees; senior people in the wrong positions; decisions seem to take forever, yet projects must be completed at warp speed; too many last-minute projects and directives; too much stress; too little work-life balance; the culture values diversity but doesn't consider workers over 50 to be a part of that diversity (affinity groups for LGBT and every ethnic group under the sun, but no affinity group for older workers, or any interest from the company in starting one); the "hurry up" culture grinds people to pulp

review_title: Good place to work in terms of the people & culture, but lacking in career advancement/compensation.
job_title: Business Analyst in New York, NY
pros: Most people are respectful and courteous. Collaboration does occur. Recognition of your efforts occur.
cons: Although the culture has started to shift towards recognizing employees for their work efforts, it's still not effective as the recognition is not coupled with appropriate compensation. The proverbial "pat on the back" is basically what one gets for their efforts. Training/skill development appears to be lacking. There's a heavy reliance on "E-Learning". I don't see as much investment in the employees as compared to other firms.

pros: Child care reimbursement up to about $2800 per year per child if using a formal day care provider.  This money is tax free up to $5000.  If you have a couple kids and must use a daycare this is an unbelievable benefit. Also 3 month paid paternity leave.
cons: Constant sales pressure; however the goals are not unreasonable.  Employee turnover is reasonably high at banking branches.  Branches being closed every year reducing the amount of management positions available as displaced managers are relocated.  Health insurance provider (Aetna) is mediocre, out of pocket costs are too high.  There are HSA programs to help with this somewhat.

pros: Very talented people at all levels.  Good processes in place.  Reasonable pay and benefits.  Good training opportunities.  Encouraged to give back to the community through volunteering time and matching monetary gifts to charity.
cons: Expectations are very high, almost un-achievable.  People are expected to work long hours without question.  Everything is highest priority. Layoffs happen so often, employees feel like on any day they could be gone with no warning.   Culture is one of making everyone else look bad so you'll look good.  Promotions happen very rarely - people are brought in from outside instead. Ocassional demotions of large numbers of people to align to a metric.

review_title: Aggressive sales, better pay at a car lot.
pros: Okay benefits and vacation time.
cons: Vacation days are dictated as to when they can be taken,  very sales oriented, layoffs occurring, compensation is extremely low for the amount of job duties being added to associates due to many other departments being closed.  Short staffed everywhere.  Always worried and threatened about not meeting sales and referral goals, very stressful.  Employee turnover rate is extremely high and employee morale is low.

pros: You will be surrounded by some of the best, brightest and sophisticated people in the industry. Management keeps you on your toes and mentally sharp. Salary is one of the highest in the industry too. When you leave you are well and over prepared for other jobs.
cons: No work life balance. Training program is non. It is a do-it-yourself learning experience. You figure it out on your own type of thing. No learning curb what so ever. You will also be held liable for mistakes from your predecessor and things you were not trained for.  Company's HR is a joke when it comes to internal bullying investigation.

pros: There are some nice customers that you get to know and gain relationships with. Technology is modern and stays up to date.
cons: I have been a teller at Bank of America for over a year and I used to love it. Now the bank is taking a horrible turn! I work at a busy branch and they only allow one teller to work at a time because of labor cuts. It's overwhelming for me and customers are all very mad and rude when they get to my window. They also expect us to keep customer service ratings up and high sales goals with one teller running everything. It's impossible!! Overall, management doesn't care about employees or customers. It's a super high stress job for not much pay.

review_title: **Used to be great place to work..."
pros: Good Benefits, Strong 4o1K plan, Excellent Structure, There are a few great Sr. Leaders in some departments.
cons:
Don't really care about Diversity. Claim to be diverse by pushing Affinity Groups but when it comes  to actions you'll see promotions are given and people are moved to jobs without the role being posted. The Affinity Groups are there to hide their true lack of Diversity. The Diversity Groups are just for 'show' for the Bank to get on "Top Diversity" lists. 
There are some true great leaders but most have been let go and the others secretly will provide advice. May of the Sr Leaders that stay are the ones that drink the koolaid and force their teams to do the same.

pros: Working from home full-time was an option when I was there.  They will pay for your related work from home expenses and professional license renewals.  Decent benefits.  They encourage volunteering.  Very big company so there are a ton of different business units where you could potentially work.
cons: Very heavy on process management for software implementations.  The Release Management process for a Project Manager is a near full-time job in itself and the rules change frequently.  Very big company so they move slowly in getting changes to market.

review_title: Amazing Upward Mobility, Use as Foot-In-Door
job_title: Financial Solutions Advisor in New York, NY
pros:
Great way to get in the door to showcase your expertise. Real and competitive base salary (no gimmicky draw or loans). 5% 401k match, 3 months paid paternal leave, 5 weeks paid vacation, 11 paid bank holidays, 5 paid personal days, 5 paid sick days, and a partirage in a pear tree. Upward mobility into Merrill Lynch Global Wealth Management, US Trust and the Private Bank, and other higher positions at Edge. 
-Clients walking-in*. 
-Back-office is always there to assist (but limited, see below). 
-True autonomy, and you don't answer to the management of the actual branches (see below)
-Week 4 of training is in Charlotte - they fly you there, pay for your hotel, and give you a healthy per diem
-Our research is one of the best, if not the best, in the industry
cons:
-Teller takes a million dollar check deposit, but can't refer to you
-If you do outbound calls, there is a high probability it will adversely affect your comp
-Your goals are always changing, and is often terribly communicated from management
-Incentives are incredibly low compared to industry standard
-Call the back-office and get a different answer every time / very few are accountable/takes ownership of your issue
-Compliance is known as the sales prevention department and will reject a perfectly suitable client proposal
-*You live and die by your bankers, the referrals come, but are coming from unlicensed bankers who have their own idea of what you do / don't really understand what you do
-*Bankers have too much political control of the branches, so if they don't like you, start looking for another job
-Morning huddles are stressed during training, but are completely depressing and a complete waste of your time

review_title: small business credit card specialist II
job_title: Small Business Specialist in Tampa, FL
pros: Good benefits, such as vacation time, sick time
cons: You will see new people all the time (because no body like to be there) and as you have new people they don't know what they are doing, so you have to fix people's mistakes all the time. The hold time for clients is absurd (at least 30 mts) so when you get them over the phone they are extremely upset (of course). Opportunities?? puff they tell you that you will have tons of opportunities to advance but that is a lie.. they want you to be there so they can have "an experts" they always find a reason to keep you in the same spot.

review_title: Bank of America: "We look really, really, good on your resume"
job_title: Senior Customer Service Representative in San Francisco, CA
pros: Hands down, the best reasons to work for Bank of America would be their benefits. Benefits include but are not limited to a 401(k) that matches 5% of your salary, a pension plan, medical, dental, vision, long term disability,tuition reimbursement, maternity leave, paternity leave,voluntary time off, purchased time off, vacation, flexible health care accounts, and they extend benefits to domestic partners.
cons: Some of the downsides of working at Bank of America include but are not limited to only having a 30 minute meal period, promotions sometimes based on seniority and favorites, and a lack of teamwork.

job_title: Teller Operations Specialist in Seattle, WA
pros: Bank of American has a great benefit package.  There's good internal organizational communication, and it is a respected company that works on many community initiatives.
cons: Process of moving up can be slow and difficult if you start as a teller (regardless of experience/education), but this tends to vary greatly by region.  The Pacific Northwest is notorious for hiring through word of mouth instead of through actual applicants (which means networking is vital).    Once an employee begins as a teller, regardless of what education they have completed before or since then - or previous experience - they are required to go through each successive position one at a time, even when their education or experience is equivalent to management level work, which makes moving up a slow process.

review_title: With shrewd career management, you can do well here...
job_title: Middle Market Underwriter in Chicago, IL
pros: The Bank operates on a global scale which provides nearly unlimited opportunities for career advancement...line of business diversification and strong capital position allows the Bank to whether cyclical downturns which lessens the odds of layoffs...job opportunities are easy to find all the way from entry level to mid-level managers...benefits are not cheap, but are widely available...if you work hard and make yourself relevant to your line of business, you will most likely be successful...
cons: Global scale makes the individual feel small...difficult to differentiate yourself at times...getting information about other lines of business for the purpose of career advancement is difficult...the environment is ever-changing...despite overall financial strenght, layoffs seem happen at the whim of the market sometimes rather than as good business practice...

job_title: AML Operations Specialist in Chicago, IL
pros: They provide a good starting salary for professionals hired directly out of university.  In my department, the culture is very easygoing -- we work forty hours a week and not a minute more, which is good for work-life balance.
cons: They're very cheap when it comes to paying for continuing professional development, office supplies, necessary travel, etc.  (even before the current downturn in the banking sector).  They pay a lot of lip service to "quality of life programs" such as flexible work weeks, telecommuting, child care assistance, etc. but most of these programs seem to exist only on paper.

review_title: BAC stock dive for a reason
job_title: Product Marketing Manager in Charlotte, NC
pros: Ok salary and benefits.  Immediate manager balances life/work but this may vary.
cons:
Large corporation with much politics. Recent news indicates many Execs not being truthful with the employees and public about merger with Merrill Lynch.
Ecommerce area is so behind the times. Grows by acquisition and not much organically. Need to hire folks who understand software development, requirements, user needs. Much self promotion and opinion with lack of data.  Amazing how some got to where they are (which proves its who you know and not what you know).  Recent massive layoffs in ecommerce handled poorly and new Execs didn't even notify the associates ahead of time.  Multiple law suits against BAC and they want you to sign letter saying you will not be part of them to get severance.  How unethical.

review_title: Thumbs up on the call center.
job_title: Customer Service Representative in Greensboro, NC
pros: Co-workers in the call center are great to work with. The call center management team is more fair and reasonable than in other call centers where I've worked.  They help train you so that you're constantly improving and not making the same mistakes again.  If you want to work in other departments of the call center, they are open to trying to get you cross-trained there.  Benefits are pretty good for part-time workers, whereas in other call centers this is not offered.
cons: When changes are made, it takes a while for us to communicate them to the customer. We often need to bounce them around to various departments. Sometimes the phone connections go out in the middle of the call, but they don't give us the ability to call the customer back, we just get the next call.

review_title: Good corporate culture, but tough to move upwards
job_title: Technical Project Manager in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Great company programs, such as working from home. Lots of other "bennies" such as discounts to all kinds of things. Good people and good comraderie amongst work groups. Good support structure for getting your job done - technical tools, training, reference information and support teams.
cons: Unless you are "favored", the odds of moving up a level are very low. And that part is subjective, depending on how your manager and the next two levels of manager like to operate.

review_title: Its been an interesting experience over the past few years
pros: The benefits are definitely above par, and also it is nice to get those bank holidays that no-one else does :). If you have a good team and good management it makes going to work a lot easier. There is definitely room for professional growth and movement within your division if you are a top performer.
cons: I work in consumer banking - so I'm at a branch that is open to the public. I really wish the hours weren't so long. Sometimes I am literally at work for 10 or 11 hours straight - and I feel like I've gotten little or nothing accomplished .

review_title: Great place to develop a career.
pros:
Great benefits - affordable health, vision, dental
Above average 401k plan
Excellent vacation / personal time
Quality management
Global Brand
Outstanding training and education available
cons: Constant change, a new executive will come into power and things will change drastically to the "new" vision.  Quite often this "new" vision is exactly how things work before the previous manager, so there is a constant cycle of going back to old ways so that upper management can put on their resume that they were "champions of change."  Change is good, but like anything if you put consistent focus on prizing something it becomes change simply for the sake of changing.

job_title: IT Security Analyst in Dallas, TX
pros: Fairly good compensation, many lovely colleagues, great benefits and fairly normal work life balance. In my area we rarely had to take work home with us or work overtime.
cons: Management is some of the worst I have seen. Being my first experience with the Bank I expected at the very minimum to have an experienced manager. What I got was someone who had never led a team our size and who makes decisions (even compensation related ones) based on gut feelings, impressions  and preference. It’s odd that the folks who shared a beer with him were given all the best positions in the team.

review_title: Great benefits; job security iffy if associate is within LAS division.  Mid-management leaves much to be desired.
pros: Benefits are awesome including vacation and medical.   Access to training is great.
cons:
Job security is an issue.  Bank is closing down a number of positions and buildings in Ventura County.  Competition for limited number of available jobs is stiff.
Management and interpersonal skills of mid-level and upper level management leaves much to be desired.  People can be treated unfairly and in a less than professional mannner.  Upper management does not get involved to resolve the issues the lack of skills produce.  Everything is focused on profit, profit, profit and improving their stock values for shareholders.  Thus their focus is backward, short-sighted and unproductive.

pros: My work environment is vary laid back and no pressure as long as you complete your work before deadlines. Coworkers are great and have been able to meet some really smart people. The company is very diverse
cons: not able to move up the ladder as easy as its all about who you know, not what you know. Sometimes the departments can seem very "cliqueish" either you're liked or simply not liked and not given the same growth or learning opportunity as the others. Wanting to move around the company is nearly impossible

pros: Good pay, good people (may not always be the case with such a big company), good benefits.  The Bank takes care of their people (for the most part), especially those they deem as talent.  Be willing to grow professionally, work hard, find out what peers do well, and do it better.
cons: Biggest Con is that the Bank's "diversity and inclusion" flies in the face of Christian values.  Specifically, donating to Planned Parenthood, supporting LGTB, and others.  No support or donations to Christian organizations that I know of.

pros: The pay and benefits is fare
cons: They micro manage everything and everyone. To get certify on anything they are way too strict, worse then in college and management always have favoritism towards friend, best of friends, people they know from outside of work and family members. Moving up in the ladder is not best on how good you maybe on what you do but more on who they seem to like and who they know more personality.

review_title: Relationship manager/personal banker. Not what it used to be.
job_title: Relationship Manager in San Antonio, TX
pros: Good pay and great benefits. Paid vacation/sick leave. 4 months of maternity leave, paid leave of absence, holiday pay, Sunday's off, half day Saturday work days, childcare and tuition reimbursement, 401k, etc.
cons: Work and life balance can be challenging at times due to late or early meetings. Pressure and stress. Upper management doesn't seem to care about you as an individual but cares more about how you're going to get more sales. It's getting to the point where the stress isn't left at work and instead is carried on at home. We're told that we must our "rent" by generating sales.

pros: Very stable company; solid benefits (beside compensation); PTO is quite good
cons:
1. Absolutely horrible management from lower to upper middle - Bad management styles, managers have very little experience with anything other than basic operations; managers have very poor style of dealing with subordinates; managers have very little understanding of what is going on in their organizations because of poor communication, poor relationship with their full organization; Whole bank industry and company is incredibly incestual with senior managers
2. Salary compensation is absolutely horrid for any company of this magnitude - earnings have been much better since '08 but BoA has gotten away with such poor pay since the Great Recession and they haven't made any attempt to come up to market standards
3. Insanely bureaucratic 
4. Way of doing business is embarrassing from the inside

review_title: Your experience will depend on the position.
pros: Pretty standard benefits.  3 months paid parental leave for new babies.
cons: It's an enormous company, so there are many experiences one can have.  Some lines of business have career growth/opportunity/potential, but it's not as true for the technical jobs.  Tech jobs are under constant budget scrutiny and you can spend a decade there with no sense of "job security".  People get laid off every year due to the usual reasons - downsizing, automation, outsourcing, and other efficiency improvements.

review_title: Stressful sales-driven company but offers great benefits
job_title: Financial Center Manager in Columbia, SC
pros: Great training, good bonuses if you can reach your goals, mostly great people that you can stress with together, leader in digital/mobile banking
cons: Terminated for something I was taught by management to increase revenue. Was never told it was wrong, was never told not to do it, and when finally notified I immediately stopped. After Wells Fargo incident they began cracking down heavily on ethics and I was one of three managers that got let go. I was "made an example of" in my opinion. Spotless record, leading branch manager in the market, leading in customer service scores, but none of that mattered in the end.

pros: Very easy to hit your goal. Since I was working at a bank of america that was located in a mall, the foot track was enough to hit all goals.
cons:
Allowing managers to reduce your bonus because of certain things is not fair.  Here you working as hard as possible to handle the influx of traffic , opening accounts, and trying to manage everything else to hit your goal.  Next thing, you get penalize by having them reduce your bonus.  I understand we all need to make sure that everything is sign,  but don't take away from the work that is being done.

Management sometimes can be not understanding when it comes to requesting time off.

pros: Good benefits, great team atmosphere with the people that you see everyday. Unless they are a selfish shark with can happen due to the metrics.
cons: Lackluster training started around thanksgiving and went until mid January. Had several holidays during that time, our mentors had vacation during the time and the process just seemed rushed. They expect you to learn from live interactions but you can’t dictate what comes thru the doors. Middle management only cares about sales goals not actually helping clients. Expectations are egregious, multiple trainings are sent out every week. You are expected to do trainings, stand in the lobby and greet customers as well as a slew of other things. Being bombarded with so much stuff and expected to give optimal customer service.

pros: There is nothing positive about this particular group and the role. Only the head of analytics group and some of its executives aligns with the good direction and company culture that is in place. There are still executives and managers which does not cascade down the right values and company culture principles to their groups.
cons: Terrible management has created a ill company culture that psychologically abuses its employees. There is a very high turn over in the group due to serious management problems such as oppressing employees, shutting down them and psychologically abusing them. More than 5 people leaving within a 6 month period is  example of how unhealthy this place is and how bad management  drives employees out. Executive of this group does not even address these significant management problems  and lets unhealthy management to continue its practices.

pros: The people you directly work with are great, the benefits are solid especially if you have a family but that’s about it
cons: When talking to market managers and higher the problems become apparent. The company wants you to document an asinine amount of info while seeing back to back to back customers and burning yourself out. Unrealistic expectations are placed on employees to turn every sit into a mortgage or a business account - you WILL NOT hit your goals in many cases no matter how hard you try. This is by design, as talking to other RBs and RMs will show you that entire markets are set up to fail. Market managers do not care about your concerns and will blow you off for months - the only time mine cared was when I told him I was on my way out the door. Most importantly, pay is significantly lower than their competitors

review_title: LaSalle was a good place to work but suffered from lack of strategic focus and strong executive leadership.
job_title: Vice President of Finance  in Chicago, IL
pros: Strong brand name in chosen market with a high degree of customer focus.  Compensation and benefits were above average.  Strong financial systems and very good analytical tools.
cons: Foreign owned.   Executive management competancy and leadership was not as good as it could have been.  The company talked about a commitment to work-life balance but did not live up to it.  Organization tended to be in a constant state of flux with numerous reorganizations.  Opportunities to move into different roles were limited and the criteria for promotion/title changes were not consistent across functions or even within functions.   Communication within company was not as good as it could have been.

review_title: Bank of America lacks executive talent to get through the tough times they currently face.
pros: The potential to use the brand and market power of B of A to grow businesses aggressively and innovatively.  The opportunity to work with extremely talented co-workers and teams -- the talent has seemed to gravitate to B of A until recently.
cons: The business isn't banking -- it's integrating acquired companies in full-time fire drill mode.  Ken Lewis is a deal guy and as long as he's in role there will never be a serious move to make the necessary investment in systems and structures to allow organic growth.    Morale is bad and getting worse.  Ken Lewis and some others on his hand-picked team come across as arrogant and mean-spirited.

review_title: Good stable company, but challenging to grow due to sheer size
pros:
- Stability, working thru' retirement 
- Flex-time, work from home options
- Decent medical benefits, vacation, sick-time compared to others.
- Good maternity and paternity policy,
cons:
- Lack of growth, and ability to recognize true talent.
- Too much politics and red-tape
- Performance / Appraisal process is lousy.
- Managers do not do much to grow their employees, but rather look at first their profit, not company's.
- Too much waste of time sometimes on process invention, and reinvention.
- Too many orgs and re-orgs and orgs and re-orgs and orgs and re-orgs.....
- Can be stressful at times...


- HR involvement is joke and is out of picture mostly..

review_title: A company that has lost it’s way and treats employees like commodities.
pros: Stability, generally good internal processes, generally good benefits.
cons: No real pension plan. Low pay.  Large amount of outsourcing.  Focus on maximizing short-term profits and minimizing operational costs harms long-term sustainability.  Difficult to advance.   Internal politics rather than data drive to many moves.

review_title: Overall an excellent position to put on your resume but this was a middle office position
job_title: Financial Analyst in Saint Louis, MO
pros:
*Excellent brand name to put on your resume
*Learn the fundamentals of financial analysis, credit, banking, underwriting & due diligence
*Laid-back and positive environment; not cutthroat at all
*Relatively tame hours for banking (40-50hrs/week)
*Great compensation for the hours
cons:
*Middle office position; no client-facing aspects whatsoever despite the fact that you will be underwriting credit products for some of the Bank's most ultra-high net worth individuals

*No opportunities for vertical advancement; if you want to be client-facing or in the front office, this position should be viewed solely as a launching pad

*Work can be repetitive and at times not challenging enough

review_title: Rancho Cordova, CA site sucks so bad. The words I want to use are offensive and wrong but that's truly how I feel.
job_title: Home Services Specialist II in Rancho Cordova, CA
pros: There are no pros besides the fact that I was employed during that time period of my life.
cons: Upper management and lower management have no true manger skills. They are all puppets agreeing to it all and saying yes at all times. Every year or so they redeploy all associates to new roles and the training is horrible. This site has no commen sense.  A lot of politics and drama.

review_title: micro managed all quality staff out the door
job_title: Teller Operations Specialist in Poughkeepsie, NY
pros: Benefits. Best benefits I have ever had in my working career
cons: They ask you to do too much with too little. They micro manage every minute of the work day and don't allow for unexpected customer interactions or complications. They also make goals extremely difficult to obtain and manage you out instead of coaching you up. They were not like this the entire time I worked there.

pros: benefits, childcare, tuition reimbursement.. .discount store with merchants.
cons: No time management.... You're suppose to be scheduling your entire day but pushed to speed everything up. Customers yell at you for being understaffed and you have to take it. No lunches or breaks ever anymore.

job_title: Strategic Management and Product Development and Management in New York, NY
pros:
Great benefits package and competitive pay for healthcare, 401K, and vacation time. 

An abundance of systems and software to facilitate your work when needed. 

Great environment for learning quickly and developing career skills to make you competitive
Daily easy to get promoted 
Opportunities to collaborate with different teams if strongly desired 
Great community volunteer opportunities
cons:
POLITICAL and bureaucratic to the highest degree 
Lack of transparency from management at times 
Definitely not a system meritocracy 
Promoted often with lack of alignment of pay
Poor transparency into bonus awards and methodology
Poor system integration at times 
Poor mentorship
Rigorous work hours with lack of compensation to support it. 
Competitive environment with little reward for hard work and little acknowledgement of individual accomplishments if you have the wrong manager

pros: As a BOFA employee, you will receive great benifits like HSA, 401k matching and platinum status. I noticed other companies will offer discounts, status has to be earned. At BOFA, you earned your status by being a valued employee.
cons: If you are at or close to top pay when transferring positions, you may not get a pay increase at the time of hire. You will have to wait for a cost of living pay increase at year end.

pros: great benefits, best I've ever had. Great medical, dental, vision for employee and family, 401k, pension, corporate discount program, and volunteer hours.
cons:
Team managers aren't really trained as managers. They're just thrown into positions, and for the most part, most of them are ill-prepared to MANAGE.  They tend to be good at front line support, but are not actual managers and this can lead to various levels of HR issues. Team Manager roles are sold as stepping stones and the pay reflects that.

Although benefits are top notch, pay leaves much to be desired.

review_title: Challenging place to work- but big changes ahead
job_title: Senior Vice President  in Atlanta, GA
pros: Dominant bank in the industry that allows you to see many different deals and opportunities with clients. Technology systems available to associates- numerous employees discounts and offers.  If you can play the game you can have a long career- but when they are through with you watch out.  Stressful work environment with above average competition to impress others.
cons: Very large organization and sometimes hard to navigate.  Talent planning system is broken as well as the internal job posting system. HR is non responsive and generally ineffective.  Recruiters don't provide timely return calls and there is no follow up after interviews- this occurs for both internal and external candidates.

review_title: Just a paycheck...could be alot worse
pros: Large Umbrella so you can do many different things. If you get tired with one group you could move to another group. The drawback is once you are in, you will never get a competitive wage to bring you up to market rate. Because the bank is made up of so many legacy banks there are many people doing the same job that get paid vastly different sums of money. This is unfair and builds resentment for associates that are in the same roll.
cons: Management talks a good game but bottom line we are just tools in the machine. They do not have Higher Standards. The bank is too political. You are not recognized for doing a good job, you are recognized for bieng political

pros: If you like working with people this is a good job because youre constantly interacting with customers. It doesnt take long to learn the basics because the job is very repetitive. For the most part its chill as long as you make sure you give and receive the correct amount of cash. The pay is good, and you get a nice amount of sick and vacation days.
cons: Tellers are pressured to push bank products on the customers . There isnt much room for advancement and the only way you get a raise is to advance to the next position.

review_title: Company too big for it's own good!
job_title: Senior Financial Analyst in Charlotte, NC
pros: There isn't anything positive to say about working for this company. Compensation is either at par or below what market demands.
cons: Low pay compared to rest if industry, Huge office politics hurdle. As an employee, you have a lot to prove, but management not flexible and not willing to help adjust, or provide adequate training. Management always too busy in meetings. Long hours for low pay. Good deeds go unnoticed, bad deeds remain as a stain on your record forever.

review_title: The changes Bank of America has made to Countrywide continue to be positive, but further changes are needed.
job_title: Business Analyst in Simi Valley, CA
pros: The home loan division of B.A.C. is undergoing a major culture shift and many positive changes are in process.  It is a good place to get started and learn a skill, but you will need to move on to get paid market rate.
cons:
Some Managers are very supportive and helpful and show appreciation to exceptional employees.  Other managers are very negative, expect you to work over time for free and no amount of work is ever enough.
Bottom line, if your manager does not push for you in your career, you will be overlooked and underpaid.

pros: Moderate salaries and bonuses with secure employment so this is the best place for employees who are not aggressive about career advancement or pay hikes.
cons: A laid back attitude that comes from the Retail culture which is uncommon in an Investment Bank.  In this economy, Bank of America employs 100 employees for the job of 50.  So, there is obviously too much politics to deal with in this organization which creates an unprofessional enviornment to work.

pros: Lots of branches so opportunities are there.   Goals aren't that hard to meet vs. other banks
cons: Lots of politics...  Favoritism...  Empty promises.  Constant fear of verbal and written warnings.  Bad management that will keep you from advancing.  Great talent being left out.  Lots of inner circles.  Lots of fake workers who only thinks for themselves.

pros: Good benefits, great 401K with matching funds!
cons: Too many org changes.  Changing every 6 to 9 to 12 months does not give management enough time to make meaningful changes that could turn a department or line of business around. Additionally, there have been a lot of layoffs this year which had people on edge and worried about coming to work on Wednesdays as all the layoffs occur on Wednesday.  Some are even calling Wednesday: WOW - meaning Walk Out Wednesday.

review_title: So far I've made a considerably quick climb from contractor to FTE as a VP.
pros: Little to no micro-management, distributed work environment, flexible work location, average salary, average benefits.
cons:
Bonuses have plenty of room for growth, salary could definitely improve when compared to other banks.  Health/Medical benefits are inferior to other smaller companies (i.e. Coca-Cola).  You'd expect benefits at BoA to be top-notch (i.e.: no co-pay, very low deductibles), not the case.

Employee performance reviews allow very little room for feedback from managers.  Their only choices are 1) employee sucks, 2) employee is OK and 3) employee is awesome.  Nothing in between can be reported.

review_title: Easy to move up in company!
pros: The ability to communicate with one another in different banking centers. The management I had as a teller was AMAZING! The bonuses and gifts I received (as a teller when I first started). I moved up in the company very quickly.
cons: Sales and Service specialist are like the Ginny pigs of Bank of America. We do everything (banker, greeted, open/close bank, supervisor exceptions, and teller) with little pay. They push sales terribly. Employees aren't greatly appreciated for all the hard work. No recognition from anyone outside banking center. Too many double standards. Poor bankers hate life... I've seen people sick even coming to work. Better training.. Or downtown or time aside to train.

review_title: B of A perks going away
job_title: Operations and Applications Support in Sylmar, CA
pros: The biggest pro was the My Work program where they encouraged IT people to start working from home.  In fact I was forced to start working from home over 5 years ago.  It turned out to be a really valuable perk as I soon was required to be available for my aging parents.
cons: The are making people on the My Work program return to large banking centers.  Back to the cubicle farms!

job_title: Loan Modification Underwriter in Elk Grove, CA
pros: Some of the pros for working for Bank of America are, 3 weeks paid vacation, great benefits (including adoption assistance program),  Unlimited overtime potential, and a friendly work environment.  With my experience, management had always listened to my feedback and tried to make as many adjustments within reason.
cons: They did implement quite a bit of mandatory overtime which included 10 hour shifts as well as Saturdays.  Compliance training was endless and could use some restructuring to make it more interesting.  Guides were sometimes written poorly which would cause major confusion.  Other then these few cons, Bank of America overall was a great company to work for

job_title: Bank Teller in Williston Park, NY
pros: The bank hours allowed for a good balance between work and family. Great for college kids who need flexibilty and are majoring in business, accounting or finance. The company offered tuition reimbursement for related studies. Great products and friendly customers. Management varies depending on branches but overall friendly.
cons: Pressure from nanagement to promote products to every customer even though they have a long history with the bank and have checking/savings accounts already. Closing of branches leads to relocation to where ever they feel like sending you. In the three years I was wiith the company I was relocated 3 times with any options or enough time to prepare.

review_title: The good, the bad, the ugly...
pros: If you find the right department, it can be a good place to work.
cons: Not stable within certain departments. They go thru times of bringing on a lot of employees and in time they have workforce reductions. It's not unusual for many of the fellow employees I've talked with that have been there long term to have been laid off numerous times within their tenure. High pressure, high stress, every position turns into a sales position even if they say we want to help our customers, they really mean we want to have all their money and have them owe us money too, meaning loans.

review_title: Always Changing & Not Always for the Best
pros: Fast paced, good benefits, technical people
cons: No longer allowed to Work from Home after almost 8 years. SR Management makes these off the wall decisions out of nowhere, no work gets done in those small cubes. Upper management are not always helpful. No work-life balance and too much red tape for simple things to get accomplished

review_title: Make sure you're going to stay here
pros:
Team is full of talented developers, with a wide variety of experience to draw from. 
You can work from home every so often.
They offer training in their technology stack.
If you are interested in finance, then the job will grant exposure to many areas.
Competitive starting salary for a Graduate developer.
cons:
Internal technology is not great. If you want to only work for BoA for the rest of your life, this isn't a problem.
Lots of politics involved in the development and release process.
Communication between international teams. Leads to a "us vs them" mentality. 
TONS of websites are blocked (which is understandable but it's still a Con). 
More meetings than development.

job_title: Senior Account Manager in Simi Valley, CA
pros: So far health & 401k benefits are good.  I was fortunate to have a supporting manager & peers and was welcomed well after being moved to a new department.  Training associates, they offer a lot of online classes to enhance your knowledge and be on the loop.  We always do a weekly huddle, so communication wise between associate & management is good.
cons: The only downside is once your department has able to do well they will try to move your department to out of state. Which is understanble coz cost wise they will be able to save a lot on that. You will be training people who will be replaced on your job.

pros: Benefits! Especially if you have young children(child care reimbursement), looking to adopt(adoption subsidy), or having a baby(4 months PAID maternity AND paternity leave offered). Affordable healthcare even if covering more than just yourself. Very inclusive atmosphere within the company. Able to move to many different areas within the company and still retain sonority which in many departments still counts for something.
cons: Always a risk of layoff. Very possible to move desks, building locations, managers, and possibly even job duties often. Basically don't get comfortable with anything as it can change at any time. The pay can be lower, and in some instances much lower, than the industry standard. Management may or may not know much about what your job position entails as BOA tends to shuffle mangers from one department to another. Work from home options or flex schedules are virtually eliminated.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Fort Worth, TX
pros: Good benefits, decent salary, pretty flexible with schedule. Work from  home is available, but not for the department that I worked in.  There is opportunity to move within or around the company with or without a degree.  I was there for over 11 years, but was laid off. Overall, pretty good experience.
cons: Mid level management didn't offer a lot of support, could definitely communicate more.  Working  in the banking/finance isn't the most stable form  employment right now.

pros: Professional environment makes it easy to focus on how to grow rather than if your manager will call you lazy and drop F-bombs to start your day.
cons: Not a clear path for growth with way too much emphasis on things that don't matter. More often than not it seems management spend their time in the office running reports about reports that tell us nothing beyond what is obvious. And if you should ask a question, you end up getting some nicely worded political answer that gives many words with no actual substance. This leads to the unsaid consensus that being in a management position is more about who you know than the merit of your leadership.

review_title: GT&O is a real outdated dog
job_title: Product Manager, Technology in New York, NY
pros: generous PTO at VP level
cons:
*comp/bonus  for top skill technologists is  extremely uncompetetive 
*internal tech talent is consequently unmotivated/ lazy/ has outdated skills
* the only ppl that stick around are  H1B visa slaves who can't move 
*company is really behind on agile transformation
*no fresh talent,  outdated dinosaur old-timers with outdated skills hang around like albatross around neck  and prevent any good progress
*applications and  technologies are outdated, 15+ years beyond expiration date
* sad looking tech offices that have not been revamped or renovated in last 15 years
* average IQ of thech workers here is equivalent to that of MickeyD servers

review_title: Decent place to work, easy to get into, money is good.
pros: Bank of America has some of the best benefits I have seen. Their medical plans are low cost both on premiums and deductibles. The same can be said for their dental and their vision plans. They offer tuition, adoption, and child care reimbursement.  Overall, they try their best, there is a ton of employee networks and engagement activities. I have worked for other financial institutions, Bank of America did pay the best.
cons: Work wise, they are a production shop. For entry/mid level positions it is a numbers game. Perform or be put on corrective action. Moving up can be difficult because from my personal experience it is more who you know not how you perform.  Even with the pay being higher than competitors it can feel unworthy of the expectations.

pros: Great Atmosphere, the compensation they offer and great benefits. They take the time to find out what your needs and wants are.  You feel like you are part of a team.  It is great to work for a company that makes you feel as if your opininon matters and that they are not going to take what you have to say and cast it aside.  It is important to feel like you make a difference and working for them makes you feel just that way.
cons: Sometimes can feel like they micrmagange.  Employees need to feel like they can do the job that they are assigned to do and not feel like you are being watched all the time.

review_title: Not the worst job I've had...
pros: If you are a student, there is more flexibility with your schedule than with other employer. We are put through extensive training, which does help when applying for other jobs. The pay is decent, but not in comparison to what other customer service reps make.
cons: If you do something wrong, be prepared to hear about it constantly and from numerous managers. But when you do something well, chances are no one will take notice. There is a serious lack of communication when changes are made. It seems like you onloy get promoted if you brown nose and suck up. Can't wait to finish school and leave this company behind.

review_title: I am in the PMD program, and the stress level is extremely high.
pros: You are paid a salary for the full 3 years of the program. Merrill has strong name recognition. The research department is top notch. The technology is outstanding.
cons: You must meet quarterly and annual production hurdles, which are outrageously high. If you don't pass your securities licensing tests, you get fired. If you don't meet your production hurdles on time, you get fired. All of the training is reading. Good luck finding someone to mentor you. No good financial advisor has the time or the desire to share their secrets with you. You must build your business from scratch. You are not given any leads. Most of the advisors in my office have either been in the business for 20+ years or have a wealthy family with wealthy friends. You are not going to get on a team until you have a sizeable book. Other advisors are not going to give up any of their compensation to put your on their team. I am afraid of losing my job every day because I am barely meeting the production numbers. I don't feel professional because I have not even been given an office yet. I have been in a cubicle since I started a year ago, and there are several empty offices at my location. I have to meet with my prospects in the conference room. The whole situation is very discouraging.

review_title: Bank of America is a good place to work, but not much room for growth
job_title: Teller Operations Specialist in Bakersfield, CA
pros: Bank of  America is a large company, so it is easy to relocate to a different location.
cons: Downsides include  job promotions are limited. Seems to be a bit unfair especially when it comes to being bi-langual. I always lose out on a promotion due to the fact that I am not bi-langual even though I do feel that I meet qualifications better.

pros: Time off.  As a personal banker you get 3 weeks vacation, 10 paid holidays and 10 sick days even though they make you feel guilty when using them.  There are great benefits as well but you have to be here for a year before you receive them.  Also, there are a ton of banking centers so for the most part you work relatively close to home.
cons: Scheduling time off.  It's like pulling teeth.  You have to schedule 6 months in advance when most people don't know what's going on next week.  There is a lot of focus on everything that we did not do well, they micro manage all the negative things instead of focusing on the positive or building in a positive way.  It's a lot of smoke and mirrors when senior management is around.

pros:
- Formal Work From Home program for technology associates.
- Lots of education and training opportunities from training portal.
- Limited travel required for most jobs - teams highly virtual across the world.
- Adding a 401Roth option for 2013.
cons:
Decreasing associate benefits
- Freeze / hold on pay increases
- Decreasing bonuses
- Pension plan retired
- Changing health plan with higher associate up front expenses
- Limited associate banking and loans programs - benefits are not very significant.
- No Stock Ownership Plan

job_title: Support Services Specialist in Hunt Valley, MD
pros: there's plenty of parking and the benefits are pretty good.
cons: lots of overtime with no care or understanding from management if you have outside of work issues, the building is a complete dump, the computers are old and inadequate, the computer programs crash constantly, bank of america has invested almost no money to upgrade anything, your co-workers will just ignore you, you'll get no support from management, most of the managers have never been a processor. the list goes on and on. its a factory mill of workers then churn and burn you until there's nothing left. i would only recommend this job if it is the only opportunity you have. even then be warned.

pros: Excellent staff at the middle management level and below, flexible work schedule available
cons: Leadership is full of words but no actions, doesn't value hard work or loyalty, too many cliques, requires "managing up" (aka sucking up) to get ahead.

pros: In addition to BOA being a very reputable company, they hire great people, offer great benefits, promote opportunity, and try to promote a good work/life balance. They also provide great training for new positions and make you feel as if you are a part of a family.
cons: While the management staff identifies outstanding associates, they tend to "loan" individuals to various positions rather than promote which can be discouraging when applying for other positions within the company. Also, the salary increases and bonuses have become very low to none for certain departments.

review_title: You will end up getting laid off
pros: Benefits are good. Vacation is 3 weeks and you can purchase a 4th week if wanted.
cons: Management doesn't really know what they are doing or care about the employees although they pretend too.  The sick occurrence rule is bad. I was told when I first started if you are sick take at least 2 days off at a time. I didn't understand why but once you are there you will get it. 5 occurrences within a rolling year is ridicules. Polices about how you do you job are non-productive, seems that it is more important to do all of their silly steps is much more important that doing the job right. They say they care about the customer but they really don't.

review_title: Great benefits, but only care about sales
pros: The benefits are the best reason to work here. Even part time employees receive full benefits. I enjoyed working with the other tellers and girls behind the counter.
cons: Corporate doesn't care about how bad their managers are. We lose customers and don't get new customers because of our manager. Our center is always understaffed, and the customers constantly complain. Tellers are not rewarded at our center by our manager for doing a great job with customers, we are just questioned as to why we didn't get a sale. Bank of America is not a small town bank, they only care about selling there products.

pros: The benefits are pretty good here from medical, discounts you get for working there, transportation is covered. Competitive pay for the part time needs.
cons: Opportunity for growth is minimal you can only move up if somebody moves out, varying schedules, extremely long work days, some up to 13 hours! No matter how you are hired in, even if you are better qualified for a better position in the company you have to excel at the job you have first before you look at another job, its kind of silly

pros: The company offers great benefits and premium access to many different things for employees. The work is not too difficult to manage and there seems to always be enough time to get done what needs to be done
cons: Guidelines for the banking industry imposed by the Federal government as well as by BOA itself make it difficult to keep the customers satisfied. Quite often, customers are either angry or dissatisfied with things that are completely out of the control of the employee.

review_title: Good large business, professional organization, committed to customers
pros: Large, industry leader helps everyone downstream within the organization. I worked at Merrill, which was absorbed by BofA, and to my surprise the two had very similar mindsets from two completely different retail strategies. Training was the best, most robust and detailed in the industry. Opportunities for advancement (within Merrill especially) were everywhere.
cons:
Regulations... regulations... regulations. Smaller firms have more flexibility (or less to lose?) 
Mostly post housing debacle have made doing anything creative a no-go. Regulations become increasingly difficult for smaller/single brokers to survive, especially due to social media and other restrictions (which may have changed since my time there, hopefully for my former colleagues sake..)

review_title: Technical staffing has fallen far in the last decade.
job_title: Senior Internal Software Consultant in Chicago, IL
pros: If you are a contractor from India, it's great, but the "of America" is a joke.  Those with actual technical skills have either been laid off as too expensive or left because they saw the handwriting on the wall.
cons: Their software development is a sad pale remnant of what it once was - and the remaining technical management are political game players just playing turf wars (most are cast offs from the failed financial institutions that BofA stupidly picked up since 2008).  Almost all development has been off-shored to incompetent foreign developers who deliver late and over budget, if at all.

pros: Great starting pay and affordable benefits. I love the freedom I get to perform my duties. I love being challenged to put a friendly face on a big big cooperate company. It's great that they keep telling me not to "product push" but to "make financial lives better". They're paying my college and I get a discount on learning a new language software too. Not to mention getting financial skills for my personal life as well.
cons: Training is horrible, it's all computer based, self driven, crap. They give you 60 days to complete it yourself ( you only need 30). And you can make that 2 weeks in a real live classroom. Basically click through everything and learn as you go.

job_title: Mortgage Loan Closer in Portland, OR
pros:
Over my 15 plus years employed with Bank of America I worked with some of the most amazing people, we all encouraged  each other to excel and we all worked as a team to coach each other in what areas we could work on to improve.
There was always opportunities for advancement, benefits were excellent, tuition reimbursement, paid vacation, paid holidays and great hours overall!
cons:
A lot of management positions that were posted the bank decided to not hire from within. A lot these new hire (new to Bank of America) associates I felt were not qualified and bank spent valuable time training them when they should have taken on the role the first day of the position to begin to service our clients and work on a team.
Policy changes that were not effectively discussed with associates and this direct impacted our clients

pros: I was able to move up quite a bit with Bank of America. They are really great about promoting from within. Additionally, I always felt sufficiently trained to do the job I was asked to do. My co-workers and managers were all very kind and professional.
cons: The pay could have been better. There is a policy that when moving from position to position, there is a maximum of, I believe, 10% increase that an employee can have. When moving from a position where the average national salary is about $35,000 to a position where the average national salary is around $50,000, getting a 10% increase instead of an offer letter offering a competitive salary based on the position discourages great employees from staying.

pros: Good pay and benefits for the area.  A large footprint for you to move to if you wish.  Many different lines of business to move into, if you are willing to relocate.
cons: Management at all levels needs to be more aware of what their associates actually do, instead of just assuming.  Decisions are made that effect employees with no involvement by employees in these decisions.  The same associates are recognized again and again for the same things.  Often, associates are given no specific direction on what to do or how to do it.

review_title: Great Benefits - Horrible Retail Work Environment
job_title: Financial Center Assistant Manager in Weymouth, MA
pros: Great benefits; some good leadership still left after an exodus of some of the best because of culture shifts .
cons: If you like being appreciated and valued stay away from the retail (financial) centers. Retail leadership has a difficult time for the most part showing value to especially new associates - very politically driven environment - becoming a company that promotes based on who you know. Sadly customers echo this sentiment and new regional managers are young inexperienced egomaniacs with no respect for the rich history and foundation of the company.  Loved working there for 11 years until about 3 years ago. Happy to no longer be there.

review_title: Like working in a snake pit
pros:
Health benefits
Childcare Reimbursement
Dental and Vision benefits
Parking
Partial Cafe (to soon turn Cafeteria)
30 minute or an 1 hour lunch
cons:
Management
If you're outspoken and like to share ideas, the foreclosure department isn't for you.  Management can do as they please to you without worry of repercussion of any kind because with BofA in Ft. Worth, Tx... .... Managers are golden, leaving the associate with no voice at all.  If you come in... keep your head down, say "yessah massah" and do everything they tell you with no questions asked... ... you'll make it here... Management in that department can sabotage you out of another position in an attempt to get away from that atmosphere and nothing happens to them...

review_title: Heartless management in the Midwest region
pros: Just the medical benefits of the company.
cons: Unrealistic sales goals, favoritism, in the branch banking sector when it comes to promotions preference is given to white women over men. The Midwest (Central)region of the country is a being run like the Roman Empire ; cutthroat, overbearing and oppressive.

pros: Those already on remote work program work from home 100% of the time. Work/life balance and ability to do volunteer work (8 hours/month given on work time to volunteer, if desired) and manager flexibility in emergency/dr apt, etc, is excellent, across most business units.
cons: In 2016, all remote employees near an office now have to come in to a location, even if no one from their team is in that office. Existing remote work employees who weren't within a certain distance of a location can continue to work remotely. Most newly posted positions have requirement to be in an office (even if it's not where your Manager or team mates are) so current employees working remotely are stuck and unable to find new roles unless they move to a corporate location. They do provide several mentoring programs, but career development and comp is stagnant.

pros:
Nice people, good benefits, reasonable hours, good pay. In some roles you can choose the level of complexity you want which is a nice option. You can be on projects solving tough problems working with latest technology or something more regimented. 

Management or regulators will dictate priorities so maybe not a good fit for someone who wants to run the show. But besides that I would recommend to just about everyone.
cons: Limited work from home options, priorities frequently change which makes it difficult to plan and the structure (size) of the enterprise makes these changes difficult to navigate. Promotional track is unclear if you don’t want a management role.

job_title: Financial Crimes Compliance Specialist in Charlotte, NC
pros: Good benefits package, and opportunity to do something meaningful.
cons:
- Hard to make it past band 5
- Cut salary increase  or bonus year after year
- Always going through a re-or and having to start over with a new boss
- Mistakes are always remembered but not all of your accomplishments 
- Management uses nice words to keep you working for them long after you should have moved on and always over promise and under deliver
- Constant cutting expense and jobs, never know when you’re going to be next

review_title: In technology domain, experiences might change drastically with change in manager, or department
job_title: Assistant Vice President in London, England
pros:
Stability.
Exposure to Investment Banking domain which usually pays more than other domains.
If you know how to market your skills, you can really rise in ranks.
cons:
Experience and even culture changes, sometime drastically with change in management team which happens around every 5 years.
Nice people, but many are driven just by money.
Some managers just use stick to get the work done, without a sound practice system or healh check on team and culture.
Lack of training for existing work force.
It is best to work as contractor in technology department, and not as permanent, except if you do not like working on any technology.

review_title: Bank of America- Who's minding the store?
job_title: Senior Research Analyst in New York, NY
pros: Great benefits package and a good salary were very nice to have.  Healthcare options were great.  They even let me insure my girlfriend at the time.  Matching 401K program adds up pretty quickly if you contribute the max each year as well. Promotion of junior people was rapid. Should you be a junior employee they will let you go from associate to senior analyst faster than any other place on the street.
cons: Management does not think through their actions and tends to be short sided.  I would be surprised if Banc of America Securities is still in business at in mid-2009.  Management continues to put people in charge that either don't know what their doing or don't care.

review_title: A great place to grow for students with good benefits
job_title: Sales & Service Specialist in Washington, DC
pros: It's a great opportunity for college students to get up to $5000 in tuition reimbursement while working part-time. The pay is about average for the industry, but the benefits such as tuition reimbursement and health care are very good.
cons: In my experience working at BofA in Washington, DC the management up to the market-wide level was complacent in regular violations of worker's rights regulations by limiting employee's lunch breaks to 30 minutes regardless of hours worked. I have worked for BofA in California as well and this was never an issue there.

review_title: Don't dilute the franchise anymore, overpaying for worthless companies.
job_title: Derivatives Structurer/Specialist in South San Francisco, CA
pros: 1) Pay, historically has been good, though is sliding recently.   2)  It's big:   In the current environment, it's good to be at one of the large, surviving players, and Bank of America is that.  3)  Broad and deep product and geographic diversification---good in terms of product to sell, and also good just for the sake of diversifications.
cons: Communication from management is poor;  support and investment in techology is lagging (in my area).  There is a lot of uncertainty, involving completion of some questionable acquisitions.  There is a rather parochial, Charlotte and inward-focussed culture, rather than acting like, or aspiring to truly be a global bank.

review_title: B of A; too big to fail, too big to care
pros: Biggest player in the industry. Which at times makes it a great place to work, for you have resources available to you that few others have, but at the same time the bureacracy can be stifling. The bank is so huge you can do almost anything that you can put your mind to, if you get senior management to buy in to it.
cons: Too big sometimes, get bogged down with minutae. Meetings, forms, protocols, etc, can get to you after a while.

job_title: Human Resources Staff  in Atlanta, GA
pros: Best benefits anywhere - in particular paid time off and salary. Great work from home policy. Great support in getting tools you may need to do your work. A few great people but you are better off building relationships if you are in Charlotte.
cons: They have been overstaffed in our area (within HR) for years. It was a competitive environment when times were good, and now that times are bad, there is a huge lack of professionalism displayed between peers. People are anxious about being laid off and seem to be doing anything, no matter how low, to make themselves look good (IE by making you look bad) to try to keep their jobs. Management seems completely out of touch and reactive. Very poor long-term planning.

review_title: Bank of America is an OK place to work.
job_title: Trust and Fund Services Analyst in Chicago, IL
pros: Vacation and Benefits package is good. I get 15 days paid vacation, 10 sick days and we get banking holidays as well. There are many different groups so if you want to try something new and move to another career path you won't have to move to another company and deal with all the paper work associated with a new employer.
cons: The place is so big that many talented people will be lost in the mix. When you get an opportunity to show your worth(they will be fewer than at a smaller shop) you have to seize it.

review_title: Great benefits, not great work environment
pros: The benefits really can't be beat. Great health insurance, $600.00 in an HSA every year from the bank, 401k match, tuition reimbursement up to $5,000 every year. As a senior teller I get decent hourly pay.
cons: Management is way too pushy and overly aggressive when it comes to sales. The banking center managers get treated like garbage and are expected to perform with unreasonable sales numbers. This creates a stressed manager, leading to a stressful work environment and stressed out tellers. I disagree with the sales tactics that are used in the centers. Overall, I would not recommend working in a banking center. Not enough pay for the amount of disrespect.

pros: It's a large company and they are focused on training.  If you wanted to be transfered to another location you probably could, Bank of America is everywhere (38 states).
cons: Completely sales driven - it doesn't matter what the customer needs or wants, you better be selling the credit cards and other highly rewarded "sticky products."  Inside they call their banking centers "stores" which is a good indication of how they think of each customer.

pros: BAC is a fantastic company to work for, it has tremendous benefits, great people, opportunity for advancement and is customer centric in it's approach to success.
cons:
It loses it's way in the retail setting messaging many consumer friendly initiatives, and approaches to  achieving results, but regardless of words that are being messaged by upper leadership at the end of the day it is a for profit business.
Tremendous turnover in retail segment, with low FTE to reduce operating expenses, this problem is compounded as the additional strain on the rest of the staff while identifying, selecting and training replacement staff can take its toll.

pros: Great tuition reimbursement, up to $5250 a year. Helped out a lot with my Bachelor's (must be business related). Great benefits for part time; great healthcare, 401k matching. I've been a teller through college for 4 years now and I graduate this December. I cannot think of a better job for a college student in business to get a feel for the corporate work, customer service, sales, and finance. You can really tie in your education with what you do and see at work
cons: Many of the processes and systems need to be streamlined and more efficient. It would save a lot of time, effort, and money. Sometimes there is too much focus on small issues and not enough on the big picture.

review_title: In my eyes being an employee with Bank of America
job_title: Mortgage Processor/HSS Government Lending in Jacksonville, FL
pros: Always willing to re-hire you once you are laid off in another department.  Being able to transfer to another department after the 1 year to get that advanced job that is available to employees only.
cons: Too much favoritisms from supervisor to employees.  Not giving credit to those who continue working while those others sit with supervisor and do not perform to the rest of the group.  Mocking individuals as to there body size and person in general. Unable to change to another department, supervisor stopping that transfer.  Holding back information that will help structure within the department and only give it to special people.

review_title: Bank of America can be a good company to work for,  if they become more family oriented.
job_title: Credit Card Sales & Service II in Kennesaw, GA
pros: If you apply yourself and be open to constructive critism, you can make good money in this position. Be Open to those who mean you well in your success. Be very cautious of those who are selfish and spread gossip.
cons: Management does not support their staff success and family life. In this department, most employees move out of this roll in to a roll in the same building with not much advancement. This office does not promote management for their high achievers. Most companies acknowledge their top salesmen. In this position, it's truly about who you know.

pros: I would definitely recommend working for Bank of America, because they are very flexible for college students once you are part of their team! They will even pay for your classes at the end of the year as long as they are business related. The managers there push you to succeed, and no matter how much they insist you to get your numbers up, they will always give you a second chance!! I don't think that you will ever get fired for that, at least that was my experience!!
cons: The thing I didn't like is that sometimes I didn't get our 10-min. break because of how busy we were.

review_title: Awesome A great company to work for
pros: They care about there employees and have flexible schedules if your a single parent it is understandable that there are times you need to be able to take time or need flexible schedules and you can get that a Bank Of America.  AS well as there benefits package which is truly awesome It fully covers you and there is even flexibility with that.
cons: Long hours But you get paid for every minute. Goals orientated but you she the profits in your paycheck.  Parking is a travesty though you have to get there early enough to get a parking spot and not have to walk from the garage as on hot or rainy days it is awefull
