pros: The benefits are very good. Tuition reimbursement and insurance if you want it. Also, 3,000.00 reimbursement for purchasing a new hybrid vehicle. Paid vacations starting at two weeks when you're first hired. Paid public holidays.
cons: High turnover, ineffectual management, some employees don't pull their own weight. You can't rely on people to help you out to move up in the company, you need to actively seek out mentors and ask questions all the time to get on their radar.

review_title: Many great people..strong financial company...true supporter of diversity...some cons at the senior executive level.
pros: Great associates.  Company size and scale. Brand awareness. Supporter of diversity. Strong core business performance.
cons: Job security.  Department wide layoffs are common and create a culture of uncertainty and a perception of that long term performance doesn't really matter. Layoffs often occur in December before the Holidays. Salary caps have been in place the last 3 years above a certain level salary level but do not apply to the top executive. Leadership by example is missing.

review_title: Worst company.  Not at all what I expected, but then again,  being a former mortgage customer, I should have known.
job_title: Customer Sales Specialist in Kennesaw, GA
pros: I can only speak for the contact center in Kennesaw and I can't think of any benefits of working there.
cons: I saw in the news feeds today that Bank of America is ranked no. 5 of the top most hated companies.  Having worked there, I can see why.  They do not care about the customers.  I can't tell you how many calls I received in a day customers complaining about how they are treated when they call in to make payments, activate their cards or even just to simply find out what their balances were.  Bank of America considers it sales, customers consider it harassment.  I left because I felt their practices were unethical.

review_title: Bank of America is so large it is hard to rate the company as a whole.
pros:
When interviewing with BOA, carefully analyze both the individual job and the Bank unit in which you will be working.  The company is simply too large to analyze as a whole.  

The company has brand value within the marketplace, which sometimes makes it easier to get your job done or locate a new job.
The company devotes substantial resources to online training.
cons: Due to its size, the Bank moves extremely slowly often to its detriment. Be prepared to complete a significant amount of unnecessary paperwork.  Your ability to truly impact the Bank's operations will be limited.

pros: This position has high visibility with Merrill Edge Executives. You have the chance to interact with them daily and involve yourself with a Edge initiatives to improve the process of this branch within BOA. You also speak to FAs and CAs from around the country all day long, which could possibly open other doors for your career path.
cons: Each day is very much the same. Though attention to detail is imperative there is no deviating from your daily task and you are constantly stuck on a phone and at a computer station. Not many opportunities to show your strengths and qualities you bring to the finance world.

pros: Manager was great and very understanding. I got 40 hours of PTO as soon as I got hired and 40 hours of sick time. Also benefits and matching 401K kick in right away. Training was awesome.
cons: Horrible hours. I was part time and I was literally there six days a week working 25 hours a week. Hard work will not get you promoted. You have to be liked by upper management to get a raise. No matter how many accounts you refer, they will choose others. Also, we were supposed to get bonuses for every referral but that never happened. They had us like that for a year saying we were going to start receiving commission off our sales and referrals.

review_title: The most challenging organization for which I've ever worked
job_title: Vice President in New York, NY
pros: Constant striving to improve.  Continuous adjustment to follow business' stakeholders' leads.  Response to markets are always swift and professionally done.  The depth of skill and talent of my colleagues constantly surprises me.
cons: Though no different from other large firms, IT compensation is subject to the headwinds of the markets.  Mobility is tough to come by unless you know the hiring manager well.  Internal job postings are sometimes done without serious thought and to just check a box.  Again, more of a big company complaint and not specific to BofA, but even when earnings are good, we hear of "budget concerns" and staff is pared back, despite pressure to deliver more.

review_title: Great to their employees, opportunities for advancement or a complete career change within one company
pros:
Education may help get your foot in the door but you truly have every opportunity to advance within through hard work and good ethics and taking advantage of their great training certifications and courses. started as a receptionist and worked my way up in the company with 5 promotions over the course of 10 or so years.

Benefits are great, better for employees with lower income but very good life insurance at minimal to no cost.

Diverse company not nearly as stiff as they used to be in terms of tattoos, hair, etc.

Fantastic networking programs.
cons:
Understaffed
HIGHLY regulated e.g. frequent audits, complex processes and procedures
Cutbacks on ability to work from home 
Vacation time is generous but very difficult to take the time off due to workload (no carryover/cash out option)

job_title: Financial Advisor Trainee in Bloomfield Township, MI
pros: Pay and prestige.  If you hear anyone who didn't like it they didn't work hard.  If you dont make 300 phone calls a day or set up seminars and talk to wealthy people all day you don't deserve to be there.  You don't have a choice not to hustle or grind.  It's a job where you eat what you kill and if you didn't bring in the 30 million in 3 years it's truly your fault.
cons: Work load and the government.  It's truly a career you work more than 40 unless you know alot of wealthy people/business that trust you with their money.

pros: The company has some good benefits, such as good health insurance, generous vacation time (depending on position), sick time, maternity/paternity leave and growth potential.
cons:
The department I work in is extremely disorganized and employees basically do what they want. The bad/mediocre employees enjoy this as there is no accountability for their bad behaviors. In the end, the good/professional employees end up with the brunt of the workload as management does not take action to correct the unprofessional behavior of most employees.
No matter how good your performance is, it will not help to advance your career. Who you know is all it matters in this Department and the most productive employees have been in the same position for years.

pros: BAI is able to leverage the massive strength of Bank of America behind it, which enables its employees to take advantage of the great benefits and resources.
cons: Limited career development and channels- you either sell (contribute to the bottom line) or you support/manage those who do. Even though this is a brokerage division of a larger bank, there are still the many bureaucratic rules and regulations and performance measurements of the Bank that other brokerage firms do not have to fulfill.

pros: Just started a couple of weeks ago. The interview and verification process was very smooth and professional. This is my first time working for a bank and had my reservations about it. However, from day one I was guided and helped in anything I needed to get settled. There's a ton of training to do, but it is extremely helpfull and productive. I feel it will really help me succeed. I like the fact that there's a real focus on doing the right thing for our customers. It is reinforced throughout the training process. Co-workers are very helpful as well and always upbeat...
cons: I guess if I have to give a con review it would be that the banking center needs a bit of upgrading. It's not so bad but some desks look a bit outdated.

review_title: its really good, just to many cuts so the staff level is not great
job_title: Sales & Service Specialist in Naples, FL
pros: great benefits, vacation, you can move up the ladder pretty fast. Key thing is have a great attitude with your manager and colegues look for ways where you can learn more and take their advise and move forward. before you know it you will be a personal banker.
cons: with all the staff cuts, customers are not to happy which means its harder to get them in your office, longer wait time for the teller harder for you to have them sit with you .

job_title: Merchant Teller in San Clemente, CA
pros: Overall great co-workers, fun customers, professional environment, holidays off & build rapport with the locals.
cons: Timed on every single transaction, rated against other tellers nationwide, given absurd "construction" criticisms. Managers obsessed with numbers of accounts, some GM even falsified or manipulated daily phone meetings with other local branches to earn personal benefits (greed), commissions were very rare and minimal even when meeting goals for the tellers and split with other managers, and inconsistent  & unfair in the weekend scheduling.

review_title: Good pay, great benefits...and that's all it had going for it.
job_title: Banking Center Manager II; Assistant Vice President in Dallas, TX
pros: Great pay (negotiated through multiple transfers and promotions), excellent benefits, 4 weeks paid vacation, 2 weeks paid sick time, good relationship with my manager.
cons: The positivity of the CEO and national leadership team was turned to whip cracking and "never good enough" talks from Area level management on a regular basis.  We asked the most of our least paid employees and the least from those who stood to earn from it.  I felt like a minion rather than a person.

review_title: The Walmart of the banking industry.
job_title: Personal Banker in San Jose, CA
pros:
Higher base salary for retail banking.
A good chance of getting brainwashed.
cons:
New WARNING: Meeting quarterly sales and still getting written up due to new garbage sales plan. This does NOT make sense in a sales position. Making money should just be making money without games involved.

Doesn't get paid fairly when it comes to bonuses.
Illiterate and incompetent management from top to bottom.
Corporate wide strategy set to make employees fail.
Lack of opportunities to move up.
Management doesn't care, too busy caught up in petty high school games.

Lack of opportunities to get Series licensed. Merrill Edge is a joke compared to competitors such as Schwab.

Oh and...
New WARNING: Meeting quarterly sales and still getting written up due to new garbage sales plan. This does NOT make sense in a sales position. Making money should just be making money without games involved.

review_title: Bank of America was a great organization to work for.
job_title: Operations Manager in South Pasadena, CA
pros: Excellent work culture, gives manager evaluations to staff, company bonus', good benefits, lots of learning opportunities. Excellent work culture!
cons: Lots of layoffs. Although I was a manager who scored highest on the employee satisfaction survey among my peers I was laid off. Not given the benefit of a conversation to try and fit me into another position as I found out later this was given to other associates. Also exceeded in most areas for annual reviews. Still laid off.

pros:
-Slightly flexible work schedule, great for when you are a college student 
-Benefits as a part time employee, including: paid vacation time, paid holidays, paid sick time, health care, etc
cons:
-Sales quotas, which included asking people with small account balances to sign up for savings accounts
-Sales quotas enforced even when it was not busy
-Uncomfortable to stand in the same spot for several hours without the proper floor mat, while personal bankers and management sat at their desks
-Standing required because you have to "mirror" the customer (i.e. if the customer is standing, you have to stand too)
-Could be very fast paced, with impatient, and sometimes rude, customers

review_title: The other reviews were written by Bank of America's HR, nobody who works here would give this place 5/5
pros: -there are no pro's this place is a sweat shop
cons:
-our department was told the we had to lie on our employee satisfaction surveys and give the company 5/5 in every category
-pay was awful (just enough to keep you going but never enough to save anything)
-no vertical movement was possible in the company, unless you have connections
-health insurance plans were some of the worst I've ever seen
-management treated us like cattle
-the training was awful, they never actually gave us reading material it was like one big rumor about what you should be doing, no uniformity

pros: its a good place to learn the basics of finance and money
cons: Constantly adding required redundant online tutorials and make no sense, always pressured to have clients meet a personal banker even though the client 98.9% of the time just wants to get in the bank and out. Also always get pressured to be quick and efficaint yet are required to dedicate 100% attention to client, and get many orders from three supervisors which can be confusing. Everything is constantly changing which makes everyone confused and causes the client to loose it with the bank and threaten to close accounts. Extremely difficult to move up the only way to move up is to FORCE clients to meet a personal banker in addition want to reduce the amount of tellers and have clients use the ATMs instead and many people don't like the ATMs. They really need to change the way they do business. Finally wage is too close to minimum wage for what the tellers are put through everyday.

job_title: Release Form Originator in Simi Valley, CA
pros: Good stepping stone if you want to learn about the Loan mortgage side, good exposure regarding the documents and familiarization on how the mortgage loan been process.
cons: Cons in working with in this company some Associate and Management were insecure regarding their work and there were some also not open in new ideas. If you know more compare to them there is a little window to move up. Some managers still stock in macro managment.

pros: Good benefits...the work from home program was fantastic but they're moving away from it (see cons). Parental leave is incredible...12 weeks paid as a father, both for birth and adoption. 4 weeks vacation time, lots of holidays. Worked with some really talented people.
cons: Work from home is being phased out, which is a bummer. Being a big financial institution, they are extremely risk adverse and resistant to change. They are constantly spending big money on technology improvements but there is a lot of waste. Raises are few and far between and bonuses are tiny for mid level and down. I made about 7% more than I did when I started working their 8 years earlier.

pros: The company in itself is not a bad company.  The company hires all races and religions.
cons:
Upper level managers do everything possible to not encourage employees to strive for better positions. Anyone getting into the company with the intention of moving up in the company is faced by jealous managers. Promotion is not by merit and mostly upper management is promoted even though most of the work is done by lower level employees.  There are many people in upper management who are unqualified to be there. I think these are more bureaucratic managers not leaders.  
Most available jobs go by who knows who basis.

pros: No upward mobility in my line of business. Also nepotism and favoritism run amok. Perhaps other positions that create revenue for the bank are better suited for individuals to move around the enterprise. There is some name recognition, which allowed me to land a job with another Fortune 500 company.
cons: Great benefits: health (beats our areas biggest healthcare provider's benefits!), tuition reimbursement (so, so..you get reimbursed if your classes and/or major is job related but I am sure there is a way to apply some classes to any job occupation). 401k and HSA are good too.

pros: The job provides high pay in the premier segments, however the job is relatively mundane and consists of mindless work. Essentially, your conversations consist of - Identify client - regurgitate script to client and reap the pay. (could be a plus or a minus depending on how you like to work)
cons: Whole company is blinded by the fact that they are requiring high performers to follow the company guidelines/processes - putting the client in a worse off position.

pros: Realy good benefits.  The company provides matched  401k after your first year.  Medical, dental vision for a family of four.  Costs me $280 a month. Great team.
cons: Micro Managed to death by upper Management.  Training really lacks. BOA severely understaffs it's branches to the point where customers complain all day long.  Currently, they're trying to take away Assistant Managers and go to a one leader branch.  It makes it very difficult for the team.  BOA has ridiculous sales pressures for their tellers and we get mostly graded by our referrals.

review_title: Customer Service and Sales Specialist II
pros: Great corporate culture, large corporation therefore, there are many different avenues to grow. Decent salary.
cons: Everyone makes the same amount in the department regardless of education or experience. Pay increases are minimal. The position was initially advertised as sales support so during onboarding, there were many confused individual who did not know they were required to make monthly and quarterly sales quotas. Focus is mostly on the "sales" and not the "customer service" in the job title.

pros: Pay (base salary is decent), schedule is easy to work with (in case you are finishing school), career opportunities are great (just have to make sure you have a manager that really cares about your progress).
cons: If you work outside of the affluent neighborhoods, it is harder to perform at the level that people working in those areas are because the company caters to those type of customers. Makes it hard to get the "job done" when they don't provide the services they provide in the affluent neighborhoods. Commission pay outs could be better.

review_title: Good company in general,  outdated software, company too big to fix 1000s of small problems
pros: Nice benefits, good moral foundation, overload of diversity, lots of different positions, company leading the market in digital age  with entirely new options.
cons: Disconnect between upper management and what happens in the bank.  Old software that doesn't work.  System upgrades come without any warning and typically had unintended detrimental side effects.  Direct management isn't always supportive, although they claim to be able to help.   Lack of products that client's want.  Lack of true mentor programs and no established career paths.

job_title: Financial Solutions Advisor in Palm Springs, CA
pros: Excellent array of benefits offered by BofA. That is about it though. Everything was horrible. Cannot think of anything else to say.
cons:
Every single thing about the job from day one. The absolute worst training program. More problems with systems and getting set up than any other job I’ve ever had. Never seen so many colleagues take stress leave and hate their jobs. Worst most complicated systems to use with clients. Most time consuming methods to assist clients. Heavy pressure to sell products to client they probably don’t need. I can go on and on. Avoid this place at all costs. Worst position I have ever had. Started looking for another job after my first week there. Took me a few months but quitting was the best part of my experience at BofA/Merrill Lynch. 
PS They actually lied to me telling me I’d get paid for my 4th quarter bonuses and that never happened. Also screwed and my family out of two weeks of benefits.

job_title: Operational Risk Manager in Charlotte, NC
pros: Flexible work environment and full time telecommuting is now a viable option. The paternity / maternity leave is excellent and the associates generally care about each other's well being. At times, it's like being part of a family.
cons: Constant reorganization. It simply never ends and the change is so rapid that gaps in operational risk controls develop quickly. The organization of the technology teams is lacking alignment with business needs and business processes making outside vendor systems more attractive than internal systems and this increases risk and decreases shareholder value.  The educational reimbursement has not kept up with the cost of a decent education.

review_title: Do you feel like you are being treated fairly?
pros: It can be a good place to work and go to school. They do help with tuition. Their childcare program is also a plus,if you have young children. Other benefits are available to you as well, Health insurance, 401k, pension, and dental.
cons:
A person not needing tuition or childcare or any of their other benefits, they don't compensate your salary. Career opportunities don't seem fair. Recognition is very rare. Your work schedule  is inconsistant  and is never made more than a week in advance, making personal appointments almost impossible. this contributes to low morale in the banking  center. 
Also, A person coud not live on their salary they offer.

pros: I worked in 3 different groups at LaSalle over the course of over eight years.  I was very happy there.  I  left for what I thought was a good opportunity (which was not).  The compensation was great.  They definitely fired people who were not cutting it so the accountability was there.  Although BNYM hired many of those who did get let go from LaSalle.
cons: I do think the compensation for some people who did not prove themselves was definitely inflated.  The group I was in specifically was extremely large so recongnition was hard to come by.

pros: Great starting point right out of college.  Enrolled in a training program that taught me the basics of credit.  During my employment, was able to take various training classes to expand my credit analysis skills.  The company values internal education, however it is difficult to apply some of the curriculum.
cons: There is a "glass ceiling" feel within the company, which is not unusual for a corporation of this size.  Difficult to work your way up, especially if you are looking for quick gratification.  Management style within the groups is a little harsh, the talent is not always at the top of the silos.

review_title: Slow deal flow, lots of hours, but excellent learning curve.
pros: BofA had an excellent investment banking analyst training course.  The learning curve of an investment banking analyst cannot be beat, although this is true of almost any investment bank.  Benefits and bonus seemed fair, given I was toward the top.  Although deal flow was slow, the deals I did work on were also extremely educational.
cons: Hours, hours, hours wasted on pitches that were never technically scheduled!  Also many hours spent in the office simply because that was what was expected, but did not seem necessary.

review_title: Great benifits, compensation could be better compared to job
pros: The company itself is great, they are very diverse and many people get promoted.  The benifits are great and with 3 weeks vacation from the date you start.  There are numerous discounts available to you as an associate of the bank from bank products to business partners.  The online training is great and helpful.
cons: The drawback, you cant really vacation too much if you are based only on the salary provided.  There have been times when market managment states they will reward for efforts and have not followed through. There is not enough time allocated for associates to complete training. Incentive pay outs are only done 2 times a year.

review_title: High Pressure, Decent Pay, Good Benefits
pros:
Pay is competitive
Great hours and time off
Benefits are good, even with pension being eliminated
cons:
High Pressure Sales in a Banking Environment can be challenging
Sales goal are set without much consideration of reality
Expect Upper Management to be applying consistent and serious pressure all the time
If you want to move up, but Senior Management wants you to stay where you are so they won't have to fill your position they will do whatever it takes to keep you there, including finding a reason to put you on a disciplinary plan for something minor.

pros: Excellent opportunity to gain leadership  and corporate experience.  Benefits are first class, many employee focused programs and benefits to tap into.
cons: Very political and difficult to navigate the good ol boy network at times.  Salaries are deplorable for mid level managers and front line associates.  This often leads to retention problems with the less capable associates remaining longer and having negative impact on the business.  Cross functional departments and systems are often convoluted and leads to service issues for internal and external customers.

review_title: Rich in Benefits, Poor in Salaries
pros: The benefits offered at Bank of America are top-notch: health benefits, 401K + match, tuition reimbursement, charitable gift matches, 10 sick/personal days, 10 bank holidays, at least 2 weeks vacation (incrementally increases the longer you work there), discounts or credits on banking products and services, and they generally support a healthy work/life balance.
cons: While they have started to offer competitive salaries to new hires, they didn't always, and now have not been able to bring veterans up-to-speed on their salaries. In my case, I make significantly less than my peers who are doing the same job, despite the fact that I have an advanced degree and they don't. It seems to be true that the only way to get a significant raise at this company is to leave for a while and be hired back.

review_title: I worked at Bank of America for less than a year in IT in senior management
pros: Very dedicated international teams that are very good at that jobs and the work was exciting and fast-paced.  People are very caring and will jump in to help each other.
cons: Had 7 managers in 6 months - going back and forth to 2 of them a couple of times.  This is very confusing to a new employee and frustrating as you just start to get a feel for the job and it changes - then it changes back just at the time you had forgotten how to do that job.

review_title: Lots of potential for upward mobility if aligned with a good mentor.
pros: Generous education budget, best-in-class working conditions.  This institution attracts well educated, tenured talent.  Take advantage of internal course offerings and reimbursement for continuing education and financial designations.  Well developed and conceived roles within each of the departments.  Ample opportunity to broaden skill set through cross training opportunities which arise from time to time.
cons: Easy to get buried in minutiae, bureaucratic architecture in some departments.  It pays to do your homework and research any position which you may consider interviewing for, whether internal or external.  Roles within certain departments may decentralize or restructure with little to no notice and you can find yourself looking over your shoulder. Operational roles are subject to frequent and unexpected restructure.

pros: Great benefits, most developers can work from home nearly 100% of the time.  Pay isn't anywhere near what other companies pay but if you want the flexibility of working from home then that's the trade-off.  Once you work here for a while as long as you don't cause any trouble and do your job it's nearly impossible to get fired.
cons: Forget about keeping up with the latest tech.  You'll most likely be maintaining old code or developing on top of an old platform with little or no opportunity to innovate.  Since most developers work from home it's not a conducive environment for mentoring, so if you're not already at a senior level stay away.  If you're looking for a place to chill out until you retire, this might work for you.

review_title: Great company to grow your career
pros: Excellent benefits...401K match, pre-paid legal services, discounts on banking services and products!   Also, there are endless career opportunities for those that are willing to network and go for them.  You have to be an excellent performer and the right people have to know you in order to get ahead.
cons: The bank is scaling down on their work at home opportunities, so many people are being brought back into the office.  This has been a killjoy for morale.  There are also constant layoffs, and many people are let go only to be brought back as contractors.  That's also a downer for morale as well.

pros: If this is your first job, or you're relatively new to the work force, this is probably a great place to start. Plenty of name recognition and reasonably competitive salaries and benefits.
cons: There was a time when this was a great company to work for. The benefits and pay were top notch. Management actually had a clue and knew how to run an organization of this size. But, that all went away with the Merrill Lynch merger. The company has been cutting jobs steadily since the beginning of 2009, with over 100,000 jobs cut in the five years. And, at this point, it's all about numbers. So, long time employees, with a ton of institutional experience are released, in order to make room for the cheaper, inexperienced workers.

review_title: Stay away if you are a Java or C++ developer.
job_title: Java Developer in New York, NY
pros: You may be allowed to work from home from time to time, although this practice has been banned recently.
cons:
1) You have to fight for your compensation year after year. Unless you threaten to leave there are no increases on the base and it takes to get good connections to get a decent bonus. The management will always lie that it was a bad year for the bank and "everyone" gets little or nothing. In reality, those well connected get 50k+ bonuses.

2) A group of former Linux administrators hijacked the bank. They are forcing all Java and C++ developers to move to a scripting language called Python and their Quartz framework. These people know nothing about object-oriented programming, encapsulation and best practices, yet they force everyone to embrace their technology. Lots of good Java and C++ developers left the bank. Python people got promoted and huge bonuses while the whole platform is failing.

pros:
Pay is good
Benefits are good
Growth is everywhere in the company
Amazing schedule that gives work life balance to employees
cons: People are in the company forever so they're not good at accepting people that don't know it all. A lot of the managers are kissing up to whoever they need to in order to get promoted. Huge divide between sales and operations which is part of this new transformation they are having here. It makes it difficult as a seller to work with your FCM when they want you to do service as if you were a SSA or RB. RM and PB roles are becoming a role to do everyone else's job such as the FSA and SMB Bankers.

review_title: Worked for the company for a year and a half, quit for a year and couldn't stay away!
job_title: Senior Teller in Canyon Country, CA
pros: Most people who work in a bank are of similar personalities and are very easy to get along with. Coworkers come before clients and I've made friendships that will last a lifetime. Great opportunities to move up, and it is recognized when you try your best to help the team.
cons: Lots of risk from all sides. Customers can be bullies and fraudsters are constantly finding new ways to make your job more stressful.

pros: benefit and pay. Co-workers.
cons: I work for them for over 7 years. When i started it was great . But it all went down the hill. In escalation department they just push people to meet their stats. It got so bad that associates started to get physically and mentally sick. Some of the managers try to help but they cant do anything. I know at least 5 workers that had to go on medical leave due to the stress.  And when they are back they are treated even worst then before. Company does not care about their associates. But because the pay is very good people try to stay as long as they can. If you have a employee that was working for you for 15 years and suddenly cannot handle the same job - that's a big red flag- and what they will do - let you go for a stupid rezone or treat you so bad that in the end you will quit.

pros: Flexible working schedule for students, and really nice mangers and coworkers, depending on the branch you are going to work for. Safety is guaranteed when you have to handle great volume of cash each. Most of the branched hire at least one security guard, depending on the size of your branch
cons: Low paid and high turn-over of the employees. Some of the branches require employees to work on Saturday. And seniority rule apply to vocation--you need to make sure the people started before you did not pick the same vocation time as you. And you will never be able to take vocation with your coworkers

pros: Great place to advance your career.  Great benefits, free health insurance (high deductible), free lunch, won't work more than 8 - 5 most days. Some smart people here.
cons: Company is pretty sales bias even though the sales reps have the least knowledge and rely on other department to do their job. They have a two year training program for sales but most of the reps don't even know the price of our most popular products. A lot of office politics. Probably more as the company gets bigger. Pay is significantly lower than industry average for all positions other than sales.

pros: The work environment at the Bank of America that I worked at was phenomenal. There was great team energy and I felt like I was part of a larger family. I also liked how everyone was very professional, or at least at the branch that I worked at.
cons: I wouldn't give Bank of America five stars only because their pay could've been higher/more comparable to other banking companies. It's a great team to be a part of, but given the amount of work that we do, we really need to get paid more.

review_title: Support roles in Bank of America
pros:
Given the scale of the company/ you get a variety of experience - be it various geographies/people across the cultures/projects of different kinds
The volumes are so huge in the company that you get all sorts of exposure work wise...any errors you can think of happen there/it is a good training ground to learn
Freedom of voice is encouraged and everyone has a chance to voice concerns/issues if they have.
cons: Given that the company is so huge/there are chances of getting lost in the crowd/getting good quality of work assigned to you is very important to get noticed.

pros: You get to only work with businesses and learn from what makes or breaks them, Better Compensation plan, you won't be micro-managed especially if you're a good seller, better chances to move up if you do well.
cons: I've had to ask for a salary bump up EVERY TIME, despite doing very well. If you keep quiet and don't ask for advancement and more money they probably keep you in the same place and pay you the same amount for the rest of your life.

review_title: Decent hourly pay for personal banker, recognition for top sales talent
pros: Decent rate for hourly pay. Incentive structure awards those who understand how to make the company more money and consistently and efficiently turn basic interactions into some kind of sale.
cons: incentive plans change every year and sometimes are updated within the year. The financial industry changes so frequently and you must continue to "reboot" and adapt your approach.

review_title: It started out wonderful but has significantly gone downhill.
job_title: Assistant Vice President in Lakewood, NJ
pros: Benefits, 5% 401k match, good health benefits, childcare benefits, education reimbursement , adoption benefits, vacation time, 401k yearly contribution, company discounts, and preferred bank accounts
cons: Constant cutbacks, too many regulations, poor workplace moral, extreme micromanaging atmosphere, unhappy employees, underpaid tellers, upper level management does not know what happens in the centers, extreme sales pressure without the proper partners to make sales goals. Partners ( mortgage, investment and small business) are not held to the same expectations as branch associates.

pros: The base pay and benefits are good.
cons: Constant micro-managing and measurement on a ever changing multitude of metrics makes this is a no-win job.   Everything you do -- from the number of times you pick up the phone, tell a customer about a home loan offer, or set an appointment-- is measured against managements' standards. This position is not really about helping people meet their financial goals or even bringing it assets.  There is a way too much emphasis on getting people to meet with the mortgage advisor for home loans and on selling credit cards.  If this is the only job you can get as a financial advisor, you need to seriously consider a career change.

review_title: Opportunity for growth within the Campus Programs
pros: Rotational program where participants see two different Lines of Businesses in order to gain an understanding for a future, long-term career path. Very competitive salary and outstanding benefits.
cons: Rotations are assigned, participants do not have the ability to select their position. Limited initial training within the program and the particular line of business as a whole, especially considering participants have no prior experience in the given field.

review_title: BAS - Not a bad place to work...
job_title: Investment Banking Associate in Dallas, TX
pros: BAS tends to be one of the more stable investment banks.  They may not pay the highest on the street, but they also do not get hit as hard during the downturns.
cons: Working for an investment bank tied to a commercial bank (in the pre-fallout era) did mean that you had to put up with some commercial banking PR garbage that was unnecessary.  Stuff like corporate donations to various charities, training that was a waste of time for investment banking personell...etc.  There were a few instances in 2007 of groups that received zero bonuses for the year, although this was laregly in groups that were MBS/ABS related.

pros: Bank of America has awesome benefits, great career advancement opportunities, and is a good place to learn the business of banking. I highly recommend Bank of America as a place to grow and learn about the banking industry. I truly believe that Bank of America will emerge from the financial crisis as a global leader in the financial services industry. My position as an Operations Manager allows me to work on the front lines of the evolution of bank technology, and I think that this experience is invaluable.
cons: Bank of America is currently in a precarious financial situation due to the unfortunate acquisitions of Merill Lynch and Countrywide. Executive management is not help responsible for poor strategy decisions as is evidenced by the fact that Ken Lewis is still CEO.

review_title: Great place to start, but not a career location
job_title: Investment Banking Analyst in Chicago, IL
pros: Unlike most financial institutions it is not currently firing everyone at an appalling rate.  It is also a great place to start a career as they offer excellent training, and it always looks good to have a bulge bracket bank on your resume.  They compensate their employees for hard work, however, no one in the industry is currently being compensated as they once were.
cons: Employees can expect to work long hours.  This includes whether or not there are actually deals being done.  It can be frustrating at times having to spend large amounts of time at the office working on deals you know will never be done.

pros: Vacation Time is good, Salary is comparable to other financial firms, Management is supportive of work-life balance, Feedback is readily available if wanted.
cons: Health benefits have gone downhill, There isn't much opportunity for growth and advancement.  The company is enormous and there are way too many levels of management, causing processes and changes to move at a snails pace.

pros: Definitely competitive pay, great training, ad they have a really good vacation and benefits plan. The company really cares about the employees and try their best to make sure we are treated fairly.
cons: If you start out with bad managers it's very hard to get out of, and the job itself is hard to get into. After you schedule your vacation good luck changing it or getting any other days off. They will make it very painful. Speaking your mind to your assistant manager or branch manager about things that are bothering you aren't handled very well either.

pros:
Supreme platform, lots of great investment support, base pay is good so as incentive. You can find connections with other boa employees if you look for outside work activities. 
You will never feel bored at work as FA. As. FA, you get the opportunity to carry a positive attitude to work and build your character through good and bad times.
cons: Hurdle during first year production is easy but tough in year 2 or 3unless you are lucky to find a senior FA to team or from wealthy family. I got the bull award, exceed hurdle constantly but still not able to feel secure in pursuing my goal.

review_title: Great place to start a career!
job_title: Assistant Manager in New York, NY
pros: Great benefits is a start! I have worked in many locations with ease as to transfers! If you move around a lot or know that you are going to move the company really supports the transfers and ensures a smooth transition. That is a bonus to working for such a large company, no matter where life takes you there will surely be an opportunity for you there!
cons: You must be a very flexible person and be able to easily adapt to the circumstance and environment. There is a lot of change that happens on a constant bases within the company and because it is so large every place you go wont be exactly the same.

review_title: Its a good job if you do not have a college education
job_title: Sales and Service Specialist in New York, NY
pros: Excellent benefits, all federal holidays off, ok pay. I will say this again if your the type of person that does not want to go to college this is a great job because you can really work your way up in the banking center with experience and make a decent living but if you a college graduate it can be extremely frustrating because your degree means absolutely nothing. It doesn't get you a promotion or a pay increase.
cons: If you have a college degree and work in the banking center it is difficult to get out into corporate. If it snows you better believe you are trudging through the slush and ice to get there. They push you to get sales and your check will not reflect your efforts.

job_title: Assistant Vice President in Simi Valley, CA
pros: I can't think of any.  This is truly the worst company I have ever worked for.
cons: Employees are treated like crap and live in constant fear of being laid off.  I worked there less than 2 1/2 years and was witness to over 30,000 layoffs until I got mine.  The bureaucracy is stifling and results in almost nothing ever getting done on time or at all.  Incompetence seems to be the order of the day among senior management and almost everyone is a Senior VP (which means nothing).

pros: Competitive products for clients, very open to using technology to improve associates job processes as well as client accessibility
cons: Consumer LOB is still focused on widget pushing. They are not given any business acumen to allow them to see the why behind what they are supposed to be doing.  This is a direct reflection of their middle management.

review_title: You better love BOA and banking.
pros: Benefits & Tuition Reimbursement. I was lucky enough to have awesome co workers.
cons: Management is clueless. Work-Life balance is a joke because the company really doesn't care. Company thinks that your life IS BOA. The pay sucks. There is no bonuses. The only ones that get bonuses is management. Fakeness among management gets bigger as the title goes higher. Management needs to take people skills classes, customer service & customer satisfaction training.

review_title: Bank of America exceeded all initial expectations for me.
pros: Great culture of professionalism, great benefits, honest focus on employee personal growth.
cons:
1)  Unfortunately the burden of the Countrywide acquisition creates a cloud over the future of many in the Mortgage Technology division.  It is the only division losing money due to repeated DOJ shakedowns and naturally a company must answer to its shareholders to become lean and profitable.

2)  Processes are being written constantly.  Often without full consideration for the impact of changes and the interference with other other processes.  Release management in Mortgage Technology is the definitive example of this.

pros: A good way to gain experience in a professional environment. If you are dedicated and work hard you can move up in the ranks quickly. Tellers can move up to personal bankers if their sale interactions are solid and they show enthusiasm for the job.
cons: The job is all about sale interactions, if you do not meet the extremely high expectations for sale interactions you are constantly scrutinized by management. There is also little flexibility in the schedule. It is a bank job, so you can always expect bank hours, which could be difficult for students.

review_title: Not what it used to be
pros: They used to have a great work/life balance where employees were able to work remotely, but everyone has since been called back into the office so not sure the work/life balance can be considered a PRO anymore.
cons: Back in the Hugh McColl days, BofA was a great place to work.  BofA has become much more of a Boston-based bank and mentality.  Churn and burn environment.  Really depends on your line of business but some senior executives can be very difficult to work with and often take pride in the fact that they are difficult.  Health benefits have rapidly declined over the years.

pros: The pay is good and the food in the cafeteria, while over-priced, was usually good.
cons: I am amazed they get any software into production at all. They hired people with expertise and then ignored their suggestions. They jump into coding before they think through even the basics of the design, and the team leadership was very poor. The lead developer didn't listen to the very people they brought in to add the expertise they lacked. It was a waste of my time and their money. Then to top it off they sprung a two-week furlough on ALL contractors, at the same time they gave bonuses to their employees.

review_title: What happened to this company during my forced sabbatical?
pros: Top-Notch Technology; surrounded by talented IT Staff/People.  Excellent training resources.  Challenging work.  I am not personally micro-managed.  I enjoy what I do and I have a sense of directing my own path/making my job what I want it to be.
cons: Continual layoffs, small cubicles with low walls (with hundreds of people on a large floor in a room) -- this is in IT.  Politics!

job_title: Personal Banker in Silver Spring, MD
pros: BOA usually has some of the top cutting edge technologies for their customers and tools for sales, compared to some of the competition. Also, if you need to move to another state and stay employed at BOA, there are many locations in the U.S. to choose from.
cons: The upper management micromanages every activity there is to manage. There is a high level of pressure to produce the numbers or you will be terminated after two quarters of not meeting your goals. Depending on your management team above you, you may be losing sales to the managers who sometimes compete with you for account openings, even though they do not have individual sales goals. If you don't speak Chinese or Spanish, your opportunities for employment can be very limited due to the "highly preferred" or "required" status.

review_title: Terrible company, terrible management. Please don't ever work here.
pros: The only pro is that I met some great people. Even though I was told who I could or could not go to break or lunch with. Unfortunately those great people were cut from this horrible company because BAC doesn't care about who is a hard worker and who meets their numbers. They rely on the close minded opinions of their management sheep to weed out anyone who has an independent thought and strives to do what's right for the customer and company.
cons: Low pay, high stress, unethical actions from Sr Mgmt. They don't care about their employees. People are just a number, easily replaced or cut. Your tenure doesn't matter. Your hard work and dedication doesn't matter. How other employees feel about you doesn't matter. This is the worst company you could ever work for!!

pros: Management will go out of their way to help you out. They will work with your schedule when you are in school as long as it is not too demanding. It is also a relatively relaxed work environment.
cons: People that you have to deal with can be quite rude, especially since you are dealing with their money. I also had to shave every day before work! What a bummer! Also, make sure you are never late because your job could be on the line. This job can also be quite stressful when under audit.

job_title: CRM In Military Home Loan Modification and Short Sales in Norfolk, VA
pros: Good benefits and average salary for experts, I was paid $20 hour with an MBA in Mgt. Turned down for management with 15 years of mortgage experience and no possibility of advancement, I am a man of many ethnicities, these people are Vipers looking to gather info then dump you.
cons: Mgt has their own agenda,  move up at the expense of their employees. It’s nonsense.

review_title: Great Benefits, no opportunity for Growth if you are the best
job_title: Senior Relationship Manager in Tampa, FL
pros:
Best Benefits 
401K 6% match every pay period and 2% annual contribution 
3 weeks paid vacation and 2 sick weeks 
Best infertility benefits - IVF (no lifetime cap), IUI - 100% paid for after deductible etc 
Great banking benefits - 50% more rewards on credit cards etc
cons: Middle level Management is unfair and do not promote their best employees due to personal gain. Sales goals are too aggressive and the better you do with sales the higher the goals will go. Work life balance is null in sales due to always having to meet sales quotas and not being able to take time off with family as you know you have aggressive sales goals that do not go away while you are on vacation. Managers do not allow you to take vacation when you want, even if you have earned your stripes and worked there for years. Was not able to take my wedding week off or honeymoon week and had to reschedule for 4 months down the road to appease my Manager.

review_title: I'm fortunate to work for Bank of America.
pros: Bank of America pays well for hard work and has great benefits, especially for those with families.  There is a huge pool of candidates applying for jobs so only the most talented people get chosen for a position, which means you're often working with very smart people who are good at their jobs.  There are always challenging tasks which allow every employee the opportunity to show what they're capable of.
cons: It can be very stressful at times to work at a company with such a high profile.  Everything you do in your work is scrutinized and there is always someone available to step in and take your job if you can't perform well.

review_title: review Senior Management jobs with qualifications and people skills
job_title: Vice President Operations in Charlotte, NC
pros: One reason is the prestige of working for a fortune 500 company.  Most of the employees who work for BOA are trained very well and have good work ethics and make great managers for other employers. BOA does not try to retain good employees.   The satisfaction surveys are not taken seriously. They are solely for the pasification of the employees so they feel issues are being scrutinized and there is a quise of concern. I am a 10 year associate and I experienced a lot of change. I believe the Bank is going down a path of self destruction with their associates.
cons: band 3 and 4 disregard for employees, ( Senior Management)

pros: The benefits are great and the people there are also great.  Having the opportunity to have a stable schedule and not a lot of late nights.  There is a really great team atmosphere.  The vacation time is super 3 or 4 weeks off a year.  Lots and lots of paid holidays are always a good thing to have.  8 weeks of paid leave if you have a baby, what are you kidding me who does that.  The company is a great place to work and I would reccomend it to anyone looking for a career. Overall it is a great employer.
cons: Would like faster promotions and pay increases.

review_title: The culture at BOFA benefits go-getters and those who do need added support to succeed.
pros: BOFA is a large corporation, so the opportunity to advance your career in different directions is there. As long as you continue to impress management w/ excellent performance and take care of your career goals, the sky is the limit.
cons: On the flip side of being a go-getters company, those that take more lax approach to their job or career will find it difficult to advance to any level within the company.

job_title: Banking Center Assistant Manager in Boston, MA
pros: You can not beat the Brand Recognition. Working in a banking center definitely hones in your ability to multi task.
cons: Chronically short staffed, management has to absorb the responsibilities of people who call out sick, miss work, have to be sent to other banking centers.  Days are long and can be stressful depending on which banking center you're working at.   Your day can quickly turn from helping customers with complex banking situations to disputing overdraft fees and filling in as a teller.

pros: Compensation and benefits are great.  They are hiring.  No pressure of sales, only referrals.  Automated system makes decision making easy.
cons: They prefer robotic employees who read scripts and don't get to know their customers.  Training is horrible, I was expected to train myself on a computer training course and then all of a sudden thrown on the teller line.  "360 Coaching", basically everyone can call you out on your job performance whenever they feel like it.  Hard to keep up with changes.  If you're part time, expect to work 5-6 days a week, even if you only work 20 hours.  Job stability with current market and layoffs.  Having to take negative feedback from customers, regarding changes to account fees.

review_title: A Day To Day Living Experience.
pros:
The managers let you do your job.  They are very hands-off, so if you're an independent worker and thrives on using your initiative to get things done, this is the place for you.

Although they are hands-off, they will guide and hand-hold you or the newbies when needed.  If they can't, do it, they will assign a mentor or senior to assist them.
cons: They move too slow.  The infrastructure is way too old.  The management decisions on support structure and processes takes too long to materialize.  Their thinking is still a bit old fashion, therefore making their decision process cumbersome.

review_title: Working at a place where a once great culture turned into misery.
job_title: Credit Analyst in Hunt Valley, MD
pros: Bank of America was a great experience, a good mixture of reasonable and unreasonable lower level managers, good chances to prove yourself, easy hours(relatively speaking).  Large amount of politics in a low level office.  Fellow associates were fairly nice in general.
cons: Weak salary, competitive, but not collegiate about it, everyone is a number.  Doing the right thing was not as important as doing the best thing for you, your manager, and your department.  Often felt pressure to do activities that weren't in the right spirit of judgmentally fair action.  Upper management treated the office more like a pen within which people had to be managed, and people embraced it.  People lacked professionalism in many cases, and lying/irregular behavior was common.  High turnover.

job_title: Operations Representative in College Park, GA
pros: Great benefits and a global company.
cons: I work in operations in College Park, GA.  This has got to be the worst place I have ever worked.  Management is incompetent, unprofessional, and they are bullies. They treat their long-term permanent employees horribly because they can fire us and bring in temporary employees and pay them pennies.  There is no room to grow in Lockbox and it is almost impossible to get out.

review_title: Large company... GWB Technology is not a good area to work in
job_title: Senior Vice President in Charlotte, NC
pros: A company this size has a lot of teams to support you... so you can (mostly) focus on your primary job/role.  If you are able to work within the confines of established processes you can be very effective.
cons: It is very difficult to change existing processes... even if it is clear they can/should be improved.  Very, very limited opportunity for advancement... current senior leadership direction is to bring in from outside and not promote from within.

review_title: Definitely somewhere where you move up and grow.
job_title: Sales & Service Specialist in Manassas, VA
pros: Training is very extensive, Great Hours, Great teams, Very good benefits.
cons: Depending on your location, it can be hard to meet your goals.

review_title: Good benefits, can be a great place to work - if you find the right group
pros: Benefits are solid. Flexibility in moving around to find work that interests you and fits with you. Its a big company so lots of room to explore.
cons:
Finding a good team can be tough and once you switch jobs you have to stay in it for a year, which can suck if its not a good fit (although I understand why they do this).

Lots of bureaucracy. Lots of regulation. Very corporate. I've never felt FULLY engaged at work. But I've also grown to accept thats probably not going to be the case for me at this company.

pros: Pay was great at first unlimited over time etc. BEST AND WORST OF MY 2 YEARS
cons: After a Year into my job Ive notice changes a lot of upper management leaving giving us excuses why they were going to another dept. Truthfully it was only because they saw the forecast and that forecast said 'LAYOFFS" yes!! we were laid off within 2 years! BANK OF AMERICA IS KNOWN FOR LAYING OFF GOOD EMPLOYERS!!! they wheel you in with the money (BAIT) and have you by the cord hanging for awhile.. then they CUT you OFF!! oh yeah then they had like an "in house job fair for us ..that was pretty much morphine to our pain..you know the pain is there but we will just mask it for a few hours.. that job fair was a joke!!

job_title: Consumer Sales/Service Representative in Kennesaw, GA
pros: 15.00 and some change start rate and "commission". 10 hr shifts available with 3 days off.The trainer,coworkers, and the Team Lead are awesome.
cons: They find ways to make sure u don't get the commission owed to you.micromanagement. if you have to go to the restroom you are timed and told that you must take that time off of your break.you spend your 3 off days off dreading going back .Managers ruin your sales by coming by yelling how many sales do you have.They don't have their excel system updated to where they are able to look at a spreadsheet and see how many sales you have or maybe they lack the knowledge of how to access ....so throughout the day they constantly ask you to send your sales tracker so they can see how many sales u have.They monitor your calls without a headset which is distracting and unprofessional because you will suddenly hear yourself echo from the supervisors desk and it's loud.

review_title: Slave labor. No work/life balance whatsoever. Not paid enough to deal with this.
pros: Great medical benefits. Pretty good PTO set up.
cons:
You rarely get to use that PTO because you're never allowed off work. Having regular scheduled days off is a joke; I'm a college student and explained that I had to have Tuesdays off for school, and even though I was assured during the interview process that it wouldn't be a problem, I eventually had to miss a lot of classes because they decided it was. Asking for a regular schedule will get you nowhere; they just expect you to work whenever they want you to, which means you're constantly on call.

Not to mention the long hours, which is what I meant by "Slave Labor." I've worked up to 10 hours a day with this company, and not by choice. Overtime is nice, but not that nice.

pros: Decent benefits, Great co workers, Decent starting pay
cons: Work load is very stressful from customers being upset with products always changing and long lines because we are understaffed all the time. Managers will be on your case to get referrals and threaten to fire you if you dont meet goal because corporate only cares about numbers and not the people who work for them.

pros: 13 years of experience with the Bank - decent benefit package - good partners to deal with.
cons: Unbelievable dysfunction in leadership - business needs change, but a change in leadership would bring massive changes and even layoffs, only to find out a year or two later that those positions eliminated needed to be put back in place.  And too many times the changes instituted ended up hurting the business.

job_title: Service Delivery Manager in Charlotte, NC
pros:
Great benefits
High base salary without the stress of Consulting and Investment Banking
Diversity Friendly company.  No really, BofA actually does
Relax working environment
Occasionally able to work from home.  Some groups work from home every Friday
cons:
Constantly restructuring 
The company did not pay for my relocation but did give a signing bonus
They do lay off people and will probably continue too as we automate more
Some groups can be "cut-throat" So, you have to be a good self-promoter.  
Networking and politics is a big part of the game here.  If you play, you'll be fine.  If not, you'll be left behind.

review_title: Managers Lack Integrity, Morals, or Decency
pros:
Quick Promotions within Teller and CSR slots due to constant turn over

2 Weeks paid vacation, 2 weeks unpaid to home of record or deployment related (if/when they see it as convenient to let you go) 2 weeks sick pay

$5250/year tuition assistance
cons:
Crooked management who retaliate when you refuse to compromise your integrity.  Upper Manager and HR Representatives who participate in this retaliation by lying about the actions of the managers who committed the retaliation.  Associates are nothing more than an NBK or Z # - 100% disposable.

No dental or health insurance.  No retirement program.  Nor 401K.

job_title: Financial Analyst in New York, NY
pros:
- well known global bank
- finance program allowed to rotate within several groups to support different products/services (I was fortunate enough to be in good groups, I know some of my peers were not.)
- managers looked after me for performance review purposes
- frequent finance events allowing analysts to network with higher-ups
- really focuses on building the future leaders in finance
cons:
- already a well-established bank, so no innovative or creative projects
- constant cost-cutting so computers run slow when dealing with large data
- your typical corporate banking culture

review_title: Stop merging and pay attention to business.
pros: The benefits are very good and will be getting better next year.
cons: The corporation is entirely too large and even associates at times do not know whom to call with questions or problems.  The red tape is suffocating and too many "business partners" are outsourced.

review_title: Ok Place to Work if you like the mega-corporation environment
pros:
My Work Program (flexible work arrangements - telecommuting).  This is the #1 reason why I'm still at the Bank.

They support volunteerism by letting you do volunteer work on their dime.

Positive attitudes are a must and this makes for a good work environment
cons:
Way, way too big for my taste.  Organizational structure and layers of management are too complex.

In some areas of the bank, they will eat you alive (if you let them) in terms of the hours you must work. 

Too many meetings!  Hard to get work done because of all the meetings.

Layoffs are handled VERY poorly.

review_title: Things to know before you work here
job_title: Personal Banker in Dana Point, CA
pros: The Hours are fairly good compared to most jobs.... If your decently hard working they'll promote you quickly. I started as a teller, then went to a sales and service specialist and now a personal banker.
cons: Compared to almost any bank their base pay is definitely lower. There system for opening accounts, doing account maintenance is old and not user-friendly at all.

pros:
work hours are good (only for some lines of business)
good processes/work flow
cons:
very bad for employees in a verge of building careers and are in junior/begginner level 
lower salary
not so good benefits
almost have fight for leave approval
holiday calendar of different every process based on LOB and no prominence for Indian Holidays
mind less HR policies
Over control on employee access and facility usage
excessive security measures for unnessary things
not good frontline leaders for all departments
you have to wait for 5 to 8 years even for a small promotion
mind less hierarchy.. which says..team developer.. in fact the position will not include in developing anything..
its very good for managers and above levels

job_title: Interaction Designer in San Francisco, CA
pros: Ridiculous amount of vacation right out of the gate: 4 weeks off plus 11 holidays, and 2 weeks of personal/sick time. 401(k) match - albeit at only 3% - *plus* a pension (in BAC stock, alas) that accrues at about $150 a paycheck (bimonthly). Ability to work from home and personal conf call line, choince between working on a Mac or PC, and general autonomy make it pretty hard toleave, no matter how unsatisfying and frustrating the experience.
cons: Lip service paid to the user's role in User-centered Design. Management ignorance of what design research/thinking are and unwillingness to explore beyond the status quo. Overwhelming amount of bureaucracy.

review_title: Beware if you are a legacy employee, especially if you were from Countrywide.
pros: The benefits and salary are great.  Opportunities for promotion are good.
cons: If you are working for a Countrywide trained manager, chances are they don't know how to manage people.  Bank of America has a great deal of red tape and bureaucracy like any other over-sized company.

job_title: Associate Operations Representative in College Park, GA
pros: Established company. Great discounts. Good benefits.
cons: I worked in the 6000 Feldwood Road location. It was like high school. We were trained decently, but not there were too many loopholes and every other week there was an error in how we were previously trained which made us have to go back in and retrain. There were so many weird little "do-and don'ts". There were no career advancements.

job_title: Financial Solutions Advisor in Chandler, AZ
pros:
-Typical benefits that most all investment firms offer their employees. 
-Decent building to work in but far from nice.
-Covered parking option
-Want 'Advisor' experience on your resume so you can get hired by a real firm.
cons:
-Very low base salary 
-Your title is 'Advisor' but your really not advising anyone and building a real book of business.
-Merrill Edge gets all the low end clients from BOA and Merrill L. 
-Managers are very very below average. 
-Two different working shifts?? Yes, it is a true call center environment.

review_title: Great company to work for, despite poor public opinion of Big Banks.
job_title: Assistant Vice President, Market Information Consultant in Chicago, IL
pros: Working from home has its benefits. Lots of flexibility in work schedule and ability to drive projects without constant micromanaging from higher-ups. The people I work with are incredibly smart and talented - it's a great company to develop your professional skill set and technical skills.  There are a lot of resources to develop your understanding of the company and the industry as a whole.
cons: Working from home also has its downfalls.  It can be very isolating to only have work interactions through technology. There have also been significant employee lay-offs over the past few years - doesn't help with feeling of overall job security.  I'm also doubtful that I will be able to move forward in my career path as quickly as I had been planning.

review_title: Personal Banker At Bank of America
job_title: Senior Personal Banker in Seattle, WA
pros: Really great HR team. Bank of America on the whole treats employees really well. Sometimes management is a bit questionable and it can be really political there but they pay well, and don't screw you over when you leave.
cons:
Personal growth: if you are good at sales they will keep you in sales even if you want to move into management. 
Company values: banks are all conservative. The more personality you show the less happy management will be.

review_title: It was just smoke and mirrors.
job_title: Mortgage Loan Officer in San Diego, CA
pros: Good employee benefits and the stand perks of working for a large corporation.  The offices are well furnished and the equipment is up-to-date.
cons: Much is promised, but very little is actually delivered to customers and employees.  There are many conscientious employees who are truly dedicated to providing superior service; however the company infrastructure will not allow them to provide quality service.  Everything is heavily weighted in the bank’s favor, at the customer’s expense.  This is extremely disheartening to employees and many leave.

pros: The pay was decent and I was able to promote  as quickly as possible.  Good environment to work in and there was a definite team atmosphere.  There was a positive drive to succeed and the training program was good.
cons: When I started it was required to be in your current position for 6 months to be considered for promotion.  About 5 months into my employment they changed it to 1 year, been there 5 months and 29 days?  Too bad.  I put in my year and was promoted.  They started closing call centers across  the USA and ours was one.  Lots of good people out of work.

review_title: Still finding self as a program
job_title: Financial Solutions Advisor in Los Angeles, CA
pros:
Great market resources through Merrill Lynch Research. 
Knowledgeable peers with strong backgrounds. 
Ideal for clients who don't want to pay high commissions compared to a traditional advisor.
Management actively listens to associate concerns and implements throughout the program. 
Ideal work/life balance.
cons:
Comp plan keeps changing every quarter. 
No book of business. 
Bank of America as a company does not do a good job in inculcating the culture across the company.

review_title: Tough environment; not for the faint-hearted
pros: Competitive salaries, fast-paced and challenging environment that can be professionally stimulating and fun; lots of great people to work with.
cons: Amount of work expected is often unreasonable; company recently reversed itself on its popular flexible work arrangements and is bringing employees back into offices (that don't actually inspire collaboration or creativity while at the same time putting a high expense burden back on employees); and company is often in expense-reduction mode making for a difficult work environment in which your job is very often in jeopardy.

review_title: Good depending on the branch atmosphere.
pros: Good work experience, and a step up from most customer service jobs. Great job to work while going to school if you take night or online classes. Some managers may be flexible with days allowing you to go to school 2 days a week.
cons: Depending on branch traffic it can be extremely taxing. My branch had 0 time between customers for almost the entirety of the branch's business hours. BoA is also very into their performance numbers, and require you to cold sell products to every customer and have a success rate of roughly 5%. Corporate incentive programs are often changed right before the term deadline in order to prevent people making goals and getting bonuses.

pros: Bank of America overall is a good company to work for however it does not pay you well enough for all the hard work you have to do. They seem to want reward you for your job well done but with food parties and a recognition award but it doesn't come with a salary increase. How ever with that said they do have a great Benefits plan for there employees and plenty of paid vacation.
cons: The cons would have to be salary, late policy, and I say that because Bank of America well the site I work in requires 80% of the building to be late due to a traffic alert which will never happen!

pros: Hours are great. Overtime eligible. Decent benefits. Opportuity to move up if you know people. Fairly easy to transfer to another branch if you're relocating.
cons: Low pay for the amount of bs they ask of you. Quaterly bonuses, which don't get paid out until a month and a half later. Weekly calls with market manager that go over the exact same thing. Goals constantly changing without notice. No matter your skills or experience you need to know someone to move up. Cutting cost with everything they can think of which hurts your customer satisfaction.

pros: Great benefits, reasonable salaries.  Opportunity to work with smart, talented, nice people.  Because it's a big company, once you've been hired, assuming you do a good job, there are always other opportunities within the company.
cons: Because of it's size, and because it's a heavily regulated industry, Bank of America has a lot in common with the U.S. Federal Government - lots of red tape, attempts at one-size fits all processes and solutions that end up not fitting many, require killing fleas with elephant guns, or put 2 weeks worth of process around something that could otherwise be handled in 20 minutes.   As with many employers, the drive to cut costs means the work load and stress level can be tremendous, requiring lots of overtime, and ever increasing offshoring of technology positions to India.

pros: Above average pay for managerial and technical staff. Nice work facilities.
cons: No working remote. Company got into the habit of laying people off 3-4 times a year during the down turn and haven't kick the habit. Get connected or get caught in a wave of Reduction in Force (RIF). No idea how employees last more than 10 years.

pros:
Great coworkers. Everyone truly looks out for one another. Great benefits and great hours. For those that work Saturday a day off during the week really helps to get everyday things done. Vacation package is pretty industry standard 3 weeks to start plus sick time. 

I’ve seen some complains about health insurance being expensive. In my opinion it is not that expensive for the what you get. I have a low deductible PPO plan for myself and my children and I find it to be rather affordable. 

If you come to work and do your job I think you can have a long and prosperous career.
cons: 401k does match at 5% but only after 1 year. Everything is extremely monitored and micromanaged but then again that comes with a heavily regulated industry.

review_title: Only place I know that had employees stuffing votes in a gingerbread contest
pros:
Work/Life balance, ability to work from home, fun holiday contests in between asking the offshore team to push my code snippet so I can view my changes in whatever you're calling the dev environment that month.

Career opportunities could be decent, might find a team that actually functions, compensation was approx 10% less than industry standard.
cons: Discriminatory environment where questionable favoritism is practiced for certain ethnicities, incompetence in designing code architecture, reliance on faceless teams to implement sporadic continuous integration, unnecessarily large amount of team members spread out in different areas doing the job 1 person could do in the real world. Relying on intimidation to prevent exposure of gross incompetence propping up failed custom software. Simply asking for documentation nearly would up in a shouting match witnessed by 8 people in a manager's office.

pros:
Great selection of benefits

Decent work / life balance

CEO does a good job during global town halls
cons:
If you're in an asset class that isn't seen as key to the bank but they want to keep it open in order to be a 'global power' your career will go nowhere

Much of the promotion process is based on whether people like you, as is the 360 feedback review process which is utter rubbish

Upper management full of cliques and fiefdoms

You're pressured to do 'socially responsible' work for pure PR reasons and nobody actually cares about the cause, it's all window dressing for the promotions process

Risk management are completely paranoid and have no understanding of non linear / derivative risk

When money is lost the knives are out

review_title: Great company, but could use a few tweaks
job_title: Premier Client Manager in Saint Louis, MO
pros: stable company,  leader in  banking, credit cards, mortgages, and now investments.    good   health insurance, vision and dental programs,   one of only a few companies that still offer a penison plan.  If you are not performing well in your current position, but have the right  attitude,  management will help you find annother opportunity within  the bank.  good opportunity for career growth.
cons: senior management fails to  acknowlege that  mistakes have been made with certain iniatives.  there are some managers that are managing sales people, but are not clear on the actual job resoonsibilites, or the day to day activities  that are required for the position

pros: Help pay for school, good benefits, retirement plans, 401k and pension plans.
cons: Hard to promote, the pay is not that good. If you have a family emergency it's hard to get a day off. Say they like us to work as a team but no one is willing to help you, when you have a question.

review_title: Great place to learn, bad place for promotions
job_title: Personal Banker in Country Club Hills, IL
pros: Excellent pay, incentive is great, very up to date with banking technology. Co-workers can make or break your experience. Thankfully a million ways to get a question answered
cons:
No work-life balance
Too many egos
Almost have to beg for promotion
Branch audits will be the most stressfull time your you
Managers will tell you it is 360 degree coaching but when you say something you get retaliated on
