Get ready for 10-15 new focus' a DAY
You will be defending where you work everyday because of the terrible press
Too many cutthroats

review_title: BAC Home Loans failing its loan officers
job_title: Mortgage Loan Officer in Atlanta, GA
pros: Tons of leads. They throw leads at you.
cons: They cannot close loans in a timely fashion. Fulfillment is very understaffed, and they let good processors and underwriters walk out the door rather than pay them what they're worth. I've lost credibility and income working here; in fact, I can no longer AFFORD to work here. Compensation is not competitive; pricing is in many ways not competitive. My customers are told by their realtors not to use BofA, and I can't say I blame them.

review_title: Very poor blame culture in Equities Middle Office
job_title: Head of Equity Finance Middle Office in City of London, England
pros: Ability to get involved in a range of projects as there is little taboo with regards to muscling in on other people's initiatives.  Lack of ability to hire externally means that there can be frequent opportunities for internal mobility.
cons: Strong blame culture.  Often teams are operating under significant pressure and fear or reprisals.  Middle Office strategy appears to be nebulous and frequently changes.  There is very little in the way of town halls / long term strategy communitcation which leads to an over active rumour mill which unsettles staff unneccesarily.

review_title: A diverse company with diverse internal experiences
pros: Wide range of opportunities and a very politically correct culture.  Bank of America has embraced the flexible work culture, and many employees can work form remote satellite sites or from home via telecommuting.  Lots of work to still be done in merging processes and technology from years of mergers and acquisitions.  Good benefits package
cons: Diminishing vertical movement due to layoffs aimed at middle and upper management across the board.  Consumer banking is a hectic culture, but the remainder of the bank has great work-life balance.  Bonuses and increases have been lackluster in last few years.  Remains to be seen if that will change now that stock is rising.

review_title: Bank of America is a good company to conduct business.
job_title: Data Entry Operator in College Park, GA
pros: Working for Bank of America is a good and productive opportunity, one learns all there is to learn about the position he or she is working and learning about other positions as well.
cons: The downside in working with Bank of American there is really not any that I can think of at the moment.  It is all what you as an individual puts in the job which in return you will receive back plus some.

review_title: Opportunity to learn and grown, but you are always at risk.
pros: Employees are presented with many career opportunities; within the bank and through relationships built with vendors, third parties, and customers alike.  With enough hard work, and dedication there are opportunities to promote and explore the various lines of business.
cons: Working for Bank of America is a very inconsistent experience- much like the experience of the customer.  While upper management has a strong direction, and established values- they are not executed consistently through the company.  Mid-level management has a lot of autonomy, which can cause for varied experiences for employees.  If you have a good manager, you'll have a good experience.

job_title: Accounting Analyst II in Fort Worth, TX
pros: Excellent benefits,retirement plans and time off. If you can get into a group that you click with the right people you will really enjoy your time at BAC. I really enjoyed working for the company but was in a bad group that had little work life balance and was ran by a large power click that would make your life miserable if you did not do things their way.
cons: If you end up in a group that has its power click formed then your best bet is to try be friends with them or stay out of it all together. If you avoid it completely you have a very little chance of being promoted in the appropriate timeline.  Management would not promote people within but would hire people externally with less experience and knowledge.

review_title: Responsible for 2 COO, 4 Directs and 177 FTE's.  Responsible for calendar scheduling, travel arrangements & expenses.
pros: Most interesting thing about my position was the ability to work with o workers in other countries (India, Costa Rica and Mexico). I especially enjoyed taking on the challenges of the calendaring and travel scheduling as well event planning for team and community events.
cons: As administrative assistant in BOFA it is hard to move up since they removed the position of Business Lead I & II within this position you would be able to learn more of the business and prove your analytical and communication skills.

job_title: Service to Sales Specialist in Kennesaw, GA
pros: Good hourly pay( $14.13). Great benefits( Aetna) and vacation package (10 sick days and 3 weeks vacay)
cons: They paint this pretty picture for you on how to make soooo much money in commission and it's absolutely false. You're pretty much tricking people all day to do balance transfer and direct deposits. These people are calling in to pay their bill or service their account and your whole motive is to pressure them into borrowing money of their card. You sit in this special Que. and are forced to make money off them. If you don't make your numbers you won't last. Run as fast as you can. The turnover rate is high! They have a training class every month. This should tell you something

pros: Worked here for 10+yrs. They have great benefits like no other. Offer employees discounts with a lot of things. Three weeks vacation after 5yrs of employment. Generally fun to work depending on management. Pay is decent to start. Opportunity for advancement is there if that's what you want.
cons: Was laid off without warning because they decided to eliminate the TOS role. Was handed a severance package and sent on my way. After so many years of service I expected better. Manager didn't even give a heads up. They are a competitive bank so your expected to sell sell sell even when no new customers are coming in. Hard to make your goals with the same people coming in daily.

pros: Benefits are great and the technology around mobile solutions are second to none.
cons: The company micro-manages their managers.  The amount of work that is required to complete (observations, surveys, customers complaints, opening new accounts, lobby leading, meeting all new customers, operations, ect...) in a day is unrealistic, especially when they begin to cut staff.  Higher end executives seem to be disconnected to the reality of the banking centers.  Now there goal is to cut the teller staff and increase seller staff.  In theory that sounds good but customers do not want to buy/open accounts when they had to wait 30 minutes to cash their checks.

pros: I honestly struggle to find anything Pro about this company and this role. The frontline employees (branch managers, bankers, and tellers) made me want to go to work each day. I truly enjoyed working with a great team.
cons: If you want to work in an environment where the priorities change daily, with constant reorganization (instead of firing people- they reorganize every 3-6 months). where there is no long term vision or strategy, then this is your company. There is constant turnover in the role. Constant!

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Jacksonville Beach, FL
pros: I worked with a Lot of Great People, Opportunities are Available with the Right Managers,
cons: There is Some Favoritism with Some Managers and if you speak up, it is held against you like you are a "Trouble Maker".   When I was Down Sized, I went to speak with HR in Person and they REFUSED to speak to me face to face.  That is NOT how you treat your employees or co-workers.  I was still receiving a Severance Package at the time.

review_title: Teller Position at Bank of America
pros: It all depends on the banking center you work for and which management you fall under. Very fast paced environment but given paid vacation times off out of the year. Bank is very technology advanced compared to other banks and overall a pretty great place to work.
cons: Budget cuts are minimizing staff which means more customers and less tellers and bankers to assist which leads to angry customers. NO BONUSES for exceeding sales goals like other banks do which is terrible. For example other banks would reward you for selling products such as credit cards but bank of america just gives you a pat on the back. Also very hard to get promoted.

pros: Excellent benefits. Depending on the line of business, relative stability. Decent pay. Due to general apathy of workforce, it doesn't take too much to stand out... and excel, as long as you toe the line, and kiss up a little.
cons: Too many higher-ups held over from Countrywide. Anything but a meritocracy. So focused on watching expenses, they end up cutting the legs out from beneath their employees due to a lack of support. They preach one thing, and reward another. Focus on expenses has also led them to hire a lot of unprofessional employees. Overall quality of work and workers is suffering.

review_title: Horrible, awful company that would be a waste of your time to work at. Please do not work here....this is a warning
job_title: Customer Service and Sales Specialist II in Brea, CA
pros: Nothing, well....they pay you...............they want me to write a 20 word minimum but I actually don't have anything nice to say about this company. It's a sad excuse for a company and one day due to its lack of caring about its employees or customers,  it will go down. Can't wait
cons:
Company does not care about its associates. 
Company does not care about its customers.
Bank of america is a sad excuse for a company that doesn't even pretend to care about its employees or customers.  I wouldn't be surprised when this company dies out to its lack of giving a you know what about anybody.  The fact that they don't even care about their employees should really show how much they don't care about customers or how they screw them over.

review_title: Experience can vary depending on team
job_title: Assistant Vice President, Programmer in Chicago, IL
pros:
- Competitive salary and benefits

- Good work/life balance and great flex work programs (depends on team)

- Some interesting projects (depends on team)
cons:
- Some teams do not allow flex work programs (work from home, work remotely, etc)

- There are a lot of awful legacy apps to integrate with and support, and a lot of work can be a slog

- The bureaucracy has gotten really bad and it makes it hard to get actual work done

- It's almost impossible to do anything truly innovative that would shake up the status-quo

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: The company is large and there are many opportunities to grow and learn. Leadership is very willing to mentor as long as the mentee is willing to learn. There are educational and growth opportunities everywhere. The bank has a good structure and strong leadership & HR policies provide a clear understanding as to what each person's job entails.
cons: Talent Retention. Employees abusing HR policies in regards to LOA. (Probably prevalent in most corporations.)

job_title: Assistant Vice-President, Financial Solutions Advisor in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Great Benefits and hours with the ability to help clients on both sides of the balance sheet.
cons: Intensely negative culture with very few positive comments made by management.  No investment management or holistic conversations in the role, only product pushing. Goal is to "deepen" relationships with bank customers, but the real goal is to sell a Bank of America credit card or debt product first. Extremely unrealistic goals as they are monthly.

job_title: Help Desk Coordinator in Ruskin, FL
pros: competitive environment to work, allowing you different opportunities and great for learning. great company to work for if under the right manager. the benefits are pretty good!!
cons: due to the cuts the company has taken the approach to over work those that have stayed with the company and will burn you out quick. the cons to that is the company is bleeding great talent due to failure to understand workload limits and work life balance.

review_title: Financial Center Client Service Representative I (Teller)
job_title: Financial Center Client Service Representative I in New York, NY
pros: Part-time employees get full-time benefits
cons:
Almost always understaffed and work schedule of 8+ hours in a day leads to quick burnout and decreased job satisfaction. No incentives/bonuses for teller referrals. Outdated processes and technologies. The pay could be better for tellers, who actually do a lot more than just being a 'teller'. 

All and all, it really depends on who your manager is. If you have a good manager, then work will be enjoyable. If not, then work will not be as enjoyable (lack support, voice not heard, lack of open discussion/flexibility).

review_title: Not bad; not mind blowing awesome either
pros: There is good work culture in BoFA, managers don't seem to push workers to do overtime. The technology stack I worked on is new and will be beneficial to me in the long run. Overall, technically I learned a lot, which I liked.
cons: For a technical person, we are easily spoiled by companies, treated to free food and games all the time. The stiff culture of a bank has rubbed itself on the tech department too. What I mean is that there is no "exciting" vibe at the office. You sit, log in, work and come back home. Day in and Day out. It can very easily make you monotonous.

pros: Training was fun, Buckhead, Atlanta.  They certainly give a first good impression.
cons: Hired to sell clovers, however the real incentive was in credit card processing.  The company does not adequately train reps on this complicated process and ultimately reps mislead customers.  I found the company to be unethical in baiting businesses in and increasing their processing rates shortly afterwards.  Also seasoned reps had so many more resources and were often fed leads and really didn't have to work too hard to get new businesses.  New reps go out in the field with very little resources.

job_title: Fraud Analyst II in Kennesaw, GA
pros: Benefits, location. Can't think of any other pros. Sorry. None, none, none, none, none, none, none, none. I can't think of 20 words for the pros.
cons: Higher management may ask for opinions but never follow through with it.  Advancement , bonus, and salary increase based upon on what higher ups you know or who you kiss up to. If you are a certain older age don't count on moving up. Very high turnover. Twice a year they do a massive firing so you may come in and end up with no job so NO JOB SECURITY.  Call center a gossip mill.  Parking is horrible at this location and building dusty and moldy.

pros: I honestly can't think of a single positive thing about this department. All I can say is that the entire company is not like that... Only that department
cons:
1. They will hire you saying it's a non sales role but it's the most sales centered department in the whole bank.
2. Be prepared to be micro managed and account for your every minute of every day (you only get 7 minutes of unaccounted time per day)
3. Training was limited and sparce and you are expected to perform immediately 
4. Very little employee appreciation (manager told team we should be lucky we are in a building with  A/C and plumming)
5. No matter how much you speak with upper management or HR about the morale of the team nothing is done.

review_title: You don't need a college degree to work here.
job_title: Premier Client Manager in San Francisco, CA
pros: The benefits. They may cost a little more that at other banks, but they really are first rate. I have a friend who survived cancer and it didn't put him in the poor house. In 2009 they are increasing the paid maternity leave to 3 months!!! I hope that despite the recent weakness in earnings that they don't cut back.
cons:
Top down management style. It seems like every month we have a new directive.There is so much information to keep track of that it is easy to miss something and even harder to remember where you first saw something.
In CA the computer systems are ancient, and they don't work with other parts of the country.

review_title: Worked to the Bone, with no advancement or mentorship
job_title: Senior Personal Banker in Albuquerque, NM
pros: I suppose everyone needs to eat and have a roof over their heads. This is one way to get it.
cons: The obsessive compulsive sales culture of this company ignores growing its associates and instead pays for other firms to do it. This bank is a very hungry demon hell bent on having every financial product you could want housed under one roof. Associates are forced to sell accounts clients don't need.

review_title: bofa ok but could be better
job_title: Banking Center Manager in New York, NY
pros: No license needed to be a personal banker, good place to start from the bottom and work to the top if you have the patience and know the right people.
cons: Rather not say too much since everything is being monitored by the company, even online web pages.  However, no support of banking licenses in the consumer level brings the value of the sellers down if the bank goes out of business.  In addition, the mentality of coaching each other is great if you're coaching your peers, not your superiors.  They don't take too kindly in that.

review_title: large organization that seems to promote diverse work experience
job_title: Assistant Vice President in Charlotte, NC
pros: Bank of America is a huge organization that provides a lot of opportunity to move within the organization (it easier to find new roles once you are in the bank as opposed to applying from the outside based on my experience, at least in this market).  Great benefits but I think salaries are average.  Very flexible with work location and time-off (based on my experience in finance supporting GIB and risk management supporting the mortgage LOB).
cons: Due to the large size of the organization one would expect greater economies of scale.  Merging databases across the bank can prove challenging and I have known of groups performing essentially the same function that don't even know each other exists.

review_title: A good - but uninspiring - place to work.
pros: The work is somewhat challenging, but largely uninspiring.  Little is truly cutting-edge, though there are some pockets of innovation to be found.  The work/life balance is generally great.  Working from home is a common practice.  Some jobs require that you work from home and provide you the equipment and reimbursements to set up a home office.  12 weeks of maternity - and paternity - leave.
cons: It's uninspiring not only because a lack of innovation, but also because of an opaque promotion process.  Taking on additional responsibility is easy...but it's difficult to get formally recognized for it.

job_title: Summer Analyst in New York, NY
pros:
- decent benefits
- lots of opportunities to learn about other lines of business
- a good number of events
- decent job location (1 bryant park)
- salary on par with street average, and they also pay overtime for the summer
cons: frankly, working in bofa investment banking has the same downsides as working in investment banking at most firms.  the difference is that since bofa investment banking isn't the best on the street, there's a lot less pride involved.  if you want to go to bofa for investment banking, make sure you talk to current employees and do your research about the best groups to get into.

review_title: Great name recognition and foundation for business leads and cross selling.  Good place to weather through the economy
pros: Mutiple locations through out the world.  The bank has overcome stigma from TARP by way of the pay back of these funds.  Is well diversified in banking channels.
cons: Slow to adjust to change as a result of the massive size and layers of management.  Recent technology shifts have created challenges in many areas, however thes challenges are being addressed and hope to be overcome.

pros: Good benifits...ie.$240 child care reimbursement, tuition reimbursement, medical and dental.
cons:
Constant change... One week you work late on Monday then due to market changes you now have to come in extremely early on Saturday. Which is not hard to deal with but the constant changes make it hard to have good work life balance.

Promotions are dependent on how much you kiss up to higher ups...this is normal but at Bank of America it is extreme. 

You have great benefits but if you use it...ie sick days, Maternity  or paternity leave you are treated  as if they want to say how dear you. 

High stress. If you do not open accounts you will be chewed out and made to write an action plan when the real problem is lack of good products.

review_title: Legacy Asset Services division is a dump
pros: Working remotely is a big benefit but is being phased down. Supposedly outside of LAS, things are much better.
cons: LAS is a dump. LAS is where enthusiasm goes to die. Zero organizational stability, management loves to make frequent org changes. If messing around with org charts were a sport, the Bank would be a gold medal winner hands down.

review_title: A volatile employee retention environment, but overall a very positive experience.
pros: Fast changing, fast paced environment with little time for the mundane!  Ability to work remotely or from home (depending on the job).  Good employee benefits.  Great parental leave benefits including for adoptions. Company encourages community volunteerism during work time. Overall, the people I worked with worked together great as a team and were very cooperative in helping each other succeed for the good of the team/company.
cons: Frequent management changes and reorganizations, which often leads to layoffs and assignment to new responsibilities for those who remain. Teams are often global, which is a pro and con. However, this means one may often talk with team members without ever meeting them in person.

pros: Minimal promotions opportunity, lacking internal department or lateral transfers.  Pidgeon holed into job task.  Too many middle line managers.  Top salaries paid to non-production people. The backbone of that company are the employees who do the grunt work and receive minimal pay.  Use too many contractors who are below par to complete a task.
cons: The Performance Appraisal process is bogged down, cold, manipulated, and a poor tool to provide an honest detailed review.

review_title: Most stressful job ive ever had
job_title: Teller Operations Specialist in Chicago, IL
pros: The pay was good, most of the co workers were really nice, customers for the most part were nice.
cons: The technology used was old, the bosses micro manage so much and were jerks, understaffed, bosses only looking out for themselves and how they look to higher ups. My Part time job felt like a Full time job and I had nightmares sometimes.

job_title: Banking Center Assistant Manager in Seattle, WA
pros: Depending on who your manager is there is little to no micromanagement throughout day to day business.  They only really crack down when their bosses come in for visits.
cons: No structure from banking center to banking center.  I became an assistant manager and in all the banking centers they sent me to it was as if I had to go back to basics with employees, sometimes the manager.  The common pain points are new employees who don't know better or senior employees who are burned out and no longer care.

review_title: Great Place to start a career
pros: Great company to work for if you are looking to start an actual career, any high level person you speak to will also try to make sure that you know that this is a place to grow and develop your skills. Extremely team oriented, everything you do is a reflection of the team you are on and they stress how important it is for you to seek support from your team on multiple levels. Bank of America is extremely diverse in the backgrounds of its employees. Volunteer work is highly encouraged and you do get recognition for it and its fun!
cons: It can be a bit stressful trying to stuff a bunch of banking rules and regulations into your head but again your team is there to help you!

review_title: Pretty Good Company for Stepping Stone
pros: Salary is pretty decent as well as health insurance, 401k, benefits, 4 weeks paid vacation, 10 sick days, 10 holidays. Management is friendly and approachable for questions. After 6 months, can start working 2 days from home. Early out before holiday-weekends are regular. Work environment is clean and adequate. Employee networking and mentoring opportunities available.
cons: Work-life balance seems to be skewed towards work side more often than not. Hours are long and work on weekends (albeit from home) may be needed to finish projects. Sometimes juggling multiple projects with various deadlines. As the first job out of college, it takes a lot to get used to the 9-5 especially at a desk job, but still good for stepping stone.

review_title: A job for those with a cold side.
pros: Office culture was fantastic, people are great to work with and management is always there for there employees personal needs
cons: Transactional company looking to nickel and dime their customers. A good short term business plan but will struggle to maintain longterm relationships with clients.

review_title: Unrealistic production quotas and constant threat of layoffs
pros: Very relaxed dress code. Tennis shoes, t-shirts, sandals.  I've seen many just roll out of bed and come to work. You can listen to earphones all day long. Good lunch room atmosphere.
cons: They give you plenty of work that you're supposed to complete by end of day.  If you just a little left within your last 10 minutes, they add a ton of work to your tray.

pros:
Competitive salary compared to the same position in other banks.

Overall strong company
cons:
Unfortunately busy to a point where certain management wont give PB's time to follow up with existing clients.

No longer allow PBs to be responsible for HELOC/HELOAN closings, which can serve as huge relationship builders.

Happiness in the job is truly dependent on the team you work with however management plays a key role.

pros: They were very accommodating to my school schedule. Depending on branch, managers can be nice and easy to get along with.
cons: Pay compensation was very low to the amount of work that needed to be done. Lines were always long and out the door and managers did very little to help with line. Very old systems used and slow network which in turn would take a while to service customers. Certain managers would never be consistent and enforce rules upon other employees. Can become very frustrating.Culture was terrible and felt like a school. Conference calls would be area wide and calling out employees on 'low numbers' and discuss what they need to do to improve while everyone else listens uncomfortably.

pros:
-Relatively respected position at good company
-Networking encouraged; people across company are willing to speak to you
-Lots of social activities, official and unofficial
-Depending on your placement, you will learn or expand on Excel, SQL, EPM, and other programs
cons:
-Work can be extremely slow depending on your role
-Cannot pick full time placement

pros: Get Licenses for Series 7 and Series 63. Great training program and manager. The team leads are very helpful (Depends on certain leads). Clear career progression if you are doing well. Manager will help you for your career progression. Another good thing is, once your shift is done, you don't have to take it home. Metrics are very reasonable, not hard at all as long as you follow directions.
cons: Either you make it or blow it. Very busy call center. This is just to get your foot at the door. Micromanagement to the max, and the manager has easy jobs. They seem to just talk and chilling all the time while everybody is busy working. Not encouraging sometimes.

pros: great people to work for, however, they often lash out on each other because of high stress at work. 401k is great, so is vacation time.
cons: too much stress in the work place, expect too much from there employees with minimal pay. for such a large company they do very little for there employees. i mean, they don't even offer a holiday party at the end of the year to show there appreciation. but.. things can always be worse. i could be without a job!

pros:
- 9 to 5, Monday through Friday work day
- Good benefits (health care, education/childcare reimbursement)
- Many locations
cons:

job_title: Investment Specialist in Rolling Meadows, IL
pros:
They pay you to study and take your Series 7 and 66 exams. 
Benefits are really good. Great health care and 401k. 
Coworkers are pretty awesome and made coming to work every day bearable.
cons:
CALL CENTER JOB! 
They don't mention this almost at all during the hiring process. No transparency. They also don't tell you that when you start working after you pass your exams, you get stuck working the worst shift. 
Taking 40-50 calls a day is emotionally draining. I've been taking calls for almost a year and I cant do it anymore. You deal with so much bull on a daily basis it's unbelievable. The job itself really sucks. 
The managers also clearly play favorites. If you aren't "volunteering" or kissing up, you won't move up. If you come in, do your job consistently and well, but you're quiet, you'll be completely unnoticed. 
The systems are horrible and outdated. The lack of ownership and communication between departments is astounding. 
Pay is mediocre and bonuses are hard to get. If you aren't available taking calls 80% of the time, you won't get a bonus.  Bonuses are based mainly on "soft sales" and calls that are graded by a third party. But really you have to sound like a robot and be incredibly nosy and ask where people have their money and if they want to bring it over to Merrill Edge. Some managers are super cool and made work fun. Others have ZERO people skills and get angry when you ask them questions. 

Get your certifications, get your experience, and GET OUT! Any longer than a year at this place will takes ages off your life.

review_title: Big Company. Take Advantages of Your Opportunities

pros: Pretty good benefits, lots of opportunity if you have a great network
cons:
Constant layoffs, lack of leadership, lack of strategic direction in mid to lower level of management. 
Salaries are mediocre in some departments. You're never in a position to ask for more compensation because your manager (who knows who you are and what you do) lacks the ability and controls to increase it. You will not know what your min or max salary is for your job code and conversations with your manager about it are useless. Bonuses in some departments are a joke and more insulting than their worth.

pros: This is a great position for loan officers looking to learn the industry and build their careers. For the first twelve months of your contract you receive a very fair base salary. During this time the expectation is that you will learn the B of A systems, processes, and underwriting guidelines; establish strong, mutually beneficial relationships with your financial center partners and associates from the different lines of business within the bank- Merrill, US Trust. Small Business Banking, Commercial Banking, etc.  and build your pipeline to the point that after the first 12 months, when you are transitioned to a lower base salary, your commissions are sizable enough to more than make up the difference. I've been in this role for a little more than 12 months and I am currently living this reality, but not all of my colleagues have been so lucky. During the first twelve months it is my advice to board as many loans as possible- purchase, refinance, and HELOC, and to not worry about the loan amounts. This not only puts you in a good position to reach the 12 month bonus goal, but it allows you to effectively learn the ins and outs of the internal processing, underwriting, and closing processes, and helps fortify your working relationships with your financial center partners who you will find are your strongest and most consistent source of leads. Demonstrating your ability to deliver for your teammates while simultaneously making a name for yourself with your clients and business partners in the community will put you in the best possible position to transition out of the runway period. The pricing is incredible, especially for preferred rewards clients, and jumbo loans. If a borrower has accounts with the bank you save a good amount of time tracking down asset statements, and gathering contact information, which can be a fairly arduous process compared to working for a broker or correspondent lender
cons: The underwriting standards are TOUGH, but once you learn them, you'll find yourself working almost exclusively with borrowers who are more than qualified, as opposed to chasing deals ridden with credit/income/asset issues. Most likely your processors and underwriters will be based off-site at the regional fulfillment center, which can lead to communication breakdowns. Despite the division of labor, which is intended to streamline the processing, you'll need to be plugged in every step of the way to ensure your loans close on time. Processors can get backed up and things sometimes fall through the cracks

review_title: Lost in Mr Potter's world... 'It's a wonderful life'..

job_title: Assistant Banking Center Manager in Hamilton, NJ
pros:
Benefits 
Schedule 
Holidays off
Tuition Reimbursement
Opportunity to move up (not to far up)
cons:
Schedule (if you are a prefer OT its hard to come by)
Cross training is a curse you will have to run all around doing different things
If you make to much and you are not producing numbers you will be managed out and replaced with someone at the fraction of the cost
You're not viewed as a community bank, instead as a money hungry corporate employee by the customers
They get rid of positions when they realize that another lower position is can do the similar responsibilities

pros: Good company to work for as far as benefits and vacation goes. Nice, clean, bright work environment. You also get 80 hours of personal time in addition to 3 weeks paid vacation.
cons: They absolutely do not pay enough and are far too discrete about salaries amongst peers. The band levels don't make a lot of sense as it is completely up to the department to decide if you are getting a raise each year. Also, last year, I exceeded in all metrics and received a less than 2% raise.

pros: Large organization with a tremendous breadth of opportunities to diversify skill set and experiences in the Financial Services industry.  Generally well-organized with strong management.  Seems to sincerely want to improve itself and listens to employee feedback. Supports work-life balance in most lines of business.
cons: Must be willing to navigate organization on your own to carve out career opportunities and mobility.  Salaries are competitive, but raises are slow to come by.  US-centric management structure, which can disappointing for those with international career ambitions.

review_title: A great company to work for.
pros: BOA offers so many great benefits. For example, 4 months paid maternity or paternity leave, up to 10 days paid sick days a year. Top notch insurance companies. And I could go on and on.
cons: Promotions within the company are tough to attain. Local management tends to hire personnel they personally know from their previous employment somewhere else rather than promote within,  their well qualified personnel.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Great pay and benefits and good on resume.
cons: There are no place for people from external to succeed. There are extremely few that will succeed coming from external due to politics and not giving external opportunities to develop. When you are from outside of the company they will nitpick you although they knew you are an external and micro manage you and shrink the space for you to develop and set you a path to lose. Most ppl from external were pressured to a point that they voluntarily quit the job by the internals.

pros: I worked in the call center so it was really easy to get the hours and days off I needed.
cons: In the Las Vegas Area the hourly pay for this position would be considered high but for all the work you do, Bank of America should pay more. Being a Customer Service Rep for Bank of America is extremely challenging because of management, call flow and the type of calls that you recieve. The way Bank of America processes payments and transactions are pretty confusing for even the Reps. In addition, yes I understand its a call center and calls will be monitored and recorded but they were overly meticulous on what verbiage to use.

review_title: Worked there for 3 years , so glad to leave the company
pros: Don’t work at Bank of America , I will never recommend my family and friends to work there
cons: They only look at you as a number , so aggressive with sales, so much pressure and not realistic strategies.

pros: Bank of America the best benefits in the industry. For instance: tuition reimbursement, child care reimbursement, 401k, medical, dental, vision, etc.
cons: It is sometimes a struggle to receive deserved time off. Also promotions and transfers are not as easy to come by and seemless as the company makes them out to be.  The hiring process is the worst because it is out-sourced fvrom the individual banking centers, and if you aren't even being considered for a position anymore they usually don't have the courtesy to tell you.

pros: You're working at a bank with a large presence in a diverse set of groups so the "universal" bank model can definitely add leverage for whichever group you work in.  Also, if you find opportunities in other groups you can switch to them which can be easier than switching from one bank to another.
cons: Overall it was an okay experience, but remember you are working from a bank based in Charlotte.  The man focus of the company is to cut costs and grow through acquisitions.  Layoffs are common and at no point is there much consideration for an employee's compensation.  At any point, the company will take your money (year end bonus) and run.

pros: Lots of different jobs to choose from- Fairly good benefits- Good people at the ground level- More training than you can shake a stick at
cons: High pressure training schedule. Forced to rely upon incompetent departments for common tasks. Middle and upper management lacks basic understanding of how their decision impacts the little people.  Too many of the upper management simply don't care about the ground level associates.

pros: Great pay, great benefits, and great advancement opportunities! Full time and part time employees are eligible to get full benefits, which other employers don't. The hours are great, not to early not to late, and hour long lunches gives you plenty of time to do things during your lunch.
cons: Favoritism can be apparent but it depends on a center by center basis. You do have to wait 12 months before be able to advance to another position, which can be a drag if you clearly show skills and capacity for the new position you want.

job_title: Summer Analyst in City of London, England
pros:
Nice people, approachable. Junior managers do make an effort to integrate new starts.
Reasonable work/life balance
Good pay in relation to amount of brain power involved in work.
cons:
Lack of communication from senior and middle management about important issues such as hiring strategy. 
No long term analyst developement program- training and developement is pretty haphazard. In some divisions talent is simply hired from elsewhere to fill senior jobs- not a good place to start off. Probably go here to earn more once you've learned what you need to elsewhere, i.e at better firms.

review_title: Love the people but it's a behemoth
job_title: Vice President in New York, NY
pros:
The global markets area has a lot of great people - very smart.  The old ML culture and new BofA culture has combined to make a great unit.
Because the company is so large there are many opportunities but you have to be patient since things move slowly here
Great work life balance (although this largely depends on your management chain and work area)
cons: The company is so large so there is a lot of red tape and decisions are made slowly.  Sometimes in groups that have too many levels of management, people lack empowerment and this causes operational inefficiencies.

job_title: Assistant General Counsel in Charlotte, NC
pros: Pay is comparable to a large law firm, but few if any weekends or late nights.  There are some people who have worked at Bank of America for decades and who like it.  Further, your role will change frequently, and so the job you are hired for won't be the job you're doing in even a year.
cons: Extremely stressful; lots and lots of politics (and so much of your time is spent fighting with people internally); uncertainty, with frequent rounds of layoffs that are not performance-based.  People can win medals for performance one day and be terminated shortly afterwards.  Also, few opportunities for internal advancement; promotions are rare.

review_title: Bad corporate decisions are killing the bank!
job_title: Customer Relationship Manager in Getzville, NY
pros: Great benefits, good pay. Fun work environment.
cons: Poor assessment of talent. They will hire anyone, and that anyone is usually not the most qualified person for the job. The bank is too big. Associates show a lack of ownership in my division and it definitely hurts the customer. Poor management decision are frequent and the customer is put last.

review_title: Get In the Clique or Get Fired
job_title: Senior Project Manager in Tempe, AZ
pros: Great pay after being employed for more than 3 years.  Allows "My Work" which lets employees telecommute.  This is a great opportunity and a valuable job perk.  Salaried employees get 6 weeks paid vacation starting day-one.
cons: Expected to think like the clique to fit in.  The department exercises Girl Power mentality.  If you are one of the girls, you are likely to be allowed to stay a long time within the department and will be promoted.  Poor management structure.  Management does not communicate with the employees.

pros: BAML is a aggressive and results-focused culture that also highly values relationships and relationship-building.  Things are generally done pragmatically and fairly quickly. BAML can be a good place to try to get your friends hired since the friendships are often what counts for getting head as much as your skills or knowledge.
cons: People can take things a bit personally here compared to other bulge brackets. People at the firm can have trouble taking the long view, going strategic, or making decisions based on actual business drivers rather personal or political considerations.

review_title: It would have been a great experience, if it wasn't for the district manager breathing down your neck all the time.
pros: Pay wasn't the best but it sure does beat minimum wage.
cons: Considering that the bank is the busiest in the area it would be nice for management to consider chairs, it may not seem like a big deal to some but consider working for 8 hours in one position. I understand it is a bank and their are a lot of regulations to be followed but the assistant managers displaced their stress on tellers. Forget getting sick or an emergency happening, NO DAYS OFF. My coworker had to drop a quarter at school because she couldn't get the days off and she couldn't find another job.

review_title: My experience with Bank of America was very good. I felt always opportunity to further my career within the company.
pros: The environment was a great place to work until the layoffs started. However management was very good about keeping an open door policy and talking to everyone about concerns all the time. The benefits were great working for Bank of America. I enjoyed my job very much.
cons: I feel some of the managers could have had better training. The division I worked in sometimes hired managers because they excelled at their current position and didn't give them any training to be a good manager.

pros: The Application Teamwork.  The team kept our eye on the goal, leaving drama and corporate pressures out of our immediate concerns.  We were nice to each other.
cons: Lay-offs.  In the 30 years I worked at Bank of America, I am sure I've seen 15 large lay-off situations.  That is an average of one every other year.  Boeing used to have a worse record that Bank of America, but I think that has changed.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros:
The stress level in IT is lower compared to similar banks.

The benefits package is decent, a little above average.
cons:
Very bureaucratic, process rather than result oriented. Nothing against the idea of process per se, there has to be a work discipline, but it should help one do one's job, rather than hinder, delay or frustrate.

A lot of support is outsourced and the most trivial change may trigger the process machine: a project manager, an architect, a design engineer and implementation engineer will have to available to be assigned for a routine task which will then take 2 weeks for a 15 minutes actual implementation time.

job_title: Teller Operations Specialist in Miami Lakes, FL
pros: Working with the teller team and with clients was the best part of my day. I was very passionate. They also have great benefits !
cons: It got to the point that the sales were unattainable, my team was very discouraged, most of them quit around the same time, they eliminated my job and didn't want to promote me even though my numbers were always great, and it was very hard to get the tuition reimbursement. I cried the day I left because it hurts when you put your all into a company and the end of the day you are just some employee.

pros: I actually can't think of any
cons: I worked here once before- it hasn't changed, I actually think it's gotten worse. I've had management tell me that I'm replaceable and that they basically don't care what you think or how you feel. They don't let the teller line sit while they are helping customers, this is one of the only banks that does this, but everyone else sits while they help customers so that doesn't make a ton of sense. They work with minimal staffing.

job_title: Teller I in Glen Burnie, MD
pros: Worked there part time, managers worked with my school schedule and were very flexible when it came to the schedule. Off on holidays, benefits were decent, able to purchase additional days off
cons: Tellers were forced to get referrals and harass customers. Offered pressured to make people sign up for accounts and credit cards but never received commission while the personal bankers received credit. If the bank didn't meet goals due to a few people unable to balance the cash and others not meeting goals we lost out on bonuses and raises which was absurd. Work there 2 years and never received a raise insane

review_title: Bank of America can be the best but not necessarily secure
pros: Excellent training, mentoring, competitive pay, benefits, and potentially opportunities to move within the company. They support volunteerism and education. Current technology and fast-paced.
cons: Volatile market and the company has been downsizing every quarter for the past couple years. I've seen the best talent and hardest workers let go, literally dozens that I knew personally. There doesn't to be much logical rhyme or reason to is selected for layoff so it can be nerve-wrecking. The company is so big, the people are just numbers.

pros: Tuition reimbursement, maternity leave, paternity leave, paid vacation, paid holidays, health insurance. Lucky to work with a good team.
cons: Overworked, policies are not complied with and management has told employees if they approve something it has to be done otherwise it is "insubordination", inconsiderate management, making managerial exceptions are very inconsistent, no empathy for employees, selling expectations are not attainable or customized for the traffic of each branch, excessive training, everything is micromanaged, employees are treated as if they are in grade school, no overtime is allowed yet every branch is understaffed.

pros: Decent benefits and time off
cons: Very low raises once you are employed. Numerous layoffs and management shifts. Be prepared to resell yourself even time there is a management change. They used to have a great work from home program they have cancelled due to so many layoffs and now empty building space. The culture is very stressful now. Working from home was a huge benefit and counted on as part of the compensation package for many.

job_title: Operations Project Analyst in Pittsburgh, PA
pros: Great benefits, excellent diversity and inclusion. Female leaders abound. Does thin out towards the very top though. Work life balance is okay as long as nothing is due soon.
cons: Too many buzzword aficionados trying to mask their lack of knowledge with fancy jargon. Downsizing is always a concern. There's still a culture of favoritism despite efforts to the contrary. Working across the country (and sometimes world) means weird meeting hours. Oh and way way way too many meetings and superfluous processes. They cut the little guy doing production but there is so much fat in the middle... some people have cushy do nothing jobs and others work like crazy.

pros: Great benefits. Great team. Overall experience is positive.
cons: Certain individual achievements are not applauded. Work is not delegated based on qualification and abilities. One size fit all work delegation stifles performance.Working under the constant threat of downsizing and layoffs is depressing. Top heavy management.

job_title: Bank Teller in New York, NY
pros: There is practically none.
cons:
By far, the worse job and company I ever worked for! 
- Lunch Breaks are to short by the time I got back I had to be back on the clock
- The worse management team to ever exist. Didn't know how to talk to people and there was no reward when goals were suceeded
- There was no patience to newcomers to retail banking
- we had to stand for long hours and be fake 100% of the time
- vacation & sick days were given but looked down upon when used
- not flexible with school schedules
- did not support team building ideas
The list goes on and on but overall the worse place ever!

pros: The best reason to work at the bank of America is because it is such a big company.  There are a lot of different positions all throughout the company where it is possible to rotate.  Rotating throughout the company has been a great way to learn about a variety of careers that are available to financial people.
cons: Working at bank of America in recent times has come to be a time of being scared of job cuts.  In recent times fear of bad loans has caused me to become concerned about my job security. I fear that I will likely suffer some sort of pay and or benefits cut in the months to come.

review_title: Ruthless, Political Nonsense from Management, but Great Rank & File Workers
pros:
Very talented people in the rank and file
Long tenure in the rank and file
Good benefits
Great facilities at the corporate office
cons:
Pay high salary to get you in the door, then no raise, I worked for 5 years without a raise
Pay for Performance is a joke, they tell you what the potential percentage is at the beginning of the year and then at the end the tell you there is not enough money to pay out
Constant reorganizations
Incompetent leadership in the Learning and Leadership Development organization
Acquisition of Countrywide and Merril Lynch resulted in massive layoffs.  People laid off included many associates with over 20 years of dedicated service. People were laid off according to highest salaries, not who was competent and capable.

review_title: Brian Moynihan: To be the Most Admired Company in the World - you need to attract/retain the best talent.
pros: Locations all over the country in case you need to transfer.
cons: 6 day a week schedule.

review_title: Great Potential and Platform, but currently bureaucracy/firm size limits career advancement and learning opportunties.
job_title: Vice President Capital Markets Risk Management in New York, NY
pros:
(1) Strong Brand and Global Franchise
(2) Open communciation and sharing of knowledge amongst all levels. 
(3) Inclusion of junior associates in senior level meetings
(4) Management is flexible with hours/outside work commitments
cons:
(1) Limited empowerment -i.e. one needs to consult 10 people prior to making any type of decision
(2) Size is overwhelming- difficult to navigate and get things done if you do not know who to contact.
(3) Career advancement- if you are good at your job, you will receive praise in performance review, but management may be reluctant to see you move on if you do too good of a job.

review_title: Good place if you like constant change
pros: Lots of opportunities to grow professionally within the organization.  The company promotes women and minorities and supports diversity.  Lots of smart, upwardly mobile people.  BofA has well-defined project management methods and processes.  They make available lots of online training if you have time to take it.
cons: If you don't like constant change, this is not a good place for you.  Things run at a fast pace and senior managers are rotated frequently.  Often this means that managers don't have the depth of knowledge about the area they are managing to make good decisions.

review_title: Positive - great people, strong company, opportunities to improve
pros: The environment can't be beat - everyone has a positive attitude and truly wants the company to succeed. Although the company is huge, they work to personalize each role to make employees feel wanted and needed.
cons: The company can be overwhelmingly large, but that just means there's something for everyone. Although you may not find exactly what you want to do right away, BofA can guarantee they have a role that fits your skills and assets.

review_title: It was amazing learning experience while working with BOA.
pros: Great Learning environment, work at fun, 360 degree feedback, equal employment opportunities to best performers, great trainings, great infrastructure, great facilities.
cons: Politics in Operations at times, Non flexibility in shifting associates from one project to another.

review_title: A nice place to work outside of the branch structure
job_title: Wealth Management Banker in Boston, MA
pros: A definite focus on work life balance which is very important to me as a company should work to retain employees who value their work AND their personal lives.
cons: The salaries are relatively low and I felt some of the management team did not belong there.

review_title: For the most part it's a great place to work.
pros: The pay is good, even just starting out as a teller.  You can't beat some of the benefits that they offer, like tuition and child care reimbursement, paid vacation and sick time, just to name a few.  There are many opportunities to promote within Bank of America.
cons: Even though there are many opportunities for promotions with Bank of America, I feel like sometimes the person filling the roles are either unqualified or underserving in comparison to other applicants.  The job can also be very stressful at times.

review_title: Great company to grow and develop a career.
job_title: Customer Service Representative in East Providence, RI
pros: Large company with many different roles and  positions. Well structured. Competitive benefits package. Flexibility for accommodating working parents. Competitive pay.
cons: At times customer interactions can be over analyzed, forgetting the human element. Cons in an interaction generally outweigh the pros when it it comes to evaluation of associates. This can foster a negative atmosphere. Talent development can fall to the wayside, instead focusing on meeting the metrics.

review_title: Unlimited potential, if only the silos and cultures could mesh,.
job_title: Technical Project Manager in Charlotte, NC
pros: Lots of Great ideas, seems to be a genuine 'general' concern to listen to and grow employees.
cons: Execution of those ideals isn't working. Stymied by old cultures/silos that have no interest other than turf protection. Seems to be a lot of hiring from the outside which makes it worse (then you wind up with even more culture confusion).

review_title: Great Start in the Banking Industry
job_title: Teller Operations Supervisor in Miami, FL
pros:
Learn about the banking industry and Sales environment.
Benefits (Health, Dental, 401k, Tuition Reimbursement, Merchant Discounts)
Branch environment is a typical M-F schedule, with occasional 4-5 Hour Saturdays (If a Saturday Office)
Vacation based on position and years of service with company (2 weeks vacation when you start)
All Federal Holidays are observed (The pay is prorated by hours depending on FTE or Part Time)
cons:
Company restructuring caused under-staffing due to position/department eliminations.
Excessive micro-management at bank branches.
Promotions are dependent upon region and district needs (are hard to come by)

review_title: We're better when we are connected
pros: The company is one of the top employers in the US. The company is well established and is not going anywhere anytime soon. The company has a rich history. It offers a lot of benefits to the employees and encourage community interaction.
cons: The cons are at organizational level and not necessary at the company. Therefore, one organization or vertical may have a different culture on employee satisfaction that is better than others. The company is so big that it takes time for the culture to spread around. In the mean time, employees may experience frustration on promotion, salary increase, and other culture related elements.

review_title: Bank Tellers need to have Sales skills
pros: Benefits for part-timers, education reimbursement
cons:
- Minimal/inadequate training
- Lots of pressure to get people to sign up for credit cards, new accounts, financial services, etc. -- you NEED sales skills.
- Personal Bankers set up new accounts but get the referrals from Tellers who are the first point-of-contact. They get paid more and have to do less but receive all the credit.
- Many people are regular customers, but you still have to give your sales pitch EVERY TIME regardless of previously expressed disinterest in new BoA products/services. Customers get annoyed with you for asking them over and over again to sign up for the same thing. 
- No job security -- if you don't get enough referrals you're in danger of being let go.

review_title: Polices change from one manager to another
pros: Excellent benefits.Bank of America is in every nook and corner in our city ,so easy to find a job in any of those branches
cons: No work life balance,you work over-time but they ask to to take one or two hour lunches because they don't want to give you that premium pay.Managers are inconsistent with the bank policies and some managers don't even know what they are.Always not enough people and all the work load falls on you and in between all this you have to deal with some nasty customers who think they own this world.

pros: Professional environment and culture, highly talented employees, unlimited opportunities to learn and transfer, most groups offer good work/life balance.  Consumer Banking Technology has worked very hard on its culture, and I am a big fan of its leader Bridget O'Connor.
cons:
The longer you stay, the more underpaid you become.  

Most decision-making is highly centralized, made by only a few hundred people at the very top of the company, and important decisions will be made about your future without your input or your ability to even find out who the decision-makers are.  BAC tends to follow every management fad.  Right now the fad is "delayering", which means every manager manages 8 or more people, and only a single digit percentage of employees will advance to management.

job_title: Financial Center Manager II in Vancouver, WA
pros: Outstanding opportunity for promotion with numerous methods to contribute, gain exposure and lead from your role.  Base pay is above market with fantastic medical, dental and retirement benefits.  Company highly values a culture of 360 degree coaching.  The very best most intuitive technology of any bank I know.
cons: While funding incentives are offered, a team must achieve higher than "excellent" to earn. A manager can have their entire team earn incentive but the managers will not.  They hold too much hope in their technology to cover their skeleton crews.  Often will work 6 day weeks.

pros: Great opportunity, supportive coworkers and leadership, good documentation (PRO), decent benefits, easy to reach out and find answers when you don't have them already. Overall, a good place to find yourself.
cons: Reporting and access to data is absolutely the worst, although that may not be completely fair as the company is going through a very large change as it pertains to these things. Leadership seems to be divided in what it is attempting to accomplish. Like I said, still an early adaptation of the business model though.

review_title: Not a bad place to work
pros: Hours are decent (Banking Hours)  Usually not a far commute they place you based on proximity to home.  Supervisor does not work with you in the branch.  As long as your sales goals are met there is not a lot of oversight.
cons: Not good pay structure.  Recruiter may have shorted me in negotiation.  Commission and bonuses are very difficult to attain.  Success depends on location.  Need to be in a heavy traffic banking center.  If you are placed in a center that is slow and has no traffic you really can struggle in this job.

pros: Excellent benefits. Company really rewards its employees with 3 weeks vacation form the start 10 sick days excellent health care including medical dental vision, company matches 401k 100% after a year of service, flexible scheduling and accommodation and 12 weeks paid maternity - great company to work for if you have accounts with them already as you get a ton of perks like no fees for your accounts and extra cash back on their cash credit cards
cons: Depending on what department you are in you can expect the work in a call center to be repetitive and dealing with clients does get tiring but the bank realizes that and that's why they do offer competitive benefits

job_title: Senior Vice President in Charlotte, NC
pros: Strong, stable senior leadership with a clear, rational plan for the direction of the division and strong communication. Support for raising risks and implementing ideas that reduce operating costs and/or simplify the environment. Wide variety of technology and places to make a positive contribution. Opportunies for learnig and horizontal placement. Strong diversity and inclusion atmosphere.
cons: Recent years have seen strong focus on reaching benchmark goals of cost reduction and efficiency; this has meant significant staff reductions. This trend seems to be stabilizing, but the company has not always kept its best/most experienced talent. The political environment is complex, but not unpredictable. Support for remote work has significantly diminished.

review_title: Great job as long as you work with fair Managers
pros:
Best Benefits - 4 months paid maternity leave, 401k match up to 5%, yearly bonus of 1% of your salary into your 401k, affordable health, dental and eye insurance and 3 weeks paid vacation/1 week paid personal days every year that you do not have to wait until accrued to use. 
Trainings - you will stay abreast of all regulatory and compliance procedures as training is given weekly virtually. 
Bonuses are between $2k-5k a quarter but the goals are extremely aggressive and are sometimes unobtainable. 
Employee safety is always a top priority when you work in the branch.
cons: Technology is inefficient and makes your job 10 times as hard and simple tasks can take 10 times as long all while you are trying to meet aggressive goals and have in depth conversations about the customers life priorities; management is not very helpful with this and tell you that there is nothing they can do or that they will put in a work order and nothing ever happens. Financial Center Managers have too much autonomy and disrespect employees treating them like slaves instead of human beings.

job_title: IT Project Manager in Charlotte, NC
pros: Good people to work with. Moderate red tape for such a large organization. Competitive compensation and benefits. Good variety of options for office location (in Charlotte HQ), including uptown, satellite and drop in sites in Ballantyne  (south Charlotte).
cons:
Telecommuting was becoming less and less of an option in the last few years. Merging of Global Tech operations with parallel Merrill - Lynch leadership centered in NY/NJ was creating stress amongst Charlotte staff.
Can be difficult to gain visibility and achieve promotion without constant job hopping.

pros: Provides an abundance of resources for employees willing to further educate themselves in financial matters. Great Work life balance for client facing employees. Reputable company with strong name and aspiring community involvement. Average pay but untapped qtr bonus.
cons: Aggressive sales mentality dressed in the form of client care management. Client facing employees are mircomanaged. Lack of clear communication and consistent changes between corporate and district agendas. Several departments play a role in resolving client facing issues but lack authority to provide a resolution therefore everyone is passing the buck until the ball gets dropped.

pros: 4 months paid maternity/Paternity leave,  3 weeks paid vacation, great medical, dental, vision and health account available for entire family. You can also cover a domestic partner.
cons: Poor raises if you even get one.  Peers can cause problems and nothing is done about it. Too much micromanagement. Extreme stress to meet sales goals that they relate to “relationship goals” yet they’re still sales goals.

job_title: Premium Elite Relationship Manager in Jacksonville, FL
pros: 5% match after a year. Insurance.
cons:
Where do I begin? There are many problems with the role. For one the bonuses that are mentioned at the interview can change at any time from one quarter to the next. Target pay can also change just like that. Some people depend on bonuses and stiffing people isn't a good idea. 

Training, ok let's talk about training. There's very little and no communication with management unless you do something wrong. No coaching, no continued training, no future goals conversations.....nothing! Mostly you have to ask your neighbor if you don't know something. There's a program you can research questions but it doesn't work most of the time.

Everyone knows the top 10 problems that need to be fixed and why clients are calling in, but excuses on why these problems can't be fixed are always stated. Guess what, clients don't care if you fix it because there's several other companies that have flawless systems. Oh wait, did I mention the point where reps are penalized for clients leaving due to issues outside of the reps control? Ouch, how is that fair! 

Each week new requirements for the role will be added to. Other groups will suddenly stop doing certain tasks. This requires reps to do more administrative work instead of making calls for sales. How can this be considered a sales role when so many things like systems, processes, and documents are so time consuming?

Where's your new money? Get used to hearing that. In the wake of the above you must still meet the requirements. If you get alot of folks that don't have outside assets, better start looking for a new job.

Too many cons to list fully. Turnover is very common with little change to the metrics or structure to accommodate reps. 

Overall one of the worst roles I've ever had. Do your research!!!

job_title: Banking Center Assistant Manager in Saint Petersburg, FL
pros: The training is frequent and there is always a helpline to call.  I have worked in other big companies and there was hardly any training and very few resources for solving issues.
cons: It is very difficult unless you take a different position to ever get a pay increase regardless of whether you meet your goal or not or how long you have worked with Bank of America.

review_title: Be warned, it's hard to get fair pay without a promotion!
pros: The benefits and holidays off.
cons: The demanding sales goals, and the shear size of the company. You tend to feel devalued and taken advantage of in general. I've been a teller for the bank for over 6 years and I get paid less than what they're hiring new tellers for- that doesn't seem to matter to them since we were all rudely told that the bank is not giving any raises because of the economy!

pros: Great employers, the work really hard to make sure that everyone is satisfied who works there.  The offer time off when needed and are good at working around schedules.  I was only a teller but they respected the fact that I sometimes needed time off. Also, they are very fair in the wages they pay their employees.  I have worked at other banks in the past and Bank of America gave me a starting wage higher than the other banks.
cons: Since it is such a large company, it can sometimes be hard to communicate with upper management.  Sometimes I felt like it was easy to be treated like a number.

review_title: Bad time to be at Bank of America
pros: Excellent Benefits, great perks such as hybrid car bonus, maternal/paternal leave, and tuition reimbursement.  No real push to meet any standards allows for a stress-free work environment.
cons: After several years, no advancement opportunities despite a personal drive to learn every process of the business. Management completely ignored personal/professional growth that several employees sought.  Management in my particular location had no formal managerial training. Extremely low pay which was frozen last year due to economic issues.

pros: could telework.  allows employees time to volunteer.
cons: Regarding management, my boss told me I did a good job and would give me a referral if I needed, but then didn't recommend me for a promotion.  Either he was not being forthright in talking to me about my performance or he at the last minute remember some negative things which he had not shared with me.

review_title: It was a great place to work with great access to resources and people to work with.
pros: The great resources and support available.  The autonomy and latitude given by supervisors.  The flexibility to run your practice the way you wanted to have it ran.
cons: The negative connotation  that is associated with Bank of America (post merger, combined company)  This is mediated a little bit due to the fact that a few of the others are assocated with deposit institutions and Bank of America is doing a good job of letting Merrill Lynch function as they did before.

pros: The benefits are really good. As a Personal Banker you get 3 weeks of vacation within in your first year. For those employees that have children they offer child reimburment care if you are within a certain salary.
cons: Management is not always fair to emplyees with the decisions that they make. I was hired and withing a few months I was transferred to another branch just because they neede someone bilingual. This inconvinience me because my 20 minute drive to work turned to 45 minutes. When I asked the manager if I had a choice she said that I didn't.

review_title: To big a bank to work for. They don't care about employees
pros: Nice people to work with. Some anyway
cons: You are just a number. You live every day waiting to get the call you are laid off. They don't care how good you are at your job.  Management does not have a clue or make good decisions. The bank only cares about shareholders and the bottom line. They don't care about customers or their employees.  They have horrible heath insurance and now no pension plan. They take any and all perks away so CEO can get his 8 Million a year. No raises for last year for anyone making over $75,000. But CEO got huge payout. They outsource good jobs to India and half the staff in US are not US citizens.

pros: Good training program in NY. that's about it though, cant think of much else. please look at cons and advice to management.
cons: Face time is a big issue. The culture is somewhat similar to frat hazing whereby the 3rd year associates about to be VPs will try to boss you around and create unnecessary work over weekends and late nights. The work is so mind-numbingly dull and boring, you will spend 90% of your time updating stock price numbers and repurposing the powerpoint

pros: They pay you a salary that reduces as time goes by in the program.
cons:
Absolutely no mentoring program or support from branch.  This particular branch it almost seemed that they wanted you to fail so whatever accounts you brought in would be divided up amongst the senior advisers.  Last 10 months had new complex director/manager who never had
a one on one meeting with me. No accountability or motivation to help. Had previous successful Wall St. career and was amazed at the lack of support and help given to the new PMDr's.
This position all depends upon branch management and how committed they are to the PMDP program.

job_title: Mortgage Servicing Specialist in Houston, TX
pros:
It was a great introduction into the Mortgage Industry and Loss Mitigation.
The pay was above average starting in the mid 40's with a annual bonus.
However it was a very stressful job and there was little support from management.
There is more than one office for Mortgage Servicing in the Houston area, the Westheimer & Beltway location only hires Hispanics under current management. Until new management is put in place you will not get hired unless your Spanish.  Sad but true.
cons: Training was confusing, management did not have proper background to deal with day to day affairs and employees. It was not unusual to hear screaming coming from his office.

review_title: Still a great place to work.
pros: You learn a great deal if you are willing to ask questions, dig deeper into solving problems, volunteer for the tough challenges, and collaborate internally.
cons:
Salary - It is kind of an internal joke that to make money here (in line with the market and experience) you have to either leave the bank and come back later or be a contractor. 

Get rid of poorly performing employees quickly - The bank tends to be slow to rid itself of terrible employees which leads to the top performers picking up the slack spreading resentment and negativity throughout both the immediate team and larger organization.

review_title: Bank of America was crazy and I wouldn't ever work there again
job_title: Mortgage Collections in Fort Worth, TX
pros: It's nationwide, standard benefits, community involvement
cons:
I worked in the mortgage area in collections. I did well, and made bonuses most months. When BOA does reviews they have "Meets expectations" ,"High Meets Expectations", and "low meets expectations." I would take 100-150 collections calls a day, and only got a "meets expectations" on my review. I was burned out on collections and tried to apply for another job within the entire BOA network, but the only people that ever were successful in getting another position within the company were the people that had been rated higher.

It was a rat-race and unless you are good at brown-nosing, you will never get ahead there.

review_title: Big bank that feels even bigger
pros: There are many things to like about working for a big company. One is opportunity. If you want to explore other avenues in finance, chances are, there's a department within the bank that will allow you to do so. Trouble is finding the right openings at the right time. But with telecommuting being an option in a lot of departments, you don't necessarily have to be in a central location to make it work.
cons: This company because it's so big has a very silo-like culture. Every department is out for themselves, and they rarely understand or want to talk to each other at times. I don't know if anything can be done about this because of the company's size, but management still tries.

review_title: Unweildy size leads to multiple overlapping strategies and muddled messaging
pros: Stable, good work-life balance, base salary is competitive. Pro-active outlook toward diversity. Drive toward modern customer interfaces; forward-looking.
cons: Consumer banking leads to a bottleneck for promotions and career stagnancy. Bonuses are 100% discretionary and allocated according to whim and manager favorites. Location subject to change based on unclear objectives from management. Lack of competitive rates and customer incentives. Pushing of "unofficial" quotas for investment products by unlicensed branch associates, a legal gray area. Mortgage department extremely slow and unwieldy.

pros: benefits, melting pot of cultures
cons: leadership, management, lack of direction

review_title: A great place to start for a programmer
job_title: Junior Software Developer in New York, NY
pros: Senior developers value your personal growth and encourage you to attend workshops / training. My manager even let me read textbooks at work (free online via techbus.safaribooksonline.com), as long as I still got my work done.
cons:
Political friction between business and tech, and turf wars between individual tech teams. As a junior dev, I was spared from this.
Bizarre internal software development tools. Don't expect any technology you learn here to be transferable. Focus on learning to write clean, clear code.

review_title: Decent company overall but with poor strategy execution
pros:
Easy to transfer
Easy to promote if you know the right people
Decent pay
Nice point of sale software/intranet
cons:
Cutthroat environment where doing the right thing for the client is overlooked

Incentive/performance metrics do not align. 

Company says do the right thing every time but local management has do whatever it takes attitude

Company is very cheap, makes retail feel like dime a dozen. Doesn't give access to CRM like other LOBs, no budget for morale boosters, work requests take a long time for approval.

review_title: A good employer with good work life balance if you're in the right group.
pros: The work life balance is good with flexible work schedules and the possibility of working remotely when needed. Hours are good in some areas like finance as well as operations. The campuses in some locations are very scenic and make it fun to work there.
