cons: The pay has stagnated for the most part in the last few years. If coming in make sure you get a good base salary off the bat otherwise HR make it impossible to get ahead in compensation regardless of performance.

pros: Good comensation once you reach Premier level as an FSA. GREAT learning experience. You can make a lot of money if you are good at bringing in new money, and production.
cons: No value placed on experience or FA development. Mangers r not very intelligent and DEFINITELY devoid of leadership especially in Hopewell office. All they care about is numbers.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Hunt Valley, MD
pros: Excellent benefits that start pretty much immediately, including paid vacation time, sick time and most major holidays off. They also offer FMLA and STD options.
cons: I ended up having to leave the company because of confusion over STD (short term disability). The process was not explained correctly and it was handled by an outside source which made it difficult to navigate.

job_title: Customer Service Representative II in Surfside, FL
pros: Benefits are amazing,  childcare assistance,  great health benefits,  401k to name a few.   If you can get past how you are treated and how you are expected to perform,  it's worth the benefits.
cons: No ability to truly help customers.   It's a high sales position in which the true agenda is to get everything the customer has,  sell products they really don't need to make numbers and if they aren't there doing either,  you are to get them out of your office.   Time limits set as to time allowed to spend with customer.  It's all about what you can get from the customer.

review_title: Run, take less hourly to save yourself the stress!
job_title: CMO Preferred Sales in Kennesaw, GA
pros: Domestic benefits for opposite sex, great vacation package, resume booster and nice co workers. The training was good also.
cons: Where do I begin? This is a cold calling job that happens to be inbound Your customers are not interested and you are forced to shove unnecessary solutions down their throat. No commission in about 6 months minimum after you start and earning it is almost impossible. They change the rules as they go along. It's a telemarketing sweatshop. If you go to the bathroom, expect to have a meeting with your boss explaining why you had to pee in 8-10 hours. Run. Great company, horrible department. 95% of employees are miserable. The other 5% are favorites.

review_title: Worst Bank/Financial Institution Ever Worked For
job_title: Sales & Service Specialist in Fort Worth, TX
pros: Less pay, outrageous numbers and goals to prevent associates from making incentives, NOT a fun working environment stock on the phone for an 8 to 10 hours shift and can you can even get a write off for bath room break, managers standing over your head or sitting at their desk monitoring your calls, hard working employees not recognized at the appropriate time,
cons: High associates/employee turn over rate, their new hire training sucks no face to face instructor instead you're stock with head phone for over 8 hours a days listening to instructions from trainers miles away

job_title: Lending Consultant in Los Angeles, CA
pros: I have worked for Bank of America off and on since 2009. This is  a great company to work for. The training programs are excellent and the professional opportunities are vast.
cons: However, the team you work with is really what makes or breaks your career. If you don't have a manger who supports or believes in you, you won't go anywhere. At Bank of America, I have had five different managers and only two of them really pushed me to exceed. They felt that my advancement marked how successful they were at their job. The other three felt that I was simply a number. A faceless employee who was there to make them look good.

pros: Salary is comparable to industry, and the bank offers great benefits. There are strong employee networks, mentor/mentee and development opportunities.
cons: Top performers are abused - they are shuffled across departments into the latest regulatory fire drills and charged with sorting out debacles with no direct staff. Consistently delivering and improving the bank equates to working every night and weekend for years. Top talent distinctions and leadership programs are just lip service. Mediocre performers are awarded teams and stability, exceptional performers are hoarded and driven to the brink of collapse.

job_title: Vice President in New York, NY
pros: -Good Work life balance relative to other investment banks
cons:
-Bureaucratic
-It is common knowledge at the band 5 or higher level, that BOA hires and fires capriciously in response to regulatory whims.
-Prospective job applicants be wary-BOA pays very competitive salaries but does not provide severance packages to laid off employees
-They will lay you off the second they can find  a young foreigner  on an H1 Visa who they think they can replace you with more cheaply even though the person can barely speak or write in English coherently..
-Steer clear as full time employee, best to work for them as contractor

pros: Amazing team to work on.   Super talented employees.
cons: Executive level management (and I mean maybe 3-4 levels below CEO)  have no clue.   I have seen well over 30 rounds of layoffs in the 15+ years I was employed with BofA.   Last 3 years, they laid off people 1 week before Christmas.   The layoffs must be based on solely numbers (salary numbers/severance package numbers) and NOT on talent.   The people who were let go were some of the most crucial members of critical teams.   Layoffs left projects in a disaster mode, leaving the remaining employees to pick up the pieces.   The few people left would ultimately leave on their own, the "jumping the sinking ship" mentality.

pros: Good benefits such as 401k matching, paid vacations and holidays, and leave
cons: Stressful goals/sales, poor technology, lack of pay, internal employees get cut off lower pay while excelling through the organization vs. external, micromanaged environment. No incentive pay unless you make exactly 100%, No overtime but short on staff, ongoing added training, heavy competition among peers, reports for EVERYTHING

pros: One of the best banks in the U.S. with a large customer base, which inevitably equates to more lateral or vertical movement in the company as it expands. Bank of America has set its footprint in the U.S. and continues expand internationally. Even working as a teller can bring you opportunities as you come across various types of clients. I've met a professional boxer, an NFL athlete, and a high net worth client to name a few.
cons: Management can be too lenient and uncompromising. Some even have limited knowledge in their own field. Managers from various departments and groups can seem unprofessional, but I'm assuming that it is alright with them as long as they meet their goals.

review_title: Great company for growth and learning!
pros:
Provides you with growth opportunities upon successful performance of goals! World class training and opportunities for further education for growth. 
Comapany rewards employees for performance and being a diligent worker. Comapany values integrity and always does the right thing. Provides a safe and positive working atmosphere for employees to succed and work efficiently.
cons: Management to employee morale are an issue. Management expectations are sometimes unrealistic. Economic condition change rapidly and goals are very aggressive. Must work very hard and be super detailed oriented for success to be promoted to next position.

pros: Legacy Countrywide... hopefully BAC will help make the organization better to work for. World wide organization, lots of opportunity to expand into other areas and growth. The firm is very diciplined, top down, with military like execution. Legacy Nations Bank at its core management. If you enjoy that enviroment this is a good place. The company's dicipline should help it maintain during slow/down times and taking advantage of the low cost of other financial businesses, growth during the good times should be exceptional.
cons: No work/life balance, little recognition for hard work, and low employee morale. Relatively low pay for expected work commitment. This however is the mantra of the industry right now.

review_title: OK to work there, but don't leave.
job_title: Banking Center Manager in Kingston, NY
pros: Paid calendar holidays, short customer-facing business days, great initial training made it extremely attractive to join this company
cons: High turnover, high-pressure sales practices, inconsistent policies, and a lack of senior management's "caring" for such issues was intolerable.  Also, Bank of America, for its size, did very little in the community compared to some of its smaller banking competetors.  The bank encouraged this type of service, but never allocated resources for employees to be able to participate.  Unfortunately, this was another "yes, sir" kind of company - as long as you agreed with their idea of the day you were going to be fine.

review_title: Stinks right now, might get better with economy
pros: Good benefits, pleasant work environment, possible to have many different roles
cons: I actually used to loved working here, but economic conditions have made it miserable... incentive cuts, incompetent management, duplication of effort, lack of career mobility. Either many people are extremely overpaid, or I am ridiculously underpaid... its probably both. Expect a big raise every 5 years or soJobs at the senior leadership level are difficult to get, too much secrecy in the selection process and HR has way too much control and couldn't be more clueless resulting in many many many reorgs.

review_title: For a bank, Bank of America is a good institution...for a bank.
pros: Compensation, opportunity to try new roles (not get siloed).  BAC is great about rotating associates into new roles every 18-24 months within the corporate finance organization.  There are few subject matter experts SMEs, but you have the opportunity to develop breadth of knowledge.
cons: Work-life balance, not quite benefiting the greater good.  We're in the news constantly now, and rarely for favorable reasons.  Management is talented, but not necessarily the most capable group of leaders.  That's rather problematic when evaluating growth prospects (ie. what is the value of an MBA when upper level mngt is only concerned with your ability to analyze data, rather than lead analysts?).

review_title: It's all about the revenue, get  every penny from the merchants you can or you will be fired
pros: Good name brand recognition, access to customers and prospects other banking business at BoA.
cons:
Management does not put you in a position to win. Quotas are the same regardless if you have a full territory or you split a territory, urban or suburban. You are expected to charge as much as possible in fees, including a bogus 'compliance fee'  that the majority of customers do not require with VISA.

The 2010 Blizzard of the Century was no excuse for not hitting your quota. Not one word of 'be careful out there' from management, rather, they insinuated you were home goofing off.

review_title: Good pay, hard goals, revenue driven management
pros: Many products and services to meet the needs of businesses to make sales easy. Bank culture brings together many lines of business to work together. Better salary and benefits structure over smaller banks.
cons: Management is driven by revenues only, very impersonal and punitive when not reaching goals. Management is very inflexible regarding achieving goals and milestones, though goals may be met at a later date than expected, the punitive reaction of management is detrimental to developing a strong team.

review_title: A big bureaucracy that is easy to get lost in
pros: They have a very good telecommuting program that enables you to work from home.  All needed equipment is provided, including office furniture (although the stipend is a bit low), and internet access and phone service are partially subsidized.
cons: It is a very bureaucratic organization, where management does not work towards the same goals and no one seems to really know what the priorities are.  they also do not develop staff very well, and there is very little delegation of meaningful work, so everyone wastes time "double guessing" everyone else and spinning their wheels on useless "by the numbers" work plans.

review_title: Nice place for a software engineer how would like to talk with (internal) clients.
job_title: IT Intern in City of London, England
pros:
Friendly team
Good manager
Work on the trading floor involoves talking to analysts – one can learn a lot about how the trading works without previous knowledge in this topic.
cons: IT could use more good software engineering practices. There are a few teams that do code reviews. Although there are some teams that have a lot of tests in their projects.

review_title: Entry level with a college degree
pros: The entry level programs for undergrads are waged, though you have regular benefits. The only difference is that you get paid for any OT after 40 hours, which is great. Additionally the salary is good, varying from 55 - 60 in the Southwest, and 3 weeks vacation. Its a great name to have too, fresh out of college, and there are many opportunities to transfer within the company. BofA has nearly every financial field out there.
cons: Some roles are very busy, while others can leave you idle for long periods of time. Its a wild card. Additionally it's hard to move up without leaving the company first. The benefits are good but not great, and a friendly work environment (i.e. office events) isn't promoted.

review_title: Excellent pay, low workload, but officepolitics get in the way of accomplishing much of anything
job_title: Senior Project Manager in Kansas City, MO
pros: I am able to work from home, have a fairly light workload most of the time, flexible hours, and above-average pay
cons: Management can't make up their mind, people change jobs and put a halt to what had been started before they joined, nothing much gets accomplished compared to plans due to office politics and fortress-building

pros: The benefits are awesome, the people are, awesome , the company is very family oriented and they have much compasion when it comes to family issues... i worked there for 15 yrs..I wish I could have retired from there.. any manager I had was great...and thy were there for me when I needed help personally and profesionally..I miss all of you guys at bofa
cons: The only con I wish I still worked there...but at our site unfortunatly we got caught up in a down sizing...but even then bof was still very good to us...

pros: Plenty of work to do. No time to twiddle your thumbs.
cons: There is plenty of work because they are systematically laying off everyone with experience and higher salaries. This would of course be the older people. They have lawyers to make sure they mix in enough younger people layoffs to make it look good but the game is a foot none the less. Many large companies are engaged in this same game but none do it as well (or have as many lawyers?) as Bank of America.

pros: The pay is definitely higher at this company than what other companies pay for similar positions. There was flexibility in the past with working from home, but that has shrunken. From my experience the name of the company holds a lot weight. It will open doors for you externally.
cons: It is the "good old boys club" type of atmosphere. It's all about who you know and not what you know. Expect to be treated unfairly. The hours expected are a lot but nothing nearly as bad as some other companies. Raises and bonuses are less than impressive. It is very difficult to move up and move to other departments in this company. Many people in management roles don't actually know how to manage nor do they really know what's going on in their area.

job_title: Mortgage Loan Officder in Jacksonville, FL
pros: Overall, Bank of America is a good company to work for.  The Jacksonville campus is one of the best places I have ever worked.  The people I work with are friendly and professional.
cons: The mortgage division's current leadership is extremely poor.  There is no accountability, responsibility, or ownership of loan files once they reach the processing department.  Extremely frustrating for loan officers who have to spend their time processing loans instead of selling.  Upper management's view is "we can't fix our processing department so we have to take a different route and assign more responsibility to loan officers."  So, more time processing, less time selling = less money.  It also means poor customer service.

review_title: If you're motivated, you can show continuous growth within the company and progress in your role.
pros: Bank of America offers benefits for part-time employees as well as full-time employees.
cons: BOA needs to show greater employee appreciation to have greater talent retention. There is constant flux of company goals, to the point of redundancy and predictability; it's either for the customer (so they say), or for the product push, not both.

job_title: Intermediate Financial Analyst in Fort Worth, TX
pros: Love the corporate guidance and structure, as well as daily challenges and flexibility. Such a remarkable and excellent turnaround from the Countrywide days, with continuous focus on helping customers, and evaluation of current and prospective methodologies for best meeting customer needs.  They truly put great effort into improving themselves and providing services customers want.
cons: It can be a workplace like any other, with personal conflicts, annoying things a boss might try to implement, and different people heading in different directions when everyone needs to be on the same path.  Also, being such a huge and diverse organization, finding 1.) the right person who 2.) has the right knowledge on a subject and 3.) the availability to assist can be almost impossible.

review_title: Mortgage servicing is a tough business to be in. BAC is downsizing and opportunities are limited.
job_title: Consumer Product Strategic Analyst III in Plano, TX
pros: Dress code, the people are great to work with, the company's focus on efficiency, working with the agile methodology to deliver add value projects.
cons: Lack of career growth, communication on where the company is heading is very vague and does not inspire confidence, constant reorganization due to downsizing. Capped salary advancement when promoting from within. Useless performance reviews that hold you accountable to goals that do not tie into your job functions.

pros: Benefits, maternity leave, diverse culture, learn a lot with the broad areas within the bank
cons:
Pay for the call center jobs are lacking for the amount of work a lot of associates take on.
So many opportunities for "advancement" yet many people are steadily applying elsewhere because they can't manage to get an interview for a job they are more than qualified for, unless they know someone who knows someone.
Then you have a lot of executives making policy and procedure calls but have no idea how it effects the associates day to day.

review_title: Proof that you can be too big
pros: 401k, paid time off, health and banking benefits including tuition reimbursement
cons:
-too big and impersonal - you are lucky to get an acknowledgement when applying internally for a job, never mind an actual interview.
-you are a number in a large corporation
-they have their arms around NOTHING and it doesn't matter what line of business you are in. No checks and controls in place to monitor the cash hemorrhage!
- their "pay for performance" plan is smoke and mirrors.  They restrict merit increases and performance ratings 
- externally candidates are paid top dollar to bring on board as opposed to increasing an internal candidates salary to match for the same job.

pros: There is a lot of growth opportunity within the company.  They also offer training on sales technique and how to grow your business.
cons: There isn't enough training on some of the technical or regulatory aspects of banking and you are expected to figure it out on your own.  The back office staff is vastly uninformed of regulations which makes my job much more difficult.  Also, there is no encouragement to build your career.  My manager scolded me for looking at job opportunities within the company on company time.

job_title: Senior Operations Representative in Jacksonville, FL
pros: Good work/life balance (at least in my position of Operations Rep), decent benefits, opportunity to grow, massive company with world-wide opportunities.
cons: Low pay compared to the average (I made 38,000/year as a Sr. Operation Rep in Florida), red tape due to the size of the company and because it is publicly held, seemed to be a huge push for consumer data protection (which is good), but it got to a point where it seemed that the company did not trust its employee's, a lot of rules/procedures...

pros: Benefits and lots of holidays off, the clients can be very sweet.
cons: The sales is soul crushingly hard with goals you can almost never achieve and will fire you if you don't meet, they take customer service far too seriously to a standard no one can really meet, the company told me sales isn't a big thing and it's ok if you don't always get it but my boss had hourly talks with us all how to improve our sales and why are we not meeting our goals every day and told us we can be fired if we don't improve (I managed up to 13 sales some days).

pros: Good, benefits, good hours, good Holidays.
cons: My coworker was celebrating her 30th anniversary and she got a card.... seriously? that is all her life of loyalty to this company, they don't care how hard you work, the only thing they care for is that you sell something I worked there so hard, for three years and even helped train people in my team I asked for a transfer and they said "nothing was available" when I relocated and had already found another job went to the bank and they said: we have been looking for 2 people for over 6 months. I felt they really didn't care about me at all, they only care if you sell.

pros: good benefits and days off and paid sick leave and 401k matched ,
cons: There is a lot of micromanagement.   They ask you to count how many people you sit with and how many people you send emails to.  They set extremely  high goals for you and when you achieve your goals they make them higher so you can't get your bonuses.  Team work is very bad and every body is selfish and this makes for a very toxic environment .  You will work most Saturdays.  They make you work 6 days a week but don't authorize any overtime.

pros: This company contributes to liberal organizations, and it offers benefits and competitive wages for all employees.  When the tellers got a raise, it applied to every single teller.
cons: Depends on your manager- all time off must be approved by your manager, if you don't have an understanding and supportive manager then your experience won't be as good. If you work there three years and everyone in your position suddenly gets a raise, you might be paid the same as someone who just started- you must ask for what you want!

review_title: A good starting point for anyone.
pros:
Made great friends
Learned a lot about banking systems.
Exposure to working in the corporate culture.

My manager was caring and thoughtful and wanted us to succeed.
cons:
Entitled customers
Upper management disconnected from the regions they manage
Only care about credit card sales and pressure tellers to sell credit cards to people who don't need them.

Upper management will enforce work hours so management will have to figure out how to stretch out 40 hours for 2 or 3 tellers for a 6 day work week to the point assistant manager has to work on the teller line as well to ensure all shifts are covered.

job_title: Teller Specialist in Point Pleasant Beach, NJ
pros: There is room for advancement, they encourage it because they are trying to do away with the lower positions, (tellers) The place is ususally clean. They stick to the rules for lunchtimes usually.
cons: Because they want to do away with the tellers, they are pressured so much for sales goals it can almost cause nervous breakdowns for them and their managers. They only care about the bottom dollar, do not want customers on face to face transactions that can be handled online and try to make it more and more inconvienent for customers to bank in person by cutting staff increasing wait time and forcing tellers to process quicker causing errors to put them on warning.

job_title: Vice President in New York, NY
pros: - Flexible, laid back culture
cons:
- Bank of America is far behind in all aspects of technology and is not time catching up to the street as a result of all the politics.
-Pay practices severely suffer compare to the street
- Prefer to higher consultants at a higher salary than pay it's performing employees
- Too much middle management
- Advertise increase in budgets at the bank, yet management tells employees that they need to cut and only a number of people do the actual work
- Too many people doing nothing, just occupying space and trying to take credit for your work
-Promotions do not mean anything when it comes to pay raises or bonus (they are just titles and a pat on the back)
-  Manager do not care about your  career aspirations/goals

job_title: Fraud Analyst in Hunt Valley, MD
pros: The best thing about working at BOA was the free checking account. They provided the preferred account to employees which was nice.
cons: The call center is really like a popularity contest. The managers are driven by metrics so they over push the employees who dont gent incentives for meeting metrics. Theres a manager there who flirts with all the young reps. The job is stressful and micromanaged. Plus if you get hired as a contractor you start off at 20$ an hour once the bring you over perm you drop down to 16 an hour!!!!

job_title: Vice President; Program Manager in Phoenix, AZ
pros:
- A number of great people that I worked with during my time at BofA.  
- Some strong leaders during my time there.
- Flexibility to work remotely
cons:
- Staff reductions yearly to meet financial goals meant less resources but increased work.
- Senior leadership the past 8 years did not focus on career development but more on reducing operating expenses.
 - Benefit costs increased annually and while I options decreased.  For a large company you would believe they would have good employee benefits.

review_title: They preach diversity but there’s not much in I.T. division
pros: Great benefits like 20 vacation days to start.
cons: They preach diversity yet the IT division is over 80% Indian - yes , over 80%. You’d be hard pressed to find a black person IT executive at Bank of America.  I’ve sat in meetings with 50 attendees and 46 are Indians. Mind you, this is not in their offshore India operation. This is in good ol Plano Texas. What a shame. Even some of my Indian friends that work there think it’s embarrassing.

review_title: Great benefits but goals are overreaching and management is inconsistent.
pros: Great benefits, great 401k, and the job isn't too difficult considering the pay has been raised.  You get full benefits even as a part-time associate.
cons:
A lot of pressure from managers to perform and present offers (despite the traffic in the center). 

Not enough CSRs available to cover call outs or vacations so many centers end up stuck with a line. 

Old hardware and software which causes slowdowns on the teller line.

review_title: Bank of America is a great company with alot of quirks to iron out
job_title: Client Manager in San Francisco, CA
pros: Opportunity for growth is promoted.  The weekly, quarterly, and yearly reviews help you stay on track to hit your goals.  The Bank of America culture promotes excellence, teamwork, and the strive for success.
cons:
too many tools, systems, processes, and policies that impede job duties.  For example: If a Client Manager brings in new business during the last 3 days of any month, the Client Manager is not compensated for the production.  THis is because there is a 3 day lag in the system.  
A Client Manager needs to access 10 to 15 different systems and tools to perform job functions.

review_title: Bank of America lots of room to grow but, but beware them leavings their employees stranded.
job_title: Teller Operations Specialist in Dorchester Center, MA
pros: Anyone who works hard enough can advance quickly in the company.
cons: In the wake of the financial crisis Bank of America was too quick to abandon its employees.  On top of a hiring freeze Bank of America became very stingy with its bonuses even of those who had deserved one.

review_title: Good place to work for a season
pros: Great environment with many challenges.   Constant change which is good for you if you like that.  I did.  I liked the technology that they used - Oracle, Unix, Essbase.  They seemed to have some good folks in the group I was in.  Some experts in various technologies that I could learn from
cons: Politics are bad in certain areas of the bank.  This can be a big challenge.  Also, at times the restructuring every 9-12 months got a little old and kinda disorienting at times.  At times it was hard to maintain focus because of the turbulence and change that kept on coming

review_title: Bank of America will come out on top!
job_title: Service Deliery Executive in Wilmington, DE
pros: Hard work is rewarded - people who are wiling to keep a positive attitude and work hard get recognized!  People who become obsessed with their performance or stuck in fear of being layed off would do better to keep their heads down and work hard.  Be careful of setting your own destiny by becoming distracted.  Networking is critical make sure people know what you do other than your immediate manager.
cons: Currently poor perception of the company in the Media makes it a struggle to feel like you have meaningful work.  However, if you seek it out you can find out about the great things the company is doing too!

pros:
options to advance are great if you side with the "right" people. 

always learning new things

benefits are great

bonuses can be good if the manager likes you
cons:
It's all politics, if you get on the wrong persons side you can just look for another job.

Stress is very high.

No two banking centers/markets run the same

continuous conflicting policies/prcedures

pay IS discriminatory. only way to get decent raise is to transfer positions to different locations, and the way to get the highest raise is to quit for a few months and come back

job_title: Small Business Specialist in New York, NY
pros:
It is a large bank with many thing you can offer clients
Working in Manhattan you are able to meat a lot of the senior management team
Wide range of clients so you get experience working with many different types of businesses
cons:
very political if you want to move to different parts of the business within the company
Big company with lot's of levels of sales and service teams so it can be a challenge to get what you need at anyone time

review_title: Solid place if you are self motivated
job_title: Software Developer in New York, NY
pros:
Good pay and benefits

Excellent work/life balance

Some extremely talented engineers

Pretty productive development environment

Management is eager to please

Relaxed culture

Global company
cons:
Overly bureaucratic when it comes to getting new tools and libraries approved

Recent fascination with building a highly proprietary development environment (custom database, IDE, UI toolkit, job scheduler) which is being forced on people

Company is very large and feels like it

People come and go too quickly, you're considered a veteran if you're there more than 2 years

Big talent gaps between individuals

Developers are too isolated from the users

review_title: My boss makes this a good place to work
job_title: Assistant Vice President in Plano, TX
pros: There are a myriad of opportunities that come with size. When hiring picks back up I would certainly consider moving around.
cons:
This is an old-fashioned bank in every sense of the word. Every decision is a committee decision. There is fear throughout the company in making a decision. Senior management seems to understand very little beyond how simple interest works in a money market.

Reducing headcount and doubling forecasting requirements won’t bode well for our ostriches in senior management. When unemployment numbers improve I think they’ll be surprised.

review_title: Flexible job, job environment depends on management
job_title: Sales and Service Specialist in Arcadia, CA
pros: Many good benefits come with working with this company. For students, tuition reimbursement is a great benefit. There are also other things such as hybrid vehicle purchase reimbursement. Flexible work schedule.
cons:
High pressure from management to reach sales goals, management does the least amount of work, have the ability to have others do their job for them. Favoritism is inevitable. I know associates who have had the worst working experience because of favoritism.

Sales goals are so bad, I've seen associates do unethical and business practices in order to open accounts not suitable for customers, resulting in customers being charged a ridiculous amount of fees.

review_title: No longer a good place to work.
pros: Base pay can be good, if you're willing to put up with the stress, threats and backstabbing.
cons: BOA was a great place to work when I first started and through until 2008. Since then everything that made it great (benefits, bonus potentials, work/life balance, teamwork, integrity, dignity) has been stripped bare and all that's left is desperation. Goals, performance reviews and bonus levels are changed mid-stream making them difficult to meet. Your experience at BOA is only as good as your manager, and there aren't many good ones left. Too many managers at BOA who are only out for themselves and will bury you to get ahead, if that's what it takes. It makes me sad to see what BOA has become.

review_title: In Loss Mitigation, it's been a bit shaky.
pros: Virtual workplace has been very good to me.  The benefits are very impressive, especially if you use the company savings website where you can earn WOW points and earn cash back.
cons: Compensation!  In order for me to get paid the average in what I do, I would have to leave the bank, find another job, and then get re-hired with a different salary.  LAS is not a fun area to work in.  I'm always afraid that I'm going to be the next one on the chopping block.  But it's par for the course in this group.  We don't make money for the bank, we are on the losing end.

pros:
Paid holidays off. 
Vacation which they require you to decide early, so its good to plan ahead. You get two weeks if you're full tim
Tuition reimbursement 
Decent job setting, and breaks are highly enforced.
cons:
Referrals. You are required to make a certain amount daily. If you do not they threaten taking away your benefits (which I don't think it legal). You are required to sell items to customers. Customers do not like being annoyed with this.
Managers tend to make their own rules which are not correct. In the year I worked I had about 3 different managers due to how they shift people around. 
pay was low

pros: Company has good ideas and good intent
cons:
Company doesn't follow through with the good ideas and good intent
Company does not set associates up with proper tools and training for success
Management does not receive people management training nor expected to practice it
Different units within company are not required to practice the same company culture, guidelines, or deliver the same results 
Contact HR for advice and get 3 different people with 3 different answers

pros: Pay is decent. The emoloyees are normally good people trying to make a living. The benefits can be good if you are a permanent employee
cons: Management has no clue how to train, maintain staff, or be nice to the staff they supervise. Often there is favortism. Many times good employees are let go while the lazy ones continue to bs their way through pay checks. No room for growth. Employees can be gossipy

review_title: Used to be a great company to work for
pros: Large company with lots of opportunities to do something different.
cons: Getting rid of the MyWork program "unofficially" is a step backwards. The program supported a healthy work-life balance and now that several employees are being asked to come back into the office, the work-life balance has been compromised.

job_title: Vice President Systems Engineer/ECommerce Release Management in Conifer, CO
pros: When I worked there they had the Work From Home program which allowed remote employees the opportunity to stay employed. They paid for internet, phone and office equipment. I worked with good people. When they bought my original company they bridged my years there, so when they laid me off I had enough years to be considered a retiree.
cons: They are dissolving the Work From Home program and laying off a lot of people. The ability to advance is not on your merit, but the whims of the managers.  It wasn't a horrible place to work. It's a massive corporation so you are just another cog.

pros: Great co-workers, great hours, good pay. Company was great when it was about the client and coworkers, not anymore. Great credit cards and that's about it.
cons: Where to start upper management is all about sales, they claim to be about what is best for the client but in fact it's the opposite. It's all about pushing credit cards down people's throats and by any means necessary. Not a family environment, if your a single individual you can succeed greatly but if you have children they are very unforgiving. Upper management is under qualified for what they do. If you don't meet your numbers be prepared to be written up, moved, or fired.

pros:
Gold Plated benefits. Generous vacation & sick time. PPO plans available. All federal Holidays observed. Excellent mortgage & auto discounts.

On-site training still exists and helps in the onboarding process.

Plenty of work for the growing areas with bonus opportunities for salaried employees and OT for hourly workers.
cons:
Full on cost cutting mode right now. Small layoffs every month and big ones every 3 months. Prime targeted criteria  right now is salary (if its's too high) & band level (if it's too low.)

Work from Home program is being dismantled.

All work is metricized and will eventually boil down to a production job.

Bank does not make it easy to find new opportunities within itself.

job_title: Teller/Client Service Representative in Las Vegas, NV
pros:
- Benefits (hard to beat the benefits for entry level job) health insurance, tuition reimbursement, childcare help, etc
- Can be flexible with school or other commitments if you are part time. Largly depends on branch manager. Some managers will be very accomodating to you others really couldn't care less about what you have going on outside work. 
- Easy to move up inside the branch if you have at least some ambition
- People you work with in the branch really dictate if you can tolerate your job. If your co workers suck you are going to want to quit, if they are awesome it makes you at least get through the day. I've been lucky to work with great co workers. I have friends who work at other branches that haven't been so lucky. If you have two or more women working together who don't like each other you're in for some drama. A good branch manager really helps.
- A lot of tellers at a branch are either part time students, part time moms, or full timers who are content with being tellers. Like I said before if you can balance your drawer, provide decent customer service, have stamina to deal with being overworked, be cool with your manager and co workers, and refer people to the bankers you can get a promotion if you want it. 
- Start at $13.50 an hour, raises are like 20 cents a year. No bonuses.
cons:
- UNDERSTAFFED. BoA is really pushing people to online/mobile/atm banking and has been reducing staff every quarter. I've worked at two separate branches and we lost 3 people in the first one without replacement and 2 in the second without replacement each year. You are regularly processing 250-300+ transactions a day which exhausts you at the end of the day as you have to engage customers for referrals on top of that. You really stop caring about giving good customer service or referring clients by the end of the day because you are too tired from the 100 people you've already helped that day. 
- SALES ORIENTED. Make no mistake - management loves you if you can refer clients to the bankers for sales or will see you as expendable if you can't. Simple truth. Only the top 10-15ish out of 100 CSRs in a market make their quarterly BCR (banker conservation rate goal). If you can be one who meets their goals you are in line for a promotion if you can't you're out of luck.
- NEPOTISM. Market leaders will look to give out promotions to those they like. They have a lot of influence over how the branch operates but may only visit the branch once every couple months. PRO TIP: Get in good with the market leader if you are looking to advance. Can't stress that enough.

job_title: Financial Center Operations Manager in Phoenix, AZ
pros: The few instances where you can really help customers is very rewarding. Mostly everyone I worked with had a pretty good team attitude because we were so understaffed we all had to work together in order to make it through the day.  I have never seen more employees cry at work than I have here.
cons: Tons of micromanaging, almost impossible to take time off, customers are generally not happy to see you. It takes tough skin to be able to do this job day in and day out. A lot of times we cannot help customers who genuinely need/deserve it, very frustrating.

pros:
Wow, the culture is really great and they take care of their own here.

The pay is great as long as you're willing to put the work in you'll get what you put into your work.

If you are in this area and you want to start your career in finance with the best firm in the city, it's Merrill Edge.
cons:
I would say the training needs work, but I felt prepared for what I do now.

Systems are old and they need to be revamped with an overall better platform for reps.

review_title: Great opportunities to advance within certain areas of the country.
pros: Committed to diversity and inclusion, process improvement, and customer satisfaction.  Lots of opprtunity to advance if you're willing to relocate.
cons: Within operations, there is more upheaval, reorganization, and layoffs as the company tries to increase profits by reducing headcount.   Leadership is frequently moved around from one function to another, which can be disruptive.  System conversions rarely live up to expectations.

job_title: Senior Digital Service Specialist in Utica, NY
pros: The benefits are wonderful. Compensation is okay.
cons: They honestly don't care about the employees. Getting the time off that you need is nearly impossible. Getting assistance from a manager is nearly impossible. Hardly any room for growth despite what they say. All the matters is STATS STATS STATS! Employee feedback is barely if ever implemented. In my time there we took on the role of 3 other departments without seeing a pay increase. No warning or explanation about changes they're just sprung on you. It's honestly a burn out job. Most people only put up with it because its one of the better paying jobs in the area. Also extremely difficult to get a schedule change regardless of the amount of time you've been there.

job_title: Senior Business Control Specialist in Charlotte, NC
pros: If you are willing to seek out a mentor and challenge your own comfort zone, there is opportunity to do meaningful and rewarding at this company.  Comprehensive benefits package is solid.  You can grow here, but nobody is going to gift you growth.  Use peripheral vision to look for opportunities to outperform the mean.
cons: On the other hand, if you want to float, and do just enough to get by, this company is big enough to do that too.  Not a recommended long term strategy...eventually you will lose the game of musical chairs.

job_title: Financial Center Manager in New York, NY
pros: Good benefits, pay is competitive
cons: Lots of politics, can’t be yourself, can’t call HR on your manager for fear of retaliation, budget is an issue in the retail sector (can’t buy pens) but corporate have lavish events with alcohol and catered food. Manager can stop you from many opportunities. You can be an amazing associate but if your manager doesn’t like you then you will never get ahead. Hope you get a good one and hope your on his/her good side.

job_title: Senior Client Service Representative in Phoenix, AZ
pros: The job is easy, the benefits are good
cons: They bait and switched the job description, a recruiter calls and tells you that the position is tech support and you expect it to be tech support. Instead, you get to the production floor and are tasked with servicing everything related to deposits and cards. Additionally every other department when they don't know how to solve a problem dumps it off on you. About half of the time you're tasked with doing things that are part of your job.

pros: My experience has largely been on the technology side - it is indeed an organisation which is too big to fail and I guess since the volume of people involved in the organisation is so high, it is likely to come across and work with enough talented people around you.
cons: The bank is very true to its name - it is indeed a organisation which is too much driven from America inspite of the fact that there is a general acknowledgement that it would work better if control is spread out to other regions too (EMEA and APAC). This is particularly a problem specific to the technology side.

job_title: Vendor Manager in New York, NY
pros: Good benefits and employee benefit programs
cons:
-Horrible Management, unless you are will to kiss a lot of tail, don’t expect to get what your worth.
-No support and lack of training from management (They already get their paycheck, why would they help you, right?)
-Global Human Resources is only there because the company needs HR, they are in favor of management and provides no support to regular employees.
-Long hours when busy
-Not a good work/life balance
-You can be moved from one location to another at any time within consideration of your time, schedule and/or life.
-Expects ten times more from employee than they are willing to give back in return.

job_title: Senior Vice President  in Charlotte, NC
pros: Due to the diverse lines of business, challenging opportunities are really only limited by your own personal preferences.  The people are wonderful and there is truly a sense of teamwork and achieving success through cooperative efforts.  There is enough change to feel the the organization is evolving in a positive direction without feeling chaotic.
cons: The hours can be long sometimes.  In addition, due to the geographical dispersion of resources, it can be challenging to capitalize on the social aspects of the workplace.  Celebrating successes is done in a variety of ways, but sometimes just getting together is a nice touch and helps build stronger relationships.

review_title: Taking it to the next level
pros: satisfaction of a job well done. Coming up with great ideas and exploring possibilities that might not have been processed in the past. Directing others to do a great job so that at the end of the day, we all feel a sense of accomplishment. Don't take no for an answer. Sell products and services that help those in need feel part of something bigger.
cons: Not being able to get loans funded in a timely mannger. Sometimes, clients are left waiting in limbo for weeks waiting on their home equity loan or mortgage. Often, it's hard to get in touch with the  loan processor

review_title: Know what you are getting into
job_title: Process Design Manager in Charlotte, NC

The upside of this is that I could work late (after putting the kids down for the night) or start my day really early.  It also made working the weekends more "appealing".  THe downside is that I was always "online" so had to work on not working.l
cons: A lot of job uncertainty, and layoffs.  Constant feeling that you need to "prove" yourself against the other team mates in your group as we were forced ranked against each other.  This promoted some politic playing in some groups.

review_title: If you want a paycheck its fine but if you want more than a check try some one else

Its an entitlement company and do your best to negotiate your first package as you can get promoted 2-3 times and will still make less than the people you manage

job_title: Senior Vice President in New York, NY
pros: Base salary and benefits are good.  Lot of flexibility allowed with work hours (in IT).  Many are working remotely -- many hardly ever have to go into the office.
cons: Bonuses for those outside of the top 100 are not competitive.  Very difficult to succeed if you're based in Charlotte, NC.  Being such a large company, there are some ridiculous benefits such as the excessive paternity time off given to MEN!  It definitely helps to be a minority to succeed.

review_title: Pay not worth the sacrifice and responsibilities.
pros: Great benefits especially if you're part time. If you work over 20+ hours you get tuition reimbursement, 401K after 6 months matched 5%, pension plan, health insurance (which has increasing worsened over time). Great job when you're a student.
cons: Working weekends and hardly any long weekends. Pay significantly much lower than other banks. Very little room for creativity as every rule has to be followed to the tee. Promotion based completely on your relationship with management rather than merit. Management lacking in experience and corporate minded.  No access to internet or email thus resulting in alot of paper wastage.

review_title: Fun place to work...but you do A LOT of work  management don't feel  dont feel like doing
pros: Fun place to work, they are very flexible with schedule. My coworkers were awesome. Customers make the day go by fast and fun.
cons: Management tends to be very lazy... Always passing on tasks and responsibilities to other people so they won't have to do it themselves. My branch manager admitted to not letting people be off on Monday's and Friday's (which were our peak days) because that would mean she actually had to work... And she hated working.

review_title: It all depends on the management.
job_title: Teller Operations Specialist in Branson, MO
pros: Working with people and being in an entry level management position in a bank can be very nice.  The training, although a bit much at times, is very well prepared, and they ensure that continuous training occurs.
cons: The management structure does not allow for an equal distribution of the work load.  Every time you override something, there is a possibility that you will loose your job because of it.  You constantly live in fear of loosing your job even if you are a motivated hard working employee.

pros: Good benefits, for the most part.
cons: In the call center area, manager(s) not aware of their employees responsibilities.  It appeared the managers did not have to full understand their employees job responsibilities/duties.  The role as a CRM was not treated as a management of portfolios, but handled as a call center environment, thus taking away the "management" part of the job. Metrics were unattainable unless you were favored or found ways around it that were unethical.

pros: Bank of America has the best website and online tools in the industry. They also offer a very competitive leave package for new parents. The company has a major market share in many large cities which offers some opportunities to transfer.
cons: Bank of America is eliminating many jobs and shifting to an almost entirely part-time workforce. Customers and associates are being short changed in this process. Branch locations in some areas are in very poor condition and are very understaffed.

review_title: Laid back until we were laid off"
job_title: Home Services Specialist II in Richmond, VA
pros: Good benefits including healthcare, backup day care and hybrid purchase program to name a few.  Our satellite office was extremely laid back but have heard different about larger offices.  The bonus system seemed to be working well.
cons: The systems are comical for a company of this size.  It was a 20 minute process to disclose a loan on the antiquated Edge system they were running.  It is nearly impossible to terminate somebody which leads to mediocrity. Don't work here if you want a secure job where you can work for 30 years.

pros: Benefits, flexible work schedule, opportunity for advancement
cons: Constant changes, poor strategic decisions made, little to no consequences for low performers, bad reporting

pros: Lot of opportunity if the organization's financial funding situation and reporting manager's favorable moods align.
cons: During low tide of initiative funding one will be subjected to a maze of political posturing and slow erosion of core competency skills. And one's survival depends on good network inside the organization. Non-technology folks have been placed at key roles in technology organizations which adds to misery and confusion. Senior folks have been stuck at same roles for longer periods either due to lack of learning or job insecurity and in turn unhealthy team experience which in turn causes low morale.

review_title: Positive, supportive environment which fosters great career opportunities in the years to come.
job_title: Operations Management Analyst in Charlotte, NC
pros: Great team environment, supportive coworkers, amazing networking opportunities with the company's top C-suite executives and leadership teams. Lots of potential through the different affinity networks, programs, and skill sets (Khan Academy, Lynda, etc.) that are provided on behalf of the bank. Always ways to develop yourself and move forward. Compensation is strong initially but the salary bumps year to year could use some improvement, especially for those in their 20s, but not a legitimate concern by any means.
cons: Your advancement in the company comes only through years and years of experience, networking, and bureaucratics involved (re-organizations and constant change of leadership). Innovation/creativity is not needed; you think like the bank for the bank's best benefit.

review_title: Good Pay, Good Benefits, Needs new senior leadership within mortgage technology
pros: I really enjoyed my time at Bank of America until recent changes to senior leadership. Many pros included working from home, constant challenge, unique technologies, and great support from my manager. I was provided minimal oversight and permitted to reach out amongst the organization to solve problems within our division.
cons: Recent change in senior leadership within Mortgage Technology caused serious frustration amongst the development staff. My direct manager provided great support, however, the management above that was constantly changing direction and did not understand how to successfully run their division in the current market.  That combined with long lasting hiring freeze, attrition, and only outsourcing all full time positions to offshore, I made the decision to leave.

review_title: They care only about the company.
job_title: Personal Banker in Laguna Hills, CA
pros: They offer 401k with matching, vacation, sick, and personal paid days off.
cons: They are unfair to employees. They understaffed all branches to the extent that work is physically exhausting. Pay scale for each employee is very different, even if they have the same experience. Unrealistic expectations for sales goals.

review_title: Acceptable temp job as you search for a true career.
job_title: Financial Solutions Advisor in Chandler, AZ
pros: The only benefit is to get your licenses and get out.
cons: This was by far was the worst experience I've had. The systems were very outdated and you need to track all of your sales, if not you won't receive any sales credit. The managers are just glorified sales reps with no true management experience. It felt that compliance was in place only for the industry requirements but they turned a blind eye for all the "A" shares the reps push. Not recommended for an experienced advisor. I find it a joke when I read these false reviews from recruiting and management trying to make this company look career worthy.

pros: The benefits are great, especially if you plan on staying with the company. In addition to medical, dental, and 401k matching, you can also get tuition reimbursement, child care, adoption reimbursement, and reimbursement for the purchase of a hybrid vehicle. Plenty of opportunity for growth if willing to relocate.
cons: Products, policies, and employees are constantly changing. Gone are the days of knowing your tellers and bankers personally. Turnover seems to be high as employees struggle with the ever-changing environment. Policies are followed inconsistently across banking centers. Hiring, training, and placement seem like they are done almost sporadically.

job_title: Financial Center Manager in Parlin, NJ
pros: There are many opportunities for growth in your career if you apply yourself. The tuition reimbursement is better than most employers offer. Benefits start on your date of hire.
cons: Work with less than a skeleton crew and no work life balance.  Associates are often stressed out because there is so much to do and there aren't enough associates to get it done on schedule.

review_title: Ops Analyst - okay to start out in, but not something long term
job_title: Senior Operations Analyst in New York, NY
pros:
Convenient location, pretty good work-life balance in my group.  Group overall was friendly.  
Benefits are okay.  Good to name to have on your resume.
cons:
Pay is very low, no bonus, and raises are minuscule (don't expect more than 2-3% at the most) 
No room to advance
Tedious at times with silly processes/procedures
Management too focused on "metrics" which aren't useful
If you're in NY and not at One Bryant Park, you're almost like a second rate employee, no perks

review_title: Good place to develope skills and build knowledge
job_title: Quality Assurance Analyst in Simi Valley, CA
pros: There are many resources to help you learn a diverse range of skills and subject areas which can directly help you advance into different lines of business or grow within your functional area.
cons: It is difficult to find the time (as an hourly associate at least) to put in the effort to seriously learn new skills and subject area at a professional level since production and deliverable targets already take up most of your time if not all

review_title: Not my dream job, but it paid the bills.
pros: Good benefits package for medical and dental. Employee discount program. 100% match for 401K program up to 5% of your salary.
cons: Very focused on expense reduction.  Doesn't care about employee engagement (even though they say they do). No corporate culture encouraging focus on the customer.  Management talks out of both sides of their mouth. SO much red tape to get something done.  More focused on documenting the process being changed than on the change itself.

pros: Global brand recognition and employee banking perks.  Offices world-wide and tech employees are allowed to work from home.  Employee affinity groups allow for networking and volunteerism.  Gift matching program allows employees to make charitable donations that the company will match.  Most career development (conferences, certifications, training, etc.) is approved.  Tuition reimbursement program for pursuing Master's degrees.
cons: A heavily regulated industry and antiquated processes do not give millennials the flexibility they are looking for.  In such a large organization, it is easy to get overlooked.  No strong and consistent culture - varies from group to group.  Investments must be managed in-house so employees are forced to use Merrill Lynch Financial Advisors or open self-directed accounts (which are not discounted services).

job_title: Relationship Manager in San Diego, CA
pros: Some of the employees are awesome...too bad they have to put up with so much nonsense!
cons: The branches are constantly under staffed.  Customers complain that no one ever answers the phone.  The comp plan is extremely complicated and the goals are way too high; especially when they move you around four times in one year.  The training is lackluster, most of it is done online with no one to mentor you!  Invest more time and training for your employees and hire more staff!

review_title: Definitely Dont know what they are doing
job_title: Human Resources Generalist in Charlotte, NC
pros: Not much right now. Typical old fashion banking mentality,
cons:
Disorganized

job_title: Loan Originator in Post Falls, ID

With their new IFullfill mortgage software system you need to do that job of your processor and loan officer.  The processors don't do anything to help you.  I've been a mortgage loan officer for 23 years but only at B of A for 2 years.  There's alot more work for loan officers than there should be & you don't get paid enough.  You would actually make more money at  Starbucks and that pretty sad.  That is pretty much the only draw back.

review_title: Lies, Secrets, and More Lies Shrouded in Secrecy
pros: You can take pretty thorough notes about how NOT to run a company.
cons: Toxic work environment in more ways than one, i.e. unclean air, infighting, miserable employees, angry clients; inexperienced management team; dishonest HR dept; nepotism; rodents; ostensible thugs and criminals; lies, secrets, and more lies shrouded in secrecy. Prepare to fight for everything: you will fight with bad people that are determined to make you fail; you will fight with outdated copy machines and other equipment; you will fight through system issues with your computer; you will fight for an accurate record of your metrics; you will fight to keep your personal information private; you will fight with HR to support you . . .

pros: CEO is very consistent in his message.  Great brand name.  Strong technology.  Good associates that are working hard on the front lines to make the bank successful.
cons: There is no Work Life Balance, things are Constantly Changing, Working Environment does not lend to great teamwork as their are competing priorities among business partners.  New transformation has not worked at all.  created an environment where there is a lot of finger pointing.

pros:
Fortune 500 company 
Good exposure to work with a lot of bright people.
Large company with a lot of organized systems
Opportunity to move and grow (being an international co).
cons:
Working on equities floor in London. Very political. 
Get promoted based on who's feet your kissing, not based on skill set.
Gallo favours the French, entire management is French, which he commented once in a staff auditorium 'if you're French or a mathematician you've made it, if not your job is to just sell the franchise' .

job_title: Senior Corporate Recruiter in Charlotte, NC
pros: Keeping busy is great! Great managers to work with overall.
cons: No work/life balance. The recruiting team will hire who they like even if the person does not perform. Upon my resignation, it was due to the fact that they will hire white Caucasian only. There were 3 of us that were there longer and outperformed the 2 others that were hired. Very unfair.

job_title: Vice President FSA in Washington, DC
pros: Experience is what everyone should enter this job looking to get experience and get out. In the investment world, attainable low goals are critical to learning the craft.
cons: An incoherent future and two organizations that have little in common and seem to have irreconcilable differences.  Merrill Lynch should be a feeder but instead edge is the destination for failed PMDs.

pros: Great benefits that are extremely affordable. Great job security. Pay isn't great, but its certainly not horrible. HR is phenomenal in response time and accuracy.
cons: It's extremely hard to move up in this company and is generally based on favoritism. Such favoritism has nothing to do with a job well done as much as it has to do with who likes who more. I say like any other company, this company has its ups and downs. Not a horrible place to work, but not a place to make it your career unless you move up to higher management levels outside of the branch.

job_title: Financial Solutions Advisor in Saint Louis, MO
pros:
Compensation
Benefits
Numerous contact with potential new clients
cons:
Bank of America and Merrill Edge management are not on the same page
Bank of America management still has a mentality that you should be selling one product every time you meet with a customer while the sales cycle for the brokerage industry takes time.
Most of the banking staff is miserable at their jobs and after a few months are looking for new jobs thus getting their buy in for teamwork is very difficult
The compliance is over the top and constantly has you on egg shells.

pros: Good work life balance. No firing culture, stable career. Good proportion of employees are 5+ and even 10+ experience bracket, which brings domain expertise to new joiners.

Promotions are very rare, might demotivate a good employee working for stretch of 5+ years.

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Arlington, VA
pros: I can’t say any good word about this company
cons:
Tellers - main horses for the lowest salary.  They work hard, because they never have them enough. No chairs to sit down, a lot of responsibilities, a lot of pressure. Management  is terrible. No respect to  those who help them to have success. 
Branch managers do not allow you to use all your benefits  ( sick leaves). Very often they push you to take longer lunch (1.5 hours) because they want you to stay longer and don’t want to pay overtime.  Part time employees- they do not give them shifts they need. During interview process I let HR know I can work part time in the morning only . I was hired by BOA. Then my manager started to push me to work in the afternoon. 
The worst company I’ve ever worked. Nightmare. Happy I left them.

job_title: Senior Change Analyst in Charlotte, NC
pros:
Because the company is huge, you will have many opportunities to network and choose different career paths. It is comforting to know that as long as you do your job well, you will have certain job stability.
Even though certain jobs are time-intensive , overall the Bank cares a whole lot about life-balance and programs such as "My Work" clearly demonstrate that.
cons: There is a lot of management politics. If you get along with upper management, you can get away with not doing a whole of work and yet get reconized (for nothing!). It is a highly competitive environment, so watch out...

job_title: Sales & Service Specialist in Tallahassee, FL
pros: Benefits, not to be confused with overall compensation are good,  The company as a whole is very strong.  If you get a decent position that is not in the consumer banking sector, chances are that you will be well compensated.  If not, you probably not last long... as most people don't.
cons: Poor consumer banking management and communication.  Extremely poor training for new associates, and is only getting worse.  If you work in a busy branch you will be extremely overextended and will eventually quit.  Although reviews are supposed to be annual, I have not had mine yet this year, and it is very overdue.

review_title: I managed the Data Center for one of the companies purchased by BAC
pros:
Possibility for growth into other areas of BAC
Every holiday off
Managers get 4 weeks of vacation starting.
cons:
Micromanagement to the extreme.
It feels as if a committee is needed consisting of managers from many different branches in order to make simple decisions.  Clearly managers who are ready to take responsibility for their actions are lacking - or at least where I worked, that was the case.
If you can kiss a managers butt very well, you are likely to get into a higher position

review_title: A great place to work, but not so good for advancement even for the best of the best....
pros: Fair compensation (not great)....great benefits...........great people to work with..........fair management....lots of paid time off.
cons: Management is very narrow minded.  They don't really care about keeping young talent.  There isn't too much room for advancement once you are employed, so buyer beware.  I have rarely seen any promotions throughout the company... it seems to be pure luck rather than hardwork, etc.  The "BIG" company mentality kills productivity and sometimes cuts off the blood supply to manager's brains.

review_title: Best job out of college I could have ever hoped for
job_title: Senior Risk Control Specialist in Charlotte, NC
pros: Great benefits package, great performance metrics and reviews, awesome ways to get involved and network with mobility around the world, and very supportive of diversity and minorities
cons: Due to its large size, it's sometimes hard to see the company's strategy from your perspective in a specific line of business, and depending on what department you are in you may feel disconnected from the customer/business partners you work with or work for

pros: Bank of America was like a second family to me.  The schedule was very flexible.  There is a lot of room for growth.  You can take on as much as you would like.  You can learn as much as you would like.  They help you get to where you like to go.
cons: Different rules for Wealth Management and Banks.  Bank managers should have the same authority that Wealth Management reps have to help WM clients while they are in the bank instead of having to call in to get help.

review_title: This company can not get out of its own way...stay away
job_title: Commercial Lender in Los Angeles, CA
pros: There are some very intelligent people that you can learn a lot from.  Benefits are pretty good with a relaxed environment where customers come first.  You will definitely learn a lot of new things by working here.
cons: Morale and pay/bonuses are down from the good old days.  Management needs to right the ship before it sinks.  I have heard that the competition offers a lot better opportunity for its employees.  I almost wish the bank got broken up into smaller pieces.

review_title: In the area I work in, the management is very supportive and I'm really using my skills. Good work/life balance.
job_title: Business Support Manager in Charlotte, NC
pros: Work/Life balance is great. I feel very supported by management. I also have gotten a lot of recognition and exposure to executives. They have leveraged and developed my skill set. I have decent freedom with my time/location.
cons: Too many meetings, lots of discussion, sometimes need people to just take ownership rather than push it away. Also need people to make good decisions rather than endlessly discuss everything as a team.

pros: Great diverse environment; Health benefits and 401K plan is AWESOME!
cons: Pay can be better for working in a downtown office. Parking is expensive and the cafeteria is getting worst.. Hard to advance within the organization if you haven't been there for 10 plus years. The site good use some work.

review_title: Large Disfunctional Corporation With Lots of Great Employees
pros: Great diversity of people.  Good benefits, especially for employees with children.  Managers have a lot of flexibility with their teams, which can be helpful to employees.
cons: Seems to be in continual flux.  Managers change frequently, so business practices change accordingly.  What is "urgent" one day is forgotten the next.  Managers are placed in charge of teams with which the manager has no experience in the LOB.

pros: Immediate managers seemed to care about employees. They ran contests and gave out awards to keep morale up. Personally, I was straight out of college and landed this job in the midst of the economical crisis, so I was lucky to get a job. I was...much smarter than the vast majority of my colleagues, and BofA recognized this, along with my ambition. Within months I was the SVPs sidekick and was reviewing people's work who'd been at the company for 20+ years.
cons: THE PAY. It's a dead end job. You can have a degree from MIT and not move up the ladder. The company's so big it's stagnant.

review_title: This company has many opportunities, but also risk.
pros: Career growth and opportunities abound, with decent salaries and salary growth. Also, there were opportunities to work from home.  Given the political and regulatory environment, management is doing that best it can to keep employees educated, prepared, and employeed.
cons: There are constant middle management, and therefore, layoffs every year. Banks are also dealing with constant political grandstanding against banks and regulation worries. This led to more layoffs, more reductions in bonuses and eventually more centralized control over work efforts.

pros: Career development opportunities.  Competitive pay.  Great benefits.  Co-workers are among some of the best folks around.  Promotions from within the company are the norm
cons: There really aren't too many cons when it comes to getting in to the bank.  Some areas within the company can become very "micro-managed", however that has more to do with the particular leader in the division, rather than the company as a whole.

review_title: Growth, flexibility, and great management are just the beginning at Bank of America.
pros: The sheer size of the help and tools BofA dumps on its employees is amazing! The company wants to see every associate get better in their field and find the exact position to fulfill their needs. I feel connected to all associates, even if I haven't met them - that's how connected you feel at BofA.
cons: The biggest downfall I see working for BofA is their reputation: most people think it's a big bad company out to get everyone with fees and hidden charges. The truth is, BofA is working relentlessly on building up its reputation. And I say we are doing a great job so far.

review_title: Good place to work if you produce and know what you are doing
pros: Pay is good, benefits are good, work from home is awesome, management is really trying to change to encourage career development, management is also trying to change the culture to be customer focused and trying to break down barriers between internal organizations
cons: work is 24x7, not much clarity in job responsibilities we just do what needs to be done to keep systems up and running, the only people that really move around are the managers, the main people that keep the systems up and running stay the same because they don't want them to move. the people we work with in India are great but there is a lack of communication and team collaboration.

pros: The people I worked with were the only reason I stayed as long as I did.
cons: SOME of the management does not care about their employees. The standards did not apply to the managers at the branch and it was upsetting to all of the employees. There was no efficient communication between the tellers and management (with certain people, not all) and one manager in particular couldn't concern herself with anyone else in the bank.

review_title: Bank of America as an employer
pros: Compared to other medium to large companies, Bank of America still offers vacation, sick and personal days versus using the PTO approach.  Our health benefits appear to be comparable to other companies.  The bank does still offer a work from home option although this is phasing out.  Our mobile and on-line banking applications are top-notch.  Generous compensation and bonuses at certain levels of the organization.
cons: Classroom or instructor led training opportunities are very scarce. Promotion opportunities/upward mobility is extremely difficult if not impossible.  The bank is heading more toward collaboration which means they are hiring primarily in fewer locations.  Continual budget pressures equates to smaller staff while the workload has not decreased along with the budget.

job_title: Mortgage Resolution Specialist in Fort Worth, TX
pros: Benefits surpass any company out there.. to have vacation and sick hrs available upfront without having to earn them is an exceptional benefit, not to mention the various reimbursement possibilities, from child care, tuition adoption, temporary hardship advances etc. the bank core values are strong! Anyone can advance so long as you apply yourself.. Honestly the possibilities are endless within BOA  no matter what dept or division you enter into you will surely attain transferrable skills that  can be used in other areas of the bank!
cons: Pay isn't as competitive as other Banks...

pros: Tons of leads, high loan amount leads, management was great, I liked working there because of all of the leads however it wasn't worth it when nothing would close

pros: I work with Preferred Banking and Merrill Edge within Consumer Banking at corporate. I enjoy the atmosphere and work/life balance that the role provides.

review_title: Not for those who wish to keep their soul...

review_title: Huge Company with Pros and Cons

cons: Too big to fail and too big to really make an impact. If you really want to be noticed for working hard and being paid for performance, your one of thousands.  To make an impactful change you need to be at the top tiers of executive management, otherwise you are just another pawn in the game.

pros: Good only if you want to do anything by entertaining managers to make money
cons:

They bought team from Dublin (all server side developers with clueless manager) to New York to run their first web based project. I've completed most important initial design with in first 3 months.

One Wednesday evening they informed my agency that I'm no longer working their. Not even 1 day notice. I realized that they wanted to cut corners and replaced me with a Jr. level person who can continue on my design.

I feel relaxed after leaving this depressing work environment. It's not a good place if you are looking for work life balance, a good culture, an organized environment to grow.

pros: Great opportunity to learn the trade. Easy to understand goals. Company trying to focus on planning and client needs first.

You draw on what the branch has for clientele. Very outdated/complicated system to track/record results. Trying to update but year(s) away.

job_title: Assistant Vice President in New York, NY
pros: The best part of working at BAML was the work/life balance. I enjoyed being able to work conveniently and also to be challenged. I was able to work with different groups and get different perspectives of various business functions.

pros:
