cons:
Very high inertia, it requires a lot of tenacity to push an idea forward - creating positive momentum is hard - but worthwhile
The con for change - is that the sponsorship for ideas may not be constant - needs continuous work to keep moving forward.

review_title: Great place to work - Company should work to shed some bad habits.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Rolling Meadows, IL

job_title: Senior Fraud Analyst in Fort Worth, TX
pros:
Bank of America offers great benefits. The insurance is very good, they offer 4 months of paternity leave, paid time off and sick time. The pay is very good.

review_title: WAKE UP Bank of America . . . Internal issues are brewing!
job_title: Account Manager in Los Angeles, CA

review_title: Some senior leaders talk out of both sides of their mouths!
job_title: Personal Banker in San Diego, CA
pros: There is a lot of opportunity to grow but be prepared for a tremendous amount of stress and very little life balance. You are also able to transfer accross the nation if you need to transfer. job_title: Senior Personal Banker in Houston, TX
pros: Large company with the opportunities to learn a lot about banking. Nice co-workers...always having a blast. pros: Great benefits, and the pay was pretty decent.  It had a good environment to work in with great customers and people.  The job was interesting and could be fun at times. review_title: 3 years at BAC after 10 years with MBNA
job_title: Senior Project Manager in Wilmington, DE

review_title: Bank of America is a good place to work!

review_title: Difficult to Grow Career, Too Big of a Company

review_title: Bank of America - Good place to work.  It depends on what you are looking for...

review_title: It was a good entry level position after college, but glad I've moved on.

The company handled the merger with Merrill Lynch incredibly poorly.  I still understand there is animosity between the two loyalties.

pros: The hours were very flexible, the managers allowed all the students to work around their school schedules. Good benefits: health, dental, vision, tuition reimbursement. cons: It can get boring doing the same thing everyday. Quarterly bonuses are at the discretion of the branch manager, so they may play favoritism and distribute bonuses unfairly. Turnover is high, no one at my branch stayed for over 2 years.

job_title: Edge Call Center/Money Magr Services, Obligations Team, Regd CA in Jacksonville, FL
pros: The campus is beautiful and there is a variety of positions available.
cons: I felt in my last position that I was not given enough supervision in regards to the Series 66 licensing requirement and procedure.  I was not aware that I would not have the opportunity to retake the 66 in the event of a fail.  I am 7,63 and life, health & annuity licensed.  I am now being told I can not post for any positions requiring the 66 for 1 year.  I was very close to passing and would have liked the opportunity to take the test the 2nd time as others had.

review_title: Great people, great company...in that order.
job_title: Intermediate Financial Analyst in New York, NY
pros:
The people are really wonderful.  Very helpful, want you to learn and not just push buttons and get answers.  I constantly feel like I am getting something out of every work day.
The work/life balance is superb.  The upper management wants to make sure their employees are getting home to see their families.  They know that if the employees are happy, they will do better work.
cons: It's hard working for such a public company that has been under a lot of scrutiny.  Can't really talk about where you work with friends or family because you always know someone who was "burned" by the company.  Personally, you can't help that, but it still makes it difficult.

review_title: Solid Waste rolls readily downhill at this company.
pros: The company has great benefits and a real commitment at the corporate level to diversity and inclusion.
cons: Much of the benefit of working here is lost at the retail level due to horrible management.  Both the general lack of ability of most retail managers combined with some of the worst policies, effectively allows working conditions to develop that are a real shame.  In addition, retail branch staff are treated as red-headed step children.  You might have been a CEO in the past - but if you take a teller job, you will be treated like a moron who is incapable of thought.

review_title: Good solid bank to work for!
pros: The benefits are great. You have the opportunity to take advantage of 401 k , medical, vision, dental, child care benefits and possible tuition reimbursement. Other perks involve cash back and reward points granted  when enrolled in the  preferred rewards program at no cost.
cons: The only downside would be not much flexibility with scheduling. Running a tight ship and scaling back where ever possible, so often work short handed and critical that you actually work as scheduled because of it.

pros: Easy to become rated as one of the best tellers in your market if you understand the computer system for transactions and always try to get referrals.
cons:
Some of your numbers are rated as how your whole branch is (like customer service) which can hurt you if everyone is not doing their part. 
You can not be promoted from ANY position until you commit at least 1 year of work at your current position, no matter how well you are doing.
Most customer complaints are blamed on tellers because you see the customers more than any other position in the bank (watch your back).

pros:
You will be working in some good technology framework which is proprietary to Bank of America.  Helps you grow you tech as well as knowledge in financial products. 
Lot of opportunities to move within the Bank if you network well.
cons:
Getting pre approvals for your personal trading. It is painful to get pre approved for every buy and sell. And with all the restrictions in place you better forget about speculating on markets. 
Lot of politics within the management. 
Performance reviews aren't legit. If you are close to your boss and if its your 'time' to get promoted, you will be given great reviews no matter what work you did.
Not great bonuses. 
Not a great place to grow especially if you are starting here.

job_title: Financial Center Manager in Toms River, NJ
pros: Benefits, 401K, Work with great people in the branches, experience is great, operational excellence is a huge focus.
cons: Short staffed, job security disappears over 50, branch management is a dead end job, there is no room for advancement. Goals are hard to attain but the company still makes money.

pros: I enjoy working at bank of america because it is a well paying job and I do not get physically tired. when it is slow, and I am all caught up on my training and organized I am free to be on my phone and converse among fellow coworkers. I enjoy the hour break and the two ten minute breaks as well.
cons: I feel like there is aways that pressure of being detail oriented and if you make one transaction wrong, it can cost you the job. I also feel like we are always so understaffed which makes it horrible for not only the customers but us as well. It doesn't make it easy that we removed the merchant line either.

pros: Working for Bank of America meant that I had great coworkers, received excellent benefits, and had plenty of room to grow. Additionally, our customers were enjoyable to work with; I looked forward to seeing coworkers and customers every day.
cons: The pay was not very good for the amount of pressure that was put on us. I worked more than 20 hours per week, despite the fact that I was a full-time student and needed time to do homework. The bosses were not appreciative when I made referrals, always wanting MORE. No amount of work was good enough.

review_title: Not a positive experience. Leadership is detached and the turnover is very high.
job_title: Financial Solutions Advisor in Boston, MA
pros: Work life balance is about it.
cons:
Management forcing customers to do online / mobile banking so BOA can reduce headcount to bare minimum. 
Lots of very skilled/licensed professionals being let go. 
Side note, with so little consumer traffic, these professionals new job standard is to cold call all day long to get high $ consumers back in to create transactional revenue. 
BOA pretends to be customer-oriented, but employees are threatened in every single morning huddle if they do not sell enough bank products that day. 
Clients are fleeing to smaller banks and credit unions, no surprise.
Constant change on systems and processes that don't make any difference in everyday work life. 
Unrealistic goal expectations with low bonus payouts. 
No recognition. Turnover is very high, company has a revolving door.

pros: Good benefits and educational computer training
cons: There's no such thing as growing with this company any more. Expect temporary assignments or to be laid off. Expect performance reviews to be unfair for exceed expectation employees due to leadership not effectively communicating with senior leadership.  Pay to risk is not really meeting the market and needs re-evaluated.

job_title: Financial Center Manager in Queen Creek, AZ
pros: Great benefits and potential to move up within the company.
cons: Upper management is out to get their employees into trouble, not sure why but even if your branch is exceeding all goals, the management starts to target and dig to find something to go to HR about and get you out of the company to move someone else up and in.

job_title: Relationship Manager in Union City, CA
pros: Tuition reimbursement,  3 weeks vacation and paid Holidays. Potential to get big bonuses.
cons:
Relationship Manager is really a Personal Banker. They changed the title but the job is the same. It is like calling a dish washer a dish manager. The title does not matter because you are still washing dishes.

If you don't meet sales goals not only do you not get a bonus but you get micro managed, written up or even fired.

pros:
Decent base salary. 

Opportunity to learn more about the wealth management and banking industry.

Good bonus potential and career advancement.
cons:
Weak and dishonest leadership team.

Unrealistic goals that are uniform across the enterprise despite the fact that different areas have naturally different economic environments and therefore varying ranges of opportunity. 

Shoddy systems:  you can lose credit for accounts that you have done all the work for and your leadership will laugh at you and say verbatim " this company loves to not pay you for the work that you do".

job_title: Senior Vice President in Charlotte, NC
pros: Opportunities to work in different lines of business.  Core company values are not just written down, they are practiced by successful leaders and associates. During this past year, Bank of America has been the place to work in financial services during this market and economic storm.  I would not want to work anywhere else in Financial Services.  Strong and decisive management is also another reason to work for Bank of America.
cons: Decision making process can sometimes be slowed down by need to be inclusive in the process.  The sheer size of the company can sometimes make it difficult to find the right person to help you.

job_title: Sales & Service Specialist in Chicago, IL
pros: Great benefits package, alot of perks, alot of banking centers you get the weekends off, tution reimbursement, bonus package (just got cut 25% for next year), alot of exposure with senior management.
cons: Right now we are in a hiring freeze and alot of people are being let go for various reasons, but your staffing levels are hitting an all time low in our market and its causing alot of customer dissatisfaction and causing our customer to leave.

review_title: Run, Don't Walk Away From This Company
pros: Your co-workers/peers are usually great people
cons: Benefits are expensive - Corporate management has no idea what it is doing - the company allows inadequate, unskilled individuals to stay in management positions way too long - the compensation for their FA's is very low compared to other firms (Smith Barney, Edward Jones, etc.) - their IT systems are slow, cumbersome and outdated - they do not respect, appreciate or reward their branch personnel - I could go on and on but simply put, this company is horrible from top to bottom.  If you are looking for a job in financial services or banking, there are a 100 different firms and banks I would recommend over B of A.

pros: BOA gives better benefits than many companies, tuition reimbursement, 3 weeks vacation to many associates in first year, child care reimbursement, $5000 towards buying a home, health care with low deductibles and everyone is covered.
cons: Many times the bank sets goals way above what is obtainable, making it changing in cases for associates to do the right thing.  There always seems to be a staffing issues.  They should focus on consistency with staff.

review_title: Great resume builder with solid company
job_title: Credit Card Analyst II in Atlanta, GA
pros:
- Nice job title

- Allows you to see how people in various professions live and what they make, what there credit looks like.

- Great resume builder

- Gives you valuable knowledge for managing your personal finances and knowing your rights and what the law mandates and who to complain to.

- Decide which accounts to approve for reopening, limits increases, and adding coapplicants
cons: - High Stress: precollections work. Cutting the limit/closing accounts while speaking to customers over the phone that display risk characteristics. 98% of these customers late end up in collections or need some financial assistance after. These are typically customers with solid incomes of 36k +

pros: The work is challenging and the compensation is good.  Hard work seems to be rewarded by bonuses and promotions.  I would recommend the bank to anyone who wants to work hard, and gain valuable skills
cons: The hours can be long at times and the competition is above average and tough.  I wouldn't call this a con though.  If you want to work for a great company then you have to make sacrifices...give and take.

pros: Pay is competitive. In today’s job market I do thank God that I have a job and I can clothe, shelter and educate my son.
cons: A rudderless ship where senior management doesn’t know how to get out of the way. Additionally, BAC encourages an adversarial relationship between HR and employees. It seems the one thing BAC HR is not good at is interpersonal relationships, which is a pretty big drawback in HUMAN Resources.

review_title: Its a great enviroment to work in.
pros: It allow you for advancement. The beneft perks are great.  It allow you the opportunity to learn multiple roles. Great.
cons: Its a large company, and if your not sharp you will be there today and gone tomorrow if you apply yourself and be a self starter.

review_title: I enjoy working at BAC overall.
pros: I have made good friends with co-workers and even management. I enjoy working here for the benefits and bonus. Management is very aware of thier employees but not so much the actual work itself.
cons: There have been alot of times where they said they would allow us to post out on x date but eveytime we got close they would extend it more. I am way overworked with too many files and cases to handle all at once. They need to even out their workload.

review_title: For a summer internship, it was a great experience.
pros: Good pay, people were great, Charlotte is a great town with a lot of young people. The town is also very affordable.
cons: I personally didn't like the fact that the offices aren't as busy as in other companies. People often work from home, which is a nice perk, but I like seeing co-workers more often.

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Las Vegas, NV
pros: Initial training was great and left me knowledgeable about the corporate culture of the bank as well as a good understanding of how to do my job well and how my performance will be measured.  Compensation was good with an opportunity to earn more for overtime.
cons: Unfortunately the longer I worked there I realized that it seemed like their values were more for show as they frequently neglected to follow through.  I felt there was a lack of autonomy in my job as well as a lack of opportunity within the company.

review_title: Such a great work enviroment and awesome college job!
pros:
Great benefits even if you only work part time! 
Awesome college job and offers the best tuition reimbursment; only takes about two weeks for the bank to reimburse you the funds. (Fry's Electronics takes about 6-9 months and they don't even reimburse you the full amount that they say they will)
A lot of learning opportunity and great place to build a career if you like the financial industry!
cons:
Sales goals are sometimes challenging
There aren't really any solid bonuses just points that you can earn and trade in for product

pros: Diversity at Bank of America is one the most positive characteristic of Bank of America. With a diverse workforce, the company is able to grow as a dynamic, living organization that goes beyond the numbers.
cons: Fulfilling quota is never a fun aspect at any organization; however, the competitive nature of the banking industry cannot be escaped by any one, any bank, or banking center. On the other hand, competition amongst banking centers and even banks allows for better end products for the consumers. Therefore if managed correctly, this requirement can be a positive.

job_title: Senior Vice President in Denver, CO
pros: Having moved from GWIM Lewrning to the LOB, Merrill Lynch, I have to say that so far the experience is MUCH better.  Fair manager, more opportunity.   Don't know about bonus or pay increases yet, but hopeful that will be much improved too!
cons: Across the company there is no transparency in pay ranges..and believe me, the ranges are huge.  Having been a manager I can tell you it's shocking the difference in pay between people doing the same job.   I transferred from an area that was like the phone company....all about friends and family for promotions, pay increases and bonuses.

job_title: Senior Vice President in Charlotte, NC
pros: Good company with lots of talented people who want to succeed.  Internal values are opposite of what media portrays.  Beginning to find its way gradually with new direction of CEO.  Smaller is better.
cons: Senior Leaders are arrogant and most have been internally grown for 25 plus years.  They are aloof and recycle the old approaches.  Once you reach Sr. Leader/Executive status, you are either with the "in" group or not.  Lots of red tape and over procesed culture.

job_title: Senior Operations Analyst in Charlotte, NC
pros: Like minded colleagues who are passionate about their work, for the most part. However, some got away with everything- arriving late, leaving early, lengthy lunches and little work performed. Metrics were not really tracked for some time.
cons: Felt like my ideas meant nothing to management. Some ideas were stolen by managers, who claimed credit for them- even in my presence. Felt like I had to watch my back at all times. Job changes and revisions to job descriptions are not uncommon.

review_title: Good name to have on your resume, lot of red tape though
job_title: Analyst I-Trading Support in Chicago, IL
pros: Benefits are really good.  3 weeks vacation automatic and option to buy a 4th week. People I worked with were diverse and friendly.  You get higher compensation because you're in the finance industry.  Also, when I left work I didn't have to worry about it when I got home, but that was specific to my line of business- can't say that was the case with the traders and investment bankers.
cons: Tons of red tape.  Need approval to get anything done.  Everything is so locked down because of the financial collapse from the late 2000's, which is understandable.  A lot of the perks from pre-collapse aren't there anymore.

review_title: Fun job when you're allowed to perform your duties, terrible when you're hounded by management
pros: Good opportunities for growth and advancement, great benefits even to part-time employees, great introduction to professional working atmosphere, great start to a future in financial services
cons: Terrible disconnect between regional managers/upper-level management and retail branches, you're often just a number, your input is never considered by management, sales expectations often absurd, push people out the door even if they've been with the company for years, work-life balance is awful

review_title: Great Place to work and earn some decent money while doing it!
job_title: Personal Banker in North Little Rock, AR
pros: Excellent training opportunities, got sent to St. Louis to train with people and  a great model for coaching and development in your new role.  Promotion was always available
cons: The culture was changing from being customer to more sales oriented and it put strain on the model they were attempting to build which hurt associate morale

review_title: Great place that is large and hard to navigate but rewarding
pros: challenging work: the work is hard but resources are availalbe to help support , great people,: unbelievable people/peers.  strong compensation/benefits: some of the best in US.
cons: High expectations: business leaders never want to hear "no" and ask for 100% complete and drive people to over-work. management decisions: can sometimes be hard to swallow as they are busy too and seem to not have time to assist and then can fuss a little when it is not done they way they want.

review_title: Worst company I have ever worked for.
job_title: Fraud Initiation Analyst I in Kennesaw, GA
pros: Benefits were good. That is about it.
cons: Environment is very depressing. I worked in ATM Debit Fraud Claim (FCI) and hated every minute of it. Worked a total of four years at this bank and three of that being in Fraud. I worked as a Teller inside the banking center the other year. Teller work was O.K. not as depressing as Fraud. The management in fraud is the worst and they destroy everyone's morale. Calls are back to back all day every day. You get counted off when you use the bathroom. It is ran like a high school basically. They prefer you ask to use the bathroom. One department does not speak to the other and basically all you do is get yelled at and cussed out all day every day from the terrible customers.

job_title: Financial Solutions Advisor Core I in Jacksonville, FL
pros: Good place to get sales experiance to sell over the phone.
cons: If you are experianced financial professional and you are above 40 year old you should foget this company  since the management is doing everything to get rid if you. If you are lucky and get a team lead who know how to put togeather a team and to lead them, then you are lucky and you wil have  a chance to stay at Merrill.

pros: Having Bank of America on your resume helps it look very official and well-grounded. Pay was good for my age group, 18-22 yrs old/ college student. Management was very flexible with my school schedule, almost never had issues with this. Tuition reimbursement was fantastic, almost covered my entire tuition, about $5000 a year for job-related courses I made at least a B or C in.
cons: Management got pretty uptight and overbearing on many of the associates, even our STELLAR associates who never did anything wrong, truly. Made several of our female associates cry after getting corrected harshly or unnecessarily.

review_title: Its a nice gig, if you can keep it.
pros: Good salary.  Depending on the team and space you are in, you have the ability to a part of multiple projects, doing a variety of things.  They have 20 days of vacation besides the standard 11 bank holidays.
cons: Continuous re-orgs keeps the lay off broom sweeping.  You never know when you can be next.  It all seems so random and stupid.  All the associates are scared.  Your team doesn't have any stability because your teammate one month will be gone next month.

pros: Good Benefits, Several opportunities due to the size of the company
cons: Some very senior leaders have poor leadership skills. In some departments a fear based leadership is favored over a respect based leadership. The culture in technology requires significant improvement. Several strides have been made to correct the issues. However some of the senior leadership who are clearly not leadership material continue to move up in the company. The work on changing the culture can not happen until these senior leaders are either coached up or let go.

review_title: Worst experience ever in my 17+ years in the mortgage.
job_title: MOrtgage Loan Originator in Carmel, IN
pros: They have a big name, offer good health insurance and direct deposit on a bi-weekly pay schedule. 401k and lots of locations.
cons: The reputation of their big name is not great in our market and there is an obvious lack of commitment to non-banking footprint markets. You cannot trust management, because they do not know the real objectives at least three layers up. Actions and words from corporate clearly did not match as they decimated their retail mortgage presence and brand value in the Indiana market. Clear disregard for the value of employees and the customer. BoA will have a major uphill battle if it ever wants a presence in our market again.

pros: Good Company Benefits - Insurance, 401K, paid Vacation
cons: They do not look out for employees. Management within the team haven't a clue what's going on. Annual Layoffs be prepared to pack your things on a yearly  basis. Yo need to make sure you are sucking up to get ahead, your work stands for nothing it's all about friends & who can I use to promote myself.

job_title: Financial Center Client Service Representative I in Chesterfield, MO
pros: Bank of America is a great place to work for. The team I worked with was awesome. They were amazing people. The bank has great management. Great benefit. Good paid. Ethical business.
cons: Since the bank is doing their best everyday to please customer. Some customers just feel too comfortable to be rude to bank associates helping them to meet their financial needs. Most customers are good, but there are many rude customers out there.

job_title: Relationship Manager in Toms River, NJ
pros:
Great Coworkers.
Compensation is Fair.
Good Benefits.
cons:
Sales Goals are determined illogically based solely on feet walking through the door and not opportunity that exists.  They are based on a lot of cross selling and ultimately they are not determined in a way that puts the customer first.  A lot of emphasis is put on closing percentage and so you are discouraged from helping a client with a service need if there is no real opportunity for a sale. 
People get put into management positions that have never worked in a bank.

review_title: Mediocre Big Bank with legal problems created by Management
pros:
Offers very nice office accommodations
Limited training offered. Up to you to ask questions- sink or swim.
401K matching is 5% of salary
Offers discount for hybrid car purchases (up to $4,000 I believe)
cons:
Given the size of the bank, managers cultivate a culture based on company rules, taking the human aspect of our many
As mediocre of a place as it gets. Bonus pay is determined by three ratings- exceeds expectations (top 5%), meets expectations (85%), does not meet expectations (bottom 10%)
Definitely not a place people in the office spend time together outside of work.

job_title: Financial Center Manager in Falls Church, VA
pros:
Great brand name
Competitive products 
Technology is second to none
cons: Branch managers have no say in hiring and management of relationship managers and sales associates. Sales goals consists of a significant portion of performance but the sales managers keep hiring staff who are not qualified in the role.

pros: Great benefits: child care plus, tuition reimbursement, health insurance, vacation time.  They are finally starting to open up some opportunities for advancement in my area.
cons: large layoffs periodically.  Instability due to this .  Stagnation in a lot of roles with no room for advancement.  Upper management does not seem to listen to what their subordinates are conveying.  Income seems to be lower compared to jobs at other companies. Small raises and no bonus.

job_title: Customer Marketing Specialist in Fort Worth, TX
pros: The money, the benefits, but thats about all
cons: Morale is very low, people tend to not care for their jobs there, or get complacent.  They don't really seem to care much about their people.   Definately just a number up here.  Occasionally you will find management that cares.  If you want to move up in the company, you have to play the game (as most corporate structures)

review_title: Overall Great Company. Small Adujments Need to be Made.
pros: Great company, great benefits such as the amazing paternity leave and knowledgeable teams around you or available to you.
cons: The hours do not make work life balance simple because the only day you can count on not being at the branch is Sunday. I know there used to be "Bankers hours" that people would joke about but it is because they haven't seen all the meetings and work that go on in the background.

pros: For me, the compensation was far better than the competitors in the local market for similar positions. Huge amount of opportunity to advance into a variety of career paths. Ultimately attainable goals.
cons: This job pays more than similar roles because it requires more of you. There are deadlines. Goals are quite high and there is a lot of organizational pressure on you not only to succeed but to excel. They do give you the tools to make it happen though. Rigid systems and protocols. Bonus structure seems like it keeps getting diluted.

pros:
-Get to interact with lots of people on a daily basis. 
-Decent pay and benefits.
-Good place to work if you're also going to school; generally flexible hours.
-If you want to move up, the natural progression would likely be a merchant teller or personal banker.
cons:
-Sometimes I was asked to work more than 8 hours and didn't get paid OT (which I think BofA got in trouble for). 
-Experience will likely vary depending on which banking center you work at. 
-Pressure for teller referrals can weigh heavily on some tellers.

review_title: Selling your soul for a paycheck
pros: Getting paid every two weeks
cons: Over 300000 employees - they cuould lose half and not miss a beat. Everyone protecting the tiniest piece of "turf" . An offer of help to someone on a project is met with disdain that you are trying to steal their small piece of the action. Bloated bloated company with mcu resentment towards anyone new or coming from recent aquisitions. You are on conference calls all day long with nothing accomplished and everyone "works" from home. You can hear the kids screamingi in the background on every call - and always the same excuse, the nanny didn't come today. If you want ot have anxiety about how little you do all day waiting for the layoff yo come this is the place to be. If ever a company should have been allowed to fail - this is the one

review_title: I am a tiny cog lost in this huge machine. My voice is hardly heard above the din of media anger and management orders.
pros: Tuition reimbursement. 3 months fully paid maternity leave for moms and dads! Free Prima checking accounts. Reimbursement of 3k for any new hybrid. Paid community service for 2 hours per week.
cons: Difficult to get vacation when you want due to schedule demand of banking center. Low pay compared to industry. Poor public image of company. Stressful to balance risk management and customer service.

review_title: A lot of kool-aid, but not so much competence
pros: Generally nice people, decent compensation. Most support functions operate fairly well.
cons:
Mid to high-level management (excepting much of C-suite) is sub-par, provincial and inbred. There is a lot of time spent on internal jockeying and competition. While this is typical in large FIs, it seems worse here. 
HR is a  problem. While it has gotten slightly better, the role of HR as the "secret police" within BAC tends to do more harm than good. They help create an atmosphere that is tense in an unproductive way while not being good at the blocking and tackling of the normal HR function.

job_title: Registered Client Associate in New York, NY
pros: the technology is great to understand the financial markets. ml/boa will sponsor your series7/66. you can enter the FA program if you do well and can convince mgt that you are capable of bringing in business.
cons: not a whole lot. you must choose to work with FA's who will help you understand the business and explain the business to you. if you don't pick their brains the job isn't worth doing.

pros: You have great opportunity to advance if you want to stick around in the next 3-10+ years. Like any other customer service jobs, you get to see different people and talk to them. Some of the customers are really nice and we usually had a great time talking when doing transactions
cons: It really depend on the managers, if your manager is really good and knows how to be a leader, you will have a great time. However, vice versa, some of my friends left the company within 2 months because he/she couldnt stand the manager.

review_title: I loved working as a part-time teller
job_title: 25 Hour Per Week Teller in Waynesboro, VA
pros: Part-time hours gave me full-time health insurance benefits and paid vacation days.  It was great since I still have children at home that needed to be driven to activities.
cons: Stressful!  There is a high value placed on getting referrals and selling credit cards.  If you are not comfortable with that, then this is not the place for you.

pros: Pleasantly diverse retail branch environment.  Co-workers were like family and very helpful. There are not any other pros to be found, period.
cons: BofA is a soul crushing Borg. The only thing they value less than its customers are its employees. Each are just an expendable commodity to be fully exploited. BofA is constantly on the losing side of class action lawsuits brought against them from clients. They are consistently ranked as one of the worst company's in America.  Management says it cares but it's actions tell the real story. They keep getting sued and lose billions. Their stock price reflects this. The current price is less than half it's previous high from before the financial crises. Today most other firms stock priced have fully recovered and making new all time highs. BofA is left in the dust because they are a parasite.

pros: Great benefits for their employees. Great company overall. The hours are great and you get a chance to experience something new everyday. I love the idea of Bank of America.
cons: Management sucks. They don't help you further your career. When you go to an interview don't think you are going to get the job because your manager is always the one who is going to have the last word. So if you are ready and your manager doesn't like you sorry you won't move on.  The schedule is never ready on time so you never know if you are coming in or not.

review_title: Just a tiny cog in a huge wheel
pros: Flexible hours, great co-workers, pay isn't bad
cons:
The majority of marketing employees are contractors and after 18 months we are required to take 3 months off in order for BOA to not have to pay us benefits. Then you don't just come back, you have to apply all over again and start with a new employee number, etc.

There are days when you just sit around and wait for work because there are too many employees.  The process to get a job done involves the requester, traffic managers, account managers, art buyers, and artistic directors.  There are way too many layers to get a job done.

review_title: A VERY large company.   Experiences can vary widely by line of business and manager.
pros: Solid company, good benefits, can get good experience, particularly as a young person.
cons: Reorganizations and realignments are almost constant, leading to frequent changes in senior managers and their teams, as new managers want to appoint new leadership teams to demonstrate change.   Actions do not always follow the company's stated values.  HR is focused much more on supporting the will of managers than on doing the right thing for employees.

pros: Excellent benefits, excellent staff, with a fair pay rate. You get to meet amazing people everyday and are introduced infrequently to upper upper management. There is plenty of room to move up in the company and is all based upon the effort that is put forward on the sales floor.
cons: In any career field there will be co-workers and supervisors that you could care less for. There is at times a very "in your face" approach with confronting employees of a branch that are not meeting sales goal.

pros:
1.) Very good working environment. 
2.) Good facilities provided.
3.) The seniors in the team helps you to provide growth opportunities and also guide you through wherever you need technical assistance.
cons:
1.) Technical growth is minimal. They don't provide much opportunity for technical growth. The LOB doesn't support you in that.
2.) The HR Management is really pathetic, You might have to wait for the joining, on boarding, etc. 
3.) Poor policies for onshore travel.
